to the senate of the united states
 i transmit to the senate in answer to a resolution of that body pass on the 17th instant the accompanying report of head of departments which contain all the official information in the possession of the executive ask for by the resolution
 on come into office i find the military commandant of the department of california exercise the function of civil governor in that territory and leave as i be to act under the treaty of guadalupe hidalgo without the aid of any legislative provision establish a government in that territory i think it well not to disturb that arrangement make under my predecessor until congress should take some action on that subject i therefore do not interfere with the power of the military commandant who continue to exercise the function of civil governor as before but i make no such appointment confer no such authority and have allow no increase compensation to the commandant for his service
 with a view to the faithful execution of the treaty so far as lie in the power of the executive and to enable congress to act at the present session with as full knowledge and as little difficulty as possible on all matter of interest in these territories i send the hon thomas butler king as bearer of dispatch to california and certain officer to california and new mexico whose duty be particularly define in the accompany letter of instruction address to they severally by the proper department
 i do not hesitate to express to the people of those territories my desire that each territory should if prepare to comply with the requisition of the constitution of the united states form a plan of a state constitution and submit the same to congress with a prayer for admission into the union as a state but i do not anticipate suggest or authorize the establishment of any such government without the assent of congress nor do i authorize any government agent or officer to interfere with or exercise any influence or control over the election of delegate or over any convention in make or modify their domestic institution or any of the provision of their propose constitution on the contrary the instruction give by my order be that all measure of domestic policy adopt by the people of california must originate solely with themselves that while the executive of the united states be desirous to protect they in the formation of any government republican in its character to be at the proper time submit to congress yet it be to be distinctly understand that the plan of such a government must at the same time be the result of their own deliberate choice and originate with themselves without the interference of the executive
 i be unable to give any information as to law pass by any suppose government in california or of any census take in either of the territories mention in the resolution as i have no information on those subject
 as already state i have not disturb the arrangement which i find have exist under my predecessor
 in advise an early application by the people of these territories for admission as states i be actuate principally by an earnest desire to afford to the wisdom and patriotism of congress the opportunity of avoid occasion of bitter and angry dissension among the people of the united states
 under the constitution every state have the right of establish and from time to time alter its municipal law and domestic institution independently of every other state and of the general government subject only to the prohibition and guaranty expressly set forth in the constitution of the united states the subject thus leave exclusively to the respective states be not design or expect to become topic of national agitation still as under the constitution congress have power to make all needful rule and regulation respect the territories of the united states every new acquisition of territory have lead to discussion on the question whether the system of involuntary servitude which prevail in many of the states should or should not be prohibit in that territory the period of excitement from this cause which have heretofore occur have be safely pass but during the interval of whatever length which may elapse before the admission of the territories cede by mexico as states it appear probable that similar excitement will prevail to an undue extent
 under these circumstance i think and still think that it be my duty to endeavor to put it in the power of congress by the admission of california and new mexico as states to remove all occasion for the unnecessary agitation of the public mind
 it be understand that the people of the western part of california have form a plan of a state constitution and will soon submit the same to the judgment of congress and apply for admission as a state this course on their part though in accordance with be not adopt exclusively in consequence of any expression of my wish inasmuch as measure tend to this end have be promote by the officer send there by my predecessor and be already in active progress of execution before any communication from i reach california if the propose constitution shall when submit to congress be find to be in compliance with the requisition of the constitution of the united states i earnestly recommend that it may receive the sanction of congress
 the part of california not include in the propose state of that name be believe to be uninhabited except in a settlement of our countryman in the vicinity of salt lake
 a claim have be advance by the state of texas to a very large portion of the most populous district of the territory commonly designate by the name of new mexico if the people of new mexico have form a plan of a state government for that territory as cede by the treaty of guadalupe hidalgo and have be admit by congress as a state our constitution would have afford the mean of obtain an adjustment of the question of boundary with texas by a judicial decision at present however no judicial tribunal have the power of decide that question and it remain for congress to devise some mode for its adjustment meanwhile i submit to congress the question whether it would be expedient before such adjustment to establish a territorial government which by include the district so claim would practically decide the question adversely to the state of texas or by exclude it would decide it in her favor in my opinion such a course would not be expedient especially as the people of this territory still enjoy the benefit and protection of their municipal law originally derive from mexico and have a military force station there to protect they against the indians it be undoubtedly true that the property life liberty and religion of the people of new mexico be well protect than they ever be before the treaty of cession
 should congress when california shall present herself for incorporation into the union annex a condition to her admission as a state affect her domestic institution contrary to the wish of her people and even compel she temporarily to comply with it yet the state could change her constitution at any time after admission when to she it should seem expedient any attempt to deny to the people of the state the right of self government in a matter which peculiarly affect themselves will infallibly be regard by they as an invasion of their right and upon the principle lay down in our own declaration of independence they will certainly be sustain by the great mass of the american people to assert that they be a conquered people and must as a state submit to the will of their conqueror in this regard will meet with no cordial response among american freeman great number of they be native citizen of the united states not inferior to the rest of our countryman in intelligence and patriotism and no language of menace to restrain they in the exercise of an undoubted right substantially guarantee to they by the treaty of cession itself shall ever be utter by i or encourage and sustain by person act under my authority it be to be expect that in the residue of the territory cede to we by mexico the people reside there will at the time of their incorporation into the union as a state settle all question of domestic policy to suit themselves
 no material inconvenience will result from the want for a short period of a government establish by congress over that part of the territory which lie eastward of the new state of california and the reason for my opinion that new mexico will at no very distant period ask for admission into the union be round on unofficial information which i suppose be common to all who have care to make inquiry on that subject
 seeing then that the question which now excite such painful sensation in the country will in the end certainly be settle by the silent effect of cause independent of the action of congress i again submit to your wisdom the policy recommend in my annual message of await the salutary operation of those cause believe that we shall thus avoid the creation of geographical party and secure the harmony of feel so necessary to the beneficial action of our political system connect as the union be with the remembrance of past happiness the sense of present blessing and the hope of future peace and prosperity every dictate of wisdom every feeling of duty and every emotion of patriotism tend to inspire fidelity and devotion to it and admonish we cautiously to avoid any unnecessary controversy which can either endanger it or impair its strength the chief element of which be to be find in the regard and affection of the people for each other

to the senate of the united states
 i herewith transmit to the senate for their advice with regard to its ratification a convention between the united states and great britain conclude at washington on the 19th instant by john m. clayton secretary of state on the part of the united states and by the right hon sir henry lytton bulwer on the part of great britain
 this treaty have be negotiate in accordance with the general view express in my message to congress in december last its object be to establish a commercial alliance with all great maritime state for the protection of a contemplated ship canal through the territory of nicaragua to connect the atlantic and pacific ocean and at the same time to insure the same protection to the contemplated railway or canal by the tehuantepec and panama route as well as to every other interoceanic communication which may be adopt to shorten the transit to or from our territory on the pacific
 it will be see that this treaty do not propose to take money from the public treasury to effect any object contemplate by it it yield protection to the capitalist who may undertake to construct any canal or railway across the isthmus commence in the southern part of mexico and terminate in the territory of new granada it give no preference to any one route over another but propose the same measure of protection for all which ingenuity and enterprise can construct should this treaty be ratify it will secure in future the liberation of all central america from any kind of foreign aggression
 at the time negotiation be open with nicaragua for the construction of a canal through her territory i find great britain in possession of nearly half of central america as the ally and protector of the mosquito king it have be my object in negotiate this treaty not only to secure the passage across the isthmus to the government and citizen of the united states by the construction of a great highway dedicate to the use of all nation on equal term but to maintain the independence and sovereignty of all the central american republics the senate will judge how far these object have be effect
 if there be any who would desire to seize and annex any portion of the territory of these weak sister republic to the american union or to extend our dominion over they i do not concur in their policy and i wish it to be understand in reference to that subject that i adopt the view entertain so far as i know by all my predecessor
 the principle by which i have be regulate in the negotiation of this treaty be in accordance with the sentiment well express by my immediate predecessor on the 10th of february 1847 when he communicate to the senate the treaty with new granada for the protection of the railroad at panama it be in accordance with the whole spirit of the resolution of the senate of the 3d of march 1835 refer to by president polk and with the policy adopt by president jackson immediately after the passage of that resolution who dispatch an agent to central america and new granada to open negotiation with those government for the purpose of effectually protect by suitable treaty stipulation with they such individual or company as might undertake to open a communication between the atlantic and pacific ocean by the construction of a ship canal across the isthmus which connect north and south america and of securing forever by such stipulation the free and equal right of navigate such canal to all such nation on the payment of such reasonable toll as might be establish to compensate the capitalist who should engage in such undertaking and complete the work
 i also communicate herewith a copy of the correspondence between the american secretary of state and the british plenipotentiary at the time of conclude the treaty whatever honor may be due to the party first propose such a treaty justly belong to the united states my predecessor in his message of the 10th of february 1847 refer to the treaty with new granada for the protection of the panama railroad observe that--
 should the proposition thus tender be reject we may deprive the united states of the just influence which its acceptance might secure to they and confer the glory and benefit of be the first among the nation in conclude such an arrangement upon the government either of great britain or france that either of these government would embrace the offer can not be doubt because there do not appear to be any other effectual mean of securing to all nation the advantage of this important passage but the guaranty of great commercial power that the isthmus shall be neutral territory the interest of the world at stake be so important that the security of this passage between the two ocean can not be suffer to depend upon the war and revolution which may arise among different nation
 should the senate in its wisdom see fit to confirm this treaty and the treaty heretofore submit by i for their advice in regard to its ratification negotiate with the state of nicaragua on the 3d day of september last it will be necessary to amend one or both of they so that both treaty may stand in conformity with each other in their spirit and intention the senate will discover by examine they both that this be a task of no great difficulty
 i have good reason to believe that france and russia stand ready to accede to this treaty and that no other great maritime state will refuse its accession to an arrangement so well calculate to diffuse the blessing of peace commerce and civilization and so honorable to all nation which may enter into the engagement

to the senate and house of representatives
 i herewith transmit to the two houses of congress a letter from his excellency the governor of texas date on the 14th day of june last address to the late president of the united states which not having be answer by he come to my hand on his death and i also transmit a copy of the answer which i have feel it to be my duty to cause to be make to that communication
 congress will perceive that the governor of texas officially state that by authority of the legislature of that state he dispatch a special commissioner with full power and instruction to extend the civil jurisdiction of the state over the unorganized county of el paso worth presidio and santa fe situate on its northwestern limit
 he proceed to say that the commissioner have report to he in an official form that the military officer employ in the service of the united states station at santa fe interpose adversely with the inhabitant to the fulfillment of his object in favor of the establishment of a separate state government east of the rio grande and within the rightful limit of the state of texas these four county which texas thus propose to establish and organize as be within her own jurisdiction extend over the whole of the territory east of the rio grande which have heretofore be regard as an essential and integral part of the department of new mexico and actually govern and possess by her people until conquer and sever from the republic of mexico by the american arm
 the legislature of texas have be call together by her governor for the purpose as be understand of maintain her claim to the territory east of the rio grande and of establish over it her own jurisdiction and her own law by force
 these proceeding of texas may well arrest the attention of all branch of the government of the united states and i rejoice that they occur while the congress be yet in session it be i fear far from be impossible that in consequence of these proceeding of texas a crisis may be bring on which shall summon the two houses of congress and still more emphatically the executive government to an immediate readiness for the performance of their respective duty
 by the constitution of the united states the president be constitute commander in chief of the army and navy and of the militia of the several states when call into the actual service of the united states the constitution declare also that he shall take care that the law be faithfully execute and that he shall from time to time give to the congress information of the state of the union
 congress have power by the constitution to provide for call forth the militia to execute the law of the union and suitable and appropriate act of congress have be pass as well for provide for call forth the militia as for place other suitable and efficient mean in the hand of the president to enable he to discharge the constitutional function of his office
 the second section of the act of the 28th of february 1795 declare that whenever the law of the united states shall be oppose or their execution obstruct in any state by combination too powerful to be suppress by the ordinary course of judicial proceeding or the power vest in the marshal the president may call forth the militia as far as may be necessary to suppress such combination and to cause the law to be duly execute
 by the act of march 3 1807 it be provide that in all case of obstruction to the law either of the united states or any individual state or territory where it be lawful for the president to call forth the militia for the purpose of cause the law to be duly execute it shall be lawful for he to employ for the same purpose such part of the land or naval force of the united states as shall be judge necessary
 these several enactment be now in full force so that if the law of the united states be oppose or obstruct in any state or territory by combination too powerful to be suppress by the judicial or civil authority it become a case in which it be the duty of the president either to call out the militia or to employ the military and naval force of the united states or to do both if in his judgment the exigency of the occasion shall so require for the purpose of suppress such combination the constitutional duty of the president be plain and peremptory and the authority vest in he by law for its performance clear and ample
 texas be a state authorize to maintain her own law so far as they be not repugnant to the constitution law and treaty of the united states to suppress insurrection against her authority and to punish those who may commit treason against the state accord to the form provide by her own constitution and her own law
 but all this power be local and confine entirely within the limit of texas herself she can possibly confer no authority which can be lawfully exercise beyond her own boundary
 all this be plain and hardly need argument or elucidation if texas militia therefore march into any one of the other states or into any territory of the united states there to execute or enforce any law of texas they become at that moment trespasser they be no long under the protection of any lawful authority and be to be regard merely as intruder and if within such state or territory they obstruct any law of the united states either by power of arm or mere power of number constitute such a combination as be too powerful to be suppress by the civil authority the president of the united states have no option leave to he but be bind to obey the solemn injunction of the constitution and exercise the high power vest in he by that instrument and by the act of congress
 or if any civil posse armed or unarmed enter into any territory of the united states under the protection of the law thereof with intent to seize individual to be carry elsewhere for trial for alleged offense and this posse be too powerful to be resist by the local civil authority such seizure or attempt to seize be to be prevent or resist by the authority of the united states
 the grave and important question now arise whether there be in the territory of new mexico any exist law of the united states opposition to which or the obstruction of which would constitute a case call for the interposition of the authority vest in the president
 the constitution of the united states declare that--
 this constitution and the law of the united states which shall be make in pursuance thereof and all treaty make or which shall be make under the authority of the united states shall be the supreme law of the land
 if therefore new mexico be a territory of the united states and if any treaty stipulation be in force therein such treaty stipulation be the supreme law of the land and be to be maintain and uphold accordingly
 in the letter to the governor of texas my reason be give for believe that new mexico be now a territory of the united states with the same extent and the same boundary which belong to it while in the actual possession of the republic of mexico and before the late war in the early part of that war both california and new mexico be conquer by the arm of the united states and be in the military possession of the united states at the date of the treaty of peace
 by that treaty the title by conquest be confirm and these territory province or department separate from mexico forever and by the same treaty certain important right and security be solemnly guarantee to the inhabitant reside therein
 by the fifth article of the treaty it be declare that--
 the boundary line between the two republic shall commence in the gulf of mexico 3 league from land opposite the mouth of the rio grande otherwise call rio bravo del norte or opposite the mouth of its deep branch if it should have more than one branch empty directly into the sea from thence up the middle of that river follow the deep channel where it have more than one to the point where it strike the southern boundary of new mexico thence westwardly along the whole southern boundary of new mexico which run north of the town call paso to its western termination thence northward along the western line of new mexico until it intersect the first branch of the river gila or if it should not intersect any branch of that river then to the point on the say line near to such branch and thence in a direct line to the same thence down the middle of the say branch and of the said river until it empty into the rio colorado thence across the rio colorado follow the division line between upper and lower california to the pacific ocean
 the eighth article of the treaty be in the following term
 mexicans now establish in territory previously belong to mexico and which remain for the future within the limit of the united states as define by the present treaty shall be free to continue where they now reside or to remove at any time to the mexican republic retain the property which they possess in the said territory or dispose thereof and remove the proceed wherever they please without their be subject on this account to any contribution tax or charge whatever
 those who shall prefer to remain in the say territory may either retain the title and right of mexican citizen or acquire those of citizen of the united states but they shall be under the obligation to make their election within one year from the date of the exchange of ratification of this treaty and those who shall remain in the say territory after the expiration of that year without having declare their intention to retain the character of mexicans shall be consider to have elect to become citizen of the united states
 in the say territory property of every kind now belong to mexicans not establish there shall be inviolably respect the present owner the heir of these and all mexicans who may hereafter acquire say property by contract shall enjoy with respect to it guaranty equally ample as if the same belong to citizen of the united states
 the ninth article of the treaty be in these word
 the mexicans who in the territory aforesaid shall not preserve the character of citizen of the mexican republic conformably with what be stipulate in the precede article shall be incorporate into the union of the united states and be admit at the proper time to be judge of by the congress of the united states to the enjoyment of all the right of citizen of the united states accord to the principle of the constitution and in the meantime shall be maintain and protect in the free enjoyment of their liberty and property and secure in the free exercise of their religion without restriction
 it be plain therefore on the face of these treaty stipulation that all mexicans establish in territory north or east of the line of demarcation already mention come within the protection of the ninth article and that the treaty be a part of the supreme law of the land do extend over all such mexicans and assure to they perfect security in the free enjoyment of their liberty and property as well as in the free exercise of their religion and this supreme law of the land be thus in actual force over this territory be to be maintain until it shall be displace or supersede by other legal provision and if it be obstruct or resist by combination too powerful to be suppress by the civil authority the case be one which come within the provision of law and which oblige the president to enforce those provision neither the constitution nor the law nor my duty nor my oath of office leave i any alternative or any choice in my mode of action
 the executive government of the united states have no power or authority to determine what be the true line of boundary between mexico and the united states before the treaty of guadalupe hidalgo nor have it any such power now since the question have become a question between the state of texas and the united states so far as this boundary be doubtful that doubt can only be remove by some act of congress to which the assent of the state of texas may be necessary or by some appropriate mode of legal adjudication but in the meantime if disturbance or collision arise or should be threaten it be absolutely incumbent on the executive government however painful the duty to take care that the law be faithfully maintain and he can regard only the actual state of thing as it exist at the date of the treaty and be bind to protect all inhabitant who be then establish and who now remain north and east of the line of demarcation in the full enjoyment of their liberty and property accord to the provision of the ninth article of the treaty in other word all must be now regard as new mexico which be possess and occupy as new mexico by citizen of mexico at the date of the treaty until a definite line of boundary shall be establish by competent authority
 this assertion of duty to protect the people of new mexico from threatened violence or from seizure to be carry into texas for trial for alleged offense against texan law do not at all include any claim of power on the part of the executive to establish any civil or military government within that territory that power belong exclusively to the legislative department and congress be the sole judge of the time and manner of create or authorize any such government
 the duty of the executive extend only to the execution of law and the maintenance of treaty already in force and the protection of all the people of the united states in the enjoyment of the right which those treaty and law guarantee
 it be exceedingly desirable that no occasion should arise for the exercise of the power thus vest in the president by the constitution and the law with whatever mildness those power might be execute or however clear the case of necessity yet consequence might nevertheless follow of which no human sagacity can foresee either the evil or the end
 having thus lay before congress the communication of his excellency the governor of texas and the answer thereto and having make such observation as i have think the occasion call for respect constitutional obligation which may arise in the further progress of thing and may devolve on i to be perform i hope i shall not be regard as step aside from the line of my duty notwithstanding that i be aware that the subject be now before both houses if i express my deep and earnest conviction of the importance of an immediate decision or arrangement or settlement of the question of boundary between texas and the territory of new mexico all consideration of justice general expediency and domestic tranquillity call for this it seem to be in its character and by position the first or one of the first of the question grow out of the acquisition of california and new mexico and now require decision
 no government can be establish for new mexico either state or territorial until it shall be first ascertain what new mexico be and what be her limit and boundary these can not be fix or know till the line of division between she and texas shall be ascertain and establish and numerous and weighty reason conspire in my judgment to show that this divisional line should be establish by congress with the assent of the government of texas in the first place this seem by far the most prompt mode of proceed by which the end can be accomplish if judicial proceeding be resort to such proceeding would necessarily be slow and year would pass by in all probability before the controversy could be end so great a delay in this case be to be avoid if possible such delay would be every way inconvenient and might be the occasion of disturbance and collision for the same reason i would with the utmost deference to the wisdom of congress express a doubt of the expediency of the appointment of commissioner and of an examination estimate and an award of indemnity to be make by they this would be but a species of arbitration which might last as long as a suit at law
 so far as i be able to comprehend the case the general fact be now all know and congress be as capable of decide on it justly and properly now as it probably would be after the report of the commissioner if the claim of title on the part of texas appear to congress to be well rounded in whole or in part it be in the competency of congress to offer she an indemnity for the surrender of that claim in a case like this surround as it be by many cogent consideration all call for amicable adjustment and immediate settlement the government of the united states would be justify in my opinion in allow an indemnity to texas not unreasonable or extravagant but fair liberal and award in a just spirit of accommodation
 i think no event would be hail with more gratification by the people of the united states than the amicable adjustment of question of difficulty which have now for a long time agitate the country and occupy to the exclusion of other subject the time and attention of congress
 having thus freely communicate the result of my own reflection on the most advisable mode of adjust the boundary question i shall nevertheless cheerfully acquiesce in any other mode which the wisdom of congress may devise and in conclusion i repeat my conviction that every consideration of the public interest manifest the necessity of a provision by congress for the settlement of this boundary question before the present session be bring to a close the settlement of other question connect with the same subject within the same period be greatly to be desire but the adjustment of this appear to i to be in the high degree important in the train of such an adjustment we may well hope that there will follow a return of harmony and good will an increase attachment to the union and the general satisfaction of the country

fellow citizen of the senate and of the house of representatives be suddenly call in the midst of the last session of congress bya painful dispensation of divine providence to the responsible stationwhich i now hold i content myself with such communication to the legislatureas the exigency of the moment seem to require the country be shroudedin mourn for the loss of its venerable chief magistrate and all heartswere penetrate with grief neither the time nor the occasion appearedto require or to justify on my part any general expression of politicalopinion or any announcement of the principle which would govern i inthe discharge of the duty to the performance of which i have be so unexpectedlycalled i trust therefore that it may not be deem inappropriate ifi avail myself of this opportunity of the reassembling of congress to makeknown my sentiment in a general manner in regard to the policy which oughtto be pursue by the government both in its intercourse with foreign nationsand its management and administration of internal affair nation like individual in a state of nature be equal and independent possess certain right and owe certain duty to each other arisingfrom their necessary and unavoidable relation which right and dutiesthere be no common human authority to protect and enforce still theyare right and duty bind in moral in conscience and in honor although there be no tribunal to which an injured party can appeal butthe disinterested judgment of mankind and ultimately the arbitrament ofthe sword among the acknowledge right of nation be that which each possessesof establish that form of government which it may deem most conduciveto the happiness and prosperity of its own citizen of change that formas circumstance may require and of manage its internal affair accordingto its own will the people of the united states claim this right for themselves and they readily concede it to other hence it become an imperative dutynot to interfere in the government or internal policy of other nations;and although we may sympathize with the unfortunate or the oppress everywherein their struggle for freedom our principle forbid we from take anypart in such foreign contest we make no war to promote or to preventsuccession to throne to maintain any theory of a balance of power orto suppress the actual government which any country choose to establishfor itself we instigate no revolution nor suffer any hostile militaryexpedition to be fit out in the united states to invade the territoryor province of a friendly nation the great law of morality ought to havea national as well as a personal and individual application we shouldact toward other nation as we wish they to act toward we and justiceand conscience should form the rule of conduct between government insteadof mere power self interest or the desire of aggrandizement to maintaina strict neutrality in foreign war to cultivate friendly relation toreciprocate every noble and generous act and to perform punctually andscrupulously every treaty obligation these be the duty which we oweto other state and by the performance of which we well entitle ourselvesto like treatment from they or if that in any case be refuse we canenforce our own right with justice and a clear conscience in our domestic policy the constitution will be my guide and in questionsof doubt i shall look for its interpretation to the judicial decisionsof that tribunal which be establish to expound it and to the usage ofthe government sanction by the acquiescence of the country i regardall its provision as equally binding in all its part it be the willof the people express in the most solemn form and the constitute authoritiesare but agent to carry that will into effect every power which it hasgrante be to be exercise for the public good but no pretense of utility no honest conviction even of what might be expedient can justify theassumption of any power not grant the power confer upon the governmentand their distribution to the several department be as clearly expressedin that sacred instrument as the imperfection of human language will allow and i deem it my first duty not to question its wisdom add to its provision evade its requirement or nullify its command upon you fellow citizen as the representative of the states andthe people be wisely devolve the legislative power i shall comply withmy duty in lay before you from time to time any information calculatedto enable you to discharge your high and responsible trust for the benefitof our common constituent my opinion will be frankly express upon the lead subject of legislation;and if which i do not anticipate any act should pass the two houses ofcongress which should appear to i unconstitutional or an encroachmenton the just power of other department or with provision hastily adoptedand likely to produce consequence injurious and unforeseen i should notshrink from the duty of return it to you with my reason for yourfurther consideration beyond the due performance of these constitutionalobligation both my respect for the legislature and my sense of proprietywill restrain i from any attempt to control or influence your proceeding with you be the power the honor and the responsibility of the legislationof the country the government of the united states be a limited government it be confinedto the exercise of power expressly grant and such other as may be necessaryfor carry those power into effect and it be at all time an especialduty to guard against any infringement on the just right of the states over the object and subject intrust to congress its legislative authorityis supreme but here that authority cease and every citizen who trulylove the constitution and desire the continuance of its existence andit blessing will resolutely and firmly resist any interference in thosedomestic affair which the constitution have dearly and unequivocally leftto the exclusive authority of the states and every such citizen will alsodeprecate useless irritation among the several member of the union andall reproach and crimination tend to alienate one portion of the countryfrom another the beauty of our system of government consist and itssafety and durability must consist in avoid mutual collision and encroachmentsand in the regular separate action of all while each be revolve in itsown distinct orbit the constitution have make it the duty of the president to take carethat the law be faithfully execute in a government like ours in whichall law be pass by a majority of the representative of the people and these representative be choose for such short period that any injuriousor obnoxious law can very soon be repeal it would appear unlikely thatany great number should be find ready to resist the execution of thelaw but it must be bear in mind that the country be extensive thatthere may be local interest or prejudice render a law odious in onepart which be not so in another and that the thoughtless and inconsiderate mislead by their passion or their imagination may be induce madly toresist such law as they disapprove such person should recollect thatwithout law there can be no real practical liberty that when law be trampledund foot tyranny rule whether it appear in the form of a militarydespotism or of popular violence the law be the only sure protection ofthe weak and the only efficient restraint upon the strong when impartiallyand faithfully administer none be beneath its protection and none aboveit control you gentleman and the country may be assure that to theutmost of my ability and to the extent of the power vest in i i shallat all time and in all place take care that the law be faithfully execute in the discharge of this duty solemnly impose upon i by the constitutionand by my oath of office i shall shrink from no responsibility and shallendeavor to meet event as they may arise with firmness as well as withprudence and discretion the appoint power be one of the most delicate with which the executiveis invest i regard it as a sacred trust to be exercise with the soleview of advance the prosperity and happiness of the people it shallbe my effort to elevate the standard of official employment by selectingfor place of importance individual fit for the post to which theyare assign by their know integrity talent and virtue in so extensivea country with so great a population and where few person appointedto office can be know to the appoint power mistake will sometimesunavoidably happen and to the senate and house of representatives

 by the term of that act it be require that the agreement of texas to the proposition contain in it should be give on or before the 1st day of december 1850 an authenticated transcript of a law pass by the legislature of texas on the 25th day of november agree to and accept the proposition contain in the act of congress have be receive this law after recite the provision of the act of congress proceed to enact and declare as follow viz
 therefore first be it enact by the legislature of the state of texas that the state of texas hereby agree to and accept say proposition and it be hereby declare that the say state shall be bind by the term thereof accord to their true import and meaning
 second that the governor of this state be and be hereby request to cause a copy of this act authenticate under the seal of the state to be furnish to the president of the united states by mail as early as practicable and also a copy thereof certify in like manner to be transmit to each of the senators and representatives of texas in congress and that this act take effect from and after its passage
 c.g. keenan
 speaker of the house of representatives

 president of the senate
 p.h. bell
 approve november 25 1850
 from the common source of public information it would appear that a very remarkable degree of unanimity prevail not only in the legislature but among the people of texas in respect to the agreement of the state to that which have be propose by congress
 i can not refrain from congratulate congress and the country on the success of this great and leading measure of conciliation and peace the difficulty feel and the danger apprehend from the vast acquisition of territory under the late treaty with mexico seem now happily overcome by the wisdom of congress within that territory there already exist one state respectable for the amount of her population distinguish for singular activity and enterprise and remarkable in many respect from her condition and history this new state have come into the union with manifestation not to be mistaken of her attachment to that constitution and that government which now embrace she and her interest within their protect and beneficent control
 over the residue of the acquire territory regular territorial government be now establish in the manner which have be most usual in the history of this government various other act of congress may undoubtedly be requisite for the benefit as well as for the proper government of these so distant part of the country but the same legislative wisdom which have triumph over the principal difficulty and accomplish the main end may safely be rely on for whatever measure may yet be find necessary to perfect its work so that the acquisition of these vast region to the united states may rather strengthen than weaken the constitution which be over we all and the union which afford such ample daily proof of its inestimable value

whereas by an act of the congress of the united states of the 9th of september 1850 entitle an act propose to the state of texas the establishment of her northern and western boundary the relinquishment by the say state of all territory claim by her exterior to say boundary and of all her claim upon the united states and to establish a territorial government for new mexico it be provide that the follow proposition should be and the same be thereby offer to the state of texas which when agree to by the say state in an act pass by the general assembly should be bind and obligatory upon the united states and upon the say state of texas provide the say agreement by the say general assembly should be give on or before the 1st day of december 1850 namely
 first the state of texas will agree that her boundary on the north shall commence at the point at which the meridian of 100 degree west from greenwich be intersect by the parallel of 36 degree 30&#39 north latitude and shall run from say point due west to the meridian of 103 degree west from greenwich thence her boundary shall run due south to the thirty second degree of north latitude thence on the say parallel of 32 degree of north latitude to the rio bravo del norte and thence with the channel of say river to the gulf of mexico
 second the state of texas cede to the united states all her claim to territory exterior to the limit and boundary which she agree to establish by the first article of this agreement
 third the state of texas relinquish all claim upon the united states for liability of the debt of texas and for compensation or indemnity for the surrender to the united states of her ship fort arsenal custom house custom house revenue arm and munition of war and public building with their site which become the property of the united states at the time of the annexation
 fourth the united states in consideration of say establishment of boundary cession of claim to territory and relinquishment of claim will pay to the state of texas the sum of $ 10,000,000 in a stock bear 5 per cent interest and redeemable at the end of fourteen year the interest payable half yearly at the treasury of the united states
 fifth immediately after the president of the united states shall have be furnish with an authentic copy of the act of the general assembly of texas accept these proposition he shall cause the stock to be issue in favor of the state of texas as provide for in the fourth article of this agreement provide also that no more than $ 5,000,000 of say stock shall be issue until the creditor of the state hold bond and other certificate of stock of texas for which duty on import be specially pledge shall first file at the treasury of the united states release of all claim against the united states for or on account of say bond or certificate in such form as shall be prescribe by the secretary of the treasury and approve by the president of the united states provide that nothing herein contain shall be construe to impair or qualify anything contain in the third article of the second section of the 39;joint resolution for annex texas to the united states,&#39 approve march 1 1845 either as regard the number of states that may hereafter be form out of the state of texas or otherwise and
 whereas it be far provide by the eighteenth section of the same act of congress that the provision of this act be and they be hereby suspend until the boundary between the united states and the state of texas shall be adjust and when such adjustment shall have be effect the president of the united states shall issue his proclamation declare this act to be in full force and operation and
 whereas the legislature of the state of texas by an act approve the 25th of november last entitle an act accept the proposition make by the united states to the state of texas in an act of the congress of the united states approve the 9th day of september a. d. 1850 and entitle 39;an act propose to the state of texas the establishment of her northern and western boundary the relinquishment by the say state of all territory claim by her exterior to say boundary and of all her claim upon the united states and to establish a territorial government for new mexico,&#39 of which act a copy authenticate under the seal of the state have be furnish to the president enact that the state of texas hereby agree to and accept say proposition and it be hereby declare that the say state shall be bind by the term thereof accord to their true import and meaning
 now therefore i millard fillmore president of the united states of america do hereby declare and proclaim that the say act of the congress of the united states of the 9th of september last be in full force and operation
 give under my hand at the city of washington this 13th day of december a. d. 1850 and the seventy fifth of the independence of these united states
 millard fillmore

 secretary of state

to the senate of the united states
 i have receive the resolution of the senate of the 18th instant request i to lay before that body if not incompatible with the public interest any information i may possess in regard to an alleged recent case of a forcible resistance to the execution of the law of the united states in the city of boston and to communicate to the senate under the above condition what mean i have adopt to meet the occurrence and whether in my opinion any additional legislation be necessary to meet the exigency of the case and to more vigorously execute exist law
 the public newspaper contain an affidavit of patrick riley a deputy marshal for the district of massachusetts set forth the circumstance of the case a copy of which affidavit be herewith communicate private and unofficial communication concur in establish the main fact of this account but no satisfactory official information have as yet be receive and in some important respect the accuracy of the account have be deny by person whom it implicate nothing could be more unexpected than that such a gross violation of law such a high handed contempt of the authority of the united states should be perpetrate by a band of lawless confederate at noonday in the city of boston and in the very temple of justice i regard this flagitious proceeding as be a surprise not unattended by some degree of negligence nor do i doubt that if any such act of violence have be apprehend thousand of the good citizen of boston would have present themselves voluntarily and promptly to prevent it but the danger do not seem to have be timely make known or duly appreciate by those who be concern in the execution of the process in a community distinguish for its love of order and respect for the law among a people whose sentiment be liberty and law and not liberty without law nor above the law such an outrage could only be the result of sudden violence unhappily too much unprepared for to be successfully resist it would be melancholy indeed if we be oblige to regard this outbreak against the constitutional and legal authority of the government as proceed from the general feeling of the people in a spot which be proverbially call the cradle of american liberty such undoubtedly be not the fact it violate without question the general sentiment of the people of boston and of a vast majority of the whole people of massachusetts as much as it violate the law defy the authority of the government and disgrace those concerned in it their alder and abettor
 it be nevertheless my duty to lay before the senate in answer to its resolution some important fact and consideration connect with the subject
 a resolution of congress of september 23 1789 declare
 that it be recommend to the legislature of the several states to pass law make it expressly the duty of the keeper of their jail to receive and safe keep therein all prisoner commit under the authority of the united states until they shall be discharge by the course of the law thereof under the like penalty as in the case of prisoner commit under the authority of such states respectively the united states to pay for the use and keeping of such jail at the rate of 50 cent per month for each prisoner that shall under their authority be commit thereto during the time such prisoner shall be therein confine and also to support such of say prisoner as shall be commit for offense
 a further resolution of congress of the 3d of march 1791 provide that--
 whereas congress do by a resolution of the 23d day of september 1789 recommend to the several states to pass law make it expressly the duty of the keeper of their jail to receive and safe keep therein all prisoner commit under the authority of the united states in order therefore to insure the administration of justice--
 resolve by the senate and house of representatives of the united states of america in congress assemble that in case any state shall not have comply with the say recommendation the marshal in such state under the direction of the judge of the district be authorize to hire a convenient place to serve as a temporary jail and to make the necessary provision for the safe keeping of prisoner commit under the authority of the united states until permanent provision shall be make by law for that purpose and the say marshal shall be allow his reasonable expense incur for the above purpose to be pay out of the treasury of the united states
 and a resolution of congress of march 3 1821 provide that--
 where any state or states having comply with the recommendation of congress in the resolution of the 23d day of september 1789 shall have withdraw or shall hereafter withdraw either in whole or in part the use of their jail for prisoner commit under the authority of the united states the marshal in such state or states under the direction of the judge of the district shall be and hereby be authorize and require to hire a convenient place to serve as a temporary jail and to make the necessary provision for the safe keeping of prisoner commit under the authority of the united states until permanent provision shall be make by law for that purpose and the say marshal shall be allow his reasonable expense incur for the above purpose to be pay out of the treasury of the united states
 these various provision of the law remain unrepealed
 by the law of massachusetts as that law stand before the act of the legislature of that state of the 24th of march 1843 the common jail in the respective county be to be use for the detention of any person detain or commit by the authority of the court of the united states as well as by the court and magistrate of the state but these provision be abrogate and repeal by the act of the legislature of massachusetts of the 24th of march 1843
 that act declare that--
 no judge of any court of record of this commonwealth and no justice of the peace shall hereafter take cognizance or grant a certificate in case that may arise under the third section of an act of congress pass february 12 1793 and entitle an act respect fugitive from justice and person escape from the service of their master to any person who claim any other person as a fugitive slave within the jurisdiction of the commonwealth
 and it far declare that--
 no sheriff deputy sheriff coroner constable jailer or other officer of this commonwealth shall hereafter arrest or detain or aid in the arrest or detention or imprisonment in any jail or other building belong to this commonwealth or to any county city or town thereof of any person for the reason that he be claim as a fugitive slave
 and it far declare that--
 any justice of the peace sheriff deputy sheriff coroner constable or jailer who shall offend against the provision of this law by in any way act directly or indirectly under the power confer by the third section of the act of congress aforementione shall forfeit a sum not exceed $ 1,000 for every such offense to the use of the county where say offense be commit or shall be subject to imprisonment not exceed one year in the county jail
 this law it be obvious have two object the first be to make it a penal offense in all officer and magistrate of the commonwealth to exercise the power confer on they by the act of congress of the 12th of february 1793 entitle an act respect fugitive from justice and person escape from the service of their master and which power they be fully competent to perform up to the time of this inhibition and penal enactment second to refuse the use of the jail of the state for the detention of any person claim as a fugitive slave
 it be deeply to be lament that the purpose of these enactment be quite apparent it be to prevent as far as the legislature of the state could prevent the law of congress pass for the purpose of carry into effect that article of the constitution of the united states which declare that no person hold to service or labor in one state under the law thereof escape into another shall in consequence of any law or regulation therein be discharge from such service or labor but shall be deliver up on claim of the party to whom such service or labor may be due from be carry into effect but these act of state legislation although they may cause embarrassment and create expense can not derogate either from the duty or the authority of congress to carry out fully and fairly the plain and imperative constitutional provision for the delivery of person bind to labor in one state and escape into another to the party to whom such labor may be due it be quite clear that by the resolution of congress of march 3 1821 the marshal of the united states in any state in which the use of the jail of the state have be withdraw in whole or in part from the purpose of the detention of person commit under the authority of the united states be not only empower but expressly require under the direction of the judge of the district to hire a convenient place for the safe keeping of prisoner commit under authority of the united states it will be see from paper accompany this communication that the attention of the marshal of massachusetts be distinctly call to this provision of the law by a letter from the secretary of the navy of the date of october 28 last there be no official information that the marshal have provide any such place for the confinement of his prisoner if he have not it be to be regret that this power be not exercise by the marshal under the direction of the district judge immediately on the passage of the act of the legislature of massachusetts of the 24th of march 1843 and especially that it be not exercise on the passage of the fugitive slave law of the last session or when the attention of the marshal be afterwards particularly draw to it
 it be true that the escape from the deputy marshal in this case be not owe to the want of a prison or place of confinement but still it be not easy to see how the prisoner could have be safely and conveniently detain during an adjournment of the hearing for some day without such place of confinement if it shall appear that no such place have be obtain direction to the marshal will be give to lose no time in the discharge of this duty
 i transmit to the senate the copy of a proclamation issue by i on the 18th instant in relation to these unexpected and deplorable occurrence in boston together with copy of instruction from the departments of war and navy relative to the general subject and i communicate also copy of telegraphic dispatch transmit from the department of state to the district attorney and marshal of the united states for the district of massachusetts and their answer thereto
 in regard to the last branch of the inquiry make by the resolution of the senate i have to observe that the constitution declare that the president shall take care that the law be faithfully execute and that he shall be commander in chief of the army and navy of the united states and of the militia of the several states when call into the actual service of the united states and that congress shall have power to provide for call forth the militia to execute the law of the union suppress insurrection and repel invasion from which it appear that the army and navy be by the constitution place under the control of the executive and probably no legislation of congress could add to or diminish the power thus give but by increase or diminishing or abolish altogether the army and navy but not so with the militia the president can not call the militia into service even to execute the law or repel invasion but by the authority of act of congress pass for that purpose but when the militia be call into service in the manner prescribe by law then the constitution itself give the command to the president act on this principle congress by the act of february 28 1795 authorize the president to call forth the militia to repel invasion and suppress insurrection against a state government and to suppress combination against the law of the united states and cause the law to be faithfully execute but the act proceed to declare that whenever it may be necessary in the judgment of the president to use the military force thereby direct to be call forth the president shall forthwith by proclamation command such insurgent to disperse and retire peaceably to their respective abode within a limited time these word be broad enough to require a proclamation in all case where militia be call out under that act whether to repel invasion or suppress an insurrection or to aid in execute the law this section have consequently create some doubt whether the militia could be call forth to aid in execute the law without a previous proclamation but yet the proclamation seem to be in word direct only against insurgent and to require they to disperse thereby imply not only an insurrection but an organize or at least an embody force such a proclamation in aid of the civil authority would often defeat the whole object by give such notice to person intend to be arrest that they would be enable to fly or secrete themselves the force may be want sometimes to make the arrest and also sometimes to protect the officer after it be make and to prevent a rescue i would therefore suggest that this section be modify by declare that nothing therein contain shall be construe to require any previous proclamation when the militia be call forth either to repel invasion to execute the law or suppress combination against they and that the president may make such call and place such militia under the control of any civil officer of the united states to aid he in execute the law or suppress such combination and while so employ they shall be pay by and subsist at the expense of the united states
 congress not probably advert to the difference between the militia and the regular army by the act of march 3 1807 authorize the president to use the land and naval force of the united states for the same purpose for which he might call forth the militia and subject to the same proclamation but the power of the president under the constitution as commander of the army and navy be general and his duty to see the law faithfully execute be general and positive and the act of 1807 ought not to be construe as evince any disposition in congress to limit or restrain this constitutional authority for great certainty however it may be well that congress should modify or explain this act in regard to its provision for the employment of the army and navy of the united states as well as that in regard to call forth the militia it be suppose not to be doubtful that all citizen whether enrol in the militia or not may be summon as member of the posse comitatus either by the marshal or a commissioner accord to law and that it be their duty to obey such summon but perhaps it may be doubt whether the marshal or a commissioner can summon as the posse comitatus an organize militia force act under its own appropriate officer without the consent of such officer this point may deserve the consideration of congress
 i use this occasion to repeat the assurance that so far as depend on i the law shall be faithfully execute and all forcible opposition to they suppress and to this end i be prepared to exercise whenever it may become necessary the power constitutionally vest in i to the full extent i be fully persuade that the great majority of the people of this country be warmly and strongly attach to the constitution the preservation of the union the just support of the government and the maintenance of the authority of law i be persuade that their earnest wish and the line of my constitutional duty entirely concur and i doubt not firmness moderation and prudence strengthen and animate by the general opinion of the people will prevent the repetition of occurrence disturb the public peace and reprobate by all good man
 april 25 1851- warn against participating in unlawful invasions of cuba
 whereas there be reason to believe that a military expedition be about to be fit out in the united states with intention to invade the island of cuba a colony of spain with which this country be at peace and
 whereas it be believe that this expedition be instigate and set on foot chiefly by foreigner who dare to make our shore the scene of their guilty and hostile preparation against a friendly power and seek by falsehood and misrepresentation to seduce our own citizen especially the young and inconsiderate into their wicked scheme an ungrateful return for the benefit confer upon they by this people in permit they to make our country an asylum from oppression and in flagrant abuse of the hospitality thus extend to they and
 whereas such expedition can only be regard as adventure for plunder and robbery and must meet the condemnation of the civilized world whilst they be derogatory to the character of our country in violation of the law of nation and expressly prohibit by our own our statute declare that if any person shall within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states begin or set on foot or provide or prepare the mean for any military expedition or enterprise to be carry on from thence against the territory or dominion of any foreign prince or state or of any colony district or people with whom the united states be at peace every person so offending shall be deem guilty of a high misdemeanor and shall be fine not exceed $ 3,000 and imprison not more than three year
 now therefore i have issue this my proclamation warn all person who shall connect themselves with any such enterprise or expedition in violation of our law and national obligation that they will thereby subject themselves to the heavy penalty denounce against such offense and will forfeit their claim to the protection of this government or any interference on their behalf no matter to what extremity they may be reduce in consequence of their illegal conduct and therefore i exhort all good citizen as they regard our national reputation as they respect their own law and the law of nation as they value the blessing of peace and the welfare of their country to discountenance and by all lawful mean prevent any such enterprise and i call upon every officer of this government civil or military to use all effort in his power to arrest for trial and punishment every such offender against the law of the country
 give under my hand the 25th day of april a. d. 1851 and the seventy fifth of the independence of the united states

fellow citizen of the senate and of the house of representatives
 i congratulate you and our common constituency upon the favorable auspex under which you meet for your first session our country be at peace with all the world the agitation which for a time threaten to disturb the fraternal relation which make we one people be fast subsiding and a year of general prosperity and health have crown the nation with unusual blessing none can look back to the danger which be pass or forward to the bright prospect before we without feel a thrill of gratification at the same time that he must be impress with a grateful sense of our profound obligation to a beneficent providence whose paternal care be so manifest in the happiness of this highly favor land
 since the close of the last congress certain cubans and other foreigner resident in the united states who be more or less concerned in the previous invasion of cuba instead of be discourage by its failure have again abuse the hospitality of this country by make it the scene of the equipment of another military expedition against that possession of her catholic majesty in which they be countenance aid and join by citizen of the united states on receive intelligence that such design be entertain i lose no time in issue such instruction to the proper officer of the united states as seem to be call for by the occasion by the proclamation a copy of which be herewith submit i also warn those who might be in danger of be inveigle into this scheme of its unlawful character and of the penalty which they would incur for some time there be reason to hope that these measure have suffice to prevent any such attempt this hope however prove to be delusive very early in the morning of the 3d of august a steamer call the pampero depart from new orleans for cuba have on board upward of 400 armed man with evident intention to make war upon the authority of the island this expedition be set on foot in palpable violation of the law of the united states its leader be a spaniard and several of the chief officer and some other engage in it be foreigner the person compose it however be mostly citizen of the united states
 before the expedition set out and probably before it be organize a slight insurrectionary movement which appear to have be soon suppress have take place in the eastern quarter of cuba the importance of this movement be unfortunately so much exaggerated in the account of it publish in this country that these adventurer seem to have be lead to believe that the creole population of the island not only desire to throw off the authority of the mother country but have resolve upon that step and have begin a well concert enterprise for effect it the person engage in the expedition be generally young and ill informed the steamer in which they embark leave new orleans stealthily and without a clearance after touch at key west she proceed to the coast of cuba and on the night between the 11th and 12th of august land the person on board at playtas within about 20 league of havana
 the main body of they proceed to and take possession of an inland village 6 league distant leave other to follow in charge of the baggage as soon as the mean of transportation could be obtain the latter having take up their line of march to connect themselves with the main body and having proceed about 4 league into the country be attack on the morning of the 13th by a body of spanish troop and a bloody conflict ensue after which they retreat to the place of disembarkation where about 50 of they obtain boat and reembarke therein they be however intercept among the key near the shore by a spanish steamer cruising on the coast capture and carry to havana and after be examine before a military court be sentence to be publicly execute and the sentence be carry into effect on the 16th of august
 on receive information of what have occur commodore foxhall a. parker be instruct to proceed in the steam frigate saranac to havana and inquire into the charge against the person execute the circumstance under which they be take and whatsoever refer to their trial and sentence copy of the instruction from the department of state to he and of his letter to that department be herewith submit
 accord to the record of the examination the prisoner all admit the offense charge against they of be hostile invader of the island at the time of their trial and execution the main body of the invader be still in the field make war upon the spanish authority and spanish subject after the lapse of some day be overcome by the spanish troop they disperse on the 24th of august lopez their leader be capture some day after and execute on the 1st of september many of his remain follower be kill or die of hunger and fatigue and the rest be make prisoner of these none appear to have be try or execute several of they be pardon upon application of their friend and other and the rest about 160 in number be send to spain of the final disposition make of these we have no official information
 such be the melancholy result of this illegal and ill fate expedition thus thoughtless young man have be induce by false and fraudulent representation to violate the law of their country through rash and unfounded expectation of assist to accomplish political revolution in other state and have lose their life in the undertaking too severe a judgment can hardly be pass by the indignant sense of the community upon those who be well inform themselves have yet lead away the ardor of youth and an ill direct love of political liberty the correspondence between this government and that of spain relate to this transaction be herewith communicate
 although these offender against the law have forfeit the protection of their country yet the government may so far as consistent with its obligation to other country and its fix purpose to maintain and enforce the law entertain sympathy for their unoffending family and friend as well as a feeling of compassion for themselves accordingly no proper effort have be spare and none will be spare to procure the release of such citizen of the united states engage in this unlawful enterprise as be now in confinement in spain but it be to be hope that such interposition with the government of that country may not be consider as afford any ground of expectation that the government of the united states will hereafter feel itself under any obligation of duty to intercede for the liberation or pardon of such person as be flagrant offender against the law of nation and the law of the united states these law must be execute if we desire to maintain our respectability among the nation of the earth it behoove we to enforce steadily and sternly the neutrality act pass by congress and to follow as far as may be the violation of those act with condign punishment
 but what give a peculiar criminality to this invasion of cuba be that under the lead of spanish subject and with the aid of citizen of the united states it have its origin with many in motive of cupidity money be advance by individual probably in considerable amount to purchase cuban bond as they have be call issue by lopez sell doubtless at a very large discount and for the payment of which the public land and public property of cuba of whatever kind and the fiscal resource of the people and government of that island from whatever source to be derive be pledge as well as the good faith of the government expect to be establish all these mean of payment it be evident be only to be obtain by a process of bloodshed war and revolution none will deny that those who set on foot military expedition against foreign state by mean like these be far more culpable than the ignorant and the necessitous whom they induce to go forth as the ostensible party in the proceeding these originator of the invasion of cuba seem to have determine with coolness and system upon an undertaking which should disgrace their country violate its law and put to hazard the life of ill inform and deluded man you will consider whether further legislation be necessary to prevent the perpetration of such offense in future
 no individual have a right to hazard the peace of the country or to violate its law upon vague notion of alter or reform government in other state this principle be not only reasonable in itself and in accordance with public law but be ingraft into the code of other nation as well as our own but while such be the sentiment of this government it may be add that every independent nation must be presume to be able to defend its possession against unauthorized individual band together to attack they the government of the united states at all time since its establishment have abstain and have seek to restrain the citizen of the country from enter into controversy between other power and to observe all the duty of neutrality at an early period of the government in the administration of washington several law be pass for this purpose the main provision of these law be reenact by the act of april 1818 by which amongst other thing it be declare that--
 if any person shall within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states begin or set on foot or provide or prepare the mean for any military expedition or enterprise to be carry on from thence against the territory or dominion of any foreign prince or state or of any colony district or people with whom the united states be at peace every person so offending shall be deem guilty of a high misdemeanor and shall be fine not exceed $ 3,000 and imprison not more than three year
 and this law have be execute and enforce to the full extent of the power of the government from that day to this
 in proclaim and adhere to the doctrine of neutrality and nonintervention the united states have not follow the lead of other civilized nation they have take the lead themselves and have be follow by other this be admit by one of the most eminent of modern british statesman who say in parliament while a minister of the crown that if he wish for a guide in a system of neutrality he should take that lay down by america in the day of washington and the secretaryship of jefferson and we see in fact that the act of congress of 1818 be follow the succeed year by an act of the parliament of england substantially the same in its general provision up to that time there have be no similar law in england except certain highly penal statute pass in the reign of george ii prohibit english subject from enlist in foreign service the avow object of which statute be that foreign army raise for the purpose of restore the house of stuart to the throne should not be strengthen by recruit from england herself
 all must see that difficulty may arise in carry the law refer to into execution in a country now have 3,000 or 4,000 mile of seacoast with an infinite number of port and harbor and small inlet from some of which unlawful expeditious may suddenly set forth without the knowledge of government against the possession of foreign state
 friendly relation with all but entangle alliance with none have long be a maxim with we our true mission be not to propagate our opinion or impose upon other country our form of government by artifice or force but to teach by example and show by our success moderation and justice the blessing of self government and the advantage of free institution let every people choose for itself and make and alter its political institution to suit its own condition and convenience but while we avow and maintain this neutral policy ourselves we be anxious to see the same forbearance on the part of other nation whose form of government be different from our own the deep interest which we feel in the spread of liberal principle and the establishment of free government and the sympathy with which we witness every struggle against oppression forbid that we should be indifferent to a case in which the strong arm of a foreign power be invoke to stifle public sentiment and repress the spirit of freedom in any country
