 the government of great britain and france have issue order to their naval commander on the west india station to prevent by force if necessary the landing of adventurer from any nation on the island of cuba with hostile intent the copy of a memorandum of a conversation on this subject between the charge&#39 d&#39;affaire of her britannic majesty and the acting secretary of state and of a subsequent note of the former to the department of state be herewith submit together with a copy of a note of the acting secretary of state to the minister of the french republic and of the reply of the latter on the same subject these paper will acquaint you with the ground of this interposition of two lead commercial power of europe and with the apprehension which this government could not fail to entertain that such interposition if carry into effect might lead to abuse in derogation of the maritime right of the united states the maritime right of the united states be found on a firm secure and well define basis they stand upon the ground of national independence and public law and will be maintain in all their full and just extent the principle which this government have heretofore solemnly announce it still adhere to and will maintain under all circumstance and at all hazard that principle be that in every regularly document merchant vessel the crew who navigate it and those on board of it will find their protection in the flag which be over they no american ship can be allow to be visit or search for the purpose of ascertain the character of individual on board nor can there be allow any watch by the vessel of any foreign nation over american vessel on the coast of the united states or the sea adjacent thereto it will be see by the last communication from the british charge&#39 d&#39;affaire to the department of state that he be authorize to assure the secretary of state that every care will be take that in execute the preventive measure against the expedition which the united states government itself have denounce as not be entitle to the protection of any government no interference shall take place with the lawful commerce of any nation
 in addition to the correspondence on this subject herewith submit official information have be receive at the department of state of assurance by the french government that in the order give to the french naval force they be expressly instruct in any operation they might engage in to respect the flag of the united states wherever it might appear and to commit no act of hostility upon any vessel or armament under its protection
 minister and consul of foreign nation be the mean and agent of communication between we and those nation and it be of the utmost importance that while reside in the country they should feel a perfect security so long as they faithfully discharge their respective duty and be guilty of no violation of our law this be the admit law of nation and no country have a deep interest in maintain it than the united states our commerce spread over every sea and visit every clime and our minister and consul be appoint to protect the interest of that commerce as well as to guard the peace of the country and maintain the honor of its flag but how can they discharge these duty unless they be themselves protect and if protect it must be by the law of the country in which they reside and what be due to our own public functionary reside in foreign nation be exactly the measure of what be due to the functionary of other government reside here as in war the bearer of flag of truce be sacred or else war would be interminable so in peace ambassador public minister and consul charge with friendly national intercourse be object of especial respect and protection each accord to the right belong to his rank and station in view of these important principle it be with deep mortification and regret i announce to you that during the excitement grow out of the execution at havana the office of her catholic majesty&#39;s consul at new orleans be assail by a mob his property destroy the spanish flag find in the office carry off and tear in piece and he himself induce to flee for his personal safety which he suppose to be in danger on receive intelligence of these event i forthwith direct the attorney of the united states reside at new orleans to inquire into the fact and the extent of the pecuniary loss sustain by the consul with the intention of lay they before you that you might make provision for such indemnity to he as a just regard for the honor of the nation and the respect which be due to a friendly power might in your judgment seem to require the correspondence upon this subject between the secretary of state and her catholic majesty&#39;s minister plenipotentiary be herewith transmit
 the occurrence at new orleans have lead i to give my attention to the state of our law in regard to foreign ambassador minister and consul i think the legislation of the country be deficient in not provide sufficiently either for the protection or the punishment of consul i therefore recommend the subject to the consideration of congress
 your attention be again invite to the question of reciprocal trade between the united states and canada and other british possession near our frontier overture for a convention upon this subject have be receive from her britannic majesty&#39;s minister plenipotentiary but it seem to be in many respect preferable that the matter should be regulate by reciprocal legislation document be lay before you show the term which the british government be willing to offer and the measure which it may adopt if some arrangement upon this subject shall not be make
 from the accompany copy of a note from the british legation at washington and the reply of the department of state thereto it will appear that her britannic majesty&#39;s government be desirous that a part of the boundary line between oregon and the british possession should be authoritatively mark out and that an intention be express to apply to congress for an appropriation to defray the expense thereof on the part of the united states your attention to this subject be accordingly invite and a proper appropriation recommend a convention for the adjustment of claim of citizen of the united states against portugal have be conclude and the ratification have be exchange the first installment of the amount to be pay by portugal fall due on the 30th of september last and have be pay the president of the french republic accord to the provision of the convention have be select as arbiter in the case of the general armstrong and have signify that he accept the trust and the high satisfaction he feel in act as the common friend of two nation with which france be unite by sentiment of sincere and lasting amity
 the turkish government have express its thank for the kind reception give to the sultan&#39;s agent amin bey on the occasion of his recent visit to the united states on the 28th of february last a dispatch be address by the secretary of state to mr. marsh the american minister at constantinople instruct he to ask of the turkish government permission for the hungarians then imprison within the dominion of the sublime porte to remove to this country on the 3d of march last both houses of congress pass a resolution request the president to authorize the employment of a public vessel to convey to this country louis kossuth and his associate in captivity the instruction above refer to be comply with and the turkish government having release governor kossuth and his companion from prison on the 10th of september last they embark on board of the united states steam frigate mississippi which be select to carry into effect the resolution of congress governor kossuth leave the mississippi at gibraltar for the purpose of make a visit to england and may shortly be expect in new york by communication to the department of state he have express his grateful acknowledgment for the interposition of this government in behalf of himself and his associate this country have be justly regard as a safe asylum for those whom political event have exile from their own home in europe and it be recommend to congress to consider in what manner governor kossuth and his companion bring hither by its authority shall be receive and treat
 it be earnestly to be hope that the difference which have for some time past be pende between the government of the french republic and that of the sandwich islands may be peaceably and durably adjust so as to secure the independence of those island long before the event which have of late impart so much importance to the possession of the united states on the pacific we acknowledge the independence of the hawaiian government this government be first in take that step and several of the lead power of europe immediately follow we be influence in this measure by the exist and prospective importance of the island as a place of refuge and refreshment for our vessel engage in the whale fishery and by the consideration that they lie in the course of the great trade which must at no distant day be carry on between the western coast of north america and eastern asia
 we be also influence by a desire that those island should not pass under the control of any other great maritime state but should remain in an independent condition and so be accessible and useful to the commerce of all nation i need not say that the importance of these consideration have be greatly enhance by the sudden and vast development which the interest of the united states have attain in california and oregon and the policy heretofore adopt in regard to those island will be steadily pursue
 it be gratify not only to those who consider the commercial interest of nation but also to all who favor the progress of knowledge and the diffusion of religion to see a community emerge from a savage state and attain such a degree of civilization in those distant sea it be much to be deplore that the internal tranquillity of the mexican republic should again be seriously disturb for since the peace between that republic and the united states it have enjoy such comparative repose that the most favorable anticipation for the future might with a degree of confidence have be indulge these however have be thwart by the recent outbreak in the state of tamaulipas on the right bank of the rio bravo having receive information that person from the united states have take part in the insurrection and apprehend that their example might be follow by other i cause order to be issue for the purpose of prevent any hostile expedition against mexico from be set on foot in violation of the law of the united states i likewise issue a proclamation upon the subject a copy of which be herewith lay before you this appear to be render imperative by the obligation of treaty and the general duty of good neighborhood
 in my last annual message i inform congress that citizen of the united states have undertake the connection of the two ocean by mean of a railroad across the isthmus of tehuantepec under a grant of the mexican government to a citizen of that republic and that this enterprise would probably be prosecute with energy whenever mexico should consent to such stipulation with the government of the united states as should impart a feeling of security to those who should invest their property in the enterprise a convention between the two government for the accomplishment of that end have be ratify by this government and only await the decision of the congress and the executive of that republic
 some unexpected difficulty and delay have arise in the ratification of that convention by mexico but it be to be presume that her decision will be govern by just and enlightened view as well of the general importance of the object as of her own interest and obligation
 in negotiate upon this important subject this government have have in view one and only one object that object have be and be the construction or attainment of a passage from ocean to ocean the short and the good for traveler and merchandise and equally open to all the world it have seek to obtain no territorial acquisition nor any advantage peculiar to itself and it would see with the great regret that mexico should oppose any obstacle to the accomplishment of an enterprise which promise so much convenience to the whole commercial world and such eminent advantage to mexico herself impressed with these sentiment and these conviction the government will continue to exert all proper effort to bring about the necessary arrangement with the republic of mexico for the speedy completion of the work for some month past the republic of nicaragua have be the theater of one of those civil convulsion from which the cause of free institution and the general prosperity and social progress of the states of central america have so often and so severely suffer until quiet shall have be restore and a government apparently stable shall have be organize no advance can prudently be make in dispose of the question pende between the two country
 i be happy to announce that an interoceanic communication from the mouth of the st. john to the pacific have be so far accomplish as that passenger have actually traverse it and merchandise have be transport over it and when the canal shall have be complete accord to the original plan the mean of communication will be far improve it be understand that a considerable part of the railroad across the isthmus of panama have be complete and that the mail and passenger will in future be convey thereon whichever of the several route between the two ocean may ultimately prove most eligible for traveler to and from the different states on the atlantic and gulf of mexico and our coast on the pacific there be little reason to doubt that all of they will be useful to the public and will liberally reward that individual enterprise by which alone they have be or be expect to be carry into effect peace have be conclude between the contend party in the island of st. domingo and it be hope upon a durable basis such be the extent of our commercial relation with that island that the united states can not fail to feel a strong interest in its tranquillity the office of commissioner to china remain unfilled several person have be appoint and the place have be offer to other all of whom have decline its acceptance on the ground of the inadequacy of the compensation the annual allowance by law be $ 6,000 and there be no provision for any outfit i earnestly recommend the consideration of this subject to congress our commerce with china be highly important and be become more and more so in consequence of the increase intercourse between our port on the pacific coast and eastern asia china be understand to be a country in which living be very expensive and i know of no reason why the american commissioner send thither should not be place in regard to compensation on an equal footing with minister who represent this country at the courts of europe
 by reference to the report of the secretary of the treasury it will be see that the aggregate receipt for the last fiscal year amount to $ 52,312,979.87 which with the balance in the treasury on the 1st july 1850 give as the available mean for the year the sum of $ 58,917,524.36
 the total expenditure for the same period be $ 48,005,878.68 the total import for the year end june 30 1851 be $ 215,725,995 of which there be in specie $ 4,967,901 the export for the same period be $ 217,517,130 of which there be of domestic product $ 178,546,555 foreign good reexporte $ 9,738,695 specie $ 29,231,880
 since the 1st of december last the payment in cash on account of the public debt exclusive of interest have amount to $ 7,501,456.56 which however include the sum of $ 3,242,400 pay under the twelfth article of the treaty with mexico and the further sum of $ 2,591,213.45 be the amount of award to american citizen under the late treaty with mexico for which the issue of stock be authorize but which be pay in cash from the treasury
 the public debt on the 20th ultimo exclusive of the stock authorize to be issue to texas by the act of 9th september 1850 be $ 62,560,395.26
 the receipt for the next fiscal year be estimate at $ 51,800,000 which with the probable unappropriated balance in the treasury on the 30th june next will give as the probable available mean for that year the sum of $ 63,258,743.09
 it have be deem proper in view of the large expenditure consequent upon the acquisition of territory from mexico that the estimate for the next fiscal year should be lay before congress in such manner as to distinguish the expenditure so require from the otherwise ordinary demand upon the treasury
 the total expenditure for the next fiscal year be estimate at $ 42,892,299.19 of which there be require for the ordinary purpose of the government other than those consequent upon the acquisition of our new territory and deduct the payment on account of the public debt the sum of $ 33,343,198.08 and for the purpose connect directly or indirectly with those territory and in the fulfillment of the obligation of the government contract in consequence of their acquisition the sum of $ 9,549,101.11
 if the view of the secretary of the treasury in reference to the expenditure require for these territory shall be meet by correspond action on the part of congress and appropriation make in accordance therewith there will be an estimate unappropriated balance in the treasury on the 30th june 1853 of $ 20,366,443.90 wherewith to meet that portion of the public debt due on the 1st of july following amount to $ 6,237,931.35 as well as any appropriation which may be make beyond the estimate
 in thus refer to the estimated expenditure on account of our newly acquire territory i may express the hope that congress will concur with i in the desire that a liberal course of policy may be pursue toward they and that every obligation express or imply enter into in consequence of their acquisition shall be fulfil by the most liberal appropriation for that purpose
 the value of our domestic export for the last fiscal year as compare with those of the previous year exhibit an increase of $ 43,646,322 at first view this condition of our trade with foreign nation would seem to present the most flattering hope of its future prosperity an examination of the detail of our export however will show that the increase value of our export for the last fiscal year be to be find in the high price of cotton which prevail during the first half of that year which price have since decline about one half
 the value of our export of breadstuff and provision which it be suppose the incentive of a low tariff and large importation from abroad would have greatly augment have fall from $ 68,701,921 in 1847 to $ 26,051,373 in 1850 and to $ 21,948,653 in 1851 with a strong probability amount almost to a certainty of a still further reduction in the current year
 the aggregate value of rice export during the last fiscal year as compare with the previous year also exhibit a decrease amount to $ 460,917 which with a decline in the value of the export of tobacco for the same period make an aggregate decrease in these two article of $ 1,156,751
 the policy which dictate a low rate of duty on foreign merchandise it be think by those who promote and establish it would tend to benefit the farming population of this country by increase the demand and raise the price of agricultural product in foreign market
 the foregoing fact however seem to show incontestably that no such result have follow the adoption of this policy on the contrary notwithstanding the repeal of the restrictive corn law in england the foreign demand for the product of the american farmer have steadily decline since the short crop and consequent famine in a portion of europe have be happily replace by full crop and comparative abundance of food
 it will be see by recur to the commercial statistic for the past year that the value of our domestic export have be increase in the single item of raw cotton by $ 40,000,000 over the value of that export for the year precede this be not due to any increase general demand for that article but to the short crop of the precede year which create an increase demand and an augmented price for the crop of last year should the cotton crop now go forward to market be only equal in quantity to that of the year precede and be sell at the present price then there would be a fall off in the value of our export for the present fiscal year of at least $ 40,000,000 compare with the amount export for the year end 30th june 1851
 the production of gold in california for the past year seem to promise a large supply of that metal from that quarter for some time to come this large annual increase of the currency of the world must be attend with its usual result these have be already partially disclose in the enhancement of price and a rise spirit of speculation and adventure tend to overtrade as well at home as abroad unless some salutary check shall be give to these tendency it be to be fear that importation of foreign good beyond a healthy demand in this country will lead to a sudden drain of the precious metal from we bring with it as it have do in former time the most disastrous consequence to the business and capital of the american people
 the export of specie to liquidate our foreign debt during the past fiscal year have be $ 24,963,979 over the amount of specie import the export of specie during the first quarter of the present fiscal year have be $ 14,651,827 should specie continue to be export at this rate for the remain three quarter of this year it will drain from our metallic currency during the year end 30th june 1852 the enormous amount of $ 58,607,308
 in the present prosperous condition of the national finance it will become the duty of congress to consider the good mode of pay off the public debt if the present and anticipated surplus in the treasury should not be absorb by appropriation of an extraordinary character this surplus should be employ in such way and under such restriction as congress may enact in extinguish the outstanding debt of the nation
 by reference to the act of congress approve 9th september 1850 it will be see that in consideration of certain concession by the state of texas it be provide that--
 the united states shall pay to the state of texas the sum of $ 10,000,000 in a stock bear 5 per cent interest and redeemable at the end of fourteen year the interest payable half yearly at the treasury of the united states
 in the same section of the law it be further provided--
 that no more than five million of say stock shall be issue until the creditor of the state hold bond and other certificate of stock of texas for which duty on import be specially pledge shall first file at the treasury of the united states release of all claim against the united states for or on account of say bond or certificate in such form as shall be prescribe by the secretary of the treasury and approve by the president of the united states
 the form of release thus provide for have be prescribe by the secretary of the treasury and approve it have be publish in all the lead newspaper in the commercial city of the united states and all person hold claim of the kind specify in the forego proviso be require to file their release in the form thus prescribe in the treasury of the united states on or before the 1st day of october 1851 although this publication have be continue from the 25th day of march 1851 yet up to the 1st of october last comparatively few release have be file by the creditor of texas
 the authority of the state of texas at the request of the secretary of the treasury have furnish a schedule of the public debt of that state create prior to her admission into the union with a copy of the law under which each class be contract i have from the document furnish by the state of texas determine the class of claim which in my judgment fall within the provision of the act of congress of the 9th of september 1850
 on be officially inform of the acceptance by texas of the proposition contain in the act refer to i cause the stock to be prepare and the five million which be to be issue unconditionally bear an interest of 5 per cent from the 1st day of january 1851 have be for some time ready to be deliver to the state of texas the authority of texas up to the present time have not authorize anyone to receive this stock and it remain in the treasury department subject to the order of texas the release require by law to be deposit in the treasury not having be file there the remain five million have not be issue this last amount of the stock will be withhold from texas until the condition upon which it be to be deliver shall be comply with by the creditor of that state unless congress shall otherwise direct by a modification of the law
 in my last annual message to which i respectfully refer i state briefly the reason which induce i to recommend a modification of the present tariff by convert the ad valorem into a specific duty wherever the article import be of such a character as to permit it and that such a discrimination should be make in favor of the industrial pursuit of our own country as to encourage home production without exclude foreign competition
 the numerous fraud which continue to be practice upon the revenue by false invoice and undervaluation constitute an unanswerable reason for adopt specific instead of ad valorem duty in all case where the nature of the commodity do not forbid it a striking illustration of these fraud will be exhibit in the report of the secretary of the treasury show the custom house valuation of article import under a former law subject to specific duty when there be no inducement to undervaluation and the custom house valuation of the same article under the present system of ad valorem duty so greatly reduce as to leave no doubt of the existence of the most flagrant abuse under the exist law this practical evasion of the present law combine with the languish condition of some of the great interest of the country cause by over importation and consequent depressed price and with the failure in obtain a foreign market for our increase surplus of breadstuff and provision have induce i again to recommend a modification of the exist tariff the report of the secretary of the interior which accompany this communication will present a condense statement of the operation of that important department of the government
 it will be see that the cash sale of the public land exceed those of the precede year and that there be reason to anticipate a still further increase notwithstanding the large donation which have be make to many of the states and the liberal grant to individual as a reward for military service this fact furnish very gratifying evidence of the grow wealth and prosperity of our country
 suitable measure have be adopt for commence the survey of the public land in california and oregon survey party have be organize and some progress have be make in establish the principal base and meridian line but further legislation and additional appropriation will be necessary before the proper subdivision can be make and the general land system extend over those remote part of our territory
 on the 3d of march last an act be pass provide for the appointment of three commissioner to settle private land claim in california three person be immediately appoint all of whom however decline accept the office in consequence of the inadequacy of the compensation other be promptly select who for the same reason also decline and it be not until late in the season that the service of suitable person could be secure a majority of the commissioner convene in this city on the 10th of september last when detailed instruction be give to they in regard to their duty their first meeting for the transaction of business will be hold in san francisco on the 8th day of the present month
 i have think it proper to refer to these fact not only to explain the cause of the delay in fill the commission but to call your attention to the propriety of increase the compensation of the commissioner the office be one of great labor and responsibility and the compensation should be such as to command man of a high order of talent and the most unquestionable integrity
 the proper disposal of the mineral land of california be a subject surround by great difficulty in my last annual message i recommend the survey and sale of they in small parcel under such restriction as would effectually guard against monopoly and speculation but upon further information and in deference to the opinion of person familiar with the subject i be inclined to change that recommendation and to advise that they be permit to remain as at present a common field open to the enterprise and industry of all our citizen until further experience shall have develop the good policy to be ultimately adopt in regard to they it be safe to suffer the inconvenience that now exist for a short period than by premature legislation to fasten on the country a system found in error which may place the whole subject beyond the future control of congress
 the agricultural land should however be survey and bring into market with as little delay as possible that the title may become settle and the inhabitant stimulate to make permanent improvement and enter on the ordinary pursuit of life to effect these object it be desirable that the necessary provision be make by law for the establishment of land office in california and oregon and for the efficient prosecution of the survey at an early day
 some difficulty have occur in organize the territorial government of new mexico and utah and when more accurate information shall be obtain of the cause a further communication will be make on that subject
 in my last annual communication to congress i recommend the establishment of an agricultural bureau and i take this occasion again to invoke your favorable consideration of the subject
 agriculture may justly be regard as the great interest of our people four fifth of our active population be employ in the cultivation of the soil and the rapid expansion of our settlement over new territory be daily add to the number of those engage in that vocation justice and sound policy therefore alike require that the government should use all the mean authorize by the constitution to promote the interest and welfare of that important class of our fellow citizen and yet it be a singular fact that whilst the manufacturing and commercial interest have engage the attention of congress during a large portion of every session and our statute abound in provision for their protection and encouragement little have yet be do directly for the advancement of agriculture it be time that this reproach to our legislation should be remove and i sincerely hope that the present congress will not close their labor without adopt efficient mean to supply the omission of those who have precede they
 an agricultural bureau charge with the duty of collect and disseminate correct information as to the good mode of cultivation and of the most effectual mean of preserve and restore the fertility of the soil and of procure and distribute seed and plant and other vegetable production with instruction in regard to the soil climate and treatment well adapt to their growth could not fail to be in the language of washington in his last annual message to congress a very cheap instrument of immense national benefit
 regard the act of congress approve 28th september 1850 grant bounty land to person who have be engage in the military service of the country as a great measure of national justice and munificence an anxious desire have be feel by the officer intrust with its immediate execution to give prompt effect to its provision all the mean within their control be therefore bring into requisition to expedite the adjudication of claim and i be gratified to be able to state that near 100,000 application have be consider and about 70,000 warrant issue within the short space of nine month if adequate provision be make by law to carry into effect the recommendation of the department it be confidently expect that before the close of the next fiscal year all who be entitle to the benefit of the act will have receive their warrant
 the secretary of the interior have suggest in his report various amendment of the law relate to pension and bounty land for the purpose of more effectually guard against abuse and fraud on the government to all of which i invite your particular attention the large accession to our indian population consequent upon the acquisition of new mexico and california and the extension of our settlement into utah and oregon have give increase interest and importance to our relation with the aboriginal race no material change have take place within the last year in the condition and prospect of the indian tribe who reside in the northwestern territory and west of the mississippi river we be at peace with all of they and it will be a source of pleasure to you to learn that they be gradually advance in civilization and the pursuit of social life
 along the mexican frontier and in california and oregon there have be occasional manifestation of unfriendly feeling and some depredation commit i be satisfied however that they result more from the destitute and starve condition of the indians than from any settle hostility toward the white as the settlement of our citizen progress toward they the game upon which they mainly rely for subsistence be drive off or destroy and the only alternative leave to they be starvation or plunder it become we to consider in view of this condition of thing whether justice and humanity as well as an enlightened economy do not require that instead of seek to punish they for offense which be the result of our own policy toward they we should not provide for their immediate want and encourage they to engage in agriculture and to rely on their labor instead of the chase for the mean of support
 various important treaty have be negotiate with different tribe during the year by which their title to large and valuable tract of country have be extinguish all of which will at the proper time be submit to the senate for ratification
 the joint commission under the treaty of guadalupe hidalgo have be actively engage in run and mark the boundary line between the united states and mexico it be state in the last annual report of the secretary of the interior that the initial point on the pacific and the point of junction of the gila with the colorado river have be determine and the intervene line about 150 mile in length run and mark by temporary monument since that time a monument of marble have be erect at the initial point and permanent landmark of iron have be place at suitable distance along the line
 the initial point on the rio grande have also be fix by the commissioner at latitude 32 degree 22&#39 and at the date of the last communication the survey of the line have be make thence westward about 150 mile to the neighborhood of the copper mine the commission on our part be at first organize on a scale which experience prove to be unwieldy and attend with unnecessary expense order have therefore be issue for the reduction of the number of person employ within the small limit consistent with the safety of those engage in the service and the prompt and efficient execution of their important duty
 return have be receive from all the officer engage in take the census in the states and territories except california the superintendent employ to make the enumeration in that state have not yet make his full report from cause as he allege beyond his control this failure be much to be regret as it have prevent the secretary of the interior from make the decennial apportionment of representatives among the states as require by the act approve may 23 1850 it be hope however that the return will soon be receive and no time will then be lose in make the necessary apportionment and in transmit the certificate require by law
 the superintendent of the seventh census be diligently employ under the direction of the secretary of the interior in classifying and arrange in tabular form all the statistical information derive from the return of the marshal and it be believe that when the work shall be complete it will exhibit a more perfect view of the population wealth occupation and social condition of a great country than have ever be present to the world the value of such a work as the basis of enlightened legislation can hardly be overestimate and i earnestly hope that congress will lose no time in make the appropriation necessary to complete the classification and to publish the result in a style worthy of the subject and of our national character
 the want of a uniform fee bill prescribe the compensation to be allow district attorney clerk marshal and commissioner in civil and criminal case be the cause of much vexation injustice and complaint i would recommend a thorough revision of the law on the whole subject and the adoption of a tariff of fee which as far as practicable should be uniform and prescribe a specific compensation for every service which the officer may be require to perform this subject will be fully present in the report of the secretary of the interior in my last annual message i give briefly my reason for believe that you possess the constitutional power to improve the harbor of our great lakes and seacoast and the navigation of our principal river and recommend that appropriation should be make for complete such work as have already be commence and for commence such other as might seem to the wisdom of congress to be of public and general importance without repeat the reason then urge i deem it my duty again to call your attention to this important subject the work on many of the harbor be leave in an unfinished state and consequently expose to the action of the element which be fast destroy they great number of life and vast amount of property be annually lose for want of safe and convenient harbor on the lakes none but those who have be expose to that dangerous navigation can fully appreciate the importance of this subject the whole northwest appeal to you for relief and i trust their appeal will receive due consideration at your hand
 the same be in a measure true in regard to some of the harbor and inlet on the seacoast
 the unobstructed navigation of our large river be of equal importance our settlement be now extend to the source of the great river which empty into and form a part of the mississippi and the value of the public land in those region would be greatly enhance by free the navigation of those water from obstruction in view therefore of this great interest i deem it my duty again to urge upon congress to make such appropriation for these improvement as they may deem necessary
 the survey of the delta of the mississippi with a view to the prevention of the overflow that have prove so disastrous to that region of country have be nearly complete and the report thereof be now in course of preparation and will shortly be lay before you
 the protection of our southwestern frontier and of the adjacent mexican states against the indian tribe within our border have claim my earnest and constant attention congress having fail at the last session to adopt my recommendation that an additional regiment of mount man specially adapt to that service should be raise all that remain to be do be to make the good use of the mean at my disposal accordingly all the troop adapt to that service that could properly be spare from other quarter have be concentrate on that frontier and officer of high reputation select to command they a new arrangement of the military post have also be make whereby the troop be bring near to the mexican frontier and to the tribe they be intend to overawe
 sufficient time have not yet elapse to realize all the benefit that be expect to result from these arrangement but i have every reason to hope that they will effectually check their marauding expedition the nature of the country which furnish little for the support of an army and abound in place of refuge and concealment be remarkably well adapt to this predatory warfare and we can scarcely hope that any military force combine with the great vigilance can entirely suppress it
 by the treaty of guadalupe hidalgo we be bind to protect the territory of mexico against the incursion of the savage tribe within our border with equal diligence and energy as if the same be make within our territory or against our citizen i have endeavor to comply as far as possible with this provision of the treaty order have be give to the officer command on that frontier to consider the mexican territory and its inhabitant as equally with our own entitle to their protection and to make all their plan and arrangement with a view to the attainment of this object instruction have also be give to the indian commissioner and agent among these tribe in all treaty to make the clause design for the protection of our own citizen apply also to those of mexico i have no reason to doubt that these instruction have be fully carry into effect nevertheless it be probable that in spite of all our effort some of the neighboring states of mexico may have suffer as our own have from depredation by the indians
 to the difficulty of defend our own territory as above mention be superadde in defend that of mexico those that arise from its remoteness from the fact that we have no right to station our troop within her limit and that there be no efficient military force on the mexican side to cooperate with our own
 so long as this shall continue to be the case the number and activity of our troop will rather increase than diminish the evil as the indians will naturally turn toward that country where they encounter the least resistance yet these troop be necessary to subdue they and to compel they to make and observe treaty until this shall have be do neither country will enjoy any security from their attack
 the indians in california who have previously appear of a peaceable character and dispose to cultivate the friendship of the white have recently commit several act of hostility as a large portion of the reenforcement send to the mexican frontier be draw from the pacific the military force now station there be consider entirely inadequate to its defense it can not be increase however without an increase of the army and i again recommend that measure as indispensable to the protection of the frontier
 i invite your attention to the suggestion on this subject and on other connect with his department in the report of the secretary of war the appropriation for the support of the army during the current fiscal year end 30th june next be reduce far below the estimate submit by the department the consequence of this reduction be a considerable deficiency to which i invite your early attention the expenditure of that department for the year end 30th june last be $ 9,060,268.58 the estimate for the year commencing 1st july next and end june 30 1853 be $ 7,898,775.83 show a reduction of $ 1,161,492.75 the board of commissioner to whom the management of the affair of the military asylum create by the act of 3d march last be intrust have select a site for the establishment of an asylum in the vicinity of this city which have be approve by i subject to the production of a satisfactory title
 the report of the secretary of the navy will exhibit the condition of the public service under the supervision of that department our naval force afloat during the present year have be actively and usefully employ in give protection to our widely extend and increase commerce and interest in the various quarter of the globe and our flag have everywhere afford the security and receive the respect inspire by the justice and liberality of our intercourse and the dignity and power of the nation
 the expedition command by lieutenant de haven dispatch in search of the british commander sir john franklin and his companion in the arctic seas return to new york in the month of october after having undergo great peril and suffering from an unknown and dangerous navigation and the rigor of a northern climate without any satisfactory information of the object of their search but with new contribution to science and navigation from the unfrequented polar region the officer and man of the expedition having be all volunteer for this service and having so conduct it as to meet the entire approbation of the government it be suggest as an act of grace and generosity that the same allowance of extra pay and emolument be extend to they that be make to the officer and man of like rating in the late explore expedition to the south seas
 i earnestly recommend to your attention the necessity of reorganize the naval establishment apportion and fix the number of officer in each grade provide some mode of promotion to the high grade of the navy have reference to merit and capacity rather than seniority or date of entry into the service and for retire from the effective list upon reduce pay those who may be incompetent to the performance of active duty as a measure of economy as well as of efficiency in this arm of the service the provision last mention be eminently worthy of your consideration
 the determination of the question of relative rank between the sea officer and civil officer of the navy and between officer of the army and navy in the various grade of each will also merit your attention the failure to provide any substitute when corporal punishment be abolish for offense in the navy have occasion the convening of numerous court martial upon the arrival of vessel in port and be believe to have have an injurious effect upon the discipline and efficiency of the service to moderate punishment from one grade to another be among the humane reform of the age but to abolish one of severity which apply so generally to offense on shipboard and provide nothing in its stead be to suppose a progress of improvement in every individual among seaman which be not assume by the legislature in respect to any other class of man it be hope that congress in the ample opportunity afford by the present session will thoroughly investigate this important subject and establish such mode of determine guilt and such gradation of punishment as be consistent with humanity and the personal right of individual and at the same time shall insure the most energetic and efficient performance of duty and the suppression of crime in our ship of war
 the stone dock in the navy yard at new york which be ten year in process of construction have be so far finish as to be surrender up to the authority of the yard the dry dock at philadelphia be report as complete and be expect soon to be test and deliver over to the agent of the government that at portsmouth n. h. be also nearly ready for delivery and a contract have be conclude agreeably to the act of congress at its last session for a float sectional dock on the bay of san francisco i invite your attention to the recommendation of the department touch the establishment of a navy yard in conjunction with this dock on the pacific such a station be highly necessary to the convenience and effectiveness of our fleet in that ocean which must be expect to increase with the growth of commerce and the rapid extension of our whale fishery over its water
 the naval academy at annapolis under a revised and improved system of regulation now afford opportunity of education and instruction to the pupil quite equal it be believe for professional improvement to those enjoy by the cadet in the military academy a large class of act midshipman be receive at the commencement of the last academic term and a practice ship have be attach to the institution to afford the ample mean for regular instruction in seamanship as well as for cruise during the vacation of three or four month in each year
 the advantage of science in nautical affair have rarely be more strikingly illustrate than in the fact state in the report of the navy department that by mean of the wind and current chart project and prepare by lieutenant maury the superintendent of the naval observatory the passage from the atlantic to the pacific port of our country have be shorten by about forty day
 the estimate for the support of the navy and marine corps the ensue fiscal year will be find to be $ 5,856,472.19 the estimate for the current year be $ 5,900,621
 the estimate for special object under the control of this department amount to $ 2,684,220.89 against $ 2,210,980 for the present year the increase be occasion by the additional mail service on the pacific coast and the construction of the dock in california authorize at the last session of congress and some slight addition under the head of improvement and repair in navy yard building and machinery i deem it of much importance to a just economy and a correct understanding of naval expenditure that there should be an entire separation of the appropriation for the support of the naval service proper from those for permanent improvement at navy yard and station and from ocean steam mail service and other special object assign to the supervision of this department
 the report of the postmaster general herewith communicate present an interesting view of the progress operation and condition of his department
 at the close of the last fiscal year the length of mail route within the united states be 196,290 mile the annual transportation thereon 53,272,252 mile and the annual cost of such transportation $ 3,421,754
 the length of the foreign mail route be estimate at 18,349 mile and the annual transportation thereon at 615,206 mile the annual cost of this service be $ 1,472,187 of which $ 448,937 be pay by the post office department and $ 1,023,250 be pay through the navy department
 the annual transportation within the united states exclude the service in california and oregon which be now for the first time report and embrace in the tabular statement of the department exceed that of the precede year 6,162,855 mile at an increase cost of $ 547,110
 the whole number of post office in the united states on the 30th day of june last be 19,796 there be 1,698 post office establish and 256 discontinue during the year
 the gross revenue of the department for the fiscal year include the appropriation for the franked matter of congress of the departments and officer of government and exclude the foreign postage collect for and payable to the british post office amount to $ 6,727,866.78
 the expenditure for the same period exclude $ 20,599.49 pay under an award of the auditor in pursuance of a resolution of the last congress for mail service on the ohio and mississippi river in 1832 and 1833 and the amount pay to the british post office for foreign postage collect for and payable to that office amount to $ 6,024,566.79 leave a balance of revenue over the proper expenditure of the year of $ 703,299.99
 the receipt for postage during the year exclude the foreign postage collect for and payable to the british post office amount to $ 6,345,747.21 be an increase of $ 997,610.79 or 18.65 per cent over the like receipt for the precede year
 the reduction of postage under the act of march last do not take effect until the commencement of the present fiscal year the account for the first quarter under the operation of the reduce rate will not be settle before january next and no reliable estimate of the receipt for the present year can yet be make it be believe however that they will fall far short of those of the last year the surplus of the revenue now on hand be however so large that no further appropriation from the treasury in aid of the revenue of the department be require for the current fiscal year but an additional appropriation for the year end june 30 1853 will probably be find necessary when the receipt of the first two quarter of the fiscal year be fully ascertain
 in his last annual report the postmaster general recommend a reduction of postage to rate which he deem as low as could be prudently adopt unless congress be prepared to appropriate from the treasury for the support of the department a sum more than equivalent to the mail service perform by it for the government the recommendation of the postmaster general in respect to letter postage except on letter from and to california and oregon be substantially adopt by the last congress he now recommend adherence to the present letter rate and advise against a further reduction until justify by the revenue of the department
 he also recommend that the rate of postage on print matter be so revise as to render they more simple and more uniform in their operation upon all class of print matter i submit the recommendation of the report to your favorable consideration
 the public statute of the united states have now be accumulate for more than sixty year and intersperse with private act be scatter through numerous volume and from the cost of the whole have become almost inaccessible to the great mass of the community they also exhibit much of the incongruity and imperfection of hasty legislation as it seem to be generally concede that there be no common law of the united states to supply the defect of their legislation it be most important that that legislation should be as perfect as possible define every power intend to be confer every crime intend to be make punishable and prescribe the punishment to be inflict in addition to some particular case speak of more at length the whole criminal code be now lamentably defective some offense be imperfectly describe and other be entirely omit so that flagrant crime may be commit with impunity the scale of punishment be not in all case graduate accord to the degree and nature of the offense and be often render more unequal by the different mode of imprisonment or penitentiary confinement in the different states
 many law of a permanent character have be introduce into appropriation bill and it be often difficult to determine whether the particular clause expire with the temporary act of which it be a part or continue in force it have also frequently happen that enactment and provision of law have be introduce into bill with the title or general subject of which they have little or no connection or relation in this mode of legislation so many enactment have be heap upon each other and often with but little consideration that in many instance it be difficult to search out and determine what be the law
 the government of the united states be emphatically a government of write law the statute should therefore as far as practicable not only be make accessible to all but be express in language so plain and simple as to be understand by all and arrange in such method as to give perspicuity to every subject many of the states have revise their public act with great and manifest benefit and i recommend that provision be make by law for the appointment of a commission to revise the public statute of the united states arrange they in order supply deficiency correct incongruity simplify their language and report they to congress for its action
 an act of congress approve 30th september 1850 contain a provision for the extension of the capitol accord to such plan as might be approve by the president and appropriate $ 100,000 to be expend under his direction by such architect as he should appoint to execute the same on examine the various plan which have be submit by different architect in pursuance of an advertisement by a committee of the senate no one be find to be entirely satisfactory and it be therefore deem advisable to combine and adopt the advantage of several
 the great object to be accomplish be to make such an addition as would afford ample and convenient hall for the deliberation of the two houses of congress with sufficient accommodation for spectator and suitable apartment for the committee and officer of the two branch of the legislature it be also desirable not to mar the harmony and beauty of the present structure which as a speciman of architecture be so universally admired keep these object in view i conclude to make the addition by wing detach from the present building yet connect with it by corridor this mode of enlargement will leave the present capitol uninjured and afford great advantage for ventilation and the admission of light and will enable the work to progress without interrupt the deliberation of congress to carry this plan into effect i have appoint an experienced and competent architect the corner stone be lay on the 4th day of july last with suitable ceremony since which time the work have advance with commendable rapidity and the foundation of both wing be now nearly complete
 i again commend to your favorable regard the interest of the district of columbia and deem it only necessary to remind you that although its inhabitant have no voice in the choice of representatives in congress they be not the less entitled to a just and liberal consideration in your legislation my opinion on this subject be more fully express in my last annual communication
 other subject be bring to the attention of congress in my last annual message to which i would respectfully refer but there be one of more than ordinary interest to which i again invite your special attention i allude to the recommendation for the appointment of a commission to settle private claim against the united states justice to individual as well as to the government imperatively demand that some more convenient and expeditious mode than an appeal to congress should be adopt
 it be deeply to be regret that in several instance officer of the government in attempt to execute the law for the return of fugitive from labor have be openly resist and their effort frustrate and defeat by lawless and violent mob that in one case such resistance result in the death of an estimable citizen and in other serious injury ensue to those officer and to individual who be use their endeavor to sustain the law prosecution have be institute against the allege offender so far as they could be identify and be still pende i have regard it as my duty in these case to give all aid legally in my power to the enforcement of the law and i shall continue to do so wherever and whenever their execution may be resist
 the act of congress for the return of fugitive from labor be one require and demand by the express word of the constitution the constitution declare that-- no person hold to service or labor in one state under the law thereof escape into another shall in consequence of any law or regulation therein be discharge from such service or labor but shall be deliver up on claim of the party to whom such service or labor may be due this constitutional provision be equally obligatory upon the legislative the executive and judicial department of the government and upon every citizen of the united states
 congress however must from necessity first act upon the subject by prescribe the proceeding necessary to ascertain that the person be a fugitive and the mean to be use for his restoration to the claimant this be do by an act pass during the first term of president washington which be amend by that enact by the last congress and it now remain for the executive and judicial department to take care that these law be faithfully execute this injunction of the constitution be as peremptory and as binding as any other it stand exactly on the same foundation as that clause which provide for the return of fugitive from justice or that which declare that no bill of attainder or ex post facto law shall be pass or that which provide for an equality of taxation accord to the census or the clause declare that all duty shall be uniform throughout the united states or the important provision that the trial of all crime shall be by jury these several article and clause of the constitution all rest on the same authority must stand or fall together some objection have be urge against the detail of the act for the return of fugitive from labor but it be worthy of remark that the main opposition be aim against the constitution itself and proceed from person and class of person many of whom declare their wish to see that constitution overturn they avow their hostility to any law which shall give full and practical effect to this requirement of the constitution fortunately the number of these person be comparatively small and be believe to be daily diminishing but the issue which they present be one which involve the supremacy and even the existence of the constitution
 case have heretofore arise in which individual have deny the bind authority of act of congress and even states have propose to nullify such act upon the ground that the constitution be the supreme law of the land and that those act of congress be repugnant to that instrument but nullification be now aim not so much against particular law as be inconsistent with the constitution as against the constitution itself and it be not to be disguise that a spirit exist and have be actively at work to rend asunder this union which be our cherish inheritance from our revolutionary father
 in my last annual message i state that i consider the series of measure which have be adopt at the previous session in reference to the agitation grow out of the territorial and slavery question as a final settlement in principle and substance of the dangerous and exciting subject which they embrace and i recommend adherence to the adjustment establish by those measure until time and experience should demonstrate the necessity of further legislation to guard against evasion or abuse i be not induce to make this recommendation because i think those measure perfect for no human legislation can be perfect wide difference and jarring opinion can only be reconcile by yield something on all side and this result have be reach after an angry conflict of many month in which one part of the country be array against another and violent convulsion seem to be imminent look at the interest of the whole country i feel it to be my duty to seize upon this compromise as the good that could be obtain amid conflict interest and to insist upon it as a final settlement to be adhere to by all who value the peace and welfare of the country a year have now elapse since that recommendation be make to that recommendation i still adhere and i congratulate you and the country upon the general acquiescence in these measure of peace which have be exhibit in all part of the republic and not only be there this general acquiescence in these measure but the spirit of conciliation which have be manifest in regard to they in all part of the country have remove doubt and uncertainty in the mind of thousand of good man concern the durability of our popular institution and give renew assurance that our liberty and our union may subsist together for the benefit of this and all succeed generation

  honors to henry clayon the fourth day of july 1776 the people of a few feeble and oppress colony of great britain inhabit a portion of the atlantic coast of north america publicly declare their national independence and make their appeal to the justice of their cause and to the god of battle for the maintainance of that declaration that people be few in number and without resource save only their own wise head and stout heart within the first year of that declare independence and while its maintainance be yet problematical while the bloody struggle between those resolute rebel and their haughty would be masters be still wage of undistinguished parent and in an obscure district of one of those colony henry clay be bear the infant nation and the infant child begin the race of life together for three quarter of a century they have travel hand in hand they have be companion ever the nation have pass its peril and be free prosperous and powerful the child have reach his manhood his middle age his old age and be dead in all that have concern the nation the man ever sympathise and now the nation mourn for the man the day after his death one of the public journals oppose to he politically hold the follow pathetic and beautiful language which i adopt partly because such high and exclusive eulogy originate with a political friend might offend good taste but chiefly because i could not in any language of my own so well express my thoughts---"alas who can realize that henry clay be dead who can realize that never again that majestic form shall rise in the council chamber of his country to beat back the storm of anarchy which may threaten or pour the oil of peace upon the troubled billow as they rage and menace around who can realize that the working of that mighty mind have cease that the throbbing of that gallant heart be still that the mighty sweep of that graceful arm will be feel no more and the magic of that eloquent tongue which spake as spake no other tongue besides hush hush forever who can realize that freedom 's champion the champion of a civilized world and of all tongue and kindred and people have indeed fall alas in those dark hour which as they come in the history of all nation must come in ours those hour of peril and dread which our land have experience and which she may be call to experience again to whom now may her people look up for that council counsel and advice which only wisdom and experience and patriotism can give and which only the undoubting confidence of a nation will receive perchance in the whole circle of the great and gifted of our land there remain but one on whose shoulder the mighty mantle of the depart statesman may fall one while we now write be doubtless pour his tear over the bier of his brother and his friend brother friend ever yet in political sentiment as far apart as party could make they ah it be at time like these that the petty distinction of mere party disappear we see only the great the grand the noble feature of the depart statesman and we do not even beg permission to bow at his foot and mingle our tear with those who have ever be his political adherent we do not beg this permission we claim it as a right though we feel it as a privilege henry clay belong to his country to the world mere party can not claim man like he his career have be national his fame have fill the earth his memory will endure to ` the last syllable of record time '"henry clay be dead!---he breathe his last on yesterday at twenty minute after eleven in his chamber at washington to those who follow his lead in public affair it more appropriately belong to pronounce his eulogy and pay specific honor to the memory of the illustrious dead but all americans may show the grief which his death inspire for his character and fame be national property as on a question of liberty he know no north no south no east no west but only the union which hold they all in its sacred circle so now his countryman will know no grief that be not as wide spread as the bound of the confederacy the career of henry clay be a public career from his youth he have be devote to the public service at a period too in the world 's history justly regard as a remarkable era in human affair he witness in the beginning the throe of the french revolution he see the rise and fall of napoleon he be call upon to legislate for america and direct her policy when all europe be the battle field of contend dynasty and when the struggle for supremacy imperille the right of all neutral nation his voice speak war and peace in the contest with great britain "when greece rise against the turks and strike for liberty his name be mingle with the battle cry of freedom when south america throw off the thraldom of spain his speech be read at the head of her army by bolivar his name have be and will continue to be hallow in two hemisphere for it is---`one of the few the immortal namesthat be not bear to die,'"to the ardent patriot and profound statesman he add a quality possess by few of the gifted on earth his eloquence have not be surpass in the effective power to move the heart of man clay be without an equal and the heaven bear endowment in the spirit of its origin have be most conspicuously exhibit against intestine feud on at least three important occasion he have quell our civil commotion by a power and influence which belong to no other statesman of his age and time and in our last internal discord when this union tremble to its center in old age he leave the shade of private life and give the death blow to fraternal strife with the vigor of his early year in a series of senatorial effort which in themselves would bring immortality by challenge comparison with the effort of any statesman in any age he exorcise the demon which possess the body politic and give peace to a distracted land alas the achievement cost he his life he sink day by day to the tomb his pale but noble brow bind with a triple wreath put there by a grateful country may his ashe rest in peace while his spirit go to take its station among the great and good man who precede him!''while it be customary and proper upon occasion like the present to give a brief sketch of the life of the deceased in the case of mr. clay it be less necessary than most other for his biography have be write and re write and read and re read for the last twenty five year so that with the exception of a few of the late incident of his life all be as well know as it can be the short sketch which i give be therefore merely to maintain the connection of this discourse henry clay be bear on the 12th of april 1777 in hanover county virginia of his father who die in the fourth or fifth year of henry 's age little seem to be know except that he be a respectable man and a preacher of the baptist persuasion mr. clay 's education to the end of his life be comparatively limited i say ` ` to the end of his life because i have understand that from time to time he add something to his education during the great part of his whole life mr. clay 's lack of a more perfect early education however it may be regret generally teach at least one profitable lesson it teach that in this country one can scarcely be so poor but that if he will he can acquire sufficient education to get through the world respectably in his twenty third year mr. clay be licence to practice law and emigrate to lexington kentucky here he commence and continue the practice till the year 1803 when he be first elect to the kentucky legislature by successive election he be continue in the legislature till the latter part of 1806 when he be elect to fill a vacancy of a single session in the united states senate in 1807 he be again elect to the kentucky house of representatives and by that body choose its speaker in 1808 he be re elect to the same body in 1809 he be again choose to fill a vacancy of two year in the united states senate in 1811 he be elect to the united states house of representatives and on the first day of take his seat in that body he be choose its speaker in 1813 he be again elect speaker early in 1814 be the period of our last british war mr. clay be send as commissioner with other to negotiate a treaty of peace which treaty be conclude in the latter part of the same year on his return from europe he be again elect to the low branch of congress and on take his seat in december 1815 be call to his old post the speaker 's chair a position in which he be retain by successive election with one brief intermission till the inauguration of john q. adams in march 1825 he be then appoint secretary of state and occupy that important station till the inauguration of gen. jackson in march 1829 after this he return to kentucky resume the practice of the law and continue it till the autumn of 1831 when he be by the legislature of kentucky again place in the united states senate by a re election he be continue in the senate till he resign his seat and retire in march 1842 in december 1849 he again take his seat in the senate which he again resign only a few month before his death by the foregoing it be perceive that the period from the beginning of mr. clay 's official life in 1803 to the end of it in 1852 be but one year short of half a century and that the sum of all the interval in it will not amount to ten year but mere duration of time in office constitute the small part of mr. clay 's history throughout that long period he have constantly be the most love and most implicitly follow by friend and the most dread by opponent of all live american politician in all the great question which have agitate the country and particularly in those great and fearful crisis the missouri question the nullification question and the late slavery question as connect with the newly acquire territory involve and endanger the stability of the union his have be the lead and most conspicuous part in 1824 he be first a candidate for the presidency and be defeat and although he be successively defeat for the same office in 1832 and in 1844 there have never be a moment since 1824 till after 1848 when a very large portion of the american people do not cling to he with an enthusiastic hope and purpose of still elevate he to the presidency with other man to be defeat be to be forget but to he defeat be but a trifling incident neither change he or the world 's estimate of he even those of both political party who have be prefer to he for the high office have run far brief course than he and leave he still shine high in the heaven of the political world jackson van buren harrison polk and taylor all rise after and set long before he the spell the long endure spell with which the soul of man be bind to he be a miracle who can compass it it be probably true he owe his pre eminence to no one quality but to a fortunate combination of several he be surpassingly eloquent but many eloquent man fail utterly and they be not as a class generally successful his judgment be excellent but many man of good judgment live and die unnoticed his will be indomitable but this quality often secure to its owner nothing well than a character for useless obstinacy these then be mr. clay 's lead quality no one of they be very uncommon but all take together be rarely combine in a single individual and this be probably the reason why such man as henry clay be so rare in the world mr. clay 's eloquence do not consist as many fine specimen of eloquence do do of type and figure of antithesis and elegant arrangement of word and sentence but rather of that deeply earnest and impassioned tone and manner which can proceed only from great sincerity and a thorough conviction in the speaker of the justice and importance of his cause this it be that truly touch the chord of human sympathy and those who hear mr. clay never fail to be move by it or ever afterwards forget the impression all his effort be make for practical effect he never speak merely to be hear he never deliver a fourth of july oration or an eulogy on an occasion like this as a politician or statesman no one be so habitually careful to avoid all sectional ground whatever he do he do for the whole country in the construction of his measure he ever carefully survey every part of the field and duly weigh every conflicting interest feel as he do and as the truth surely be that the world 's good hope depend on the continued union of these states he be ever jealous of and watchful for whatever might have the slight tendency to separate they mr. clay 's predominant sentiment from first to last be a deep devotion to the cause of human liberty a strong sympathy with the oppress every where and an ardent wish for their elevation with he this be a primary and all control passion subsidiary to this be the conduct of his whole life he love his country partly because it be his own country but mostly because it be a free country and he burn with a zeal for its advancement prosperity and glory because he see in such the advancement prosperity and glory of human liberty human right and human nature he desire the prosperity of his countryman partly because they be his countryman but chiefly to show to the world that freeman could be prosperous that his view and measure be always the wise need not to be affirm nor should it be on this occasion where so many think differently join in do honor to his memory a free people in time of peace and quiet when press by no common danger naturally divide into party at such time the man who be of neither party be not cannot be of any consequence mr. clay therefore be of a party take a prominent part as he do in all the great political question of his country for the last half century the wisdom of his course on many be doubt and deny by a large portion of his countryman and of such it be not now proper to speak particularly but there be many other about his course upon which there be little or no disagreement amongst intelligent and patriotic americans of these last be the war of 1812 the missouri question nullification and the now recent compromise measure in 1812 mr. clay though not unknown be still a young man whether we should go to war with great britain be the question of the day a minority oppose the declaration of war by congress while the majority though apparently incline to war have for year waver and hesitate to act decisively meanwhile british aggression multiply and grow more daring and aggravate by mr. clay more than any other man the struggle be bring to a decision in congress the question be now fully before congress come up in a variety of way in rapid succession on most of which occasion mr. clay speak add to all the logic of which the subject be susceptible that noble inspiration which come to he as it come to no other he arouse and nerve and inspire his friend and confound and bore down all opposition several of his speech on these occasion be report and be still extant but the good of these all never be during its delivery the reporter forget their vocation drop their pen and sit enchant from near the beginning to quite the close the speech now live only in the memory of a few old man and the enthusiasm with which they cherish their recollection of it be absolutely astonishing the precise language of this speech we shall never know but we do know we can not help know that with deep pathos it plead the cause of the injure sailor that it invoke the genius of the revolution that it apostrophise the name of otis of henry and of washington that it appeal to the interest the pride the honor and the glory of the nation that it shame and taunt the timidity of friend that it scorn and scout and wither the temerity of domestic foe that it beard and defy the british lion and rise and swell and madden in its course it sound the onset till the charge the shock the steady struggle and the glorious victory all pass in vivid review before the entrance hearer important and exciting as be the war question of 1812 it never so alarm the sagacious statesman of the country for the safety of the republic as afterwards do the missouri question this spring from that unfortunate source of discord negro slavery when our federal constitution be adopt we own no territory beyond the limit or ownership of the state except the territory north west of the river ohio and east of the mississippi what have since be form into the states of maine kentucky and tennessee be i believe within the
