limit of or own by massachusetts virginia and north carolina as to the north western territory provision have be make even before the adoption of the constitution that slavery should never go there on the admission of the states into the union carve from the territory we own before the constitution no question or at most no considerable question arise about slavery those which be within the limit of or own by the old state follow respectively the condition of the parent state and those within the north west territory follow the previously make provision but in 1803 we purchase louisiana of the french and it include with much more what have since be form into the state of missouri with regard to it nothing have be do to forestall the question of slavery when therefore in 1819 missouri having form a state constitution without exclude slavery and with slavery already actually exist within its limit knock at the door of the union for admission almost the entire representation of the non slave hold state object a fearful and angry struggle instantly follow this alarmed think man more than any previous question because unlike all the former it divide the country by geographical line other question have their oppose partizan in all locality of the country and in almost every family so that no division of the union could follow such without a separation of friend to quite as great an extent as that of opponent not so with the missouri question on this a geographical line could be trace which in the main would separate opponent only this be the danger mr. jefferson then in retirement wrote:``i have for a long time cease to read newspaper or to pay any attention to public affair confident they be in good hand and content to be a passenger in our bark to the shore from which i be not distant but this momentous question like a fire bell in the night awaken and fill i with terror i consider it at once as the knell of the union it be hush indeed for the moment but this that the world 's good hope depend on the continued union of these states he be ever jealous of and watchful for whatever might have the slight tendency to separate they mr. clay 's predominant all control passion subsidiary to this be the conduct of his whole life he love his country partly because it be his own country but mostly because it be a free country and he burn with a zeal for its advancement prosperity and glory because he see in such the advancement prosperity and glory of human liberty human right and human nature he desire the prosperity of his countryman partly because they be his countryman but chiefly to show to the world that freeman could be prosperous that his view and measure be always the wise need not to be affirm nor should it be on this occasion where so many think differently join in do honor to his memory a free people in time of peace and quiet when press by no common danger&mdash;naturally divide into party at such time the man who be of neither  the affair of cuba form a prominent topic in my last annual message they remain in an uneasy condition and a feeling of alarm and irritation on the part of the cuban authority appear to exist this feeling have interfere with the regular commercial intercourse between the united states and the island and lead to some act of which we have a fight to complain but the captain general of cuba be clothe with no power to treat with foreign government nor be he in any degree under the control of the spanish minister at washington any communication which he may hold with an agent of a foreign power be informal and matter of courtesy anxious to put an end to the exist inconvenience which seem to rest on a misconception i direct the newly appoint minister to mexico to visit havana on his way to vera cruz he be respectfully receive by the captain general who confer with he freely on the recent occurrence but no permanent arrangement be effect

 early in the present year official note be receive from the minister of france and england invite the government of the united states to become a party with great britain and france to a tripartite convention in virtue of which the three power should severally and collectively disclaim now and for the future all intention to obtain possession of the island of cuba and should bind themselves to discountenance all attempt to that effect on the part of any power or individual whatever this invitation have be respectfully decline for reason which it would occupy too much space in this communication to state in detail but which lead i to think that the propose measure would be of doubtful constitutionality impolitic and unavaile i have however in common with several of my predecessor direct the minister of france and england to be assure that the united states entertain no design against cuba but that on the contrary i should regard its incorporation into the union at the present time as fraught with serious peril
 be this island comparatively destitute of inhabitant or occupy by a kindre race i should regard it if voluntarily cede by spain as a most desirable acquisition but under exist circumstance i should look upon its incorporation into our union as a very hazardous measure it would bring into the confederacy a population of a different national stock speak a different language and not likely to harmonize with the other member it would probably affect in a prejudicial manner the industrial interest of the south and it might revive those conflict of opinion between the different section of the country which lately shake the union to its center and which have be so happily compromise

 in my first annual message to congress i call your attention to what seem to i some defect in the present tariff and recommend such modification as in my judgment be well adapt to remedy its evil and promote the prosperity of the country nothing have since occur to change my view on this important question
 without repeat the argument contain in my former message in favor of discriminate protective duty i deem it my duty to call your attention to one or two other consideration affect this subject the first be the effect of large importation of foreign good upon our currency most of the gold of california as fast as it be coin find its way directly to europe in payment for good purchase in the second place as our manufacturing establishment be break down by competition with foreigner the capital invest in they be lose thousand of honest and industrious citizen be throw out of employment and the farmer to that extent be deprive of a home market for the sale of his surplus produce in the third place the destruction of our manufacture leave the foreigner without competition in our market and he consequently raise the price of the article send here for sale as be now see in the increase cost of iron import from england the prosperity and wealth of every nation must depend upon its productive industry the farmer be stimulate to exertion by find a ready market for his surplus product and benefit by be able to exchange they without loss of time or expense of transportation for the manufacture which his comfort or convenience require this be always do to the good advantage where a portion of the community in which he live be engage in other pursuit but most manufacture require an amount of capital and a practical skill which can not be command unless they be protect for a time from ruinous competition from abroad hence the necessity of lay those duty upon import good which the constitution authorize for revenue in such a manner as to protect and encourage the labor of our own citizen duty however should not be fix at a rate so high as to exclude the foreign article but should be so graduate as to enable the domestic manufacturer fairly to compete with the foreigner in our own market and by this competition to reduce the price of the manufactured article to the consumer to the low rate at which it can be produce this policy would place the mechanic by the side of the farmer create a mutual interchange of their respective commodity and thus stimulate the industry of the whole country and render we independent of foreign nation for the supply require by the habit or necessity of the people
 another question wholly independent of protection present itself and that be whether the duty levy should be upon the value of the article at the place of shipment or where it be practicable a specific duty graduate accord to quantity as ascertain by weight or measure all our duty be at present ad valorem a certain percentage be levy on the price of the good at the port of shipment in a foreign country most commercial nation have find it indispensable for the purpose of prevent fraud and perjury to make the duty specific whenever the article be of such a uniform value in weight or measure as to justify such a duty legislation should never encourage dishonesty or crime it be impossible that the revenue officer at the port where the good be enter and the duty pay should know with certainty what they cost in the foreign country yet the law require that they should levy the duty accord to such cost they be therefore compel to resort to very unsatisfactory evidence to ascertain what that cost be they take the invoice of the importer attest by his oath as the good evidence of which the nature of the case admit but everyone must see that the invoice may be fabricate and the oath by which it be support false by reason of which the dishonest importer pay a part only of the duty which be pay by the honest one and thus indirectly receive from the treasury of the united states a reward for his fraud and perjury the report of the secretary of the treasury heretofore make on this subject show conclusively that these fraud have be practice to a great extent the tendency be to destroy that high moral character for which our merchant have long be distinguish to defraud the government of its revenue to break down the honest importer by a dishonest competition and finally to transfer the business of importation to foreign and irresponsible agent to the great detriment of our own citizen i therefore again most earnestly recommend the adoption of specific duty wherever it be practicable or a home valuation to prevent these fraud
 i would also again call your attention to the fact that the present tariff in some case impose a high duty upon the raw material import than upon the article manufacture from it the consequence of which be that the duty operate to the encouragement of the foreigner and the discouragement of our own citizen
 for full and detailed information in regard to the general condition of our indian affair i respectfully refer you to the report of the secretary of the interior and the accompany document
 the senate not having think proper to ratify the treaty which have be negotiate with the tribe of indians in california and oregon our relation with they have be leave in a very unsatisfactory condition
 in other part of our territory particular district of country have be set apart for the exclusive occupation of the indians and their right to the land within those limit have be acknowledge and respect but in california and oregon there have be no recognition by the government of the exclusive right of the indians to any part of the country they be therefore mere tenant at sufferance and liable to be drive from place to place at the pleasure of the white
 the treaty which have be reject propose to remedy this evil by allot to the different tribe district of country suitable to their habit of life and sufficient for their support this provision more than any other it be believe lead to their rejection and as no substitute for it have be adopt by congress it have not be deem advisable to attempt to enter into new treaty of a permanent character although no effort have be spare by temporary arrangement to preserve friendly relation with they
 if it be the desire of congress to remove they from the country altogether or to assign to they particular district more remote from the settlement of the white it will be proper to set apart by law the territory which they be to occupy and to provide the mean necessary for remove they to it justice alike to our own citizen and to the indians require the prompt action of congress on this subject the amendment propose by the senate to the treaty which be negotiate with the sioux indians of minnesota have be submit to the tribe who be party to they and have receive their assent a large tract of valuable territory have thus be open for settlement and cultivation and all danger of collision with these powerful and warlike band have be happily remove
 the removal of the remnant of the tribe of seminole indians from florida have long be a cherished object of the government and it be one to which my attention have be steadily direct admonish by past experience of the difficulty and cost of the attempt to remove they by military force resort have be have to conciliatory measure by the invitation of the commissioner of indian affairs several of the principal chief recently visit washington and whilst here acknowledge in write the obligation of their tribe to remove with the least possible delay late advice from the special agent of the government represent that they adhere to their promise and that a council of their people have be call to make their preliminary arrangement a general emigration may therefore be confidently expect at an early day

 among other subject offer to your notice by the secretary of the navy i select for special commendation in view of its connection with the interest of the navy the plan submit by he for the establishment of a permanent corps of seaman and the suggestion he have present for the reorganization of the naval academy
 in reference to the first of these i take occasion to say that i think it will greatly improve the efficiency of the service and that i regard it as still more entitled to favor for the salutary influence it must exert upon the naval discipline now greatly disturb by the increase spirit of insubordination result from our present system the plan propose for the organization of the seamen furnish a judicious substitute for the law of september 1850 abolish corporal punishment and satisfactorily sustain the policy of that act under condition well adapt to maintain the authority of command and the order and security of our ship it be believe that any change which propose permanently to dispense with this mode of punishment should be precede by a system of enlistment which shall supply the navy with seaman of the most meritorious class whose good deportment and pride of character may preclude all occasion for a resort to penalty of a harsh or degrading nature the safety of a ship and her crew be often dependent upon immediate obedience to a command and the authority to enforce it must be equally ready the arrest of a refractory seaman in such moment not only deprive the ship of indispensable aid but impose a necessity for double service on other whose fidelity to their duty may be rely upon in such an emergency the exposure to this increase and arduous labor since the passage of the act of 1850 have already have to a most observable and injurious extent the effect of prevent the enlistment of the good seaman in the navy the plan now suggest be design to promote a condition of service in which this objection will no long exist the detail of this plan may be establish in great part if not altogether by the executive under the authority of exist law but i have think it proper in accordance with the suggestion of the secretary of the navy to submit it to your approval
 the establishment of a corps of apprentice for the navy or boy to be enlist until they become of age and to be employ under such regulation as the navy department may devise as propose in the report i cordially approve and commend to your consideration and i also concur in the suggestion that this system for the early training of seaman may be most usefully ingraft upon the service of our merchant marine the other proposition of the report to which i have refer the reorganization of the naval academy i recommend to your attention as a project worthy of your encouragement and support the valuable service already render by this institution entitle it to the continuance of your foster care

 this diminution be attributable to the reduction in the rate of postage make by the act of march 3 1851 which reduction take effect at the commencement of the last fiscal year

 it have be the uniform policy of this government from its foundation to the present day to abstain from all interference in the domestic affair of other nation the consequence have be that while the nation of europe have be engage in desolate war our country have pursue its peaceful course to unexampled prosperity and happiness the war in which we have be compel to engage in defense of the right and honor of the country have be fortunately of short duration during the terrific contest of nation against nation which succeed the french revolution we be enable by the wisdom and firmness of president washington to maintain our neutrality while other nation be draw into this wide sweep whirlpool we sit quiet and unmove upon our own shore while the flower of their numerous army be waste by disease or perish by hundred of thousand upon the battlefield the youth of this favor land be permit to enjoy the blessing of peace beneath the paternal roof while the states of europe incur enormous debt under the burden of which their subject still groan and which must absorb no small part of the product of the honest industry of those country for generation to come the united states have once be enable to exhibit the proud spectacle of a nation free from public debt and if permit to pursue our prosperous way for a few year long in peace we may do the same again
 but it be now say by some that this policy must be change europe be no long separate from we by a voyage of month but steam navigation have bring she within a few days&#39 sail of our shore we see more of her movement and take a deep interest in her controversy although no one propose that we should join the fraternity of potentate who have for age lavish the blood and treasure of their subject in maintain the balance of power yet it be say that we ought to interfere between contend sovereign and their subject for the purpose of overthrow the monarchy of europe and establish in their place republican institution it be allege that we have heretofore pursue a different course from a sense of our weakness but that now our conscious strength dictate a change of policy and that it be consequently our duty to mingle in these contest and aid those who be struggle for liberty
 this be a most seductive but dangerous appeal to the generous sympathy of freeman enjoy as we do the blessing of a free government there be no man who have an american heart that would not rejoice to see these blessing extend to all other nation we can not witness the struggle between the oppressed and his oppressor anywhere without the deep sympathy for the former and the most anxious desire for his triumph nevertheless be it prudent or be it wise to involve ourselves in these foreign war be it indeed true that we have heretofore refrain from do so merely from the degrading motive of a free people
 we live in an age of progress and our be emphatically a country of progress within the last half century the number of states in this union have nearly double the population have almost quadruple and our boundary have be extend from the mississippi to the pacific our territory be checker over with railroad and furrow with canal the inventive talent of our country be excited to the high pitch and the numerous application for patent for valuable improvement distinguish this age and this people from all other the genius of one american have enable our commerce to move against wind and tide and that of another have annihilate distance in the transmission of intelligence the whole country be full of enterprise our common school be diffuse intelligence among the people and our industry be fast accumulate the comfort and luxury of life this be in part owe to our peculiar position to our fertile soil and comparatively sparse population but much of it be also owe to the popular institution under which we live to the freedom which every man feel to engage in any useful pursuit accord to his taste or inclination and to the entire confidence that his person and property will be protect by the law but whatever may be the cause of this unparalleled growth in population intelligence and wealth one tiring be clear that the government must keep pace with the progress of the people it must participate in their spirit of enterprise and while it exact obedience to the law and restrain all unauthorized invasion of the right of neighboring state it should foster and protect home industry and lend its powerful strength to the improvement of such mean of intercommunication as be necessary to promote our internal commerce and strengthen the tie which bind we together as a people
 it be not strange however much it may be regret that such an exuberance of enterprise should cause some individual to mistake change for progress and the invasion of the right of other for national prowess and glory the former be constantly agitate for some change in the organic law or urge new and untried theory of human right the latter be ever ready to engage in any wild crusade against a neighboring people regardless of the justice of the enterprise and without look at the fatal consequence to ourselves and to the cause of popular government such expedition however be often stimulate by mercenary individual who expect to share the plunder or profit of the enterprise without expose themselves to danger and be lead on by some irresponsible foreigner who abuse the hospitality of our own government by seduce the young and ignorant to join in his scheme of personal ambition or revenge under the false and delusive pretense of extend the area of freedom these reprehensible aggression but retard the true progress of our nation and tarnish its fair fame they should therefore receive the indignant frown of every good citizen who sincerely love his country and take a pride in its prosperity and honor our constitution though not perfect be doubtless the good that ever be form therefore let every proposition to change it be well weigh and if find beneficial cautiously adopt every patriot will rejoice to see its authority so exert as to advance the prosperity and honor of the nation whilst he will watch with jealousy any attempt to mutilate this charter of our liberty or pervert its power to act of aggression or injustice thus shall conservatism and progress blend their harmonious action in preserve the form and spirit of the constitution and at the same time carry forward the great improvement of the country with a rapidity and energy which freeman only can display

other under new contingency to be anticipate may serve strikingly to exhibit the importance of such a work neither these nor all consideration combine can have an appreciable value when weigh against expedient and proper if an economical and practicable route shall be find to aid by all constitutional mean in the construction of a road which will unite by speedy transit the population of the pacific and atlantic states to guard against misconception it should be remark that although the power to construct or aid in the construction of a road within the limit of a territory be not embarrassed by that question of jurisdiction which would arise within the limit of a state it be nevertheless hold to be of doubtful power and more than doubtful propriety even within the limit of a territory for the general government to undertake to administer the affair of a railroad a canal or other similar construction and therefore that its connection with a work of this character should be incidental rather than primary i will only add at present that fully appreciate the magnitude of the subject and solicitous that the atlantic and pacific shore of the republic may be bind together by inseparable tie of common interest as well as of common fealty and attachment to the union i shall be dispose so far as my own action be concern to follow the light of the constitution as expound and illustrate by those whose opinion and exposition constitute the standard of my political faith in regard to the power of the federal government it be i trust not necessary to say that no grandeur of enterprise and no present urgent inducement promise popular favor will lead i to disregard those light or to depart from that path which experience have prove to be safe and which be now radiant with the glow of prosperity and legitimate constitutional progress we can afford to wait but we can not afford to overlook the ark of our security it be no part of my purpose to give prominence to any subject which may properly be regard as set at rest by the deliberate judgment of the people but while the present be bright with promise and the future full of demand and inducement for the exercise of active intelligence the past can never be without useful lesson of admonition and instruction if its danger serve not as beacon they will evidently fail to fulfill the object of a wise design when the grave shall have close over all who be now endeavor to meet the obligation of duty the year 1850 will be recur to as a period fill with anxious apprehension a successful war have just terminate peace bring with it a vast augmentation of territory disturb question arise bear upon the domestic institution of one portion of the confederacy and involve the constitutional right of the states but notwithstanding difference of opinion and sentiment which then exist in relation to detail and specific provision the acquiescence of distinguished citizen whose devotion to the union can never be doubt have give renew vigor to our institution and restore a sense of repose and security to the public mind throughout the confederacy that this repose be to suffer no shock during my official term if i have power to avert it those who place i here may be assure the wisdom of man who know what independence cost who have put all at stake upon the issue of the revolutionary struggle dispose of the subject to which i refer in the only way consistent with the union of these states and with the march of power and prosperity which have make we what we be it be a significant fact that from the adoption of the constitution until the officer and soldier of the revolution have pass to their grave or through the infirmity of age and wound have cease to participate actively in public affair there be not merely a quiet acquiescence in but a prompt vindication of the constitutional right of the states the reserved power be scrupulously respect no statesman put forth the narrow view of casuist to justify interference and agitation but the spirit of the compact be regard as sacred in the eye of honor and indispensable for the great experiment of civil liberty which environ by inherent difficulty be yet bear forward in apparent weakness by a power superior to all obstacle there be no condemnation which the voice of freedom will not pronounce upon we should we prove faithless to this great trust while man inhabit different part of this vast continent can no more be expect to hold the same opinion or entertain the same sentiment than every variety of climate or soil can be expect to furnish the same agricultural product they can unite in a common object and sustain common principle essential to the maintenance of that object the gallant man of the south and the north could stand together during the struggle of the revolution they could stand together in the more trying period which succeed the clangor of arm as their united valor be adequate to all the trial of the camp and danger of the field so their united wisdom prove equal to the great task of found upon a deep and broad basis institution which it have be our privilege to enjoy and will ever be our most sacred duty to sustain it be but the feeble expression of a faith strong and universal to say that their son whose blood mingle so often upon the same field during the war of 1812 and who have more recently bear in triumph the flag of the country upon a foreign soil will never permit alienation of feeling to weaken the power of their united effort nor internal dissension to paralyze the great arm of freedom uplifted for the vindication of self government i have thus briefly present such suggestion as seem to i especially worthy of your consideration in provide for the present you can hardly fail to avail yourself of the light which the experience of the past cast upon the future the growth of our population have now bring we in the destine career of our national history to a point at which it well behoove we to expand our vision over the vast prospective the successive decennial return of the census since the adoption of the constitution have reveal a law of steady progressive development which may be state in general term as a duplication every quarter century carry forward from the point already reach for only a short period of time as applicable to the existence of a nation this law of progress if unchecked will bring we to almost incredible result a large allowance for a diminished proportional effect of emigration would not very materially reduce the estimate while the increase average duration of human life know to have already result from the scientific and hygienic improvement of the past fifty year will tend to keep up through the next fifty or perhaps hundred the same ratio of growth which have be thus reveal in our past progress and to the influence of these cause may be add the influx of labor masse from eastern asia to the pacific side of our possession together with the probable accession of the population already exist in other part of our hemisphere which within the period in question will feel with yearly increase force the natural attraction of so vast powerful and prosperous a confederation of self govern republic and will seek the privilege of be admit within its safe and happy bosom transfer with themselves by a peaceful and healthy process of incorporation spacious region of virgin and exuberant soil which be destine to swarm with the fast grow and fast spread million of our race these consideration seem fully to justify the presumption that the law of population above state will continue to act with undiminished effect through at least the next half century and that thousand of person who have already arrive at maturity and be now exercise the right of freeman will close their eye on the spectacle of more than 100,000,000 of population embrace within the majestic proportion of the american union it be not merely as an interesting topic of speculation that i present these view for your consideration they have important practical bearing upon all the political duty we be call upon to perform heretofore our system of government have work on what may be term a miniature scale in comparison with the development which it must thus assume within a future so near at hand as scarcely to be beyond the present of the exist generation it be evident that a confederation so vast and so varied both in number and in territorial extent in habit and in interest could only be keep in national cohesion by the strict fidelity to the principle of the constitution as understand by those who have adhere to the most restricted construction of the power grant by the people and the states interpret and apply accord to those principle the great compact adapt itself with healthy ease and freedom to an unlimited extension of that benign system of federative self government of which it be our glorious and i trust immortal charter let we then with redouble vigilance be on our guard against yield to the temptation of the exercise of doubtful power even under the pressure of the motive of concede temporary advantage and apparent temporary expediency the minimum of federal government compatible with the maintenance of national unity and efficient action in our relation with the rest of the world should afford the rule and measure of construction of our power under the general clause of the constitution a spirit of strict deference to the sovereign right and dignity of every state rather than a disposition to subordinate the states into a provincial relation to the central authority should characterize all our exercise of the respective power temporarily vest in we as a sacred trust from the generous confidence of our constituent in like manner as a manifestly indispensable condition of the perpetuation of the union and of the realization of that magnificent national future advert to do the duty become yearly strong and clear upon we as citizen of the several states to cultivate a fraternal and affectionate spirit language and conduct in regard to other states and in relation to the varied interest institution and habit of sentiment and opinion which may respectively characterize they mutual forbearance respect and noninterference in our personal action as citizen and an enlarged exercise of the most liberal principle of comity in the public dealing of state with state whether in legislation or in the execution of law be the mean to perpetuate that confidence and fraternity the decay of which a mere political union on so vast a scale could not long survive in still another point of view be an important practical duty suggest by this consideration of the magnitude of dimension to which our political system with its correspond machinery of government be so rapidly expand with increase vigilance do it require we to cultivate the cardinal virtue of public frugality and official integrity and purity public affair ought to be so conduct that a settle conviction shall pervade the entire union that nothing short of the high tone and standard of public morality mark every part of the administration and legislation of the general government thus will the federal system whatever expansion time and progress may give it continue more and more deeply rooted in the love and confidence of the people that wise economy which be as far remove from parsimony as from corrupt and corrupt extravagance that single regard for the public good which will frown upon all attempt to approach the treasury with insidious project of private interest cloak under public pretext that sound fiscal administration which in the legislative department guard against the dangerous temptation incident to overflow revenue and in the executive maintain an unsleeping watchfulness against the tendency of all national expenditure to extravagance while they be admit elementary political duty may i trust be deem as properly advert to and urge in view of the more impressive sense of that necessity which be directly suggest by the consideration now present since the adjournment of congress the vice president of the united states have pass from the scene of earth without having enter upon the duty of the station to which he have be call by the voice of his countryman having occupy almost continuously for more than thirty year a seat in one or the other of the two houses of congress and have by his singular purity and wisdom secure unbounded confidence and universal respect his fail health be watch by the nation with painful solicitude his loss to the country under all the circumstance have be justly regard as irreparable in compliance with the act of congress of march 2 1853 the oath of office be administer to he on the 24th of that month at ariadne estate near matanzas in the island of cuba but his strength gradually decline and be hardly sufficient to enable he to return to his home in alabama where on the 18th day of april in the most calm and peaceful way his long and eminently useful career be terminate entertain unlimited confidence in your intelligent and patriotic devotion to the public interest and be conscious of no motive on my part which be not inseparable from the honor and advancement of my country i hope it may be my privilege to deserve and secure not only your cordial cooperation in great public measure but also those relation of mutual confidence and regard which it be always so desirable to cultivate between member of coordinate branch of the government
whereas information have be receive by i that an unlawful expedition have be fit out in the state of california with a view to invade mexico a nation maintain friendly relation with the united states and that other expedition be organize within the united states for the same unlawful purpose andwhereas certain citizen and inhabitant of this country unmindful of their obligation and duty and of the right of a friendly power have participate and be about to participate in these enterprise so derogatory to our national character and so threaten to our tranquillity and be thereby incur the severe penalty impose by law against such offender now therefore i franklin pierce president of the united states have issue this my proclamation warn all person who shall connect themselves with any such enterprise or expedition that the penalty of the law denounce against such criminal conduct will be rigidly enforce and i exhort all good citizen as they regard our national character as they respect our law or the law of nation as they value the blessing of peace and the welfare of their country to discountenance and by all lawful mean prevent such criminal enterprise and i call upon all officer of this government civil and military to use any effort which may be in their power to arrest for trial and punishment every such offender give under my hand and the seal of the united states at washington this 18th day of january a. d. 1854 and the seventy eighth of the independence of the united states franklin pierce.by the president w.l. marcy secretary of state
to the senate of the united states
 i transmit to the senate for its consideration with a view to ratification a treaty between the united states and the mexican republic sign by the plenipotentiary of the party in the city of mexico on the 30th of december last certain amendment be propose to the instrument as hereinafter specify viz
 in order to make the duty and obligation stipulate in the second article reciprocal it be propose to add to that article the follow
 and the government of mexico agree that the stipulation contain in this article to be perform by the united states shall be reciprocal and mexico shall be under like obligation to the united states and the citizen thereof as those hereinabove impose on the latter in favor of the republic of mexico and mexican citizen
 it be also recommend that for the third article of the original treaty the follow shall be adopt as a substitute
 in consideration of the grant receive by the united states and the obligation relinquish by the mexican republic pursuant to this treaty the former agree to pay to the latter the sum of $ 15,000,000 in gold or silver coin at the treasury at washington one fifth of the amount on the exchange of ratification of the present treaty at washington and the remain four fifth in monthly installment of three million each with interest at the rate of 6 per cent per annum until the whole be pay the government of the united states reserve the right to pay up the whole sum of fifteen million at an early date as may be to it convenient
 the united states also agree to assume all the claim of their citizen against the mexican republic which may have arise under treaty or the law of nation since the date of the signature of the treaty of guadalupe and the mexican republic agree to exonerate the united states of america from all claim of mexico or mexican citizen which may have arise under treaty or the law of nation since the date of the treaty of guadalupe so that each government in the most formal and effective manner shall be exempt and exonerate of all such obligation to each other respectively
 i also recommend that the eighth article be modify by strike out all after the word attempt in the twenty third line of that article the part to be omit be as follow
 they mutually and especially obligate themselves in all case of such lawless enterprise which may not have be prevent through the civil authority before formation to aid with the naval and military force on due notice be give by the aggrieved party of the aggression of the citizen and subject of the other so that the lawless adventurer may be pursue and overtake on the high sea their element of war destroy and the delude captive hold responsible in their person and meet with the merit retribution inflict by the law of nation against all such disturber of the peace and happiness of contiguous and friendly power it be understand that in all case of successful pursuit and capture the delinquent so capture shall be judge and punish by the government of that nation to which the vessel capture they may belong conformably to the law of each nation
 at the close of the instrument it will also be advisable to substitute seventy eighth for seventy seventh year of the independence of the united states

to the senate of the united states
 in transmit to the senate the report of the secretary of state together with the document therein refer to be the correspondence call for by the resolution of that body of the 9th of january last i deem it proper to state briefly the reason which have deter i from send to the senate for ratification the propose convention between the united states of america and the united mexican states conclude by the respective plenipotentiary of the two government on the 21st day of march 1853 on the subject of a transit way across the isthmus of tehuantepec
 without advert to the want of authority on the part of the american minister to conclude any such convention or to the action of this government in relation to the right of certain of its citizen under the grant for a like object originally make to jos&eacute garay the objection to it upon its face be numerous and should in my judgment be regard as conclusive
 prominent among these objection be the fact that the convention bind we to a foreign government to guarantee the contract of a private company with that government for the construction of the contemplated transit way to protect the person engage and property employ in the construction of the say work from the commencement thereof to its completion against all confiscation spoliation or violence of whatsoever nature and to guarantee the entire security of the capital invest therein during the continuance of the contract such be the substance of the second and third article
 hence it will be perceive that the obligation which this government be ask to assume be not to terminate in a few year or even with the present generation
 and again if the regulation which may be prescribe concern the traffic on say transit way shall be clearly contrary to the spirit and intention of this convention even then this government be not to be at liberty to withdraw its protection and guaranty without first give one year&#39; notice to the mexican government
 when the fact be duly consider that the responsibility of this government be thus pledge for a long series of year to the interest of a private company establish for purpose of internal improvement in a foreign country and that country peculiarly subject to civil war and other public vicissitude it will be see how comprehensive and embarrassing would be those engagement to the government of the united states
 not less important than this objection be the consideration that the united states can not agree to the term of this convention without disregard the provision of the eighth article of the convention which this government enter into with great britain on april 19 1850 which expressly include any interoceanic communication whatever by the isthmus of tehuantepec however inconvenient may be the condition of that convention still they exist and the obligation of good faith rest alike upon the united states and great britain
 without enlarge upon these and other questionable feature of the propose convention which will suggest themselves to your mind i will only add that after the most careful consideration i have deem it my duty not to ask for its ratification by the senate

to the senate and house of representatives
 i transmit herewith report of the secretary of state the secretary of the navy and the attorney general in reply to a resolution of the senate of the 24th of march last and also to a resolution of the house of representatives of the 8th of may instant both have reference to the route of transit between the atlantic and pacific ocean through the republics of new granada and nicaragua and to the condition of affair in central america
 these document relate to question of the high importance and interest to the people of the united states
 the narrow isthmus which connect the continent of north and south america by the facility it afford for easy transit between the atlantic and pacific ocean render the country of central america an object of special consideration to all maritime nation which have be greatly augment in modern time by the operation of change in commercial relation especially those produce by the general use of steam as a motive power by land and sea to we on account of its geographical position and of our political interest as an american state of primary magnitude that isthmus be of peculiar importance just as the isthmus of suez be for correspond reason to the maritime power of europe but above all the importance to the united states of secure free transit across the american isthmus have render it of paramount interest to we since the settlement of the territories of oregon and washington and the accession of california to the union
 impel by these consideration the united states take step at an early day to assure suitable mean of commercial transit by canal railway or otherwise across this isthmus
 we conclude in the first place a treaty of peace amity navigation and commerce with the republic of new granada among the condition of which be a stipulation on the part of new granada guarantee to the united states the right of way or transit across that part of the isthmus which lie in the territory of new granada in consideration of which the united states guarantee in respect of the same territory the right of sovereignty and property of new granada
 the effect of this treaty be to afford to the people of the united states facility for at once open a common road from chagre to panama and for at length construct a railway in the same direction to connect regularly with steamship for the transportation of mail specie and passenger to and fro between the atlantic and pacific states and territories of the united states
 the united states also endeavor but unsuccessfully to obtain from the mexican republic the cession of the right of way at the northern extremity of the isthmus by tehuantepec and that line of communication continue to be an object of solicitude to the people of this republic
 in the meantime intervene between the republic of new granada and the mexican republic lie the states of guatemala salvador honduras nicaragua and costa rica the several member of the former republic of central america here in the territory of the central american states be the narrow part of the isthmus and hither of course public attention have be direct as the most invite field for enterprise of interoceanic communication between the opposite shore of america and more especially to the territory of the states of nicaragua and honduras
 paramount to that of any european state as be the interest of the united states in the security and freedom of project line of travel across the isthmus by the way of nicaragua and honduras still we do not yield in this respect to any suggestion of territorial aggrandizement or even of exclusive advantage either of communication or of commerce opportunity have not be want to the united states to procure such advantage by peaceful mean and with full and free assent of those who alone have any legitimate authority in the matter we disregard those opportunity from consideration alike of domestic and foreign policy just as even to the present day we have persevere in a system of justice and respect for the right and interest of other as well as our own in regard to each and all of the states of central america
 it be with surprise and regret therefore that the united states learn a few day after the conclusion of the treaty of guadalupe hidalgo by which the united states become with the consent of the mexican republic the rightful owner of california and thus invest with augment special interest in the political condition of central america that a military expedition under the authority of the british government have land at san juan del norte in the state of nicaragua and take forcible possession of that port the necessary terminus of any canal or railway across the isthmus within the territory of nicaragua
 it do not diminish the unwelcomeness to we of this act on the part of great britain to find that she assume to justify it on the ground of an alleged protectorship of a small and obscure band of uncivilized indians whose proper name have even become lose to history who do not constitute a state capable of territorial sovereignty either in fact or of right and all political interest in whom and in the territory they occupy great britain have previously renounce by successive treaty with spain when spain be sovereign to the country and subsequently with independent spanish america
 nevertheless and injuriously affect as the united states conceive themselves to have be by this act of the british government and by its occupation about the same time of insular and of continental portion of the territory of the state of honduras we remember the many and powerful tie and mutual interest by which great britain and the united states be associate and we proceed in earnest good faith and with a sincere desire to do whatever might strengthen the bond of peace between we to negotiate with great britain a convention to assure the perfect neutrality of all interoceanic communication across the isthmus and as the indispensable condition of such neutrality the absolute independence of the states of central america and their complete sovereignty within the limit of their own territory as well against great britain as against the united states we suppose we have accomplish that object by the convention of april 19 1850 which would never have be sign nor ratify on the part of the united states but for the conviction that in virtue of its provision neither great britain nor the united states be thereafter to exercise any territorial sovereignty in fact or in name in any part of central america however or whensoever acquire either before or afterwards the essential object of the convention the neutralization of the isthmus would of course become a nullity if either great britain or the united states be to continue to hold exclusively island or mainland of the isthmus and more especially if under any claim of protectorship of indians either government be to remain forever sovereign in fact of the atlantic shore of the three states of costa rica nicaragua and honduras
 i have already communicate to the two houses of congress full information of the protracted and hitherto fruitless effort which the united states have make to arrange this international question with great britain it be refer to on the present occasion only because of its intimate connection with the special object now to be bring to the attention of congress
 the unsettled political condition of some of the spanish american republics have never cease to be regard by this government with solicitude and regret on their own account while it have be the source of continual embarrassment in our public and private relation with they in the midst of the violent revolution and the war by which they be continually agitate their public authority be unable to afford due protection to foreigner and to foreign interest within their territory or even to defend their own soil against individual aggressor foreign or domestic the burden of the inconvenience and loss of which therefore devolve in no inconsiderable degree upon the foreign state associate with they in close relation of geographical vicinity or of commercial intercourse
 such be more emphatically the situation of the united states with respect to the republics of mexico and of central america notwithstanding however the relative remoteness of the european states from america fact of the same order have not fail to appear conspicuously in their intercourse with spanish american republics great britain have repeatedly be constrain to recur to measure of force for the protection of british interest in those country france find it necessary to attack the castle of san juan de uloa and even to debark troop at vera cruz in order to obtain redress of wrong do to frenchmen in mexico
 what be memorable in this respect in the conduct and policy of the united states be that while it would be as easy for we to annex and absorb new territory in america as it be for european states to do this in asia or africa and while if do by we it might be justify as well on the alleged ground of the advantage which would accrue therefrom to the territory annex and absorb yet we have abstain from do it in obedience to consideration of right not less than of policy and that while the courageous and self reliant spirit of our people prompt they to hardy enterprise and they occasionally yield to the temptation of take part in the trouble of country near at hand where they know how potential their influence moral and material must be the american government have uniformly and steadily resist all attempt of individual in the united states to undertake armed aggression against friendly spanish american republics
 while the present incumbent of the executive office have be in discharge of its duty he have never fail to exert all the authority in he vest to repress such enterprise because they be in violation of the law of the land which the constitution require he to execute faithfully because they be contrary to the policy of the government and because to permit they would be a departure from good faith toward those american republics in amity with we which be entitle to and will never cease to enjoy in their calamity the cordial sympathy and in their prosperity the efficient good will of the government and of the people of the united states
 to say that our law in this respect be sometimes violate or successfully evade be only to say what be true of all law in all country but not more so in the united states than in any one whatever of the country of europe suffice it to repeat that the law of the united states prohibit all foreign military enlistment or expedition within our territory have be execute with impartial good faith and so far as the nature of thing permit as well in repression of private person as of the official agent of other government both of europe and america
 among the central american republics to which modern event have impart most prominence be that of nicaragua by reason of its particular position on the isthmus citizen of the united states have establish in its territory a regular interoceanic transit route second only in utility and value to the one previously establish in the territory of new granada the condition of nicaragua would it be believe have be much more prosperous than it have be but for the occupation of its only atlantic port by a foreign power and of the disturbing authority set up and sustain by the same power in a portion of its territory by mean of which its domestic sovereignty be impaired its public land be withhold from settlement and it be deprive of all the maritime revenue which it would otherwise collect on import merchandise at san juan del norte
 in these circumstance of the political debility of the republic of nicaragua and when its inhabitant be exhaust by long continue civil war between party neither of they strong enough to overcome the other or permanently maintain internal tranquillity one of the contend faction of the republic invite the assistance and cooperation of a small body of citizen of the united states from the state of california whose presence as it appear put an end at once to civil war and restore apparent order throughout the territory of nicaragua with a new administration have at its head a distinguished individual by birth a citizen of the republic d. patricio rivas as its provisional president
 it be the establish policy of the united states to recognize all government without question of their source or their organization or of the mean by which the govern person attain their power provide there be a government de facto accept by the people of the country and with reserve only of the time as to the recognition of revolutionary government arise out of the subdivision of parent state with which we be in relation of amity we do not go behind the fact of a foreign government exercise actual power to investigate question of legitimacy we do not inquire into the cause which may have lead to a change of government to we it be indifferent whether a successful revolution have be aid by foreign intervention or not whether insurrection have overthrow exist government and another have be establish in its place accord to preexist form or in a manner adopt for the occasion by those whom we may find in the actual possession of power all these matter we leave to the people and public authority of the particular country to determine and their determination whether it be by positive action or by ascertained acquiescence be to we a sufficient warranty of the legitimacy of the new government
 during the sixty seven year which have elapse since the establishment of the exist government of the united states in all which time this union have maintain undisturbed domestic tranquillity we have have occasion to recognize government de facto found either by domestic revolution or by military invasion from abroad in many of the governments of europe
 it be the more imperatively necessary to apply this rule to the spanish american republics in consideration of the frequent and not seldom anomalous change of organization or administration which they undergo and the revolutionary nature of most of these change of which the recent series of revolution in the mexican republic be an example where five successive revolutionary government have make their appearance in the course of a few month and be recognize successively each as the political power of that country by the united states
 when therefore some time since a new minister from the republic of nicaragua present himself bear the commission of president rivas he must and would have be receive as such unless he be find on inquiry subject to personal exception but for the absence of satisfactory information upon the question whether president rivas be in fact the head of an established government of the republic of nicaragua doubt as to which arise not only from the circumstance of his avow association with armed emigrant recently from the united states but that the propose minister himself be of that class of person and not otherwise or previously a citizen of nicaragua
 another minister from the republic of nicaragua have now present himself and have be receive as such satisfactory evidence appear that he represent the government de facto and so far as such exist the government de jure of that republic
 that reception while in accordance with the establish policy of the united states be likewise call for by the most imperative special exigency which require that this government shall enter at once into diplomatic relation with that of nicaragua in the first place a difference have occur between the government of president rivas and the nicaragua transit company which involve the necessity of inquiry into right of citizen of the united states who allege that they have be aggrieve by the act of the former and claim protection and redress at the hand of their government in the second place the interoceanic communication by the way of nicaragua be effectually interrupt and the person and property of unoffending private citizen of the united states in that country require the attention of their government neither of these object can receive due consideration without resumption of diplomatic intercourse with the government of nicaragua
 far than this the document communicate show that while the interoceanic transit by the way of nicaragua be cut off disturbance at panama have occur to obstruct temporarily at least that by the way of new granada involve the sacrifice of the life and property of citizen of the united states a special commissioner have be dispatch to panama to investigate the fact of this occurrence with a view particularly to the redress of party aggrieve but measure of another class will be demand for the future security of interoceanic communication by this as by the other route of the isthmus
 it would be difficult to suggest a single object of interest external or internal more important to the united states than the maintenance of the communication by land and sea between the atlantic and pacific states and territories of the union it be a material element of the national integrity and sovereignty
 i have adopt such precautionary measure and have take such action for the purpose of afford security to the several transit route of central america and to the person and property of citizen of the united states connect with or use the same as be within my constitutional power and as existing circumstance have seem to demand should these measure prove inadequate to the object that fact will be communicate to congress with such recommendation as the exigency of the case may indicate

to the senate of the united states
 i hasten to respond briefly to the resolution of the senate of this date request the president to inform the senate if in his opinion it be not incompatible with the public interest whether anything have arise since the date of his message to the house of representatives of the 15th of march last concern our relation with the government of spain which in his opinion may dispense with the suggestion therein contain touch the propriety of provisional measures&#39 by congress to meet any exigency that may arise in the recess of congress affect those relation
 in the message to the house of representatives refer to i avail myself of the occasion to present the follow reflection and suggestion
 in view of the position of the island of cuba its proximity to our coast the relation which it must ever bear to our commercial and other interest it be vain to expect that a series of unfriendly act infringe our commercial right and the adoption of a policy threaten the honor and security of these states can long consist with peaceful relation
 in case the measure take for amicable adjustment of our difficulty with spain should unfortunately fail i shall not hesitate to use the authority and mean which congress may grant to insure the observance of our just right to obtain redress for injury receive and to vindicate the honor of our flag
 in anticipation of that contingency which i earnestly hope may not arise i suggest to congress the propriety of adopt such provisional measure as the exigency may seem to demand
 the two houses of congress may have anticipate that the hope then express would be realize before the period of its adjournment and that our relation with spain would have assume a satisfactory condition so as to remove past cause of complaint and afford well security for tranquillity and justice in the future but i be constrain to say that such be not the fact the formal demand for immediate reparation in the case of the black warrior instead of having be meet on the part of spain by prompt satisfaction have only serve to call forth a justification of the local authority of cuba and thus to transfer the responsibility for their act to the spanish government itself
 meanwhile information not only reliable in its nature but of an official character be receive to the effect that preparation be make within the limit of the united states by private individual under military organization for a descent upon the island of cuba with a view to wrest that colony from the dominion of spain international comity the obligation of treaty and the express provision of law alike require in my judgment that all the constitutional power of the executive should be exert to prevent the consummation of such a violation of positive law and of that good faith on which mainly the amicable relation of neighboring nation must depend in conformity with these conviction of public duty a proclamation be issue to warn all person not to participate in the contemplated enterprise and to invoke the interposition in this behalf of the proper officer of the government no provocation whatever can justify private expedition of hostility against a country at peace with the united states the power to declare war be vest by the constitution in congress and the experience of our past history leave no room to doubt that the wisdom of this arrangement of constitutional power will continue to be verify whenever the national interest and honor shall demand a resort to ultimate measure of redress pende negotiation by the executive and before the action of congress individual could not be permit to embarrass the operation of the one and usurp the power of the other of these depositary of the function of government
 i have only to add that nothing have arise since the date of my former message to dispense with the suggestion therein contain touch the propriety of provisional measure by congress

i have receive the bill entitle an act make appropriation for the repair preservation and completion of certain public work heretofore commence under the authority of law it reach i in the expire hour of the session and time do not allow full opportunity for examine and consider its provision or of state at length the reason which forbid i to give it my signature
 it belong to that class of measure which be commonly know as internal improvement by the general government and which from a very early period have be deem of doubtful constitutionality and expediency and have thus fail to obtain the approbation of successive chief magistrates
 on such an examination of this bill as it have be in my power to make i recognize in it certain provision national in their character and which if they stand alone it would be compatible with my conviction of public duty to assent to but at the same time it embrace other which be merely local and not in my judgment warrant by any safe or true construction of the constitution
 to make proper and sound discrimination between these different pro vision would require a deliberate discussion of general principle as well as a careful scrutiny of detail for the purpose of rightfully apply those principle to each separate item of appropriation
 public opinion with regard to the value and importance of internal improvement in the country be undivide there be a disposition on all hand to have they prosecute with energy and to see the benefit seek to be attain by they fully realize
 the prominent point of difference between those who have be regard as the friend of a system of internal improvement by the general government and those adverse to such a system have be one of constitutional power though more or less connected with consideration of expediency
 my own judgment it be well know have on both ground be oppose to a general system of internal improvement by the federal government i have entertain the most serious doubt from the inherent difficulty of its application as well as from past unsatisfactory experience whether the power could be so exercise by the general government as to render its use advantageous either to the country at large or effectual for the accomplishment of the object contemplate
 i shall consider it incumbent on i to present to congress at its next session a mature view of the whole subject and to endeavor to define approximately at least and accord to my own conviction what appropriation of this nature by the general government the great interest of the united states require and the constitution will admit and sanction in case no substitute should be devise capable of reconcile difference both of constitutionality and expediency
 in the absence of the requisite mean and time for duly consider the whole subject at present and discuss such possible substitute it become necessary to return this bill to the house of representatives in which it originate and for the reason thus briefly submit to the consideration of congress to withhold from it my approval

the repeal of the missouri compromise and the propriety of its restoration constitute the subject of what i be about to say as i desire to present my own connected view of this subject my remark will not be specifically an answer to judge douglas yet as i proceed the main point he have present will arise and will receive such respectful attention as i may be able to give they i wish far to say fellow citizen of the senate and of the house of representatives the past have be an eventful year and will be hereafter refer to as a marked epoch in the history of the world while we have be happily preserve from the calamity of war our domestic prosperity have not be entirely uninterrupted the crop in portion of the country have be nearly cut off disease have prevail to a great extent than usual and the sacrifice of human life through casualty by sea and land be without parallel but the pestilence have sweep by and restore salubrity invite the absent to their home and the return of business to its ordinary channel if the earth have reward the labor of the husbandman less bountifully than in precede season it have leave he with abundance for domestic want and a large surplus for exportation in the present therefore as in the past we find ample ground for reverent thankfulness to the god of grace and providence for his protect care and merciful dealing with we as a people although our attention have be arrest by painful interest in pass event yet our country feel no more than the slight vibration of the convulsion which have shake europe as individual we can not repress sympathy with human suffering nor regret for the cause which produce it as a nation we be remind that whatever interrupt the peace or check the prosperity of any part of christendom tend more or less to involve our own the condition of states be not unlike that of individual they be mutually dependent upon each other amicable relation between they and reciprocal good will be essential for the promotion of whatever be desirable in their moral social and political condition hence it have be my earnest endeavor to maintain peace and friendly intercourse with all nation the wise theory of this government so early adopt and steadily pursue of avoid all entangle alliance have hitherto exempt it from many complication in which it would otherwise have become involve notwithstanding this our clearly define and well sustain course of action and our geographical position so remote from europe increase disposition have be manifest by some of its government to supervise and in certain respect to direct our foreign policy in plan for adjust the balance of power among themselves they have assume to take we into account and would constrain we to conform our conduct to their view one or another of the power of europe have from time to time undertake to enforce arbitrary regulation contrary in many respect to establish principle of international law that law the united states have in their foreign intercourse uniformly respect and observe and they can not recognize any such interpolation therein as the temporary interest of other may suggest they do not admit that the sovereign of one continent or of a particular community of state can legislate for all other leave the transatlantic nation to adjust their political system in the way they may think well for their common welfare the independent power of this continent may well assert the right to be exempt from all annoying interference on their part systematic abstinence from intimate political connection with distant foreign nation do not conflict with give the wide range to our foreign commerce this distinction so clearly mark in history seem to have be overlook or disregard by some lead foreign state our refusal to be bring within and subject to their peculiar system have i fear create a jealous distrust of our conduct and induce on their part occasional act of disturb effect upon our foreign relation our present attitude and past course give assurance which should not be question that our purpose be not aggressive nor threaten to the safety and welfare of other nation our military establishment in time of peace be adapt to maintain exterior defense and to preserve order among the aboriginal tribe within the limit of the union our naval force be intend only for the protection of our citizen abroad and of our commerce diffused as it be over all the sea of the globe the government of the united states be essentially pacific in policy stand prepared to repel invasion by the voluntary service of a patriotic people and provide no permanent mean of foreign aggression these consideration should allay all apprehension that we be disposed to encroach on the right or endanger the
