to the senate and house of representatives
 in return to the house of representatives in which it originate a bill entitle an act make appropriation for the repair preservation and completion of certain public work heretofore commence under the authority of law it become necessary for i owe to the late day at which the bill be pass to state my objection to it very briefly announce at the same time a purpose to resume the subject for more deliberate discussion at the present session of congress for while by no mean insensible of the arduousness of the task thus undertake by i i conceive that the two houses be entitle to an exposition of the consideration which have induce dissent on my part from their conclusion in this instance
 the great constitutional question of the power of the general government in relation to internal improvement have be the subject of earnest difference of opinion at every period of the history of the united states annual and special message of successive president have be occupy with it sometimes in remark on the general topic and frequently in objection to particular bill the conflict sentiment of eminent statesman express in congress or in convention call expressly to devise if possible some plan calculate to relieve the subject of the embarrassment with which it be environ while they have direct public attention strongly to the magnitude of the interest involve have yet leave unsettle the limit not merely of expediency but of constitutional power in relation to work of this class by the general government
 what be intend by the phrase internal improvement what do it embrace and what exclude no such language be find in the constitution not only be it not an expression of ascertainable constitutional power but it have no sufficient exactness of meaning to be of any value as the basis of a safe conclusion either of constitutional law or of practical statesmanship
 president john quincy adams in claim on one occasion after his retirement from office the authorship of the idea of introduce into the administration of the affair of the general government a permanent and regular system of internal improvement speak of it as a system by which the whole union would have be checker over with railroad and canal afford high wage and constant employment to hundred of thousand of laborer and he place it in express contrast with the construction of such work by the legislation of the states and by private enterprise
 it be quite obvious that if there be any constitutional power which authorize the construction of railroad and canal by congress the same power must comprehend turnpike and ordinary carriage road nay it must extend to the construction of bridge to the draining of marsh to the erection of levee to the construction of canal of irrigation in a word to all the possible mean of the material improvement of the earth by develop its natural resource anywhere and everywhere even within the proper jurisdiction of the several states but if there be any constitutional power thus comprehensive in its nature must not the same power embrace within its scope other kind of improvement of equal utility in themselves and equally important to the welfare of the whole country president jefferson while intimate the expediency of so amend the constitution as to comprise object of physical progress and well being do not fail to perceive that other object of public improvement include public education by name belong to the same class of power in fact not only public instruction but hospital establishment of science and art library and indeed everything appertain to the internal welfare of the country be just as much object of internal improvement or in other word of internal utility as canal and railway
 the admission of the power in either of its sense imply its existence in the other and since if it exist at all it involve dangerous augmentation of the political function and of the patronage of the federal government we ought to see clearly by what clause or clause of the constitution it be confer
 i have have occasion more than once to express and deem it proper now to repeat that it be in my judgment to be take for grant as a fundamental proposition not require elucidation that the federal government be the creature of the individual states and of the people of the states severally that the sovereign power be in they alone that all the power of the federal government be derivative one the enumeration and limitation of which be contain in the instrument which organize it and by express term the power not delegate to the united states by the constitution nor prohibit by it to the states be reserve to the states respectively or to the people
 start from this foundation of our constitutional faith and proceed to inquire in what part of the constitution the power of make appropriation for internal improvement be find it be necessary to reject all idea of there be any grant of power in the preamble when that instrument say we the people of the united states in order to form a more perfect union establish justice insure domestic tranquillity provide for the common defense promote the general welfare and secure the blessing of liberty to ourselves and our posterity it only declare the inducement and the anticipated result of the thing ordain and establish by it to assume that anything more can be design by the language of the preamble would be to convert all the body of the constitution with its carefully weigh enumeration and limitation into mere surplusage the same may be say of the phrase in the grant of the power to congress to pay the debt and provide for the common defense and general welfare of the united states or to construe the word more exactly they be not significant of grant or concession but of restriction of the specific grant have the effect of say that in lay and collect taxis for each of the precise object of power grant to the general government congress must exercise any such definite and undoubted power in strict subordination to the purpose of the common defense and general welfare of all the states
 there be no specific grant in the constitution of a power to sanction appropriation for internal improvement and no general provision broad enough to cover any such indefinite object it become necessary to look for particular power to which one or another of the thing include in the phrase internal improvement may be refer
 in the discussion of this question by the advocate of the organization of a general system of internal improvement under the auspex of the federal government reliance be have for the justification of the measure on several of the power expressly grant to congress such as to establish post office and post road to declare war to provide and maintain a navy to raise and support army to regulate commerce and to dispose of the territory and other public property of the united states
 as to the last of these source of power that of dispose of the territory and other public property of the united states it may be concede that it authorize congress in the management of the public property to make improvement essential to the successful execution of the trust but this must be the primary object of any such improvement and it would be an abuse of the trust to sacrifice the interest of the property to incidental purpose
 as to the other assume source of a general power over internal improvement they be specific power of which this be suppose to be the incident if the framer of the constitution wise and thoughtful man as they be intend to confer on congress the power over a subject so wide as the whole field of internal improvement it be remarkable that they do not use language clearly to express it or in other word that they do not give it as a distinct and substantive power instead of make it the imply incident of some other one for such be the magnitude of the suppose incidental power and its capacity of expansion that any system establish under it would exceed each of the other in the amount of expenditure and number of the person employ which would thus be throw upon the general government
 this position may be illustrate by take as a single example one of the many thing comprehend clearly in the idea of a general system of internal improvement namely road let it be suppose that the power to construct road over the whole union accord to the suggestion of president j. q. adams in 1807 whilst a member of the senate of the united states have be concede congress would have begin in pursuance of the state of knowledge at the time by construct turnpike then as knowledge advance it would have construct canal and at the present time it would have be embark in an almost limitless scheme of railroad
 now there be in the united states the result of state or private enterprise upward of 17,000 mile of railroad and 5,000 mile of canal in all 22,000 mile the total cost of which may be estimate at little short of $ 600,000,000 and if the same work have be construct by the federal government suppose the thing to have be practicable the cost would have probably be not less than $ 900,000,000 the number of person employ in superintending managing and keep up these canal and railroad may be state at 126,000 or thereabout to which be to be add 70,000 or 80,000 employ on the railroad in construction make a total of at least 200,000 person represent in family nearly 1,000,000 soul employ on or maintain by this one class of public work in the united states
 in view of all this it be not easy to estimate the disastrous consequence which must have result from such extended local improvement be undertake by the general government state legislation upon this subject would have be suspend and private enterprise paralyze while application for appropriation would have pervert the legislation of congress exhaust the national treasury and leave the people burden with a heavy public debt beyond the capacity of generation to discharge
 be it conceivable that the framer of the constitution intend that authority draw after it such immense consequence should be infer by implication as the incident of enumerate power i can not think this and the impossibility of suppose it would be still more glaring if similar calculation be carry out in regard to the numerous object of material moral and political usefulness of which the idea of internal improvement admit it may be safely infer that if the framer of the constitution have intend to confer the power to make appropriation for the object indicate it would have be enumerate among the grant expressly make to congress when therefore any one of the power actually enumerate be adduce or refer to as the ground of an assumption to warrant the incidental or imply power of internal improvement that hypothesis must be reject or at least can be no far admit than as the particular act of internal improvement may happen to be necessary to the exercise of the grant power thus when the object of a give road the clearing of a particular channel or the construction of a particular harbor of refuge be manifestly require by the exigency of the naval or military service of the country then it seem to i undeniable that it may be constitutionally comprehend in the power to declare war to provide and maintain a navy and to raise and support army at the same time it would be a misuse of these power and a violation of the constitution to undertake to build upon they a great system of internal improvement and similar reasoning apply to the assumption of any such power as be involve in that to establish post road and to regulate commerce if the particular improvement whether by land or sea be necessary to the execution of the enumerate power then but not otherwise it fall within the jurisdiction of congress to this extent only can the power be claim as the incident of any express grant to the federal government
 but there be one clause of the constitution in which it have be suggest that express authority to construct work of internal improvement have be confer on congress namely that which empower it to exercise exclusive legislation in all case whatsoever over such district not exceed 10 mile square as may by cession of particular states and the acceptance of congress become the seat of the government of the united states and to exercise like authority over all place purchase by the consent of the legislature of the state in which the same shall be for the erection of fort magazine arsenal dockyard and other needful building but any such supposition will be see to be groundless when this provision be carefully examine and compare with other part of the constitution
 it be undoubtedly true that like authority refer back to exclusive legislation in all case whatsoever as apply to the district of columbia and there be in the district no division of power as between the general and the state government
 in those place which the united states have purchase or retain within any of the states site for dockyard or fort for example legal process of the give state be still permit to run for some purpose and therefore the jurisdiction of the united states be not absolutely perfect but let we assume for the argument&#39;s sake that the jurisdiction of the united states in a tract of land cede to it for the purpose of a dockyard or fort by virginia or maryland be as complete as in that cede by they for the seat of government and then proceed to analyze this clause of the constitution
 it provide that congress shall have certain legislative authority over all place purchase by the united states for certain purpose it imply that congress have otherwise the power to purchase but where do congress get the power to purchase manifestly it must be from some other clause of the constitution for it be not confer by this one now as it be a fundamental principle that the constitution be one of limited power the authority to purchase must be confer in one of the enumeration of legislative power so that the power to purchase be itself not an unlimited one but be limit by the object in regard to which legislative authority be directly confer
 the other expression of the clause in question confirm this conclusion since the jurisdiction be give as to place purchase for certain enumerate object or purpose of these the first great division fort magazine arsenal and dockyard be obviously referable to recognize head of specific constitutional power there remain only the phrase and other needful building wherefore needful needful for any possible purpose within the whole range of the business of society and of government clearly not but only such building as be needful to the united states in the exercise of any of the power confer on congress
 thus the united states need in the exercise of admit power not only fort magazine arsenal and dockyard but also court house prison custom house and post office within the respective states place for the erection of such building the general government may constitutionally purchase and having purchase they the jurisdiction over they belong to the united states so if the general government have the power to build a light house or a beacon it may purchase a place for that object and having purchase it then this clause of the constitution give jurisdiction over it still the power to purchase for the purpose of erect a light house or beacon must depend on the existence of the power to erect and if that power exist it must be seek after in some other clause of the constitution
 from whatever point of view therefore the subject be regard whether as a question of express or imply power the conclusion be the same that congress have no constitutional authority to carry on a system of internal improvement and in this conviction the system have be steadily oppose by the sound expositor of the function of the government
 it be not to be suppose that in no conceivable case shall there be doubt as to whether a give object be or not a necessary incident of the military naval or any other power as man be imperfect so be his method of utter his thought human language save in expression for the exact science must always fail to preclude all possibility of controversy hence it be that in one branch of the subject the question of the power of congress to make appropriation in aid of navigation there be less of positive conviction than in regard to the general subject and it therefore seem proper in this respect to revert to the history of the practice of the government
 among the very early act of the first session of congress be that for the establishment and support of light house approve by president washington on the 7th of august 1789 which contain the follow provision
 that all expense which shall accrue from and after the 15th day of august 1789 in the necessary support maintenance and repair of all light house beacon buoy and public pier erect place or sink before the passing of this act at the entrance of or within any bay inlet harbor or port of the united states for render the navigation thereof easy and safe shall be defray out of the treasury of the united states provide nevertheless that none of the say expense shall continue to be so defray after the expiration of one year from the day aforesaid unless such light house beacon buoy and public pier shall in the meantime be cede to and vest in the united states by the state or states respectively in which the same may be together with the land and tenement thereunto belong and together with the jurisdiction of the same
 act contain appropriation for this class of public work be pass in 1791 1792 1793 and so on from year to year down to the present time and the tenor of these act when examine with reference to other part of the subject be worthy of special consideration
 it be a remarkable fact that for a period of more than thirty year after the adoption of the constitution all appropriation of this class be confine with scarcely an apparent exception to the construction of light house beacon buoy and public pier and the stakage of channel to render navigation safe and easy it be true but only by indicate to the navigator obstacle in his way not by remove those obstacle nor in any other respect change artificially the preexist natural condition of the earth and sea it be obvious however that work of art for the removal of natural impediment to navigation or to prevent their formation or for supply harbor where these do not exist be also mean of render navigation safe and easy and may in supposable case be the most efficient as well as the most economical of such mean nevertheless it be not until the year 1824 that in an act to improve the navigation of the river ohio and mississippi and in another act make appropriation for deepen the channel lead into the harbor of presque isle on lake erie and for repair plymouth beach in massachusetts bay we have any example of an appropriation for the improvement of harbor in the nature of those provide for in the bill return by i to the house of representatives
 it appear not probable that the abstinence of congress in this respect be attributable altogether to consideration of economy or to any failure to perceive that the removal of an obstacle to navigation might be not less useful than the indication of it for avoidance and it may be well assume that the course of legislation so long pursue be induce in whole or in part by solicitous consideration in regard to the constitutional power over such matter vest in congress
 one other peculiarity in this course of legislation be not less remarkable it be that when the general government first take charge of lighthouse and beacon it require the work themselves and the land on which they be situate to be cede to the united states and although for a time this precaution be neglect in the case of new work in the sequel it be provide by general law that no light house should be construct on any site previous to the jurisdiction over the same being cede to the united states
 constitutional authority for the construction and support of many of the public work of this nature it be certain may be find in the power of congress to maintain a navy and provide for the general defense but their number and in many instance their location preclude the idea of their be fully justify as necessary and proper incident of that power and they do not seem susceptible of be refer to any other of the specific power vest in congress by the constitution unless it be that to raise revenue in so far as this relate to navigation the practice under all my predecessor in office the express admission of some of they and absence of denial by any sufficiently manifest their belief that the power to erect light house beacon and pier be possess by the general government in the act of congress as we have already see the inducement and object of the appropriation be expressly declare those appropriation be for light house beacon buoy and public pier erect or place within any bay inlet harbor or port of the united states for render the navigation thereof easy and safe
 if it be contend that this review of the history of appropriation of this class lead to the inference that beyond the purpose of national defense and maintenance of a navy there be authority in the constitution to construct certain work in aid of navigation it be at the same time to be remember that the conclusion thus deduce from contemporaneous construction and long continue acquiescence be themselves directly suggestive of limitation of constitutionality as well as expediency regard the nature and the description of those aid to navigation which congress may provide as incident to the revenue power for at this point controversy begin not so much as to the principle as to its application
 in accordance with long establish legislative usage congress may construct light house and beacon and provide as it do other mean to prevent shipwreck on the coast of the united states but the general government can not go beyond this and make improvement of river and harbor of the nature and to the degree of all the provision of the bill of the last session of congress
 to justify such extend power it have be urge that if it be constitutional to appropriate money for the purpose of point out by the construction of light house or beacon where an obstacle to navigation exist it be equally so to remove such obstacle or to avoid it by the creation of an artificial channel that if the object be lawful then the mean adopt solely with reference to the end must be lawful and that therefore it be not material constitutionally speak whether a give obstruction to navigation be indicate for avoidance or be actually avoid by excavate a new channel that if it be a legitimate object of expenditure to preserve a ship from wreck by mean of a beacon or of revenue cutter it must be not less so to provide place of safety by the improvement of harbor or where none exist by their artificial construction and thence the argument naturally pass to the propriety of improve river for the benefit of internal navigation because all these object be of more or less importance to the commercial as well as the naval interest of the united states
 the answer to all this be that the question of open speedy and easy communication to and through all part of the country be substantially the same whether do by land or water that the use of road and canal in facilitate commercial intercourse and unite by community of interest the most remote quarter of the country by land communication be the same in their nature as the use of navigable water and that therefore the question of the facility and aid to be provide to navigation by whatsoever mean be but a subdivision of the great question of the constitutionality and expediency of internal improvement by the general government in confirmation of this it be to be remark that one of the most important act of appropriation of this class that of the year 1833 under the administration of president jackson by include together and provide for in one bill as well river and harbor work as road work impliedly recognize the fact that they be alike branch of the same great subject of internal improvement
 as the population territory and wealth of the country increase and settlement extend into remote region the necessity for additional mean of communication impress itself upon all mind with a force which have not be experience at the date of the formation of the constitution and more and more embarrassed those who be most anxious to abstain scrupulously from any exercise of doubtful power hence the recognition in the message of presidents jefferson madison and monroe of the eminent desirableness of such work with admission that some of they could lawfully and should be conduct by the general government but with obvious uncertainty of opinion as to the line between such as be constitutional and such as be not such as ought to receive appropriation from congress and such as ought to be consign to private enterprise or the legislation of the several states
 this uncertainty have not be remove by the practical working of our institution in later time for although the acquisition of additional territory and the application of steam to the propulsion of vessel have greatly magnify the importance of internal commerce this fact have at the same time complicate the question of the power of the general government over the present subject
 in fine a careful review of the opinion of all my predecessor and of the legislative history of the country do not indicate any fix rule by which to decide what of the infinite variety of possible river and harbor improvement be within the scope of the power delegate by the constitution and the question still remain unsettled president jackson concede the constitutionality under suitable circumstance of the improvement of river and harbor through the agency of congress and president polk admit the propriety of the establishment and support by appropriation from the treasury of light house beacon buoy and other improvement within the bay inlet and harbor of the ocean and lake coast immediately connect with foreign commerce
 but if the distinction thus make rest upon the difference between foreign and domestic commerce it can not be restrict thereby to the bay inlet and harbor of the ocean and lake because foreign commerce have already penetrate thousand of mile into the interior of the continent by mean of our great river and will continue so to extend itself with the progress of settlement until it reach the limit of navigability
 at the time of the adoption of the constitution the vast valley of the mississippi now teem with population and supply almost boundless resource be literally an unexplored wilderness our advancement have outstrip even the most sanguine anticipation of the father of the republic and it illustrate the fact that no rule be admissible which undertake to discriminate so far as regard river and harbor improvement between the atlantic or pacific coast and the great lake and river of the interior region of north america indeed it be quite erroneous to suppose that any such discrimination have ever exist in the practice of the government to the contrary of which be the significant fact before state that when after abstain from all such appropriation for more than thirty year congress enter upon the policy of improve the navigation of river and harbor it commence with the river mississippi and ohio
 the congress of the union adopt in this respect one of the idea of that of the confederation have take heed to declare from time to time as occasion require either in act for dispose of the public land in the territories or in act for admit new states that all navigable river within the same shall be deem to be and remain public highway
 out of this condition of thing arise a question which at successive period of our public annal have occupy the attention of the good mind in the union this question be what water be public navigable water so as not to be of state character and jurisdiction but of federal jurisdiction and character in the intent of the constitution and of congress a proximate but imperfect answer to this important question be furnish by the act of congress and the decision of the supreme court of the united states define the constitutional limit of the maritime jurisdiction of the general government that jurisdiction be entirely independent of the revenue power it be not derive from that nor be it measure thereby
 in that act of congress which in the first year of the government organize our judicial system and which whether we look to the subject the comprehensive wisdom with which it be treat or the deference with which its provision have come to be regard be only second to the constitution itself there be a section in which the statesman who frame the constitution have place on record their construction of it in this matte it enact that the district court of the united states shall have exclusive cognizance of all civil case of admiralty and maritime jurisdiction include all seizure under the law of impost navigation or trade of the united states when the seizure be make on water which be navigable from the sea by vessel of 10 or more ton burden within their respective district as well as upon the high sea in this contemporaneous exposition of the constitution there be no trace or suggestion that nationality of jurisdiction be limit to the sea or even to tide water the law be mark by a sagacious apprehension of the fact that the great lakes and the mississippi be navigable water of the united states even then before the acquisition of louisiana have make wholly our own the territorial greatness of the west it repudiate unequivocally the rule of the common law accord to which the question of whether a water be public navigable water or not depend on whether it be salt or not and therefore in a river confine that quality to tide water a rule result from the geographical condition of england and applicable to an island with small and narrow stream the only navigable portion of which for ship be in immediate contact with the ocean but wholly inapplicable to the great inland fresh water sea of america and its mighty river with secondary branch exceed in magnitude the large river of great britain
 at a late period it be true that in disregard of the more comprehensive definition of navigability afford by that act of congress it be for a time hold by many that the rule establish for england be to be receive in the united states the effect of which be to exclude from the jurisdiction of the general government not only the water of the mississippi but also those of the great lakes to this construction it be with truth object that in so far as concern the lake they be in fact sea although of fresh water that they be the natural marine communication between a series of populous states and between they and the possession of a foreign nation that they be actually navigate by ship of commerce of the large capacity that they have once be and might again be the scene of foreign war and that therefore it be do violence to all reason to undertake by mean of an arbitrary doctrine of technical foreign law to exclude such water from the jurisdiction of the general government in regard to the river mississippi it be object that to draw a line across that river at the point of ebb and flood of tide and say that the part below be public navigable water and the part above not while in the latter the water be at least equally deep and navigable and its commerce as rich as in the former with numerous port of foreign entry and delivery be to sanction a distinction artificial and unjust because regardless of the real fact of navigability
 we may conceive that some such consideration lead to the enactment in the year 1845 of an act in addition to that of 1789 declare that--
 the district court of the united states shall have possess and exercise the same jurisdiction in matter of contract and tort arise in upon or concern steamboat and other vessel of 20 ton burden and upward enrol and license for the coast trade and at the time employ in business of commerce and navigation between port and place in different states and territories upon the lake and navigable water connect say lake as be now possess and exercise by the say court in case of the like steamboat and other vessel employ in navigation and commerce upon the high sea or tide water within the admiralty and maritime jurisdiction of the united states
 it be observable that the act of 1789 apply the jurisdiction of the united states to all water which be navigable from the sea for vessel of 10 ton burden and that of 1845 extend the jurisdiction to enrol vessel of 20 ton burden on the lake and navigable water connect say lake though not water navigable from the sea provide such vessel be employ between place in different states and territories
 thus it appear that these provision of law in effect prescribe condition by which to determine whether any water be public navigable water subject to the authority of the federal government the condition include all water whether salt or fresh and whether of sea lake or river provide they be capable of navigation by vessel of a certain tonnage and for commerce either between the united states and foreign country or between any two or more of the states or territories of the union this exclude water wholly within any particular state and not use as the mean of commercial communication with any other state and subject to be improve or obstruct at will by the state within which it may happen to be
 the constitutionality of these provision of statute have be call in question their constitutionality have be maintain however by repeat decision of the supreme court of the united states and they be therefore the law of the land by the concurrent act of the legislative the executive and the judicial department of the government regard as afford a criterion of what be navigable water and as such subject to the maritime jurisdiction of the supreme court and of congress these act be objectionable in this that the rule of navigability be an arbitrary one that congress may repeal the present rule and adopt a new one and that thus a legislative definition will be able to restrict or enlarge the limit of constitutional power yet this variableness of standard seem inherent in the nature of thing at any rate neither the first congress compose of the statesman of the era when the constitution be adopt nor any subsequent congress have afford we the mean of attain great precision of construction as to this part of the constitution
 this reflection may serve to relieve from undeserved reproach an idea of one of the great man of the republic president jackson he seek amid all the difficulty of the subject for some practical rule of action in regard to appropriation for the improvement of river and harbor prescribe for his own official conduct the rule of confine such appropriation to place below the port of entry or delivery establish by law he see clearly as the author of the above mention act of 1789 and 1845 do that there be no inflexible natural line of discrimination between what be national and what local by mean of which to determine absolutely and unerringly at what point on a river the jurisdiction of the united states shall end he perceive and of course admit that the constitution while confer on the general government some power of action to render navigation safe and easy have of necessity leave to congress much of discretion in this matter he confide in the patriotism of congress to exercise that discretion wisely not permit himself to suppose it possible that a port of entry or delivery would ever be establish by law for the express and only purpose of evade the constitution
 it remain therefore to consider the question of the measure of discretion in the exercise by congress of the power to provide for the improvement of river and harbor and also that of the legitimate responsibility of the executive in the same relation
 in matter of legislation of the most unquestionable constitutionality it be always material to consider what amount of public money shall be appropriate for any particular object the same consideration apply with augmented force to a class of appropriation which be in their nature peculiarly prone to run to excess and which be make in the exercise of incidental power have intrinsic tendency to overstep the bound of constitutionality
 if an appropriation for improve the navigability of a river or deepen or protect a harbor have reference to military or naval purpose then its rightfulness whether in amount or in the object to which it be apply depend manifestly on the military or naval exigency and the subject matter afford its own measure of legislative discretion but if the appropriation for such an object have no distinct relation to the military or naval want of the country and be wholly or even mainly intend to promote the revenue from commerce then the very vagueness of the propose purpose of the expenditure constitute a perpetual admonition of reserve and caution through disregard of this it be undeniable that in many case appropriation of this nature have be make unwisely without accomplish beneficial result commensurate with the cost and sometimes for evil rather than good independently of their dubious relation to the constitution
 among the radical change of the course of legislation in these matter which in my judgment the public interest demand one be a return to the primitive idea of congress which require in this class of public work as in all other a conveyance of the soil and a cession of the jurisdiction to the united states i think this condition ought never to have be waive in the case of any harbor improvement of a permanent nature as where pier jetty sea wall and other like work be to be construct and maintain it would powerfully tend to counteract endeavor to obtain appropriation of a local character and chiefly calculate to promote individual interest the want of such a provision be the occasion of abuse in regard to exist work expose they to private encroachment without sufficient mean of redress by law indeed the absence in such case of a cession of jurisdiction have constitute one of the constitutional objection to appropriation of this class it be not easy to perceive any sufficient reason for require it in the case of arsenal or fort which do not equally apply to all other public work if to be construct and maintain by congress in the exercise of a constitutional power of appropriation they should be bring within the jurisdiction of the united states
 there be another measure of precaution in regard to such appropriation which seem to i to be worthy of the consideration of congress it be to make appropriation for every work in a separate bill so that each one shall stand on its own independent merit and if it pass shall do so under circumstance of legislative scrutiny entitle it to be regard as of general interest and a proper subject of charge on the treasury of the union
 during that period of time in which the country have not come to look to congress for appropriation of this nature several of the states whose production or geographical position invite foreign commerce have enter upon plan for the improvement of their harbor by themselves and through mean of support draw directly from that commerce in virtue of an express constitutional power need for its exercise only the permission of congress harbor improvement thus construct and maintain the expenditure upon they be defray by the very facility they afford be a voluntary charge on those only who see fit to avail themselves of such facility and can be justly complain of by none on the other hand so long as these improvement be carry on by appropriation from the treasury the benefit will continue to inure to those alone who enjoy the facility afford while the expenditure will be a burden upon the whole country and the discrimination a double injury to place equally require improvement but not equally favor by appropriation
 these consideration add to the embarrassment of the whole question amply suffice to suggest the policy of confine appropriation by the general government to work necessary to the execution of its undoubted power and of leave all other to individual enterprise or to the separate states to be provide for out of their own resource or by recurrence to the provision of the constitution which authorize the states to lay duty of tonnage with the consent of congress

fellow citizen of the senate and of the house of representatives the constitution of the united states provide that congress shall assemble annually on the first monday of december and it have be usual for the president to make no communication of a public character to the senate and house of representatives until advise of their readiness to receive it i have defer to this usage until the close of the first month of the session but my conviction of duty will not permit i long to postpone the discharge of the obligation enjoin by the constitution upon the president to give to the congress information of the state of the union and recommend to their consideration such measure as he shall judge necessary and expedient it be matter of congratulation that the republic be tranquilly advance in a career of prosperity and peace whilst relation of amity continue to exist between the united states and all foreign power with some of they grave question be depend which may require the consideration of congress of such question the most important be that which have arise out of the negotiation with great britain in reference to central america by the convention conclude between the two government on the 19th of april 1850 both party covenant that neither will ever occupy or fortify or colonize or assume or exercise any dominion over nicaragua costa rica the mosquito coast or any part of central america "it be the undoubted understanding of the united states in make this treaty that all the present states of the former republic of central america and the entire territory of each would thenceforth enjoy complete independence and that both contract party engage equally and to the same extent for the present and for the future that if either then have any claim of right in central america such claim and all occupation or authority under it be unreservedly relinquish by the stipulation of the convention and that no dominion be thereafter to be exercise or assume in any part of central america by great britain or the united states this government consent to restriction in regard to a region of country wherein we have specific and peculiar interest only upon the conviction that the like restriction be in the same sense obligatory on great britain but for this understanding of the force and effect of the convention it would never have be conclude by we so clear be this understanding on the part of the united states that in correspondence contemporaneous with the ratification of the convention it be distinctly express that the mutual covenant of nonoccupation be not intend to apply to the british establishment at the balize this qualification be to be ascribe to the fact that in virtue of successive treaty with previous sovereign of the country great britain have obtain a concession of the right to cut mahogany or dyewood at the balize but with positive exclusion of all domain or sovereignty and thus it confirm the natural construction and understand import of the treaty as to all the rest of the region to which the stipulation apply it however become apparent at an early day after enter upon the discharge of my present function that great britain still continue in the exercise or assertion of large authority in all that part of central america commonly call the mosquito coast and cover the entire length of the state of nicaragua and a part of costa rica that she regard the balize as her absolute domain and be gradually extend its limit at the expense of the state of honduras and that she have formally colonize a considerable insular group know as the bay islands and belong of right to that state all these act or pretension of great britain be contrary to the right of the states of central america and to the instruction to he on the subject and the correspondence between he and the british secretary for foreign affair by which you will perceive that the two government differ widely and irreconcilably as the mosquito coast and in different part of central america these pretension as to the mosquito coast be found on the assumption of political relation between great britain and the remnant of a tribe of indians on that coast enter into at a time when the whole country be a colonial possession of spain it can not be successfully controvert that by the public law of europe and america no possible the contrary by repeat and successive treaty renounce and relinquish all pretension of her own and recognize the full and sovereign right of spain in the most unequivocal term yet these pretension so without solid foundation in the beginning and thus repeatedly abjure be at a recent period revive by great britain against the central american states the legitimate successor to all the ancient jurisdiction of spain in that region they be first apply only to a define part of the coast of nicaragua afterwards to the whole of its atlantic coast and lastly to a part of the coast of costa rica and they be now reassert to this extent notwithstanding engagement to the united states on the eastern coast of nicaragua and costa rica the interference of great britain though exert at one time in the protectorship of the mosquito indians the extended jurisdiction and limit of the balize and the colony of the bay islands and thereupon proceed by implication to infer that if the stipulation of many tie of interest and kindre it have appear to i proper not to consider an amicable solution of the controversy hopeless there be however reason to apprehend that with great britain in the actual occupation of the dispute territory and the treaty therefore practically null so far as regard our right this international difficulty can not long remain undetermined without involve in serious danger the friendly relation which it be the interest as well as the duty of both country to cherish and preserve it will afford i sincere gratification if future effort shall result in the success anticipate heretofore with more confidence than the aspect of the case permit i now to entertain one other subject of discussion between the united states and great britain have grow out of the attempt which the exigency of the war in which she be engage with russia induce she to make to draw recruit from the united states it be the traditional and settle policy of the united states to maintain impartial neutrality during the war which from time to time occur among the great power of the world perform all the duty of neutrality toward the respective belligerent state we may reasonably expect they not to interfere with our lawful enjoyment of its benefit notwithstanding the existence of such hostility our citizen retain the individual right to continue all their accustomed pursuit by land or by sea at home or abroad subject only to such restriction in this relation as the law of war the usage of nation or special treaty may impose and it be our sovereign right that our territory and jurisdiction shall not be invade by either of the belligerent party for the transit of their army the operation of their fleet the levy of troop for their service the fitting out of cruiser by or against either or any other act or incident of war and these undeniable right of neutrality individual and national the united states will under no circumstance surrender in pursuance of this policy the law of the united states do not forbid their citizen to sell to either of the belligerent power article contraband of war or take munition of war or soldier on board their private ship for transportation and although in so do the individual citizen expose his property or person to some of the hazard of war his act do not involve any breach of national neutrality nor of themselves implicate the government thus during the progress of the present war in europe our citizen have without national responsibility therefor sell gunpowder and arm to all buyer regardless of the destination of those article our merchantman have be and still continue to be largely employ by great britain and by france in transport troop provision and munition of war to the principal seat of military operation and in bring home their sick and wounded soldier but such use of our mercantile marine be not interdict either by the international or by our municipal law and therefore do not compromise our neutral relation with russia but our municipal law in accordance with the law of nation peremptorily forbid not only foreigner but our own citizen to fit out within the united states a vessel to commit hostility against any state with which the united states be at peace or to increase the force of any foreign armed vessel intend for such hostility against a friendly state whatever concern may have be feel by either of the belligerent power lest private armed cruiser or other vessel in the service of one might be fit out in the port of this country to depredate on the property of the other all such fear have prove to be utterly groundless our citizen have be withhold from any such act or purpose by good faith and by respect for the law while the law of the union be thus peremptory in their prohibition of the equipment or armament of belligerent cruiser in our port they provide not less absolutely that no person shall within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states enlist or enter himself or hire or retain another person to enlist or enter himself or to go beyond the limit or jurisdiction of the united states with intent to be enlist or enter in the service of any foreign state either as a soldier or as a marine or seaman on board of any vessel of war letter of marque or privateer and these enactment be also in strict conformity with the law of nation which declare that no state have the right to raise troop for land or sea service in another state without its consent and that whether forbid by the municipal law or not the very attempt to do it without such consent be an attack on the national sovereignty such be the public right and the municipal law of the united states no solicitude on the subject be entertain by this government when a year since the british parliament pass an act to provide for the enlistment of foreigner in the military service of great britain nothing on the face of the act or in its public extensively with little or no disguise ordinary legal step be immediately take to arrest and punish party concern and so put an end to act infringe the municipal law and derogatory to our sovereignty this country originate with it or at least have its approval and sanction but it also appear that the public agent engage in it bad stringent instruction not to violate the municipal law of the united to i desirable and useful to bring to the special notice of congress unlike the great states of europe and asia and many of those of america these united states be waste their strength neither in
