fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives in obedience to the command of the constitution it have now become my duty to give to congress information of the state of the union and recommend to their consideration such measure as i judge to be necessary and expedient "but first and above all our thank be due to almighty god for the numerous benefit which he have bestow upon this people and our united prayer ought to ascend to he that he would continue to bless our great republic in time to come as he have bless it in time past since the adjournment of the last congress our constituent have enjoy an unusual degree of health the earth have yield her fruit abundantly and have bountifully reward the toil of the husbandman our great staple have command high price and up till within a brief period our manufacturing mineral and mechanical occupation have largely partake of the general prosperity we have possess all the element of material wealth in rich abundance and yet notwithstanding all these advantage our country in its monetary interest be at the present moment in a deplorable condition in the midst of unsurpassed plenty in all the production of agriculture and in all the element of national wealth we find our manufacture suspend our public work retard our private enterprise of different kind abandon and thousand of useful laborer throw out of employment and reduce to want the revenue of the government which be chiefly derive from duty on import from abroad have be greatly reduce whilst the appropriation make by congress at its last session for the current fiscal year be very large in amount under these circumstance a loan may be require before the close of your present session but this although deeply to be regret would prove to be only a slight misfortune when compare with the suffering and distress prevail among the people with this the government can not fail deeply to sympathize though it may be without the power to extend relief it be our duty to inquire what have produce such unfortunate result and whether their recurrence can be prevent in all former revulsion the blame might have be fairly attribute to a variety of cooperate cause but not so upon the present occasion it be apparent that our exist misfortune have proceed solely from our extravagant and vicious system of paper currency and bank credit excite the people to wild speculation and gambling in stock these revulsion must continue to recur at successive interval so long as the amount of the paper currency and bank loan and discount of the country shall be leave to the discretion of 1,400 irresponsible banking institution which from the very law of their nature will consult the interest of their stockholder rather than the public welfare the framer of the constitution when they give to congress the power to coin money and to regulate the value thereof and prohibit the states from coin money emit bill of credit or make anything but gold and silver coin a tender in payment of debt suppose they have protect the people against the evil of an excessive and irredeemable paper currency they be not responsible for the exist anomaly that a government endow with the sovereign attribute of coin money and regulate the value thereof should have no power to prevent other from drive this coin out of the country and fill up the channel of circulation with paper which do not represent gold and silver it be one of the high and most responsible duty of government to insure to the people a sound circulate medium the amount of which ought to be adapt with the utmost possible wisdom and skill to the want of internal trade and foreign exchange if this be either greatly above or greatly below the proper standard the marketable value of every man 's property be increase or diminish in the same proportion and injustice to individual as well as incalculable evil to the community be the consequence unfortunately under the construction of the federal constitution which have now prevail too long to be change this important and delicate duty have be dissever from the coin power and virtually transfer to more than 1,400 state bank act independently of each other and regulate their paper issue almost exclusively by a regard to the present interest of their stockholder exercise the sovereign power of provide a paper currency instead of coin for the country the first duty which these bank owe to the public be to keepin their vault a sufficient amount of gold and silver to insure the convertibility of their note into coin at all time and under all circumstance no bank ought ever to be charter without such restriction on its business as to secure this result all other restriction be comparatively vain this be the only true touchstone the only efficient regulator of a paper currency the only one which can guard the public against overissue and bank suspension as a collateral and eventual security it be doubtless wise and in all case ought to be require that bank shall hold an amount of united states or state security equal to their note in circulation and pledge for their redemption this however furnish no adequate security against overissue on the contrary it may be pervert to inflate the currency indeed it be possible by this mean to convert all the debt of the united states and state governments into bank note without reference to the specie require to redeem they however valuable these security may be in themselves they can not be convert into gold and silver at the moment of pressure as our experience teach in sufficient time to prevent bank suspension and the depreciation of bank note in england which be to a considerable extent a paper money country though vastly behind our own in this respect it be deem advisable anterior to the act of parliament of 1844 which wisely separate the issue of note from the banking department for the bank of england always to keep on hand gold and silver equal to one third of its combine circulation and deposit if this proportion be no more than sufficient to secure the convertibility of its note with the whole of great britain and to some extent the continent of europe as a field for its circulation render it almost impossible that a sudden and immediate run to a dangerous amount should be make upon it the same proportion would certainly be insufficient under our banking system each of our 1,400 bank have but a limited circumference for its circulation and in the course of a very few day the depositor and note holder might demand from such a bank a sufficient amount in specie to compel it to suspend even although it have coin in its vault equal to one third of its immediate liability and yet i be not aware with the exception of the bank of louisiana that any state bank throughout the union have be require by its charter to keep this or any other proportion of gold and silver compare with the amount of its combine circulation and deposit what have be the consequence in a recent report make by the treasury department on the condition of the bank throughout the different state accord to return date near to january 1857 the aggregate amount of actual specie in their vault be $ 58,349,838 of their circulation $ 214,778,822 and of their deposit $ 230,351,352 thus it appear that these bank in the aggregate have considerably less than one dollar in seven of gold and silver compare with their circulation and deposit it be palpable therefore that the very first pressure must drive they to suspension and deprive the people of a convertible currency with all its disastrous consequence it be truly wonderful that they should have so long continue to preserve their credit when a demand for the payment of one seventh of their immediate liability would have drive they into insolvency and this be the condition of the bank notwithstanding that four hundred million of gold from california have flow in upon we within the last eight year and the tide still continue to flow indeed such have be the extravagance of bank credit that the bank now hold a considerably less amount of specie either in proportion to their capital or to their circulation and deposit combine than they do before the discovery of gold in california whilst in the year 1848 their specie in proportion to their capital be more than equal to one dollar for four and a half in 1857 it do not amount to one dollar for every six dollar and thirty three cent of their capital in the year 1848 the specie be equal within a very small fraction to one dollar in five of their circulation and deposit in 1857 it be not equal to one dollar in seven and a half of their circulation and deposit from this statement it be easy to account for our financial history for the last forty year it have be a history of extravagant expansion in the business of the country follow by ruinous contraction at successive interval the good and most enterprising man have be tempt to their ruin by excessive bank loan of mere paper credit excite they to extravagant importation of foreign good wild speculation and ruinous and demoralize stock gambling when the crisis arrive as arrive it must the bank can extend no relief to the people in a vain struggle to redeem their liability in specie they be compel to contract their loan and their issue and at last in the hour of distress when their assistance be most need they and their debtor together sink into insolvency it be this paper system of extravagant expansion raise the nominal price of every article far beyond its real value when compare with the cost of similar article in country whose circulation be wisely regulate which have prevent we from compete in our own market with foreign manufacturer have produce extravagant importation and have counteract the effect of the large incidental protection afford to our domestic manufacture by the present revenue tariff but for this the branch of our manufacture compose of raw material the production of our own country such as cotton iron and woolen fabric would not only have acquire almost exclusive possession of the home market but would have create for themselves a foreign market throughout the world deplorable however as may be our present financial condition we may yet indulge in bright hope for the future no other nation have ever exist which could have endure such violent expansion and contraction of paper credit without last injury yet the buoyancy of youth the energy of our population and the spirit which never quail before difficulty will enable we soon to recover from our present financial embarrassment and may even occasion we speedily to forget the lesson which they have teach in the meantime it be the duty of the government by all proper mean within its power to aid in alleviate the suffering of the people occasion by the suspension of the bank and to provide against a recurrence of the same calamity unfortunately in either aspect of the ease it can do but little thank to the independent treasury the government have not suspend payment as it be compel to do by the failure of the bank in 1837 it will continue to discharge its liability to the people in gold and silver its disbursement in coin will pass into circulation and materially assist in restore a sound currency from its high credit should we be compel to make a temporary loan it can be effect on advantageous term this however shall if possible be avoid but if not then the amount shall be limit to the low practicable sum i have therefore determine that whilst no useful government work already in progress shall be suspend new work not already commence will be postpone if this can be do without injury to the country those necessary for its defense shall proceed as though there have be no crisis in our monetary affair but the federal government can not do much to provide against a recurrence of exist evil even if insurmountable constitutional objection do not exist against the creation of a national bank this would furnish no adequate preventive security the history of the last bank of the united states abundantly prove the truth of this assertion such a bank could not if it would regulate the issue and credit of 1,400 state bank in such a manner as to prevent the ruinous expansion and contraction in our currency which afflict the country throughout the existence of the late bank or secure we against future suspension in 1825 an effort be make by the bank of england to curtail the issue of the country bank under the most favorable circumstance the paper currency have be expand to a ruinous extent and the bank put forth all its power to contract it in order to reduce price and restore the equilibrium of the foreign exchange it accordingly commence a system of curtailment of its loan and issue in the vain hope that the joint stock and private bank of the kingdom would be compel to follow its example it find however that as it contract they expand and at the end of the process to employ the language of a very high official authority whatever reduction of the paper circulation be effect by the bank of england in 1825 be more than make up by the issue of the country bank "but a bank of the united states would not if it could restrain the issue and loan of the state bank because its duty as a regulator of the currency must often be in direct conflict with the immediate interest of its stockholder if we expect one agent to restrain or control another their interest must at least in some degree be antagonistic but the director of a bank of the united states would feel the same interest and the same inclination with the director of the state bank to expand the currency to accommodate their favorite and friend with loan and to declare large dividend such have be our experience in regard to the last bank after all we must mainly rely upon the patriotism and wisdom of the states for the prevention and redress of the evil if they will afford we a real specie basis for our paper circulation by increase the denomination of bank note first to twenty and afterwards to fifty dollar if they will require that the bank shall at all time keep on hand at least one dollar of gold and silver for every three dollar of their circulation and deposit and if they will provide by a self execute enactment which nothing can arrest that the moment they suspend they shall go into liquidation i believe that such provision with a weekly publication by each bank of a statement of its condition would go far to secure we against future suspension of specie payment congress in my opinion possess the power to pass a uniform bankrupt law applicable to all banking institution throughout the united states and i strongly recommend its exercise this would make it the irreversible organic law of each bank 's existence that a suspension of specie payment shall produce its civil death the instinct of self preservation would then compel it to perform its duty in such a manner as to escape the penalty and preserve its life the existence of bank and the circulation of bank paper be so identify with the habit of our people that they can not at this day be suddenly abolish without much immediate injury to the country if we could confine they to their appropriate sphere and prevent they from administer to the spirit of wild and reckless speculation by extravagant loan and issue they might be continue with advantage to the public but this i say after long and much reflection if experience shall prove it to be impossible to enjoy the facility which well regulate bank might afford without at the same time suffer the calamity which the excess of the bank have hitherto inflict upon the country it would then be far the less evil to deprive they altogether of the power to issue a paper currency and confine they to the function of bank of deposit and discount our relation with foreign government be upon the whole in a satisfactory condition the diplomatic difficulty which exist between the government of the united states and that of great britain at the adjournment of the the convention of april 19 1850 commonly call the clayton and bulwer treaty have be the most unfortunate of all because the two government place directly opposite and contradictory construction upon its first and most important article whilst in the united states we believe that this treaty would place both power upon an exact equality by the stipulation that neither will ever occupy or fortify or colonize or assume or exercise any dominion over any part of central america it be contend by the british government that the true construction of this language have leave they in the rightful possession of all that portion of central america which be in their occupancy at the date of the treaty in fact that the treaty be a virtual recognition on the part of the united states of the right adjacent bay islands except the comparatively small portion of this between the sarstoon and cape honduras accord to their construction the treaty do no more than simply prohibit they from extend whether this important domestic institution should or should not continue to exist indeed this be the only possible mode in which their will could be authentically ascertain the election of delegate to a convention must necessarily take place in separate district from this cause it may readily happen as have often be the case that a majority of the people of a state or territory be on one side of small majority whilst in other those of different sentiment may receive majority sufficiently great not only to overcome the vote give for the former but to leave a large majority of the whole people constituent the truth be that no other authentic and satisfactory mode exist of ascertain the will of a majority of the people of any state or territory on an important and exciting question like that of slavery in kansas except by leave it to a direct vote how wise then be it for congress to pass over all subordinate and intermediate agency and proceed directly to the source of all legitimate power under our institutions!how vain would any other principle prove in practice this may be illustrate by the case of kansas should she be admit into the union with a constitution either maintain or practice of the old states of the union which have abolish slavery a territorial government be establish for utah by act of congress approve the 9th september 1850 and the constitution and law of the little doubt that such be his determination without enter upon a minute history of occurrence it be sufficient to say that all the officer of the united states judicial and executive with the single exception of two indian agent have find it necessary for their own personal safety to withdraw from the territory and there no long remain any government in utah but the despotism of brigham young this be the condition of affair in the territory i could not mistake the path of duty as chief executive magistrate i be bind to restore the supremacy of the constitution and law within its limit in order to effect this purpose i appoint a new governor and other federal officer for utah and send with they a military force for their protection and to aid as a posse comitatus in case of need in the execution of the law with the religious opinion of the mormons as long as they remain mere opinion however deplorable in themselves and revolt to the moral and religious sentiment of all christendom i have no right to interfere action alone when in violation of the constitution and law of the united states become the legitimate subject for the jurisdiction of the civil magistrate my instruction to governor cumming have therefore be frame in strict accordance with these principle at their date a hope be indulge that no necessity might exist for employ the military in restore and maintain the authority of the law but this hope have now vanish governor young have by proclamation declare his determination to maintain his power by force and have already commit act of hostility against the united states unless he should retrace his step the territory of utah will be in a state of open rebellion he have commit these act of hostility notwithstanding major van vliet an officer of the army send to utah by the commanding general to purchase provision for the troop have give he the strong assurance of the peaceful intention of the government and that the troop would only be employ as a posse comitatus when call on by the civil authority to aid in the execution of the law there be reason to believe that governor young have long contemplate this result he know that the continuance of his despotic power depend upon the exclusion of all settler from the territory except those who will acknowledge his divine mission and implicitly obey his will and that an enlightened public opinion there would soon prostrate institution at war with the law both of god and man he have therefore for several year in order to maintain his independence be industriously employ in collect and fabricate arm and munition of war and in discipline the mormon for military service as superintendent of indian affair he have have an opportunity of tamper with the indian tribe and excite their hostile feeling against the united states this accord to our information he have accomplish in regard to some of these tribe while other have remain true to their allegiance and have communicate his intrigue to our indian agent he have lay in a store of provision for three year which in case of necessity as he inform major van vliet he will conceal and then take to the mountain and bid defiance to all the power of the government "a great part of all this may be idle boasting but yet no wise government will lightly estimate the effort which may be inspire by such frenzied fanaticism as exist among the mormons in utah this be the first rebellion which have exist in our territories and humanity itself require that we should put it down in such a manner that it shall be the last to trifle with it would be to encourage it and to render it formidable we ought to go there with such an impose force as to convince these delude people that resistance would be vain and thus spare the effusion of blood we can in this manner good convince they that we be their friend not their enemy in order to accomplish this object it will be necessary accord to the estimate of the war department to raise four additional regiment and this i earnestly recommend to congress at the present moment of depression in the revenue of the country i be sorry to be oblige to recommend such a measure but i feel confident of the support of congress cost what it may in suppress the insurrection and in restore and maintain the sovereignty of the constitution and law over the territory of utah i recommend to congress the establishment of a territorial government over arizona incorporate with it such portion of new mexico as they may deem expedient i need scarcely adduce argument in support of this recommendation we be bind to protect the life and the property of our citizen inhabit arizona and these be now without any efficient protection their present number be already considerable and be rapidly increase notwithstanding the disadvantage under which they labor besides the propose territory be believe to be rich in mineral and agricultural resource especially in silver and copper the mail of the united states to california be now carry over it throughout its whole extent and this route be know to be the near and believe to be the good to the pacific long experience have deeply convince i that a strict construction of the power grant to congress be the only true as well as the only safe theory of the constitution whilst this principle shall guide my public conduct i consider it clear that under the war make power congress may appropriate money for the construction of a military road through the territories of the united states when this be absolutely necessary for the defense of any of the states against foreign invasion the constitution have confer upon congress power to declare war to raise and support army to provide and maintain a navy and to call forth the militia to repel invasion these high sovereign power necessarily involve important and responsible public duty and among they there be none so sacred and so imperative as that of preserve our soil from the invasion of a foreign enemy the constitution have therefore leave nothing on this point to construction but expressly require that the united states shall protect each of they the states against invasion now if a military road over our own territories be indispensably necessary to enable we to meet and repel the invader it follow as a necessary consequence not only that we possess the power but it be our imperative duty to construct such a road it would be an absurdity to invest a government with the unlimited power to make and conduct war and at the same time deny to it the only mean of reach and defeat the enemy at the frontier without such a road it be quite evident we can not protect california and our pacific possession against invasion we can not by any other mean transport man and munition of war from the atlantic states in sufficient time successfully to defend these remote and distant portion of the republic experience have prove that the route across the isthmus of central america be at good but a very uncertain and unreliable mode of communication but even if this be not the case they would at once be close against we in the event of war with a naval power so much strong than our own as to enable it to blockade the port at either end of these route after all therefore we can only rely upon a military road through our own territories and ever since the origin of the government congress have be in the practice of appropriate money from the public treasury for the construction of such road the difficulty and the expense of construct a military railroad to connect our atlantic and pacific states have be greatly exaggerated the distance on the arizona route near the thirty second parallel of north latitude between the western boundary of texas on the rio grande and the eastern boundary of california on the colorado from the good exploration now within our knowledge do not exceed 470 mile and the face of the country be in the main favorable for obvious reason the government ought not to undertake the work itself by mean of its own agent this ought to be commit to other agency which congress might assist either by grant of land or money or by both upon such term and condition as they may deem most beneficial for the country provision might thus be make not only for the safe rapid and economical transportation of troop and munition of war but also of the public mail the commercial interest of the whole country both east and west would be greatly promote by such a road and above all it would be a powerful additional bond of union and although advantage of this kind whether postal commercial or political can not confer constitutional power yet they may furnish auxiliary argument in favor of expedite a work which in my judgment be clearly embrace within the war make power for these reason i commend to the friendly consideration of congress the subject of the pacific railroad without finally commit myself to any they as almost indispensable ten of these small vessel would be of incalculable advantage to the naval service and the whole cost of their construction would not exceed $ 2,300,000 or $ 230,000 each the report of the secretary of the interior be worthy of grave consideration it treat of the numerous important and diversified branch of domestic administration intrust to he by law among these the most prominent be the public land and our relation with the indians our system for the disposal of the public land originate with the father of the republic have be improve as experience point the way still more than a thousand million of acre remain unsold what a boundless prospect this present to our country of future prosperity and power!we have heretofore dispose of 363,862,464 acre of the public land whilst the public land as a source of revenue be of great importance their importance be far great as furnish home for a hardy and independent race of honest and industrious citizen who individual and company and thus the price be greatly enhance to those who desire to purchase for actual settlement in order to limit the area of speculation as much as possible the extinction of the indian title and the extension of the public survey ought only to keep pace with the tide of emigration if congress should hereafter grant alternate section to states or company as they have do those emigrate to our distant states and territories hence expensive military expedition be frequently necessary to overawe and chastise the more lawless and hostile the present system of make they valuable present to influence they to remain at peace have prove ineffectual it be believe to be the well policy to colonize they in suitable locality where they can receive the rudiment of education select with my full concurrence as the one in my judgment well calculate to attain the important object contemplate by congress the late disastrous monetary revulsion may have one good effect should  i have receive from j. calhoun esq president of the late constitutional convention of kansas a copy duly certify by himself of the constitution frame by that body with the expression of a hope that i would submit the same to the consideration of congress with the view of the admission of kansas into the union as an independent state in compliance with this request i herewith transmit to congress for their action the constitution of kansas with the ordinance respect the public land as well as the letter of mr. calhoun date at lecompton on the 14th ultimo by which they be accompany having receive but a single copy of the constitution and ordinance i send this to the senate
 a great delusion seem to pervade the public mind in relation to the condition of party in kansas this arise from the difficulty of induce the american people to realize the fact that any portion of they should be in a state of rebellion against the government under which they live when we speak of the affair of kansas we be apt to refer merely to the existence of two violent political party in that territory divide on the question of slavery just as we speak of such party in the states this present no adequate idea of the true state of the case the dividing line there be not between two political party both acknowledge the lawful existence of the government but between those who be loyal to this government and those who have endeavor to destroy its existence by force and by usurpation between those who sustain and those who have do all in their power to overthrow the territorial government establish by congress this government they would long since have subvert have it not be protect from their assault by the troop of the united states such have be the condition of affair since my inauguration ever since that period a large portion of the people of kansas have be in a state of rebellion against the government with a military leader at their head of a most turbulent and dangerous character they have never acknowledge but have constantly renounce and defy the government to which they owe allegiance and have be all the time in a state of resistance against its authority they have all the time be endeavor to subvert it and to establish a revolutionary government under the so call topeka constitution in its stead even at this very moment the topeka legislature be in session whoever have read the correspondence of governor walker with the state department recently communicate to the senate will be convince that this picture be not overdrawn he always protest against the withdrawal of any portion of the military force of the united states from the territory deem its presence absolutely necessary for the preservation of the regular government and the execution of the law in his very first dispatch to the secretary of state date june 2 1857 he say
 the most alarming movement however proceed from the assembling on the 9th june of the so call topeka legislature with a view to the enactment of an entire code of law of course it will be my endeavor to prevent such a result as it would lead to inevitable and disastrous collision and in fact renew the civil war in kansas
 this be with difficulty prevent by the effort of governor walker but soon thereafter on the 14th of july we find he request general harney to furnish he a regiment of dragoon to proceed to the city of lawrence and this for the reason that he have receive authentic intelligence verify by his own actual observation that a dangerous rebellion have occur involve an open defiance of the law and the establishment of an insurgent government in that city
 in the governor&#39;s dispatch of july 15 he inform the secretary of state that--
 this movement at lawrence be the beginning of a plan originate in that city to organize insurrection throughout the territory and especially in all town city or county where the republican party have a majority lawrence be the hotbed of all the abolition movement in this territory it be the town establish by the abolition society of the east and whilst there be respectable people there it be fill by a considerable number of mercenary who be pay by abolition society to perpetuate and diffuse agitation throughout kansas and prevent a peaceful settlement of this question having fail in induce their own so call topeka state legislature to organize this insurrection lawrence have commence it herself and if not arrest the rebellion will extend throughout the territory
 and again
 in order to send this communication immediately by mail i must close by assure you that the spirit of rebellion pervade the great mass of the republican party of this territory instigate as i entertain no doubt they be by eastern society have in view result most disastrous to the government and to the union and that the continued presence of general harney here be indispensable as originally stipulate by i with a large body of dragoon and several battery
 on the 20th july 1857 general lane under the authority of the topeka convention undertake as governor walker inform we to organize the whole so call free state party into volunteer and to take the name of all who refuse enrollment the profess object be to protect the poll at the election in august of the new insurgent topeka state legislature
 the object of take the name of all who refuse enrollment be to terrify the free state conservative into submission this be prove by recent atrocity commit on such man by topekaites the speedy location of large body of regular troop here with two battery be necessary the lawrence insurgent await the development of this new revolutionary military organization
 in the governor&#39;s dispatch of july 27 he say that general lane and his staff everywhere deny the authority of the territorial law and counsel a total disregard of these enactment
 without make further quotation of a similar character from other dispatch of governor walker it appear by a reference to mr. stanton&#39;s communication to general cass of the 9th of december last that the important step of call the legislature together be take after i he have become satisfied that the election order by the convention on the 21st instant could not be conduct without collision and bloodshed so intense be the disloyal feeling among the enemy of the government establish by congress that an election which afford they an opportunity if in the majority of make kansas a free state accord to their own profess desire could not be conduct without collision and bloodshed
 the truth be that up till the present moment the enemy of the exist government still adhere to their topeka revolutionary constitution and government the very first paragraph of the message of governor robinson date on the 7th of december to the topeka legislature now assemble at lawrence contain an open defiance of the constitution and law of the united states the governor say
 the convention which frame the constitution at topeka originate with the people of kansas territory they have adopt and ratify the same twice by a direct vote and also indirectly through two election of state officer and member of the state legislature yet it have please the administration to regard the whole proceeding revolutionary
 this topeka government adhere to with such treasonable pertinacity be a government in direct opposition to the exist government prescribe and recognize by congress it be a usurpation of the same character as it would be for a portion of the people of any state of the union to undertake to establish a separate government within its limit for the purpose of redress any grievance real or imaginary of which they might complain against the legitimate state government such a principle if carry into execution would destroy all lawful authority and produce universal anarchy
 from this statement of fact the reason become palpable why the enemy of the government authorize by congress have refuse to vote for delegate to the kansas constitutional convention and also afterwards on the question of slavery submit by it to the people it be because they have ever refuse to sanction or recognize any other constitution than that frame at topeka
 have the whole lecompton constitution be submit to the people the adherent of this organization would doubtless have vote against it because if successful they would thus have remove an obstacle out of the way of their own revolutionary constitution they would have do this not upon a consideration of the merit of the whole or any part of the lecompton constitution but simply because they have ever resist the authority of the government authorize by congress from which it emanate
 such be the unfortunate condition of affair in the territory what be the right as well as the duty of the law abide people be they silently and patiently to submit to the topeka usurpation or adopt the necessary measure to establish a constitution under the authority of the organic law of congress
 that this law recognize the right of the people of the territory without any enable act from congress to form a state constitution be too clear for argument for congress to leave the people of the territory perfectly free in frame their constitution to form and regulate their domestic institution in their own way subject only to the constitution of the united states and then to say that they shall not be permit to proceed and frame a constitution in their own way without an express authority from congress appear to be almost a contradiction in term it would be much more plausible to contend that congress have no power to pass such an enable act than to argue that the people of a territory might be keep out of the union for an indefinite period and until it might please congress to permit they to exercise the right of self government this would be to adopt not their own way but the way which congress might prescribe
 it be impossible that any people could have proceed with more regularity in the formation of a constitution than the people of kansas have do it be necessary first to ascertain whether it be the desire of the people to be relieve from their territorial dependence and establish a state government for this purpose the territorial legislature in 1855 pass a law for take the sense of the people of this territory upon the expediency of call a convention to form a state constitution at the general election to be hold in october 1856 the sense of the people be accordingly take and they decide in favor of a convention it be true that at this election the enemy of the territorial government do not vote because they be then engage at topeka without the slight pretext of lawful authority in frame a constitution of their own for the purpose of subvert the territorial government
 in pursuance of this decision of the people in favor of a convention the territorial legislature on the 27th day of february 1857 pass an act for the election of delegate on the third monday of june 1857 to frame a state constitution this law be as fair in its provision as any that ever pass a legislative body for a similar purpose the right of suffrage at this election be clearly and justly define every bona fide inhabitant of the territory of kansas on the third monday of june the day of the election who be a citizen of the united states above the age of 21 and have reside therein for three month previous to that date be entitle to vote in order to avoid all interference from neighbor states or territories with the freedom and fairness of the election provision be make for the registry of the qualified voter and in pursuance thereof 9,251 voter be register governor walker do his whole duty in urge all the qualified citizen of kansas to vote at this election in his inaugural address on the 27th may last he inform they that--
 under our practice the preliminary act of frame a state constitution be uniformly perform through the instrumentality of a convention of delegate choose by the people themselves that convention be now about to be elect by you under the call of the territorial legislature create and still recognize by the authority of congress and clothe by it in the comprehensive language of the organic law with full power to make such an enactment the territorial legislature then in assemble this convention be fully sustain by the act of congress and the authority of the convention be distinctly recognize in my instruction from the president of the united states
 the governor also clearly and distinctly warn they what would be the consequence if they should not participate in the election
 the people of kansas then he say be invite by the high authority know to the constitution to participate freely and fairly in the election of delegate to frame a constitution and state government the law have perform its entire appropriate function when it extend to the people the fight of suffrage but it can not compel the performance of that duty throughout our whole union however and wherever free government prevail those who abstain from the exercise of the right of suffrage authorize those who do vote to act for they in that contingency and the absentee be as much bind under the law and constitution where there be no fraud or violence by the act of the majority of those who do vote as if all have participate in the election otherwise as voting must be voluntary self government would be impracticable and monarchy or despotism would remain as the only alternative
 it may also be observe that at this period any hope if such have exist that the topeka constitution would ever be recognize by congress must have be abandon congress have adjourn on the 3d march previous having recognize the legal existence of the territorial legislature in a variety of form which i need not enumerate indeed the delegate elect to the house of representatives under a territorial law have be admit to his seat and have just complete his term of service on the day previous to my inauguration
 this be the propitious moment for settle all difficulty in kansas this be the time for abandon the revolutionary topeka organization and for the enemy of the exist government to conform to the law and to unite with its friend in frame a state constitution but this they refuse to do and the consequence of their refusal to submit to lawful authority and vote at the election of delegate may yet prove to be of a most deplorable character would that the respect for the law of the land which so eminently distinguish the man of the past generation could be revive it be a disregard and violation of law which have for year keep the territory of kansas in a state of almost open rebellion against its government it be the same spirit which have produce actual rebellion in utah our only safety consist in obedience and conformity to law should a general spirit against its enforcement prevail this will prove fatal to we as a nation we acknowledge no master but the law and should we cut loose from its restraint and everyone do what seemeth good in his own eye our case will indeed be hopeless
 the enemy of the territorial government determine still to resist the authority of congress they refuse to vote for delegate to the convention not because from circumstance which i need not detail there be an omission to register the comparatively few voter who be inhabitant of certain county of kansas in the early spring of 1857 but because they have predetermine at all hazard to adhere to their revolutionary organization and defeat the establishment of any other constitution than that which they have frame at topeka the election be therefore suffer to pass by default but of this result the qualified elector who refuse to vote can never justly complain
 from this review it be manifest that the lecompton convention accord to every principle of constitutional law be legally constitute and be invest with power to frame a constitution
 the sacred principle of popular sovereignty have be invoke in favor of the enemy of law and order in kansas but in what manner be popular sovereignty to be exercise in this country if not through the instrumentality of establish law in certain small republic of ancient time the people do assemble in primary meeting pass law and direct public affair in our country this be manifestly impossible popular sovereignty can be exercise here only through the ballot box and if the people will refuse to exercise it in this manner as they have do in kansas at the election of delegate it be not for they to complain that their right have be violate
 the kansas convention thus lawfully constitute proceed to frame a constitution and having complete their work finally adjourn on the 7th day of november last they do not think proper to submit the whole of this constitution to a popular vote but they do submit the question whether kansas should be a free or a slave state to the people this be the question which have convulse the union and shake it to its very center this be the question which have light up the flame of civil war in kansas and have produce dangerous sectional party throughout the confederacy it be of a character so paramount in respect to the condition of kansas as to rivet the anxious attention of the people of the whole country upon it and it alone no person think of any other question for my own part when i instruct governor walker in general term in favor of submit the constitution to the people i have no object in view except the all absorb question of slavery in what manner the people of kansas might regulate their other concern be not a subject which attract any attention in fact the general provision of our recent state constitution after an experience of eight year be so similar and so excellent that it would be difficult to go far wrong at the present day in frame a new constitution
 i then believe and still believe that under the organic act the kansas convention be bind to submit this all important question of slavery to the people it be never however my opinion that independently of this act they would have be bind to submit any portion of the constitution to a popular vote in order to give it validity have i entertain such an opinion this would have be in opposition to many precedent in our history commence in the very good age of the republic it would have be in opposition to the principle which pervade our institution and which be every day carry out into practice that the people have the right to delegate to representative choose by themselves their sovereign power to frame constitution enact law and perform many other important act without require that these should be subject to their subsequent approbation it would be a most inconvenient limitation of their own power impose by the people upon themselves to exclude they from exercise their sovereignty in any lawful manner they think proper it be true that the people of kansas might if they have please have require the convention to submit the constitution to a popular vote but this they have not do the only remedy therefore in this case be that which exist in all other similar case if the delegate who frame the kansas constitution have in any manner violate the will of their constituent the people always possess the power to change their constitution or their law accord to their own pleasure
 the question of slavery be submit to an election of the people of kansas on the 21st december last in obedience to the mandate of the constitution here again a fair opportunity be present to the adherent of the topeka constitution if they be the majority to decide this exciting question in their own way and thus restore peace to the distracted territory but they again refuse to exercise their right of popular sovereignty and again suffer the election to pass by default
 i heartily rejoice that a wise and well spirit prevail among a large majority of these people on the first monday of january and that they do on that day vote under the lecompton constitution for a governor and other state officer a member of congress and for member of the legislature this election be warmly contest by the party and a large vote be poll than at any previous election in the territory we may now reasonably hope that the revolutionary topeka organization will be speedily and finally abandon and this will go far toward the final settlement of the unhappy difference in kansas if fraud have be commit at this election either by one or both party the legislature and the people of kansas under their constitution will know how to redress themselves and punish these detestable but too common crime without any outside interference
 the people of kansas have then in their own way and in strict accordance with the organic act frame a constitution and state government have submit the all important question of slavery to the people and have elect a governor a member to represent they in congress member of the state legislature and other state officer they now ask admission into the union under this constitution which be republican in its form it be for congress to decide whether they will admit or reject the state which have thus be create for my own part i be decidedly in favor of its admission and thus terminate the kansas question this will carry out the great principle of nonintervention recognize and sanction by the organic act which declare in express language in favor of nonintervention by congress with slavery in the states or territories leave the people thereof perfectly free to form and regulate their domestic institution in their own way subject only to the constitution of the united states in this manner by localize the question of slavery and confine it to the people whom it immediately concern every patriot anxiously expect that this question would be banish from the hall of congress where it have always exert a baneful influence throughout the whole country
 it be proper that i should briefly refer to the election hold under an act of the territorial legislature on the first monday of january last on the lecompton constitution this election be hold after the territory have be prepare for admission into the union as a sovereign state and when no authority exist in the territorial legislature which could possibly destroy its existence or change its character the election which be peaceably conduct under my instruction involve a strange inconsistency a large majority of the person who vote against the lecompton constitution be at the very same time and place recognize its valid existence in the most solemn and authentic manner by vote under its provision i have yet receive no official information of the result of this election
 as a question of expediency after the right have be maintain it may be wise to reflect upon the benefit to kansas and to the whole country which would result from its immediate admission into the union as well as the disaster which may follow its rejection domestic peace will be the happy consequence of its admission and that fine territory which have hitherto be tear by dissension will rapidly increase in population and wealth and speedily realize the blessing and the comfort which follow in the train of agricultural and mechanical industry the people will then be sovereign and can regulate their own affair in their own way if a majority of they desire to abolish domestic slavery within the state there be no other possible mode by which this can be effect so speedily as by prompt admission the will of the majority be supreme and irresistible when express in an orderly and lawful manner they can make and unmake constitution at pleasure it would be absurd to say that they can impose fetter upon their own power which they can not afterwards remove if they could do this they might tie their own hand for a hundred as well as for ten year these be fundamental principle of american freedom and be recognize i believe in some form or other by every state constitution and if congress in the act of admission should think proper to recognize they i can perceive no objection to such a course this have be do emphatically in the constitution of kansas it declare in the bill of right that all political power be inherent in the people and all free government be round on their authority and institute for their benefit and therefore they have at all time an inalienable and indefeasible right to alter reform or abolish their form of government in such manner as they may think proper the great state of new york be at this moment govern under a constitution frame and establish in direct opposition to the mode prescribe by the previous constitution if therefore the provision change the kansas constitution after the year 1864 could by possibility be construe into a prohibition to make such a change previous to that period this prohibition would be wholly unavaile the legislature already elect may at its very first session submit the question to a vote of the people whether they will or will not have a convention to amend their constitution and adopt all necessary mean for give effect to the popular will
 it have be solemnly adjudge by the high judicial tribunal know to our law that slavery exist in kansas by virtue of the constitution of the united states kansas be therefore at this moment as much a slave state as georgia or south carolina without this the equality of the sovereign states compose the union would be violate and the use and enjoyment of a territory acquire by the common treasure of all the states would be close against the people and the property of nearly half the member of the confederacy slavery can therefore never be prohibit in kansas except by mean of a constitutional provision and in no other manner can this be obtain so promptly if a majority of the people desire it as by admit it into the union under its present constitution
 on the other hand should congress reject the constitution under the idea of afford the disaffect in kansas a third opportunity of prohibit slavery in the state which they might have do twice before if in the majority no man can foretell the consequence
 if congress for the sake of those man who refuse to vote for delegate to the convention when they might have exclude slavery from the constitution and who afterwards refuse to vote on the 21st december last when they might as they claim have stricken slavery from the constitution should now reject the state because slavery remain in the constitution it be manifest that the agitation upon this dangerous subject will be renew in a more alarming form than it have ever yet assume
 every patriot in the country have indulge the hope that the kansas and nebraska act would put a final end to the slavery agitation at least in congress which have for more than twenty year convulse the country and endanger the union this act involve great and fundamental principle and if fairly carry into effect will settle the question should the agitation be again revive should the people of the sister states be again estranged from each other with more than their former bitterness this will arise from a cause so far as the interest of kansas be concern more trifling and insignificant than have ever stir the element of a great people into commotion to the people of kansas the only practical difference between admission or rejection depend simply upon the fact whether they can themselves more speedily change the present constitution if it do not accord with the will of the majority or frame a second constitution to be submit to congress hereafter even if this be a question of mere expediency and not of right the small difference of time one way or the other be of not the least importance when contrast with the evil which must necessarily result to the whole country from a revival of the slavery agitation
 in consider this question it should never be forget that in proportion to its insignificance let the decision be what it may so far as it may affect the few thousand inhabitant of kansas who have from the beginning resist the constitution and the law for this very reason the rejection of the constitution will be so much the more keenly feel by the people of fourteen of the states of this union where slavery be recognize under the constitution of the united states
 again the speedy admission of kansas into the union would restore peace and quiet to the whole country already the affair of this territory have engross an undue proportion of public attention they have sadly affect the friendly relation of the people of the states with each other and alarm the fear of patriot for the safety of the union kansas once admit into the union the excitement become localized and will soon die away for want of outside aliment then every difficulty will be settle at the ballot box
 besides and this be no trifling consideration i shall then be enable to withdraw the troop of the united states from kansas and employ they on branch of service where they be much need they have be keep there on the earnest importunity of governor walker to maintain the existence of the territorial government and secure the execution of the law he consider that at least 2,000 regular troop under the command of general harney be necessary for this purpose act upon his reliable information i have be oblige in some degree to interfere with the expedition to utah in order to keep down rebellion in kansas this have involve a very heavy expense to the government kansas once admit it be believe there will no long be any occasion there for troop of the united states
 i have thus perform my duty on this important question under a deep sense of responsibility to god and my country my public life will terminate within a brief period and i have no other object of earthly ambition than to leave my country in a peaceful and prosperous condition and to live in the affection and respect of my countryman the dark and ominous cloud which now appear to be impend over the union i conscientiously believe may be dissipate with honor to every portion of it by the admission of kansas during the present session of congress whereas if she should be reject i greatly fear these cloud will become dark and more ominous than any which have ever yet threaten the constitution and the union
 april 6 1858- proclamation regard the rebellion in utah
 whereas the territory of utah be settle by certain emigrant from the states and from foreign country who have for several year past manifest a spirit of insubordination to the constitution and law of the united states the great mass of those settler act under the influence of leader to whom they seem to have surrender their judgment refuse to be control by any other authority they have be often advise to obedience and these friendly counsel have be answer with defiance the officer of the federal government have be drive from the territory for no offense but an effort to do their swear duty other have be prevent from go there by threat of assassination judge have be violently interrupt in the performance of their function and the record of the court have be seize and destroy or conceal many other act of unlawful violence have be perpetrate and the right to repeat they have be openly claim by the lead inhabitant with at least the silent acquiescence of nearly all the other their hostility to the lawful government of the country have at length become so violent that no officer bear a commission from the chief magistrate of the union can enter the territory or remain there with safety and all those officer recently appoint have be unable to go to salt lake or anywhere else in utah beyond the immediate power of the army indeed such be believe to be the condition to which a strange system of terrorism have bring the inhabitant of that region that no one among they could express an opinion favorable to this government or even propose to obey its law without expose his life and property to peril
 after carefully consider this state of affair and maturely weigh the obligation i be under to see the law faithfully execute it seem to i right and proper that i should make such use of the military force at my disposal as might be necessary to protect the federal officer in go into the territory of utah and in perform their duty after arrive there i accordingly order a detachment of the army to march for the city of salt lake or within reach of that place and to act in case of need as a posse for the enforcement of the law but in the meantime the hatred of that misguided people for the just and legal authority of the government have become so intense that they resolve to measure their military strength with that of the union they have organize an armed force far from contemptible in point of number and train it if not with skill at least with great assiduity and perseverance while the troop of the united states be on their march a train of baggage wagon which happen to be unprotecte be attack and destroy by a portion of the mormon force and the provision and store with which the train be laden be wantonly burn in short their present attitude be one of decide and unreserve enmity to the united states and to all their loyal citizen their determination to oppose the authority of the government by military force have not only be express in word but manifest in overt act of the most unequivocal character
 fellow citizen of utah this be rebellion against the government to which you owe allegiance it be levy war against the united states and involve you in the guilt of treason persistence in it will bring you to condign punishment to ruin and to shame for it be mere madness to suppose that with your limited resource you can successfully resist the force of this great and powerful nation
 if you have calculate upon the forbearance of the united states if you have permit yourself to suppose that this government will fail to put forth its strength and bring you to submission you have fall into a grave mistake you have settle upon territory which lie geographically in the heart of the union the land you live upon be purchase by the united states and pay for out of their treasury the proprietary right and title to it be in they and not in you utah be bound on every side by states and territories whose people be true to the union it be absurd to believe that they will or can permit you to erect in their very midst a government of your own not only independent of the authority which they all acknowledge but hostile to they and their interest
 do not deceive yourself nor try to mislead other by propagate the idea that this be a crusade against your religion the constitution and law of this country can take no notice of your creed whether it be true or false that be a question between your god and yourself in which i disclaim all right to interfere if you obey the law keep the peace and respect the just right of other you will be perfectly secure and may live on in your present faith or change it for another at your pleasure every intelligent man among you know very well that this government have never directly or indirectly seek to molest you in your worship to control you in your ecclesiastical affair or even to influence you in your religious opinion
 this rebellion be not merely a violation of your legal duty it be without just cause without reason without excuse you never make a complaint that be not listen to with patience you never exhibit a real grievance that be not redress as promptly as it could be the law and regulation enact for your government by congress have be equal and just and their enforcement be manifestly necessary for your own welfare and happiness you have never ask their repeal they be similar in every material respect to the law which have be pass for the other territories of the union and which everywhere else with one partial exception have be cheerfully obey no people ever live who be free from unnecessary legal restraint than you human wisdom never devise a political system which bestow more blessing or impose light burden than the government of the united states in its operation upon the territories
 but be anxious to save the effusion of blood and to avoid the indiscriminate punishment of a whole people for crime of which it be not probable that all be equally guilty i offer now a free and full pardon to all who will submit themselves to the just authority of the federal government if you refuse to accept it let the consequence fall upon your own head but i conjure you to pause deliberately and reflect well before you reject this tender of peace and good will
 now therefore i james buchanan president of the united states have think proper to issue this my proclamation enjoin upon all public officer in the territory of utah to be diligent and faithful to the full extent of their power in the execution of the law command all citizen of the united states in say territory to aid and assist the officer in the performance of their duty offer to the inhabitant of utah who shall submit to the law a free pardon for the sedition and treason heretofore by they commit warn those who shall persist after notice of this proclamation in the present rebellion against the united states that they must expect no further lenity but look to be rigorously deal with accord to their desert and declare that the military force now in utah and hereafter to be send there will not be withdraw until the inhabitant of that territory shall manifest a proper sense of the duty which they owe to this government
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix to these present do at the city of washington the 6th day of april 1858 and of the independence of the united states the eighty second
 james buchanan
 by the president
 lewis cass secretary of state

fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives when we compare the condition of the country at the present day with what it be one year ago at the meeting of congress we have much reason for gratitude to that almighty providence which have never fail to interpose for our relief at the most critical period of our history one year ago the sectional strife between the north and the south the present condition of the territory of utah when contrast with what it be one year ago be a subject for congratulation it be then in a state of open rebellion and cost what it might the character territory to protect these civil officer and to aid they as a posse comitatus in the execution of the law in case of need i order a detachment of the army to accompany they to utah the necessity for adopt these measure be now demonstrate on the 15th of september 1857 governor young issue his proclamation in the style of an independent sovereign announce his purpose to resist by force of arm the entry of the united states troop into our own territory of utah by this he require all the force in the territory to hold themselves in readiness to march at a moment 's notice to repel any and all such invasion and establish martial law from its date throughout the territory these prove to be no idle threat forts bridger and supply be vacate and burn down by the mormons to deprive our troop of a shelter after their long and fatigue march order be issue by daniel h. wells style himself lieutenant general nauvoo legion to stampede the animal of the united states troop on their march to set etc these order be promptly and effectually obey on the 4th of october 1857 the mormons capture and burn on green river three of our supply train consist of seventy five wagon load with provision and tent for the army and carry away several hundred animal this diminish the supply of provision so materially that general johnston be oblige to reduce the ration and even with this precaution there be only sufficient leave to subsist the troop until the 1st of june our little army behave admirably in their encampment at fort bridger under these try privation in the midst of the mountain in a dreary unsettled and inhospitable region more than a thousand mile from home they pass the severe and inclement winter without a murmur they look forward with confidence for relief from their country in due season and in this they be not disappointed the secretary of war employ all his energy to forward they the necessary supply and to muster and send such a military force to utah as would render resistance on the part of the mormon hopeless and thus terminate the war without the effusion of blood in his effort he be efficiently sustain by congress they grant appropriation sufficient to cover the deficiency thus necessarily create and also provide for raise two regiment of volunteer for the purpose of quell disturbance in the territory of utah for the protection of supply and emigrant train and the suppression of indian hostility on the frontier happily there be no occasion to call these regiment into service if there have be i should have feel serious embarrassment in select they so great be the number of our brave and patriotic citizen anxious to serve their country in this distant and apparently dangerous expedition thus it have ever be and thus may it ever be the wisdom and economy of send sufficient reenforcement to utah be establish not only by the event but in the opinion of those who from their position and opportunity be the most capable of form a correct judgment
