ought to do justice an appropriation promptly make for this purpose could not fail to exert a favorable influence on our negotiation with spain our position in relation to the independent states south of we on this continent and especially those within the limit of north america be of a peculiar character the northern boundary of mexico be coincident with our own southern boundary from ocean to ocean and we must necessarily feel a deep interest in all that concern the well being and the fate of so near a neighbor we have always cherish the kind wish for the success of that republic and have indulge the hope that it might at last after all its trial enjoy peace and prosperity under a free and stable government we have never hitherto interfere directly or indirectly with its internal affair and it be a duty which we owe to ourselves to protect the integrity of its territory against the hostile interference of any other power our geographical position our direct interest in all that concern mexico and our well settle policy in regard to the north american continent render this an indispensable duty mexico have be in a state of constant revolution almost ever since it achieve its independence one military leader after another have usurp the government in rapid succession and the various constitution from time to time adopt have be set at naught almost as soon as they be proclaim the successive government have afford no adequate protection either to mexican citizen or foreign resident against lawless violence heretofore a seizure of the capital by a military chieftain have be generally follow by at least the nominal submission of the country to his rule for a brief period but not so at the present crisis of mexican affair a civil war have be rage for some time throughout the republic between the central government at the city of mexico which have endeavor to subvert the constitution last frame by military power and those who maintain the authority of that constitution the antagonist party each hold possession of different states of the republic and the fortune of the war be constantly change meanwhile the most reprehensible mean have be employ by both party to extort money from foreigner as well as native to carry on this ruinous contest the truth be that this fine country bless with a productive soil and a benign climate have be reduce by civil dissension to a condition of almost hopeless anarchy and imbecility it would be vain for this government to attempt to enforce payment in money of the claim of american citizen now amount to more than $ 10,000,000 against mexico because she be destitute of all pecuniary mean to satisfy these demand our late minister be furnish with ample power and instruction for the adjustment of all pende question with the central government of mexico and he perform his duty with zeal and ability the claim of our citizen some of they arise out of the violation of an express provision of the treaty of guadalupe hidalgo and other from gross injury to person as well as property have remain unredressed and even unnoticed remonstrance against these grievance have be address without effect to that government meantime in various part of the republic instance have be numerous of the murder imprisonment and plunder of our citizen by different party claim and exercise a local jurisdiction but the central government although repeatedly urge thereto have make no effort either to punish the author of these outrage or to prevent their recurrence no american citizen can now visit mexico on lawful business without imminent danger to his person and property there be no adequate protection to either and in this respect our treaty with that republic be almost a dead letter this state of affair be bring to a crisis in may last by the promulgation of a decree levy a contribution pro rata upon all the capital in the republic between certain specified amount whether hold by mexicans or foreigner mr. forsyth regard this decree in the light of a force loan formally protest against its application to his countryman and advise they not to pay the contribution but to suffer it to be forcibly exact act upon this advice an american citizen refuse to pay the contribution and his property be seize by armed man to satisfy the amount not content with this the government proceed still far and issue a decree banish he from the country our minister immediately notify they that if this decree should be carry into execution he would feel it to be his duty to adopt the most decide measure that belong to the power and obligation of the representative office notwithstanding this warning the banishment be enforce and mr. forsyth promptly announce to the government the suspension of the political relation of his legation with they until the pleasure of his own government should be ascertain this government do not regard the contribution impose by the decree of the 15th may last to be in strictness a force loan and as such prohibit by the tenth article of the treaty of 1826 between great britain and mexico to the benefit of which american citizen be entitle by treaty yet the imposition of the contribution upon foreigner be consider an unjust and oppressive measure besides internal faction in other part of the republic be at the same time levy similar exaction upon the property of our citizen and interrupt their commerce there have be an entire failure on the part of our minister to secure redress for the wrong which our citizen have endure notwithstanding his persevere effort and from the temper manifest by the mexican government he have repeatedly assure we that no favorable change could be expect until the united states should give strike evidence of their will and power to protect their citizen and that severe chastening be the only earthly remedy for our grievance from this statement of fact it would have be bad than idle to direct mr. forsyth to retrace his step and resume diplomatic relation with that government and it be therefore deem proper to sanction his withdrawal of the legation from the city of mexico abundant cause now undoubtedly exist for a resort to hostility against the government still hold possession of the capital should they succeed in subdue the constitutional force all reasonable hope will then have expire of a peaceful settlement of our difficulty on the other hand should the constitutional party prevail and their authority be establish over the republic there be reason to hope that they will be animate by a less unfriendly spirit and may grant that redress to american citizen which justice require so far as they may possess the mean but for this expectation i should at once have recommend to congress to grant the necessary power to the president to take possession of a sufficient portion of the remote and unsettled territory of mexico to be hold in pledge until our injury shall be redress and our just demand be satisfied we have already exhaust every milder mean of obtain justice in such a case this remedy of reprisal be recognize by the law of nation not only as just in itself but as a means of prevent actual war but there be another view of our relation with mexico arise from the unhappy condition of affair along our southwestern frontier which demand immediate action in that remote region where there be but few white inhabitant large band of hostile and predatory indians roam promiscuously over the mexican states of chihuahua and sonora and our adjoining territories the local government of these states be perfectly helpless and be keep in a state of constant alarm by the indians they have not the power if they possess the will even to restrain lawless mexicans from pass the border and commit depredation on our remote settler a state of anarchy and violence prevail throughout that distant frontier the law be a dead letter and life and property wholly insecure for this reason the settlement of arizona be arrest whilst it be of great importance that a chain of inhabitant should extend all along its southern border sufficient for their own protection and that of the united states mail pass to and from california well found apprehension be now entertain that the indians and wander mexicans equally lawless may break up the important stage and postal communication recently establish between our atlantic and pacific possession this pass very near to the mexican boundary throughout the whole length of arizona i can imagine no possible remedy for these evil and no mode of restore law and order on that remote and unsettled frontier but for the government of the united states to assume a temporary protectorate over the northern portion of chihuahua and sonora and to establish military post within the same and this i earnestly recommend to congress this protection may be withdraw as soon as local government shall be establish in these mexican states capable of perform their duty to the united states restrain the lawless and preserve peace along the border i do not doubt that this measure will be view in a friendly spirit by the government and people of chihuahua and sonora as it will prove equally effectual for the protection of their citizen on that remote and lawless frontier as for citizen of the united states and in this connection permit i to recall your attention to the condition of arizona the population of that territory numbering as be allege more than 10,000 soul be practically without a government without law and without any regular administration of justice murder and other crime be commit with impunity this state of thing call loudly for redress and i therefore repeat my recommendation for the establishment of a territorial government over arizona the political condition of the narrow isthmus of central america through which transit route pass between the atlantic and pacific ocean present a subject of deep interest to all commercial nation it be over these transit that a large proportion of the trade and travel between the european and asiatic continent be destine to pass to the united states these route be of incalculable importance as a means of communication between their atlantic and pacific possession the latter now extend throughout seventeen degree of latitude on the pacific coast embrace the important state of california and the flourish territory of oregon and washington all commercial nation therefore have a deep and direct interest that these communication shall be render secure from interruption if an arm of the sea connect the two ocean penetrate through nicaragua and costa rica it could not be pretend that these states would have the right to arrest or retard its navigation to the injury of other nation the transit by land over this narrow isthmus occupy nearly the same position it be a highway in which they themselves have little interest when compare with the vast interest of the rest of the world whilst their right of sovereignty ought to be respect it be the duty of other nation to require that this important passage shall not be interrupt by the civil war and revolutionary outbreak which have so frequently occur in that region the stake be too important to be leave at the mercy of rival company claim to hold conflicting contract with nicaragua the commerce of other nation be not to stand still and await the adjustment of such petty controversy the government of the united states expect no more than this and they will not be satisfied with less they would not if they could derive any advantage from the nicaragua transit not common to the rest of the world its neutrality and protection for the common use of all nation be their only object they have no objection that nicaragua shall demand and receive a fair compensation from the company and individual who may traverse the route but they insist that it shall never hereafter be close by an arbitrary decree of that government if dispute arise between it and those with whom they may have enter into contract these must be adjust by some fair tribunal provide for the purpose and the route must not be close pende the controversy this be our whole policy and it can not fail to be acceptable to other nation all these difficulty might be avoid if consistently with the good faith of nicaragua the use of this transit could be throw open to general competition provide at the same time for the payment of a reasonable rate to the nicaraguan government on passenger and freight in august 1852 the accessory transit company make its first interoceanic trip over the nicaraguan route and continue in successful operation with great advantage to the public until the 18th february 1856 when it be close and the grant to this company as well as its charter be summarily and arbitrarily revoke by the government of president rivas previous to this date however in 1854 serious dispute concern the settlement of their account have arise between the company and the government threaten the interruption of the route at any moment these the united states in vain endeavor to compose it would be useless to narrate the various proceeding which take place between the party up till the time when the transit be discontinue suffice it to say that since february 1856 it have remain closed greatly to the prejudice of citizen of the united states since that time the competition have cease between the rival route of panama and nicaragua and in consequence thereof an unjust and unreasonable amount have be exact from our citizen for their passage to and from californiaa treaty be sign on the 16th day of november 1857 by the secretary of state and minister of nicaragua under the stipulation of which the use and protection of the transit route would have be secure not only to the united states but equally to all other nation how and on what pretext this treaty have fail to receive the ratification of the nicaraguan government will appear by the paper herewith communicate from the state department the principal objection seem to have be to the provision authorize the united states to employ force to keep the route open in case nicaragua should fail to perform her duty in this respect from the feebleness of that republic its frequent change of government and its constant internal dissension this have become a most important stipulation and one essentially necessary not only for the security of the route but for the safety of american citizen pass and repasse to and from our pacific possession be such a stipulation embrace in a treaty between the united states and nicaragua the knowledge of this fact would of itself most probably prevent hostile party from commit aggression on the route and render our actual interference for its protection unnecessary the executive government of this country in its intercourse with foreign nation be limit to the employment of diplomacy alone when this fail it can proceed no far it can not legitimately resort to force without the direct authority of congress except in resist and repel hostile attack it would have no authority to enter the territory of nicaragua even to prevent the destruction of the transit and protect the life and property of our own citizen on their passage it be true that on a sudden emergency of this character the president would direct any armed force in the vicinity to march to their relief but in do this he would act upon his own responsibility under these circumstance i earnestly recommend to congress the passage of an act authorize the president under such restriction as they may deem proper to employ the land and naval force of the united states in prevent the transit from be obstruct or close by lawless violence and in protect the life and property of american citizen travel thereupon require at the same time that these force shall be withdraw the moment the danger shall have pass away without such a provision our citizen will be constantly expose to interruption in their progress and to lawless violence a similar necessity exist for the passage of such an act for the protection of the panama and tehuantepec route in reference to the panama route the united states by their exist treaty with new granada expressly guarantee the neutrality of the isthmus with the view that the free transit from the one to the other sea may not be interrupt or embarrass in any future time while this treaty exist "in regard to the tehuantepec route which have be recently open under the most favorable auspex our treaty with mexico of the 30th december 1853 secure to the citizen of the united states a right of transit over it for their person and merchandise and stipulate that neither government shall interpose any obstacle thereto it also concede to the united states the right to transport across the isthmus in closed bag the mail of the united states not intend for distribution along the line of the communication also the effect of the united states government and its citizen which may be intend for transit and not for distribution on the isthmus free of custom house or other charge by the mexican government "these treaty stipulation with new granada and mexico in addition to the consideration applicable to the nicaragua route seem to require production have be diminish in nearly the same proportion i regret to state that the government of brazil still continue to levy an export duty of about 11 per cent on coffee notwithstanding this article be admit free from duty in the united states this be a heavy charge upon the consumer of coffee in our country as we purchase half of the entire surplus crop of that article raise in brazil our minister under instruction will reiterate his effort to have this export duty remove and it be hope that the enlightened government of the emperor will adopt this wise just and equal policy in not in the aggregate of very large amount but some of these rest upon plain principle of justice and their settlement ought not to be long delay a renewed and earnest and i trust a successful effort will be make by our minister to procure their final adjustment on the 2d of june last congress pass a joint resolution authorize the president to adopt such measure and use such force as in his difference in an amicable and peaceful manner if this be practicable his experience and discretion justify the hope that he may prove successful in convince the paraguayan government that it be due ayres which it be believe will prove sufficient for the occasion it be my earnest desire however that it may not be find necessary to resort to this last alternative when congress meet in december last the business of the country have just be crush by one of those periodical revulsion which be the inevitable consequence of our unsound and extravagant system of bank credit and inflated currency with all the element of national wealth in abundance our manufacture be suspend our useful public and private enterprise be arrest and thousand of laborer be deprive of employment and reduce to want universal distress prevail among the commercial manufacturing and mechanical class this revulsion be feel the more severely in the united states because similar cause have produce the like deplorable effect throughout the commercial nation of europe all be experience sad reverse at the same moment our manufacturer everywhere suffer severely not because of the recent reduction in the tariff of duty on import but because there be no demand at any price for their production the people be oblige to restrict themselves in their purchase to article of prime necessity in the general prostration of business the iron manufacturer in different states probably suffer more than any other class and much destitution be the inevitable consequence among the great number of workman who have be employ in this useful branch of industry there could be no supply where there be no demand to present an example there could be no demand for railroad iron after our magnificent system of railroad extend its benefit to every portion of the union have be bring to a dead pause the same consequence have result from similar cause to many other branch of useful manufacture it be self evident that where there be no ability to purchase manufacture article these can not be sell and consequently must cease to be produce no government and especially a government of such limited power as that of the united states could have prevent the late revulsion the whole commercial world seem for year to have be rush to this catastrophe the same ruinous consequence would have follow in the united states whether the duty upon foreign import have remain as they be under the tariff of 1846 or have be raise to a much high standard the tariff of 1857 have no agency in the result the general cause exist throughout the world could not have be control by the legislation of any particular country the periodical revulsion which have exist in our past history must continue to return at interval so long as our present unbounded system of bank credit shall prevail they will however probably be the less severe in future because it be not to be expect at least for many year to come that the commercial nation of europe with whose interest our own be so materially involved will expose themselves to similar calamity but this subject be treat so much at large in my last annual message that i shall not now pursue it far still i respectfully renew the recommendation in favor of the passage of a uniform bankrupt law applicable to banking institution this be all the direct power over the subject which i believe the federal government possess such a law would mitigate though it might not prevent the evil the instinct of self preservation might produce a wholesome restraint upon their banking business if they know in advance that a suspension of specie payment would inevitably produce their civil death but the effect of the revulsion be now slowly but surely pass away the energy and enterprise of our citizen with our unbounded resource will within the period of another year restore a state of wholesome industry and trade capital have again accumulate in our large city the rate of interest be there very low confidence be gradually revive and so soon as it be discover that this capital can be profitably employ in commercial and manufacturing enterprise and in the construction of railroad and other work of public and private improvement prosperity will again smile throughout the land it be vain however to disguise the fact from ourselves that a speculative inflation of our currency without a corresponding inflation in other country whose manufacture come into competition with our own must ever produce disastrous result to our domestic manufacture no tariff short of absolute prohibition can prevent these evil consequence in connection with this subject it be proper to refer to our financial condition the same cause which have produce pecuniary distress throughout the country have so reduce the amount of import from foreign country that the revenue have prove inadequate to meet the necessary expense of the government to supply the deficiency congress by the act of december 23 1857 authorize the issue of $ 20,000,000 of treasury note and this prove inadequate they authorize by the act of june 14 1858 a loan of $ 20,000,000 to be apply to the payment of appropriation make by law "no statesman would advise that we should go on increase the national debt to meet the ordinary expense of the government this would be a most ruinous policy in case of war our credit must be our chief resource at least for the first year and this would be greatly impair by having contract a large debt in time of peace it be our true policy to increase our revenue so as to equal our expenditure it would be ruinous to continue to borrow besides it may be proper to observe that the incidental protection thus afford by a revenue tariff would at the present moment to some extent increase the confidence of the manufacture interest and give a fresh impulse to our reviving business to this surely no person will object in regard to the mode of assess and collect duty under a strictly revenue tariff i have long entertain and often express the opinion that sound policy require this should be do by specific duty in case to which these can be properly apply they be well adapt to commodity which be usually sell by weight or by measure and which from their nature be of equal or of nearly equal value such for example be the article of iron of different class raw sugar and foreign wine and spirit in my deliberate judgment specific duty be the good if not the only mean of secure the revenue against false and fraudulent invoice and such have be the practice adopt for this purpose by other commercial nation besides specific duty would afford to the american manufacturer the incidental advantage to which he be fairly entitle under a revenue tariff the present system be a slide scale to his disadvantage under it when price be high and business prosperous the duty rise in amount when he least require their aid on the contrary when price fall and he be struggle against adversity the duty be diminish in the same proportion greatly to his injury neither would there be danger that a high rate of duty than that intend by congress could be levy in the form of specific duty it would be easy to ascertain the average value of any import article for a series of year and instead of subject it to an ad valorem duty at a certain rate per centum to substitute in its place an equivalent specific duty by such an arrangement the consumer would not be injure it be true he might have to pay a little more duty on a give article in one year but if so he would pay a little less in another and in a series of year these would counterbalance each other and amount to the same thing so far as his interest be concern this inconvenience would be trifle when contrast with the additional security thus afford against fraud upon the revenue in which every consumer be directly interested i have throw out these suggestion as the fruit of my own observation to which congress in their well judgment will give such weight as they may justly deserve the report of the secretary of the treasury will explain in detail the operation of that amendment of our patent law be worthy of the serious consideration of congress the post office department occupy a position very different from that of the other departments for many year it be the policy of the government to render this a self sustain department and if this can not now be accomplish in the present condition of the country we ought to make as near an approach to it as may be practicable the postmaster general be place in a most embarrassing position by the exist law he be oblige to carry these into effect he have no other alternative he find however that this can not be do without heavy demand upon the treasury over and above what be receive for postage and these have be progressively increase from year to year until they amount for the last fiscal year end on the 30th of june 1858 to more than $ 4,500,000 whilst it be estimate that for the present fiscal year they will amount to $ 6,290,000 these sum be exclusive of the annual appropriation of $ 700,000 for compensation for the mail service perform for the two houses of congress and the other departments and officer of the government in the transmission of free matter "the cause of these large deficit be mainly attributable to the increase expense of transport the mail in 1852 the sum pay for this service be but a fraction above four million and a quarter since that year it have annually increase until in 1858 it have reach more than eight million and a quarter and for the service of 1859 it be estimate that it will amount to more than $ 10,000,000.the receipt of the post office department can be make to approach or to equal its expenditure only by mean of the legislation of congress in apply any remedy care should be take that the people shall not be deprive of the advantage which they be fairly entitle to enjoy from the post office department the principal remedy recommend to the consideration of congress by the postmaster general be to restore the former rate of postage upon single letter to 5 cent to substitute for the franking privilege the delivery to those now entitle to enjoy it of post office stamp for their correspondence and to direct the department in make contract for the transportation of the mail to confine itself to the payment of the sum necessary for this single purpose without require it to be transport in post coach or carriage of any particular description under the present system the expense to the government be greatly increase by require that the mail shall be carry in such vehicle as will accommodate passenger this will be do without pay from the department over all road where the travel will remunerate the contractor these recommendation deserve the grave consideration of congress i would again call your attention to the construction of a pacific railroad time and reflection have but serve to confirm i in the truth and justice of the observation which i make on this subject in my last annual message to which i beg leave respectfully to refer it be freely admit that it would be inexpedient for this government to exercise the power of construct the pacific railroad by its own immediate agent such a policy would increase the patronage of the executive to a dangerous extent and introduce a system of jobbing and corruption which no vigilance on the part of federal official could either prevent or detect this can only be do by the keen eye and active and careful supervision of individual and private interest the construction of this road ought therefore to be commit to company incorporate by the states or other agency whose pecuniary interest would be directly involve congress might then assist they in the work by grant of land or of money or both under such condition and restriction as would secure the transportation of troop and munition of war free from any charge and that of the united states mail at a fair and reasonable price the progress of event since the commencement of your last session have show how soon difficulty disappear before a firm and determined resolution at that time such a road be deem by wise and patriotic man to be a visionary project the great distance to be overcome and the intervene mountain and desert in the way be obstacle which in the opinion of many could not be surmount now after the lapse of but a single year these obstacle it have be discover be far less formidable than they be suppose to be and mail stage with passenger now pass and repass regularly twice in each week by a common wagon road between san francisco and st. louis and memphis in less than twenty five day the service have be as regularly perform as it be in former year between new york and this city whilst disclaim all authority to appropriate money for the construction of this road except that derive from the war make power of the constitution there be important collateral consideration urge we to undertake the work as speedily as possible the first and most momentous of these be that such a road would be a powerful bond of union between the states east and west of the rocky mountains this be so self evident as to require no illustration but again in a commercial point of view i consider this the great question of the day with the eastern front of our republic stretch along the atlantic and its western front along the pacific if all the part should be unite by a safe easy and rapid intercommunication we must necessarily command a very large proportion of the trade both of europe and asia our recent treaty with china and japan will open these rich and populous empire to our commerce and the history of the world prove that the nation which have gain possession of the trade with eastern asia have always become wealthy and powerful the peculiar geographical position of california and our pacific possession invite american capital and enterprise into this fruitful field to reap the rich harvest however it be an indispensable prerequisite that we shall first have a railroad to convey and circulate its product throughout every portion of the union besides such a railroad through our temperate latitude which would not be impede by the frost and snow of winter nor by the tropical heat of summer would attract to itself much of the travel and the trade of all nation pass between europe and asia on the 21st of august last lieutenant j. n. maffit of the united states brig dolphin capture the slaver echo formerly the putnam of new orleans near kay verde on the coast of cuba with more than 300 african negro on board the prize under the command of lieutenant bradford of the united states navy arrive at charleston on the 27th august when the negro 306 in number be deliver into the custody of the united states marshal for the district of south carolina they be first place in castle pinckney and afterwards in fort sumter for safe keeping and be detain there until the 19th september when the survivor 271 in number be deliver on board the united states steam niagara to be transport to the coast of africa under the charge of the agent of the united states pursuant to the provision of the act of the 3d march 1819 in addition to the act prohibit the slave trade under the second section of this act the president be authorize to make such regulation and arrangement as he may deem expedient for the safe keeping support and removal beyond the limit of the united states of all such negro mulattoe or person of color capture by vessel of the united states as may be deliver to the marshal of the district into which they be bring and to appoint a proper person or person reside upon the coast of africa as agent or agent for receive the negro mulattoe or person of color deliver from on board vessel seize in the prosecution of the slave trade by commander of united states armed vessel "a doubt immediately arise as to the true construction of this act it be quite clear from its term that the president be authorize to provide for the safe keeping support and removal of these negro up till the time of their delivery to the agent on the coast of africa but no express provision be make for their protection and support after they have reach the place of their destination still an agent be to be point to receive they in africa and it could not have be suppose that congress intend he should desert they at the moment they be receive and turn they loose on that inhospitable coast to perish for want of food or to become again the victim of the slave trade have this be the intention of congress the employment of an agent to receive they who be require to reside on the coast be unnecessary and they might have be land by our vessel anywhere in africa and leave expose to the suffering and the fate which would certainly await they mr. monroe in his special message of december 17 1819 at the first session after the act be pass announce to congress what in his opinion be its true construction he believe it to be his duty under it to follow these unfortunate into africa and make provision for they there until they should be able to provide for themselves in communicate this interpretation of the act to congress he state that some doubt have be entertain as to its true intent and meaning and he submit the question to they so that they might should it be deem advisable amend the same before further proceeding be have under it nothing be do by congress to explain the act and mr. monroe proceed to carry it into execution accord to his own interpretation this then become the practical construction when the africans from on board the echo be deliver to the marshal at charleston it become my duty to consider what disposition ought to be make of they under the law for many reason it be expedient to remove they from that locality as speedily as possible although the conduct of the authority and citizen of charleston in give countenance to the execution of the law be just what might have be expect from their high character yet a prolong continuance of 300 africans in the immediate vicinity of that city could not have fail to become a source of inconvenience and anxiety to its inhabitant where to send they be the question there be no portion of the coast of africa to which they could be remove with any regard to humanity except to liberia under these circumstance an agreement be enter into with the colonization society on the 7th of september last a copy of which be herewith transmit under which the society engage for the consideration of $ 45,000 to receive these africans in liberia from the agent of the united states and furnish they during the period of one year thereafter with comfortable shelter clothing provision and medical attendance cause the child to receive schooling and all whether child or adult to be instruct in the art of civilized life suitable to their condition this aggregate of $ 45,000 be base upon an allowance of $ 150 for each individual and as there have be considerable mortality among they and may be more before they reach africa the society have agree in an equitable spirit to make such a deduction from the amount as under the circumstance may appear just and reasonable this can not be fix until we shall ascertain the actual number which may become a charge to the society it be also distinctly agree that under no circumstance shall this government be call upon for any additional expense the agent of the society manifest a laudable desire to conform to the wish of the government throughout the transaction they assure i that after a careful calculation they would be require to expend the sum of $ 150 on each individual in comply with the agreement and they would have nothing leave to remunerate they for their care trouble and responsibility at all event i could make no well arrangement and there be no other alternative during the period when the government itself through its own agent undertake the task of provide for capture negro in africa the cost per head be very much great there having be no outstanding appropriation applicable to this purpose i could not advance any money on the agreement i therefore recommend that an appropriation may be make of the amount necessary to carry it into effect other capture of a similar character may and probably will be make by our naval force and i earnestly recommend that congress may amend the second section of the act of march 3 1819 so as to free its construction from the ambiguity which have so long exist and render the duty of the president plain in execute its provision i recommend to your favorable regard the local interest of the district of columbia as the residence of congress and the executive departments of the government we can not fail to feel a deep concern in its welfare this be heighten by the high character and the peaceful and orderly conduct of its resident inhabitant i can not conclude without perform the agreeable duty of express my gratification that congress so kindly respond to the recommendation of my last annual message by afford i sufficient time before the close of their late session for the examination of all the bill present to i for approval this change in the practice of congress have prove to be a wholesome reform it exert a beneficial influence on the transaction of legislative business and elicit the general approbation of the country it enable congress to adjourn with that dignity and deliberation so become to the representative of this great republic without having crowd into general appropriation bill provision foreign to their nature and of doubtful constitutionality and expediency let i warmly and strongly commend this precedent establish by themselves as a guide to their proceeding during the present session
to the senate and house of representatives
 the brief period which remain of your present session and the great urgency and importance of legislative action before its termination for the protection of american citizen and their property whilst in transit across the isthmus route between our atlantic and pacific possession render it my duty again to recall this subject to your notice i have heretofore present it in my annual message both in december 1857 and 1858 to which i beg leave to refer in the latter i state that--
 the executive government of this country in its intercourse with foreign nation be limit to the employment of diplomacy alone when this fail it can proceed no far it can not legitimately resort to force without the direct authority of congress except in resist and repel hostile attack it would have no authority to enter the territory of nicaragua even to prevent the destruction of the transit and protect the life and property of our own citizen on their passage it be true that on a sudden emergency of this character the president would direct any armed force in the vicinity to march to their relief but in do this he would act upon his own responsibility
 under these circumstance i earnestly recommend to congress the passage of an act authorize the president under such restriction as they may deem proper to employ the land and naval force of the united states in prevent the transit from be obstruct or close by lawless violence and in protect the life and property of american citizen travel thereupon require at the same time that these force shall be withdraw the moment the danger shall have pass away without such a provision our citizen will be constantly expose to interruption in their progress and to lawless violence
 a similar necessity exist for the passage of such an act for the protection of the panama and tehuantepec route
 another subject equally important command the attention of the senate at the last session of congress
 the republic south of the united states on this continent have unfortunately be frequently in a state of revolution and civil war ever since they achieve their independence as one or the other party have prevail and obtain possession of the port open to foreign commerce they have seize and confiscate american vessel and their cargo in an arbitrary and lawless manner and exact money from american citizen by force loan and other violent proceeding to enable they to carry on hostility the executive government of great britain france and other country possess the war make power can promptly employ the necessary mean to enforce immediate redress for similar outrage upon their subject not so the executive government of the united states
 if the president order a vessel of war to any of these port to demand prompt redress for outrage commit the offend party be well aware that in case of refusal the commander can do no more than remonstrate he can resort to no hostile act the question must then be refer to diplomacy and in many case adequate redress can never be obtain thus american citizen be deprive of the same protection under the flag of their country which the subject of other nation enjoy the remedy for this state of thing can only be supply by congress since the constitution have confide to that body alone the power to make war without the authority of congress the executive can not lawfully direct any force however near it may be to the scene of difficulty to enter the territory of mexico nicaragua or new granada for the purpose of defend the person and property of american citizen even though they may be violently assail whilst pass in peaceful transit over the tehuantepec nicaragua or panama route he can not without transcend his constitutional power direct a gun to be fire into a port or land a seaman or marine to protect the life of our countryman on shore or to obtain redress for a recent outrage on their property the banditti which inf our neighboring republic of mexico always claim to belong to one or other of the hostile party might make a sudden descent on vera cruz or on the tehuantepec route and he would have no power to employ the force on shipboard in the vicinity for their relief either to prevent the plunder of our merchant or the destruction of the transit
 in reference to country where the local authority be strong enough to enforce the law the difficulty here indicate can seldom happen but where this be not the case and the local authority do not possess the physical power even if they possess the will to protect our citizen within their limit recent experience have show that the american executive should itself be authorize to render this protection such a grant of authority thus limit in its extent could in no just sense be regard as a transfer of the war make power to the executive but only as an appropriate exercise of that power by the body to whom it exclusively belong the riot at panama in 1856 in which a great number of our citizen lose their life furnish a pointed illustration of the necessity which may arise for the exertion of this authority
 i therefore earnestly recommend to congress on whom the responsibility exclusively rest to pass a law before their adjournment confer on the president the power to protect the life and property of american citizen in the case which i have indicate under such restriction and condition as they may deem advisable the knowledge that such a law exist would of itself go far to prevent the outrage which it be intend to redress and to render the employment of force unnecessary
 without this the president may be place in a painful position before the meeting of the next congress in the present disturb condition of mexico and one or more of the other republics south of we no person can foresee what occurrence may take place before that period in case of emergency our citizen see that they do not enjoy the same protection with subject of european governments will have just cause to complain on the other hand should the executive interpose and especially should the result prove disastrous and valuable life be lose he might subject himself to severe censure for having assume a power not confide to he by the constitution it be to guard against this contingency that i now appeal to congress
 having thus recommend to congress a measure which i deem necessary and expedient for the interest and honor of the country i leave the whole subject to their wisdom and discretion

to the house of representatives of the united states
 i return with my objection to the house of representatives in which it originate the bill entitle an act donate public land to the several states and territories which may provide college for the benefit of agriculture and the mechanic art present to i on the 18th instant
 this bill make a donation to the several states of 20,000 acre of the public land for each senator and representative in the present congress and also an additional donation of 20,000 acre for each additional representative to which any state may be entitle under the census of 1860
 accord to a report from the interior department base upon the present number of senators and representatives the land give to the states amount to 6,060,000 acre and their value at the minimum government price of $ 1.25 per acre to $ 7,575,000
 the object of this gift as state by the bill be the endowment support and maintenance of at least one college in each state where the lead object shall be without exclude other scientific or classical study to teach such branch of learn as be relate to agriculture and the mechanic art as the legislature of the states may respectively prescribe in order to promote the liberal and practical education of the industrial class in the several pursuit and profession in life
 as there do not appear from the bill to be any beneficiary in existence to which this endowment can be apply each state be require to provide within five year at least not less than one college or the grant to say state shall cease in that event the say state shall be bind to pay the united states the amount receive of any land previously sell and that the title to purchaser under the state shall be valid
 the grant in land itself be confine to such states as have public land within their limit worth $ 1.25 per acre in the opinion of the governor for the remain states the secretary of the interior be direct to issue land scrip to the amount of their distributive share in acre under the provision of this act say scrip to be sell by say states and the proceed thereof apply to the use and purpose prescribe in this act and for no other use or purpose whatsoever the land be grant and the scrip be to be issue in section or subdivision of section of not less than one quarter of a section
 accord to an estimate from the interior department the number of acre which will probably be accept by state have public land within their own limit will not exceed 580,000 acre and it may be much less leave a balance of 5,480,000 acre to be provide for by scrip these grant of land and land scrip to each of the thirty three states be make upon certain condition the principal of which be that if the fund shall be lose or diminish on account of unfortunate investment or otherwise the deficiency shall be replace and make good by the respective states
 i shall now proceed to state my objection to this bill i deem it to be both inexpedient and unconstitutional
 1 this bill have be pass at a period when we can with great difficulty raise sufficient revenue to sustain the expense of the government should it become a law the treasury will be deprive of the whole or nearly the whole of our income from the sale of public land which for the next fiscal year have be estimate at $ 5,000,000
 a bare statement of the case will make this evident the minimum price at which we dispose of our land be $ 1.25 per acre at the present moment however the price have be reduce to those who purchase the bounty land warrant of the old soldier to 85 cent per acre and of these warrant there be still outstanding and unlocated as appear by a report february 12 1859 from the general land office the amount of 11,990,391 acre this have already greatly reduce the current sale by the government and diminish the revenue from this source if in addition thirty three states shall enter the market with their land scrip the price must be greatly reduce below even 85 cent per acre as much to the prejudice of the old soldier who have not already part with their land warrant as to government it be easy to perceive that with this glut of the market government can sell little or no land at $ 1.25 per acre when the price of bounty land warrant and scrip shall be reduce to half this sum this source of revenue will be almost entirely dry up under the bill the states may sell their land scrip at any price it may bring there be no limitation whatever in this respect indeed they must sell for what the scrip will bring for without this fund they can not proceed to establish their college within the five year to which they be limited it be manif therefore that to the extent to which this bill will prevent the sale of public land at $ 1.25 per acre to that amount it will have precisely the same effect upon the treasury as if we should impose a tax to create a loan to endow these state college
 surely the present be the most unpropitious moment which could have be select for the passage of this bill
 2 waive for the present the question of constitutional power what effect will this bill have on the relation establish between the federal and state government the constitution be a grant to congress of a few enumerate but most important power relate chiefly to war peace foreign and domestic commerce negotiation and other subject which can be good or alone exercise beneficially by the common government all other power be reserve to the states and to the people for the efficient and harmonious working of both it be necessary that their several sphere of action should be keep distinct from each other this alone can prevent conflict and mutual injury should the time ever arrive when the state government shall look to the federal treasury for the mean of support themselves and maintain their system of education and internal policy the character of both government will be greatly deteriorate the representative of the states and of the people feel a more immediate interest in obtain money to lighten the burden of their constituent than for the promotion of the more distant object intrust to the federal government will naturally incline to obtain mean from the federal government for state purpose if a question shall arise between an appropriation of land or money to carry into effect the object of the federal government and those of the states their feeling will be enlist in favor of the latter this be human nature and hence the necessity of keep the two government entirely distinct the preponderance of this home feeling have be manifest by the passage of the present bill the establishment of these college have prevail over the press want of the common treasury no nation ever have such an inheritance as we possess in the public land these ought to be manage with the utmost care but at the same time with a liberal spirit toward actual settler
 in the first year of a war with a powerful naval nation the revenue from custom must in a great degree cease a resort to loan will then become necessary and these can always be obtain as our father obtain they on advantageous term by pledge the public land as security in this view of the subject it would be wise to grant money to the states for domestic purpose than to squander away the public land and transfer they in large body into the hand of speculator
 a successful struggle on the part of the state government with the general government for the public land would deprive the latter of the mean of perform its high duty especially at critical and dangerous period besides it would operate with equal detriment to the good interest of the states it would remove the most wholesome of all restraint on legislative body that of be oblige to raise money by taxation from their constituent and would lead to extravagance if not to corruption what be obtain easily and without responsibility will be lavishly expend
 3 this bill should it become a law will operate greatly to the injury of the new states the progress of settlement and the increase of an industrious population own an interest in the soil they cultivate be the cause which will build they up into great and flourish commonwealth nothing could be more prejudicial to their interest than for wealthy individual to acquire large tract of the public land and hold they for speculative purpose the low price to which this land scrip will probably be reduce will tempt speculator to buy it in large amount and locate it on the good land belong to the government the eventual consequence must be that the man who desire to cultivate the soil will be compel to purchase these very land at rate much high than the price at which they could be obtain from the government
 4 it be extremely doubtful to say the least whether this bill would contribute to the advancement of agriculture and the mechanic art object the dignity and value of which can not be too highly appreciated
 the federal government which make the donation have confessedly no constitutional power to follow it into the states and enforce the application of the fund to the intended object as donor we shall possess no control over our own gift after it shall have pass from our hand it be true that the state legislature be require to stipulate that they will faithfully execute the trust in the manner prescribe by the bill but should they fail to do this what would be the consequence the federal government have no power and ought to have no power to compel the execution of the trust it would be in as helpless a condition as if even in this the time of great need we be to demand any portion of the many million of surplus revenue deposit with the states for safekeepe under the act of 1836
 5 this bill will injuriously interfere with exist college in the different states in many of which agriculture be teach as a science and in all of which it ought to be so taught these institution of learn have grow up with the growth of the country under the foster care of the states and the munificence of individual to meet the advance demand for education they have prove great blessing to the people many indeed most of they be poor and sustain themselves with difficulty what the effect will be on these institution of create an indefinite number of rival college sustain by the endowment of the federal government it be not difficult to determine
 under this bill it be provide that scientific and classical study shall not be exclude from they indeed it would be almost impossible to sustain they without such a provision for no father would incur the expense of send a son to one of these institution for the sole purpose of make he a scientific farmer or mechanic the bill itself negative this idea and declare that their object be to promote the liberal and practical education of the industrial class in the several pursuit and profession of life this certainly ought to be the case in this view of the subject it would be far well if such an appropriation of land must be make to institution of learn in the several states to apply it directly to the establishment of professorship of agriculture and the mechanic art in exist college without the intervention of the state legislature it would be difficult to foresee how these legislature will manage this fund each representative in congress for whose district the proportion of 20,000 acre have be grant will probably insist that the proceed shall be expend within its limit there will undoubtedly be a struggle between different locality in each state concern the division of the gift which may end in disappoint the hope of the true friend of agriculture for this state of thing we be without remedy not so in regard to state college we might grant land to these corporation to establish agricultural and mechanical professorship and should they fail to comply with the condition on which they accept the grant we might enforce specific performance of these before the ordinary court of justice
 6 but do congress possess the power under the constitution to make a donation of public land to the different states of the union to provide college for the purpose of educate their own people
 i presume the general proposition be undeniable that congress do not possess the power to appropriate money in the treasury raise by taxis on the people of the united states for the purpose of educate the people of the respective states it will not be pretend that any such power be to be find among the specific power grant to congress nor that it be necessary and proper for carry into execution any one of these power should congress exercise such a power this would be to break down the barrier which have be so carefully construct in the constitution to separate federal from state authority we should then not only lay and collect taxis duty impost and excise for federal purpose but for every state purpose which congress might deem expedient or useful this would be an actual consolidation of the federal and state government so far as the great taxing and money power be concern and constitute a sort of partnership between the two in the treasury of the united states equally ruinous to both
 but it be contend that the public land be place upon a different footing from money raise by taxation and that the proceed arise from their sale be not subject to the limitation of the constitution but may be appropriate or give away by congress at its own discretion to states corporation or individual for any purpose they may deem expedient
 the advocate of this bill attempt to sustain their position upon the language of the second clause of the third section of the fourth article of the constitution which declare that the congress shall have power to dispose of and make all needful rule and regulation respect the territory or other property belong to the united states they contend that by a fair interpretation of the word dispose of in this clause congress possess the power to make this gift of public land to the states for purpose of education
 it would require clear and strong evidence to induce the belief that the framer of the constitution after having limit the power of congress to certain precise and specific object intend by employ the word dispose of to give that body unlimited power over the vast public domain it would be a strange anomaly indeed to have create two fund the one by taxation confine to the execution of the enumerate power delegate to congress and the other from the public land applicable to all subject foreign and domestic which congress might designate that this fund should be dispose of not to pay the debt of the united states nor to raise and support army nor to provide and maintain a navy nor to accomplish any one of the other great object enumerate in the constitution but be divert from they to pay the debt of the states to educate their people and to carry into effect any other measure of their domestic policy this would be to confer upon congress a vast and irresponsible authority utterly at war with the well know jealousy of federal power which prevail at the formation of the constitution the natural intendment would be that as the constitution confine congress to well define specific power the fund place at their command whether in land or money should be appropriate to the performance of the duty correspond with these power if not a government have be create with all its other power carefully limited but without any limitation in respect to the public land
 but i can not so read the word dispose of as to make they embrace the idea of give away the true meaning of word be always to be ascertain by the subject to which they be apply and the know general intent of the lawgiver congress be a trustee under the constitution for the people of the united states to dispose of their public land and i think i may venture to assert with confidence that no case can be find in which a trustee in the position of congress have be authorize to dispose of property by its owner where it have be hold that these word authorize such trustee to give away the fund intrust to his care no trustee when call upon to account for the disposition of the property place under his management before any judicial tribunal would venture to present such a plea in his defense the true meaning of these word be clearly state by chief justice taney in deliver the opinion of the court 19 howard p. 436 he say in reference to this clause of the constitution
 it begin its enumeration of power by that of dispose in other word make sale of the land or raise money from they which as we have already say be the main object of the cession from the states and which be the first thing provide for in the article
 it be unnecessary to refer to the history of the time to establish the known fact that this statement of the chief justice be perfectly well rounded that it never be intend by the framer of the constitution that these land should be give away by congress be manifest from the conclude portion of the same clause by it congress have power not only to dispose of the territory but of the other property of the united states in the language of the chief justice p. 437
 and the same power of make needful rule respect the territory be in precisely the same language apply to the other property of the united states associate the power over the territory in this respect with the power over movable or personal property that is the ship arm or munition of war which then belong in common to the state sovereignty
 the question be still clear in regard to the public land in the states and territories within the louisiana and florida purchase these land be pay for out of the public treasury from money raise by taxation now if congress have no power to appropriate the money with which these land be purchase be it not clear that the power over the land be equally limited the mere conversion of this money into land could not confer upon congress new power over the disposition of land which they have not possess over money if it could then a trustee by change the character of the fund intrust to his care for special object from money into land might give the land away or devote it to any purpose he think proper however foreign from the trust the inference be irresistible that this land partake of the very same character with the money pay for it and can be devoted to no object different from those to which the money could have be devote if this be not the case then by the purchase of a new territory from a foreign government out of the public treasury congress could enlarge their own power and appropriate the proceed of the sale of the land thus purchase at their own discretion to other and far different object from what they could have apply the purchase money which have be raise by taxation
 it have be assert truly that congress in numerous instance have grant land for the purpose of education these grant have be chiefly if not exclusively make to the new states as they successively enter the union and consist at the first of one section and afterwards of two section of the public land in each township for the use of school as well as of additional section for a state university such grant be not in my opinion a violation of the constitution the united states be a great landed proprietor and from the very nature of this relation it be both the right and the duty of congress as their trustee to manage these land as any other prudent proprietor would manage they for his own good advantage now no consideration could be present of a strong character to induce the american people to brave the difficulty and hardship of frontier life and to settle upon these land and to purchase they at a fair price than to give to they and to their child an assurance of the mean of education if any prudent individual have hold these land he could not have adopt a wise course to bring they into market and enhance their value than to give a portion of they for purpose of education as a mere speculation he would pursue this course no person will contend that donation of land to all the states of the union for the erection of college within the limit of each can be embrace by this principle it can not be pretend that an agricultural college in new york or virginia would aid the settlement or facilitate the sale of public land in minnesota or california this can not possibly be embrace within the authority which a prudent proprietor of land would exercise over his own possession i purposely avoid any attempt to define what portion of land may be grant and for what purpose to improve the value and promote the settlement and sale of the remainder without violate the constitution in this case i adopt the rule that sufficient unto the day be the evil thereof

fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives our deep and heartfelt gratitude be due to that almighty power which have bestow upon we such varied and numerous blessing throughout the past year the general health of the country have be excellent our harvest have be unusually plentiful and prosperity smile throughout the land indeed notwithstanding our demerit we have much reason to believe from the past event in our history that we have enjoy the special protection of divine providence ever since our origin as a nation we have be expose to many threatening and alarm difficulty in our progress but on each successive occasion the impending cloud have be dissipate at the moment it appear ready to burst upon our head and the danger to our institution have pass away may we ever be under the divine guidance and protection whilst it be the duty of the president from time to time to give to congress information of the state of the union i shall not refer in detail to the recent sad and bloody occurrence at harpers ferry still it be proper to observe that these event however bad and cruel in themselves derive their chief importance from the apprehension that they be but symptom of an incurable disease in the public mind which may break out in still more dangerous outrage and terminate at last in an open war by the north to abolish slavery in the south whilst for myself i entertain no such apprehension they ought to afford a solemn warning to we all to beware of the approach of danger our union be a stake of such inestimable value as to demand our constant and watchful vigilance for its preservation in this view let i implore my countryman north and south to cultivate the ancient feeling of mutual forbearance and good will toward each other and strive to allay the demon spirit of sectional hatred and strife now alive in the land this advice proceed from the heart of an old public functionary whose service commence in the last generation among the wise and conservative statesman of that day now nearly all pass away and whose first and dear earthly wish be to leave his country tranquil prosperous united and powerful we ought to reflect that in this age and especially in this country there be an incessant flux and reflux of public opinion question which in their day assume a most threatening aspect have now nearly go from the memory of man they be volcano burn out and on the lava and ashe and squalid scoria of old eruption grow the peaceful olive the cheer vine and the sustain corn such in my opinion will prove to be the fate of the present sectional excitement should those who wisely seek to apply the remedy continue always to confine their effort within the pale of the constitution if this course be pursue the exist agitation on the subject of domestic slavery like everything human will have its day and give place to other and less threatening controversy public opinion in this country be all powerful and when it reach a dangerous excess upon any question the good sense of the people will furnish the corrective and bring it back within safe limit still to hasten this auspicious result at the present crisis we ought to remember that every rational creature must be presume to intend the natural consequence of his own teaching those who announce abstract doctrine subversive of the constitution and the union must not be surprised should their heated partisan advance one step far and attempt by violence to carry these doctrine into practical effect in this view of the subject it ought never to be forget that however great may have be the political advantage result from the union to every portion of our common country these would all prove to be as nothing should the time ever arrive when they can not be enjoy without serious danger to the personal safety of the people of fifteen member of the confederacy if the peace of the domestic fireside throughout these states should ever be invade if the mother of family within this extensive region should not be able to retire to rest at night without suffer dreadful apprehension of what may be their own fate and that of their child before the morning it would be vain to recount to such a people the political benefit which result to they from the union self preservation be the first instinct of nature and therefore any state of society in which the sword be all the time suspend over the head of the people must at last become intolerable but i indulge in no such gloomy foreboding on the contrary i firmly believe that the event at harpers ferry by cause the people to pause and reflect upon the possible peril to their cherished institution will be the mean under providence of allay the exist excitement and prevent further outbreak of a similar character they will resolve that the constitution and the union shall not be endanger by rash counsel know that should the silver cord be loose or the golden bowl be break at the fountain human power could never reunite the scattered and hostile fragment i cordially congratulate you upon the final settlement by the supreme court of the united states of the question of slavery in the territories which have present an aspect so truly formidable at the commencement of my administration the right have be establish of every citizen to take his property of any kind include slave into the common territories belong equally to all the states of the confederacy and to have it protect there under the federal constitution neither congress nor a territorial legislature nor any human power have any authority to annul or impair this vest right the supreme judicial tribunal of the country which be a coordinate branch of the government have sanction and affirm these principle of constitutional law so manifestly just in themselves and so well calculate to promote peace and harmony among the states it be a striking proof of the sense of justice which be inherent in our people that the property in slave have never be disturb to my knowledge in any of the territories even throughout the late trouble in kansas there have not be any attempt as i be credibly inform to interfere in a single instance with the right of the master have any such attempt be make the judiciary would doubtless have afford an adequate remedy should they fail to do this hereafter it will then be time enough to strengthen their hand by further legislation have it be decide that either congress or the territorial legislature possess the power to annul or impair the right to property in slave the evil would be intolerable in the latter event there would be a struggle for a majority of the member of the legislature at each successive election and the sacred right of property hold under the federal constitution would depend for the time be on the result the agitation would thus be render incessant whilst the territorial condition remain and its baneful influence would keep alive a dangerous excitement among the people of the several state thus have the status of a territory during the intermediate period from its first settlement until it shall become a state be irrevocably fix by the final decision of the supreme court fortunate have this be for the prosperity of the territories as well as the tranquillity of the states now emigrant from the north and the south the east and the west will meet in the territories on a common platform having bring with they that specie of property well adapt in their own opinion to promote their welfare from natural cause the slavery question will in each case soon virtually settle itself and before the territory be prepare for admission as a state into the union this decision one way or the other will have be a foregone conclusion meanwhile the settlement of the new territory will proceed without serious interruption and its progress and prosperity will not be endanger or retard by violent political struggle when in the progress of event the inhabitant of any territory shall have reach the number require to form a state they will then proceed in a regular manner and in the exercise of the right of popular sovereignty to form a constitution preparatory to admission into the union after this have be do to employ the language of the kansas and nebraska act they shall be receive into the union with or without slavery as their constitution may prescribe at the time of their admission this sound principle have happily be recognize in some form or other by an almost unanimous vote of both houses of the last congress all lawful mean at my command have be employ and shall continue to be employ to execute the law against the african slave trade after a most careful and rigorous examination of our coast and a thorough investigation of the subject we have not be able to discover that any slave have be import into the united states except the cargo by the wanderer number between three and four hundred those engage in this unlawful enterprise have be rigorously prosecute but not with as much success as their crime have deserve a number of they be still under prosecution our history prove that the father of the republic in advance of all other nation condemn the african slave trade it be notwithstanding deem expedient by the framer of the constitution to deprive congress of the power to prohibit the migration or importation of such person as any of the states now exist shall think proper to admit prior to the year 1808 it will be see that this restriction on the power of congress be confine to such state only as might think proper to admit the importation of slave it do not extend to other states or to the trade carry on abroad accordingly we find that so early as the 22d march 1794 congress pass an act impose severe penalty and punishment upon citizen and resident of the united states who should engage in this trade between foreign nation the provision of this act be extend and enforce by the act of 10th may 1800.again the states themselves have a clear right to waive the constitutional privilege intend for their benefit and to prohibit by their own law this trade at any time they think proper previous to 1808 several of they exercise this right before that period and among they some contain the great number of slave this give to congress the immediate power to act in regard to all such state because they themselves have remove the constitutional barrier congress accordingly pass an act on 28th february 1803 to prevent the importation of certain person into certain states where by the law thereof their admission be prohibit in this manner the importation of african slave into the united states be to a great extent prohibit some year in advance of 1808.as the year 1808 approach congress determine not to suffer this trade to exist even for a single day after they have the power to abolish it on the 2d of march 1807 they pass an act to take effect from and after the 1st day of january 1808 prohibit the importation of african slave into the united states this be follow by subsequent act of a similar character to which i need not specially refer such be the principle and such the practice of our ancestor more than fifty year ago in regard to the african slave trade it do not occur to the revered patriot who have be delegate to the convention and afterwards become member of congress that in pass these law they have violate the constitution which they have frame with so much care and deliberation they suppose that to prohibit congress in express term from exercise a specify power before an appoint day necessarily involve the right to exercise this power after that day have arrive if this be not the case the framer of the constitution have expend much labor in vain have they imagine that congress would possess no power to prohibit the trade either before or after 1808 they would not have take so much care to protect the states against the exercise of this power before that period nay more they would not have attach such vast importance to this provision as to have exclude it from the possibility of future repeal or amendment to which other portion of the constitution be expose it would then have be wholly unnecessary to ingraft on the fifth article of the constitution prescribe the mode of its own future
