african slave previous to that period accord to the adverse construction the clause itself on which so much care and discussion have be employ by the member of the convention be an absolute nullity from the beginning and all that have since be do under it a mere usurpation it be well and wise to confer this power on congress because have it be leave to the states its efficient exercise would have be impossible in that event any one state could have effectually continue the trade not only for itself but for all the other slave states though never so much against their will and why because african slave when once bring within the limit of any one state in accordance with its law can not practically be exclude from any state where slavery exist and even if all the states have separately pass law prohibit the importation of slave these law would have fail of effect for want of a naval force to capture the slaver and to guard the coast such a force no state can employ in time of peace without the consent of congress these act of congress it be believe have with very rare and insignificant exception accomplish their purpose for a period of more than half a century there have be no perceptible addition to the number of our domestic slave during this period their advancement in civilization have far surpass that of any other portion of the african race the light and the blessing of christianity have be extend to they and both their moral and physical condition have be greatly improve reopen the trade and it would be difficult to determine whether the effect would be more deleterious on the interest of the master or on those of the native bear slave of the evil to the master the one most to be dread would be the introduction of wild heathen and ignorant barbarian among the sober orderly and quiet slave whose ancestor have be on the soil for several generation this might tend to barbarize demoralize and exasperate the whole mass and produce most deplorable consequence the effect upon the exist slave would if possible be still more deplorable at present he be treat with kindness and humanity he be well feed well clothe and not overwork his condition be incomparably well than that of the coolie which modern nation of high civilization have employ as a substitute for african slave both the philanthropy and the self interest of the master have combine trade be openly tolerate and this in defiance of solemn treaty with a power abundantly able at any moment to enforce their execution there the master intent upon present gain extort from the slave as much labor as his physical power be capable of endure know that when death come to his relief his place can be supply at a price reduce to the low point by the competition of rival african slave trader should this ever be the case in our country which i do not deem possible the present useful character of the domestic institution wherein those too old and too young to work be provide for with care and humanity and those capable of labor be not overtaske would undergo an unfortunate change the feeling of reciprocal dependence and attachment which now exist between master and slave would be convert into mutual distrust and hostility but we be oblige as a christian and moral nation to consider what would be the effect upon unhappy africa itself if we should reopen the slave trade this would give the trade an impulse and extension which it have never have even in its palmy day the numerous victim require to supply it would convert the whole slave coast into a perfect pandemonium for united states write our late minister in 1856 and of its purpose to punish these wrong will avail i assure you that the universal belief here be that there be nothing to be apprehend from the will feel authorize to ask from congress the power to enter mexico with the military force of the united states at the call of the constitutional authority in order to protect the citizen and the treaty right of the united states unless such a power be confer upon he neither the one nor the other will be respect in the exist state of anarchy and disorder and the outrage already perpetrate will never be chastise and as i assure you in my no 23 all these evil must increase until every vestige of order and government disappear from the country i have be reluctantly lead to the same opinion and in justice to my countryman who have suffer wrong from mexico and who may still suffer they i feel bound to announce this conclusion to congress the case present however be not merely a case of individual claim although our just claim against mexico have reach a very large amount nor be it merely the case of protection to the life and property of the few americans who may still remain in mexico although the life and property of every american citizen ought to be sacredly protect in every quarter of the world but it be a question which relate to the future as well as to the present and the past and which involve indirectly at least the whole subject of our duty to mexico as a neighboring state the exercise of the power of the united states in that country to redress the wrong and protect the right of our own citizen be none the less to be desire because efficient and necessary aid may thus be render at the same time to restore peace and order to mexico itself in the accomplishment of this result the people of the united states must necessarily feel a deep and earnest interest mexico ought to be a rich and prosperous and powerful republic she possess an extensive territory a fertile soil and an incalculable store of mineral wealth she occupy an important position between the gulf and the ocean for transit route and for commerce be it possible that such a country as this can be give up to anarchy and ruin without an effort from any quarter for its rescue and its safety will the commercial nation of the world which have so many interest connect with it remain wholly indifferent to such a result can the united states especially which ought to share most largely in its commercial intercourse allow their immediate neighbor thus to destroy itself and injure they yet without support from some quarter it be impossible to perceive how mexico can resume her position among nation and enter upon a career which promise any good result the aid which she require and which the interest of all commercial country require that she should have it belong to this government to render not only by virtue of our neighborhood to mexico along whose territory we have a continuous frontier of nearly a thousand mile but by virtue also of our establish policy which be inconsistent with the intervention of any european power in the domestic concern of that republic the wrong which we have suffer from mexico be before the world and must deeply impress every american citizen a government which be either unable or unwilling to redress such wrong be derelict to its high duty the difficulty consist in select and enforce the remedy we may in vain apply to the constitutional government at vera cruz although it be well disposed to do we justice for adequate redress whilst its authority be acknowledge in all the important port and throughout the seacoast of the republic its power do not extend to the city of mexico and the states in its vicinity where nearly all the recent outrage have be commit on american citizen we must penetrate into the interior before we can reach the offender and this can only be do by pass through the territory in the occupation of the constitutional government the most acceptable and least difficult mode of accomplish the object will be to act in concert with that government their consent and their aid might i believe be obtain but if not our obligation to protect our own citizen in their just right secure by treaty would not be the less imperative for these reason i recommend to congress to pass a law authorize the president under such condition as they may deem expedient to employ a sufficient military force to enter mexico for the purpose of obtain indemnity for the past and security for the future i purposely refrain from any suggestion as to whether this force shall consist of regular troop or volunteer or both this question may be most appropriately leave to the decision of congress i would merely observe that should volunteer be select such a force could be easily raise in this country among those who sympathize with the suffering of our unfortunate fellow citizen in mexico and with the unhappy condition of that republic such an accession to the force of the constitutional government would enable it soon to reach the city of mexico and extend its power over the whole republic in that event there be no reason to doubt that the just claim of our citizen would be satisfied and adequate redress obtain for the injury inflict upon they the constitutional government have ever evince a strong desire to do justice and this might be secure in advance by a preliminary treaty it may be say that these measure will at least indirectly be inconsistent with our wise and settle policy not to interfere in the domestic concern of foreign nation but do not the present case fairly constitute an exception an adjoining republic be in a state of anarchy and confusion from which she have prove wholly unable to extricate herself she be entirely destitute of the power to maintain peace upon her border or to prevent the incursion of banditti into our territory in her fate and in her fortune in her power to establish and maintain a settle government we have a far deep interest socially commercially and politically than any other nation she be now a wreck upon the ocean drift about as she be impel by different faction as a good neighbor shall we not extend to she a help hand to save she if we do not it would not be surprising should some other nation undertake the task and thus force we to interfere at last under circumstance of increase difficulty for the maintenance of our establish policy i repeat the recommendation contain in my last annual message that authority may be give to the president to establish one or more temporary military post across the mexican line in sonora and chihuahua where these may be necessary to protect the life and property of american and mexican citizen against the incursion and depredation of the indians as well as of lawless rover on that remote region the establishment of one such post at a point call arispe in sonora in a country now almost depopulated by the hostile inroad of the indians from our side of the line would it be believe have prevent much injury and many cruelty during the past season a state of lawlessness and violence prevail on that distant frontier life and property be there wholly insecure the population of arizona now number more than 10,000 soul be practically destitute of government of law or of any arizona the treaty with nicaragua of the 16th of february 1857 to which i refer in my last annual message fail to receive the ratification of the government of that republic for reason which i need prevent the evil neither would this require any additional appropriation for the naval service the chief objection urge against the grant of this authority be that congress by confer it would violate the constitution that it would be a transfer of the war making or strictly speak the war declare power to the executive if this be well rounded it would of course be conclusive a very brief examination however will place this objection at rest congress possess the sole and exclusive power under the constitution to declare war they alone can"raise and support army and provide and maintain a navy but after congress shall have declare war and provide the force necessary to carry it on the president as commander in chief of the army and navy can alone employ this force in make war against the enemy this be the plain language and history prove that it be the well know intention of the framer of the constitution it will not be deny that the general power to declare war be without limitation and embrace within itself not only what writer on the law of nation term a public or perfect war but also an imperfect war and in short every specie of hostility however confine or limited without the authority of congress the president can not fire a hostile gun in any case except to repel the attack of an enemy it will not be doubt that under this power congress could if they think proper authorize the president to employ the force at his command to seize a vessel belong to an american citizen which have be illegally and unjustly capture in a foreign port and restore it to its afterwards occur must they wait until the mischief have be do and can they apply the remedy only when it be too late to confer this authority to meet future case under circumstance strictly specify be as clearly within the war declare power as such an authority confer upon the president by act of congress after the deed have be do in the progress of a great nation many exigency must arise imperatively require that congress should authorize the president to act promptly on certain condition which may or may not afterwards arise our history have already present a number of such case i protection nor redress can be otherwise obtain the thirty fifth congress terminate on the 3d of march 1859 without having pass the act make appropriation for the service of the post office department for president and vice president and this measure have be approve by the country i would again express a most decide opinion in favor of the construction of a pacific railroad for the reason state in consist not in withhold the mean necessary to accomplish important national object confide to we by the constitution but in take care that the money appropriate for these purpose shall be faithfully and frugally expend it will appear from the report of the secretary of the treasury that it be extremely doubtful to say the least whether we shall be able to pass through the present and the next increase the national debt to meet the ordinary expense of the government this policy would cripple our resource and impair our credit in case the existence of war should render it necessary to borrow money should such a deficiency occur as i apprehend i would recommend that the necessary revenue be raise by an increase of our present duty on import i need not repeat the opinion express in my last mr. president and fellow citizen of new york

 the fact with which i shall deal this evening be mainly old and familiar nor be there anything new in the general use i shall make of they if there shall be any novelty it will be in the mode of present the fact and the inference and observation follow that presentation

 in his speech last autumn at columbus ohio as report in the new york times senator douglas say

 our father when they frame the government under which we live understand this question just as well and even well than we do now

 i fully indorse this and i adopt it as a text for this discourse i so adopt it because it furnish a precise and an agree starting point for a discussion between republicans and that wing of the democracy head by senator douglas it simply leave the inquiry what be the understanding those father have of the question mention

 what be the frame of government under which we live

 the answer must be the constitution of the united states that constitution consist of the original frame in 1787 and under which the present government first go into operation and twelve subsequently frame amendment the first ten of which be frame in 1789

 who be our father that frame the constitution i suppose the thirty nine who sign the original instrument may be fairly call our father who frame that part of the present government it be almost exactly true to say they frame it and it be altogether true to say they fairly represent the opinion and sentiment of the whole nation at that time their name be familiar to nearly all and accessible to quite all need not now be repeat

 i take these thirty nine for the present as be our father who frame the government under which we live

 what be the question which accord to the text those father understand just as well and even well than we do now

 it be this do the proper division of local from federal authority or anything in the constitution forbid our federal government to control as to slavery in our federal territories

 upon this senator douglas hold the affirmative and republicans the negative this affirmation and denial form an issue and this issue this question be precisely what the text declare our father understand well than we

 let we now inquire whether the thirty nine or any of they ever act upon this question and if they do how they act upon it how they express that well understanding

 in 1784 three year before the constitution the united states then own the northwestern territory and no other the congress of the confederation have before they the question of prohibit slavery in that territory and four of the thirty nine who afterward frame the constitution be in that congress and vote on that question of these roger sherman thomas mifflin and hugh williamson vote for the prohibition thus show that in their understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything else properly forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory the other of the four james m'henry vote against the prohibition show that for some cause he think it improper to vote for it

 in 1787 still before the constitution but while the convention be in session frame it and while the northwestern territory still be the only territory own by the united states the same question of prohibit slavery in the territory again come before the congress of the confederation and two more of the thirty nine who afterward sign the constitution be in that congress and vote on the question they be william blount and william few and they both vote for the prohibition thus show that in their understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything else properly forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory this time the prohibition become a law be part of what be now well know as the ordinance of 87

 the question of federal control of slavery in the territory seem not to have be directly before the convention which frame the original constitution and hence it be not record that the thirty nine or any of they while engage on that instrument express any opinion on that precise question

 in 1789 by the first congress which sit under the constitution an act be pass to enforce the ordinance of 87 include the prohibition of slavery in the northwestern territory the bill for this act be report by one of the thirty nine thomas fitzsimmons then a member of the house of representatives from pennsylvania it go through all its stage without a word of opposition and finally pass both branch without yea and nay which be equivalent to a unanimous passage in this congress there be sixteen of the thirty nine father who frame the original constitution they be john langdon nicholas gilman wm s. johnson roger sherman robert morris thos fitzsimmon william few abraham baldwin rufus king william paterson george clymer richard bassett george read pierce butler daniel carroll james madison

 this show that in their understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything in the constitution properly forbid congress to prohibit slavery in the federal territory else both their fidelity to correct principle and their oath to support the constitution would have constrain they to oppose the prohibition

 again george washington another of the thirty nine be then president of the united states and as such approve and sign the bill thus complete its validity as a law and thus show that in his understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything in the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory

 no great while after the adoption of the original constitution north carolina cede to the federal government the country now constitute the state of tennessee and a few year later georgia cede that which now constitute the states of mississippi and alabama in both deed of cession it be make a condition by the cede states that the federal government should not prohibit slavery in the ceded territory besides this slavery be then actually in the ceded country under these circumstance congress on take charge of these country do not absolutely prohibit slavery within they but they do interfere with it take control of it even there to a certain extent in 1798 congress organize the territory of mississippi in the act of organization they prohibit the bringing of slave into the territory from any place without the united states by fine and give freedom to slave so buy this act pass both branch of congress without yea and nay in that congress be three of the thirty nine who frame the original constitution they be john langdon george read and abraham baldwin they all probably vote for it certainly they would have place their opposition to it upon record if in their understanding any line divide local from federal authority or anything in the constitution properly forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory

 in 1803 the federal government purchase the louisiana country our former territorial acquisition come from certain of our own states but this louisiana country be acquire from a foreign nation in 1804 congress give a territorial organization to that part of it which now constitute the state of louisiana new orleans lie within that part be an old and comparatively large city there be other considerable town and settlement and slavery be extensively and thoroughly intermingle with the people congress do not in the territorial act prohibit slavery but they do interfere with it take control of it in a more marked and extensive way than they do in the case of mississippi the substance of the provision therein make in relation to slave be

 first that no slave should be import into the territory from foreign part

 second that no slave should be carry into it who have be import into the united states since the first day of may 1798

 third that no slave should be carry into it except by the owner and for his own use as a settler the penalty in all the case be a fine upon the violator of the law and freedom to the slave

 this act also be pass without yea and nay in the congress which pass it there be two of the thirty nine they be abraham baldwin and jonathan dayton as state in the case of mississippi it be probable they both vote for it they would not have allow it to pass without record their opposition to it if in their understanding it violate either the line properly divide local from federal authority or any provision of the constitution

 in 1819 20 come and pass the missouri question many vote be take by yea and nay in both branch of congress upon the various phase of the general question two of the thirty nine rufus king and charles pinckney be member of that congress mr. king steadily vote for slavery prohibition and against all compromise while mr. pinckney as steadily vote against slavery prohibition and against all compromise by this mr. king show that in his understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything in the constitution be violate by congress prohibit slavery in federal territory while mr. pinckney by his vote show that in his understanding there be some sufficient reason for oppose such prohibition in that case

 the case i have mention be the only act of the thirty nine or of any of they upon the direct issue which i have be able to discover

 to enumerate the person who thus act as be four in 1784 two in 1787 seventeen in 1789 three in 1798 two in 1804 and two in 1819 20 there would be thirty of they but this would be count john langdon roger sherman william few rufus king and george read each twice and abraham baldwin three time the true number of those of the thirty nine whom i have show to have act upon the question which by the text they understand well than we be twenty three leave sixteen not show to have act upon it in any way

 here then we have twenty three out of our thirty nine father who frame the government under which we live who have upon their official responsibility and their corporal oath act upon the very question which the text affirm they understand just as well and even well than we do now and twenty one of they a clear majority of the whole thirty nine so act upon it as to make they guilty of gross political impropriety and willful perjury if in their understanding any proper division between local and federal authority or anything in the constitution they have make themselves and swear to support forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory thus the twenty one act and as action speak louder than word so action under such responsibility speak still louder

 two of the twenty three vote against congressional prohibition of slavery in the federal territory in the instance in which they act upon the question but for what reason they so vote be not know they may have do so because they think a proper division of local from federal authority or some provision or principle of the constitution stand in the way or they may without any such question have vote against the prohibition on what appear to they to be sufficient ground of expediency no one who have swear to support the constitution can conscientiously vote for what he understand to be an unconstitutional measure however expedient he may think it but one may and ought to vote against a measure which he deem constitutional if at the same time he deem it inexpedient it therefore would be unsafe to set down even the two who vote against the prohibition as having do so because in their understanding any proper division of local from federal authority or anything in the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory

 the remain sixteen of the thirty nine so far as i have discover have leave no record of their understanding upon the direct question of federal control of slavery in the federal territory but there be much reason to believe that their understanding upon that question would not have appear different from that of their twenty three compeer have it be manifest at all

 for the purpose of adhere rigidly to the text i have purposely omit whatever understanding may have be manifest by any person however distinguish other than the thirty nine father who frame the original constitution and for the same reason i have also omit whatever understanding may have be manifest by any of the thirty nine even on any other phase of the general question of slavery if we should look into their act and declaration on those other phase as the foreign slave trade and the morality and policy of slavery generally it would appear to we that on the direct question of federal control of slavery in federal territory the sixteen if they have act at all would probably have act just as the twenty three do among that sixteen be several of the most noted anti slavery man of those time as dr. franklin alexander hamilton and gouverneur morris while there be not one now know to have be otherwise unless it may be john rutledge of south carolina

 the sum of the whole be that of our thirty nine father who frame the original constitution twenty one a clear majority of the whole certainly understand that no proper division of local from federal authority nor any part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control slavery in the federal territory while all the rest probably have the same understanding such unquestionably be the understanding of our father who frame the original constitution and the text affirm that they understand the question well than we

 but so far i have be consider the understanding of the question manifest by the framer of the original constitution in and by the original instrument a mode be provide for amend it and as i have already state the present frame of the government under which we live consist of that original and twelve amendatory article frame and adopt since those who now insist that federal control of slavery in federal territory violate the constitution point we to the provision which they suppose it thus violate and as i understand that all fix upon provision in these amendatory article and not in the original instrument the supreme court in the dred scott case plant themselves upon the fifth amendment which provide that no person shall be deprive of life liberty or property without due process of law while senator douglas and his peculiar adherent plant themselves upon the tenth amendment provide that the power not delegate to the united states by the constitution be reserve to the states respectively or to the people

 now it so happen that these amendment be frame by the first congress which sit under the constitution the identical congress which pass the act already mention enforce the prohibition of slavery in the northwestern territory not only be it the same congress but they be the identical same individual man who at the same session and at the same time within the session have under consideration and in progress toward maturity these constitutional amendment and this act prohibit slavery in all the territory the nation then own the constitutional amendment be introduce before and pass after the act enforce the ordinance of 87 so that during the whole pendency of the act to enforce the ordinance the constitutional amendment be also pende

 the seventy six member of that congress include sixteen of the framer of the original constitution as before state be pre- eminently our father who frame that part of the government under which we live which be now claim as forbid the federal government to control slavery in the federal territory

 be it not a little presumptuous in any one at this day to affirm that the two thing which that congress deliberately frame and carry to maturity at the same time be absolutely inconsistent with each other and do not such affirmation become impudently absurd when couple with the other affirmation from the same mouth that those who do the two thing allege to be inconsistent understand whether they really be inconsistent well than we well than he who affirm that they be inconsistent

 it be surely safe to assume that the thirty nine framer of the original constitution and the seventy six member of the congress which frame the amendment thereto take together do certainly include those who may be fairly call our father who frame the government under which we live and so assume i defy any man to show that any one of they ever in his whole life declare that in his understanding any proper division of local from federal authority or any part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory i go a step far i defy any one to show that any live man in the whole world ever do prior to the beginning of the present century and i might almost say prior to the beginning of the last half of the present century declare that in his understanding any proper division of local from federal authority or any part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory to those who now so declare i give not only our father who frame the government under which we live but with they all other live man within the century in which it be frame among whom to search and they shall not be able to find the evidence of a single man agree with they

 now and here let i guard a little against be misunderstood i do not mean to say we be bind to follow implicitly in whatever our father do to do so would be to discard all the light of current experience to reject all progress all improvement what i do say be that if we would supplant the opinion and policy of our father in any case we should do so upon evidence so conclusive and argument so clear that even their great authority fairly consider and weigh can not stand and most surely not in a case whereof we ourselves declare they understand the question well than we

 if any man at this day sincerely believe that a proper division of local from federal authority or any part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory he be right to say so and to enforce his position by all truthful evidence and fair argument which he can but he have no right to mislead other who have less access to history and less leisure to study it into the false belief that our father who frame the government under which we live be of the same opinion thus substitute falsehood and deception for truthful evidence and fair argument if any man at this day sincerely believe our father who frame the government under which we live use and apply principle in other case which ought to have lead they to understand that a proper division of local from federal authority or some part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory he be right to say so but he should at the same time brave the responsibility of declare that in his opinion he understand their principle well than they do themselves and especially should he not shirk that responsibility by assert that they understand the question just as well and even well than we do now

 but enough let all who believe that our father who frame the government under which we live understand this question just as well and even well than we do now speak as they speak and act as they act upon it this be all republicans ask all republicans desire in relation to slavery as those father mark it so let it be again mark as an evil not to be extend but to be tolerate and protect only because of and so far as its actual presence among we make that toleration and protection a necessity let all the guarantee those father give it be not grudgingly but fully and fairly maintain for this republicans contend and with this so far as i know or believe they will be content

 you say we be sectional we deny it that make an issue and the burden of proof be upon you you produce your proof and what be it why that our party have no existence in your section get no vote in your section the fact be substantially true but do it prove the issue if it do then in case we should without change of principle begin to get vote in your section we should thereby cease to be sectional you can not escape this conclusion and yet be you willing to abide by it if you be you will probably soon find that we have cease to be sectional for we shall get vote in your section this very year you will then begin to discover as the truth plainly be that your proof do not touch the issue the fact that we get no vote in your section be a fact of your making and not of our and if there be fault in that fact that fault be primarily your and remain until you show that we repel you by some wrong principle or practice if we do repel you by any wrong principle or practice the fault be ours but this bring you to where you ought to have start to a discussion of the right or wrong of our principle if our principle put in practice would wrong your section for the benefit of our or for any other object then our principle and we with it be sectional and be justly oppose and denounce as such meet we then on the question of whether our principle put in practice would wrong your section and so meet it as if it be possible that something may be say on our side do you accept the challenge no then you really believe that the principle which our father who frame the government under which we live think so clearly right as to adopt it and indorse it again and again upon their official oath be in fact so clearly wrong as to demand your condemnation without a moment 's consideration

 some of you delight to flaunt in our face the warning against sectional party give by washington in his farewell address less than eight year before washington give that warning he have as president of the united states approve and sign an act of congress enforce the prohibition of slavery in the northwestern territory which act embody the policy of the government upon that subject up to and at the very moment he pen that warning and about one year after he pen it he write lafayette that he consider that prohibition a wise measure express in the same connection his hope that we should at some time have a confederacy of free states

 wrong as we think slavery be we can yet afford to let it alone where it be because that much be due to the necessity arise from its actual presence in the nation but can we while our vote will prevent it allow it to spread into the national territories and to overrun we here in these free states if our sense of duty forbid this then let we stand by our duty fearlessly and effectively let we be divert by none of those sophistical contrivance wherewith we be so industriously ply and belabor contrivance such as grope for some middle ground between the right and the wrong vain as the search for a man who should be neither a live man nor a dead man such as a policy of do not care on a question about which all true man do care such as union appeal beseech true union man to yield to disunionists reverse the divine rule and call not the sinner but the righteous to repentance such as invocation to washington implore man to unsay what washington say and undo what washington do

 what be the frame of government under which we live

 upon this senator douglas hold the affirmative and republicans the negative this affirmation and denial form an issue and this issue this question be precisely what the text declare our father understand well than we

 in 1784 three year before the constitution the united states then own the northwestern territory and no other the congress of the confederation have before they the question of prohibit slavery in that territory and four of the 39 who afterward frame the constitution be in that congress and vote on that question of these roger sherman thomas mifflin and hugh williamson vote for the prohibition thus show that in their understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything else properly forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory the other of the four james m. henry vote against the prohibition show that for some cause he think it improper to vote for it

 in 1787 still before the constitution but while the convention be in session frame it and while the northwestern territory still be the only territory own by the united states the same question of prohibit slavery in the territory again come before the congress of the confederation and two more of the 39 who afterward sign the constitution be in that congress and vote on the question they be william blount and william few and they both vote for the prohibition thus show that in their understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything else properly forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory this time the prohibition become a law be part of what be now well know as the ordinance of 87

 the question of federal control of slavery in the territory seem not to have be directly before the convention which frame the original constitution and hence it be not record that the 39 or any of they while engage on that instrument express any opinion of that precise question

 this show that in their understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything in the constitution properly forbid congress to prohibit slavery in the federal territory else both their fidelity to correct principle and their oath to support the constitution would have constrain they to oppose the prohibition

 again george washington another of the 39 be then president of the united states and as such approve and sign the bill thus complete its validity as a law and thus show that in his understanding no line divide local from federal authority nor anything in the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory

 no great while after the adoption of the original constitution north carolina cede to the federal government the country now constitute the state of tennessee and a few year later georgia cede that which now constitute the states of mississippi and alabama in both deed of cession it be make a condition by the ceding state that the federal government should not prohibit slavery in the ceded country besides this slavery be then actually in the ceded country under these circumstance congress on take charge of these country do not absolutely prohibit slavery within they but they do interfere with it take control of it even there to a certain extent in 1798 congress organize the territory of mississippi in the act of organization they prohibit the bringing of slave into the territory from any place without the united states by fine and give freedom to slave so brought this act pass both branch of congress without yea and nay in that congress be three of the 39 who frame the original constitution they be john langdon george read and abraham baldwin they all probably vote for it certainly they would have place their opposition to it upon record if in their understanding any line divide local from federal authority or anything in the constitution properly forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory

 in 1803 the federal government purchase the louisiana country our former territorial acquisition come from certain of our own state but this louisiana country be acquire from a foreign nation in 1804 congress give a territorial organization to that part of it which now constitute the state of louisiana new orleans lie within that part be an old and comparatively large city there be other considerable town and settlement and slavery be extensively and thoroughly intermingle with the people congress do not in the territorial act prohibit slavery but they do interfere with it take control of it in a more marked and extensive way than they do in the case of mississippi the substance of the provision therein make in relation to slave be

 this act also be pass without yea and nay in the congress which pass it there be two of the 39 they be abraham baldwin and jonathan dayton as state in the case of mississippi it be probable they both vote for it they would not have allow it to pass without record their opposition to it if in their understanding it violate either the line properly divide local from federal authority or any provision of the constitution

 the case i have mention be the only act of the 39 or of any of they upon the direct issue which i have be able to discover

 to enumerate the person who thus act as be four in 1784 two in 1787 17 in 1789 three in 1798 two in 1804 and two in 181920 there would be 30 of they but this would be count john langdon roger sherman william few rufus king and george read each twice and abraham baldwin three time the true number of those of the 39 whom i have show to have act upon the question which by the text they understand well than we be 23 leave 16 not show to have act upon it in any way

 here then we have 23 out of our 39 father who frame the government under which we live who have upon their official responsibility and their corporal oath act upon the very question which the text affirm they understand just as well and even well than we do now and 21 of they a clear majority of the whole 39"so act upon it as to make they guilty of gross political impropriety and wilful perjury if in their understanding any proper division between local and federal authority or anything in the constitution they have make themselves and swear to support forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory thus the 21 act and as action speak louder than word so action under such responsibility speak still louder

 two of the 23 vote against congressional prohibition of slavery in the federal territory in the instance in which they act upon the question but for what reason they so vote be not know they may have do so because they think a proper division of local from federal authority or some provision or principle of the constitution stand in the way or they may without any such question have vote against the prohibition on what appear to they to be sufficient ground of expediency no one who have swear to support the constitution can conscientiously vote for what he understand to be an unconstitutional measure however expedient he may think it but one may and ought to vote against a measure which he deem constitutional if at the same time he deem it inexpedient it therefore would be unsafe to set down even the two who vote against the prohibition as having do so because in their understanding any proper division of local from federal authority or anything in the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in federal territory

 the remain 16 of the 39 so far as i have discover have leave no record of their understanding upon the direct question of federal control of slavery in the federal territory but there be much reason to believe that their understanding upon that question would not have appear different from that of their 23 compeer have it be manifest at all

 for the purpose of adhere rigidly to the text i have purposely omit whatever understanding may have be manifest by any person however distinguish other than the 39 father who frame the original constitution and for the same reason i have also omit whatever understanding may have be manifest by any of the 39 even on any other phase of the general question of slavery if we should look into their act and declaration on those other phase as the foreign slave trade and the morality and policy of slavery generally it would appear to we that on the direct question of federal control of slavery in federal territory the 16 if they have act at all would probably have act just as the 23 do among that 16 be several of the most noted anti slavery man of those time as dr. franklin alexander hamilton and gouverneur morris while there be not one now know to have be otherwise unless it may be john rutledge of south carolina

 but so far i have be consider the understanding of the question manifest by the framer of the original constitution in and by the original instrument a mode be provide for amend it and as i have already state the present frame of the government under which we live consist of that original and 12 amendatory article frame and adopt since those who now insist that federal control of slavery in federal territory violate the constitution point we to the provision which they suppose it thus violate and as i understand they all fix upon provision in these amendatory article and not in the original instrument the supreme court in the dred scott case plant themselves upon the fifth amendment which provide that no person shall be deprive of life liberty or property without due process of law while senator douglas and his peculiar adherent plant themselves upon the tenth amendment provide that the power not delegate to the united states by the constitution be reserve to the states respectively or to the people

 now it so happen that these amendment be frame by the first congress which sit under the constitution the identical congress which pass the act already mention enforce the prohibition of slavery in the northwestern territory not only be it the same congress but they be the identical same individual man who at the same session and at the same time within the session have under consideration and in progress toward maturity these constitutional amendment and this act prohibit slavery in all the territory the nation then own the constitutional amendment be introduce before and pass after the act enforce the ordinance of 87 so that during the whole pendency of the act to enforce the ordinance the constitutional amendment be also pende

 the 76 member of that congress include 16 of the framer of the original constitution as before state be preeminently our father who frame that part of the government under which we live which be now claim as forbid the federal government to control slavery in the federal territory

 be it not a little presumptuous in any one at this day to affirm that the two thing which that congress deliberately frame and carry to maturity at the same time be absolutely inconsistent with each other and do not such affirmation become impudently absurd when couple with the other affirmation from the same mouth that those who do the two thing allege to be inconsistent understand whether they really be inconsistent well than we well than he who affirm that they be inconsistent

 it be surely safe to assume that the 39 framer of the original constitution and the 76 member of the congress which frame the amendment thereto take together do certainly include those who may be fairly call our father who frame the government under which we live and so assume i defy any man to show that any one of they ever in his whole life declare that in his understanding any proper division of local from federal authority or any part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory i go a step far i defy any one to show that any live man in the whole world ever do prior to the beginning of the present century and i might almost say prior to the beginning of the last half of the present century declare that in his understanding any proper division of local from federal authority or any part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory to those who now so declare i give not only our father who frame the government under which we live but with they all other live man within the century in which it be frame among whom to search and they shall not be able to find the evidence of a single man agree with they

 now and here let i guard a little against be misunderstood i do not mean to say we be bind to follow implicitly in whatever our father do to do so would be to discard all the light of current experience to reject all progress all improvement what i do say be that if we would supplant the opinion and policy of our father in any case we should do so upon evidence so conclusive and argument so clear that even their great authority fairly consider and weigh can not stand and most surely not in a case whereof we ourselves declare they understand the question well than we

 if any man at this day sincerely believe that a proper division of local from federal authority or any part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory he be right to say so and to enforce his position by all truthful evidence and fair argument which he can but he have no right to mislead other who have less access to history and less leisure to study it into the false belief that our father who frame the government under which we live be of the same opinion thus substitute falsehood and deception for truthful evidence and fair argument if any man at this day sincerely believe our father who frame the government under which we live use and apply principle in other case which ought to have lead they to understand that a proper division of local from federal authority or some part of the constitution forbid the federal government to control as to slavery in the federal territory he be right to say so but he should at the same time brave the responsibility of declare that in his opinion he understand their principle well than they do themselves and especially should he not shirk that responsibility by assert that they understand the question just as well and even well than we do now

 and now if they would listen as i suppose they will not i would address a few word to the southern people

 i would say to they you consider yourself a reasonable and a just people and i consider that in the general quality of reason and justice you be not inferior to any other people still when you speak of we republicans you do so only to denounce we as reptile or at the good as no well than outlaw you will grant a hearing to pirate or murderer but nothing like it to black republicans in all your contention with one another each of you deem an unconditional condemnation of black republicanism as the first thing to be attend to indeed such condemnation of we seem to be an indispensable prerequisite license so to speak among you to be admit or permit to speak at all now can you or not be prevail upon to pause and to consider whether this be quite just to we or even to yourself bring forward your charge and specification and then be patient long enough to hear we deny or justify

 you say we be sectional we deny it that make an issue and the burden of proof be upon you you produce your proof and what be it why that our party have no existence in your section get no vote in your section the fact be substantially true but do it prove the issue if it do then in case we should without change of principle begin to get vote in your section we should thereby cease to be sectional you can not escape this conclusion and yet be you willing to abide by it if you be you will probably soon find that we have cease to be sectional for we shall get vote in your section this very year you will then begin to discover as the truth plainly be that your proof do not touch the issue the fact that we get no vote in your section be a fact of your making and not of our and if there be fault in that fact that fault be primarily your and remain so until you show that we repel you by some wrong principle or practice if we do repel you by any wrong principle or practice the fault be ours but this bring you to where you ought to have start to a discussion of the right or wrong of our principle if our principle put in practice would wrong your section for the benefit of our or for any other object then our principle and we with it be sectional and be justly oppose and denounce as such meet we then on the question of whether our principle put in practice would wrong your section and so meet we as if it be possible that something may be say on our side do you accept the challenge no then you really believe that the principle which our father who frame the government under which we live think so clearly right as to adopt it and indorse it again and again upon their official oath be in fact so clearly wrong as to demand your condemnation without a moment 's consideration

 some of you delight to flaunt in our face the warning against sectional party give by washington in his farewell address less than eight year before washington give that warning he have as president of the united states approve and sign an act of congress enforce the prohibition of slavery in the northwestern territory which act embody the policy of the government upon that subject up to and at the very moment he pen that warning and about one year after he pen it he write la fayette that he consider that prohibition a wise measure express in the same connection his hope that we should at some time have a confederacy of free state

 bear this in mind and see that sectionalism have since arise upon this same subject be that warn a weapon in your hand against we or in our hand against you could washington himself speak would he cast the blame of that sectionalism upon we who sustain his policy or upon you who repudiate it we respect that warning of washington and we commend it to you together with his example pointing to the right application of it

 but you say you be conservative eminently conservative while we be revolutionary destructive or something of the sort what be conservatism be it not adherence to the old and try against the new and untried we stick to contend for the identical old policy on the point in controversy which be adopt by our father who frame the government under which we live while you with one accord reject and scout and spit upon that old policy and insist upon substitute something new true you disagree among yourself as to what that substitute shall be you be divide on new proposition and plan but you be unanimous in reject and denounce the old policy of the father some of you be for revive the foreign slave trade some for a congressional slave code for the territories some for congress forbid the territories to prohibit slavery within their limit some for maintain slavery in the territories through the judiciary some for the gur reat pur rinciple that if one man would enslave another no third man should object fantastically call popular sovereignty but never a man among you in favor of federal prohibition of slavery in federal territory accord to the practice of our father who frame the government under which we live not one of all your various plan can show a precedent or an advocate in the century within which our government originate consider then whether your claim of conservatism for yourself and your charge of destructiveness against we be base on the most clear and stable foundation

 again you say we have make the slavery question more prominent than it formerly be we deny it we admit that it be more prominent but we deny that we make it so it be not we but you who discard the old policy of the father we resist and still resist your innovation and thence come the great prominence of the question would you have that question reduce to its former proportion go back to that old policy what have be will be again under the same condition if you would have the peace of the old time readopt the precept and policy of the old time

 you charge that we stir up insurrection among your slave we deny it and what be your proof harper 's ferry john brown john brown be no republican and you have fail to implicate a single republican in his harper 's ferry enterprise if any member of our party be guilty in that matter you know it or you do not know it if you do know it you be inexcusable for not designate the man and prove the fact if you do not know it you be inexcusable for assert it and especially for persist in the assertion after you have try and fail to make the proof you need not be tell that persist in a charge which one do not know to be true be simply malicious slander

 some of you admit that no republican designedly aid or encourage the harper 's ferry affair but still insist that our doctrine and declaration necessarily lead to such result we do not believe it we know we hold to no doctrine and make no declaration which be not hold to and make by our father who frame the government under which we live you never deal fairly by we in relation to this affair when it occur some important state election be near at hand and you be in evident glee with the belief that by charge the blame upon we you could get an advantage of we in those election the election come and your expectation be not quite fulfil every republican man know that as to himself at least your charge be a slander and he be not much incline by it to cast his vote in your favor republican doctrine and declaration be accompany with a continual protest against any interference whatever with your slave or with you about your slave surely this do not encourage they to revolt true we do in common with our father who frame the government under which we live declare our belief that slavery be wrong but the slave do not hear we declare even this for anything we say or do the slave would scarcely know there be a republican party i believe they would not in fact generally know it but for your misrepresentation of we in their hearing in your political contest among yourself each faction charge the other with sympathy with black republicanism and then to give point to the charge define black republicanism to simply be insurrection blood and thunder among the slave

 mr. jefferson do not mean to say nor do i that the power of emancipation be in the federal government he speak of virginia and as to the power of emancipation i speak of the slaveholding state only the federal government however as we insist have the power of restrain the extension of the institution the power to insure that a slave insurrection shall never occur on any american soil which be now free from slavery

 john brown 's effort be peculiar it be not a slave insurrection it be an attempt by white man to get up a revolt among slave in which the slave refuse to participate in fact it be so absurd that the slave with all their ignorance see plainly enough it could not succeed that affair in its philosophy correspond with the many attempt relate in history at the assassination of king and emperor an enthusiast brood over the oppression of a people till he fancy himself commission by heaven to liberate they he venture the attempt which end in little else than his own execution orsini 's attempt on louis napoleon and john brown 's attempt at harper 's ferry be in their philosophy precisely the same the eagerness to cast blame on old england in the one case and on new england in the other do not disprove the sameness of the two thing

 and how much would it avail you if you could by the use of john brown helper 's book and the like break up the republican organization human action can be modify to some extent but human nature can not be change there be a judgment and a feeling against slavery in this nation which cast at least a million and a half of vote you can not destroy that judgment and feeling that sentiment by break up the political organization which rally around it you can scarcely scatter and disperse an army which have be form into order in the face of your heavy fire but if you could how much would you gain by force the sentiment which create it out of the peaceful channel of the ballot box into some other channel what would that other channel probably be would the number of john browns be lessen or enlarge by the operation

 but you will break up the union rather than submit to a denial of your constitutional right

 this plainly state be your language perhaps you will say the supreme court have decide the dispute constitutional question in your favor not quite so but waive the lawyer 's distinction between dictum and decision the court have decide the question for you in a sort of way the court have substantially say it be your constitutional right to take slave into the federal territory and to hold they there as property when i say the decision be make in a sort of way i mean it be make in a divided court by a bare majority of the judge and they not quite agree with one another in the reason for make it that it be so make as that its avow supporter disagree with one another about its meaning and that it be mainly base upon a mistaken statement of fact the statement in the opinion that the right of property in a slave be distinctly and expressly affirm in the constitution

 wrong as we think slavery be we can yet afford to let it alone where it be because that much be due to the necessity arise from its actual presence in the nation but can we while our vote will prevent it allow it to spread into the national territories and to overrun we here in these free states if our sense of duty forbid this then let we stand by our duty fearlessly and effectively let we be divert by none of those sophistical contrivance wherewith we be so industriously ply and belabor contrivance such as grope for some middle ground between the right and the wrong vain as the search for a man who should be neither a live man nor a dead man such as a policy of do not care on a question about which all true man do care such as union appeal beseech true union man to yield to disunionists reverse the divine rule and call not the sinner but the righteous to repentance such as invocation to washington implore man to unsay what washington say and undo what washington do
