republic and it be for the maintenance of the constitution and his authority derive from it that the civil war commence and still continue to be prosecute throughout the year 1858 the constitutional party grow strong and strong in the previous history of mexico a successful military revolution at the capital have almost universally be the signal for submission throughout the republic not so on the present occasion a majority of the citizen persistently sustain the constitutional government when this be recognize in april 1859 by the government of the united states its authority extend over a large majority of the mexican states and people include vera cruz and all the other important seaport of the republic from that period our commerce with mexico begin to revive and the constitutional government have afford it all the protection in its power meanwhile the government of miramon still hold sway at the capital and over the surround country and continue its outrage against the few american citizen who still have the courage to remain within its power to cap the climax after the battle of tacubaya in april 1859 general marquez order three citizen of the united states two of they physician to be seize in the hospital at that place take out and shoot without crime and without trial this be do notwithstanding our unfortunate countryman be at the moment engage in the holy cause of afford relief to the soldier of both party who have be wound in the battle without make any distinction between they the time have arrive in my opinion when this government be bind to exert its power to avenge and redress the wrong of our citizen and to afford they protection in mexico the interpose obstacle be that the portion of the country under the sway of miramon could not be reach without pass over territory under the jurisdiction of the constitutional government under these circumstance i deem it my duty to recommend to congress in my last annual message the employment of a sufficient military force to penetrate into the interior where the government of miramon be to be find with or if need be without the consent of the juarez government though it be not doubted that this consent could be obtain never have i have a clear conviction on any subject than of the justice as well as wisdom of such a policy no other alternative be leave except the entire abandonment of our fellow citizen who have go to mexico under the faith of treaty to the systematic injustice cruelty and oppression of miramon 's government besides it be almost certain that the simple authority to employ this force would of itself have accomplish all our object without strike a single blow the constitutional government would then ere this have be establish at the city of mexico and would have be ready and willing to the extent of its ability to do we justice in addition and i deem this a most important consideration european government would have be deprive of all pretext to interfere in the territorial and domestic concern of mexico we should thus have be relieve from the obligation of resist even by force should this become necessary any attempt by these government to deprive our neighboring republic of portion of her territory a duty from which we could not shrink without abandon the traditional and established policy of the american people i be happy to observe that firmly rely upon the justice and good faith of these government there be no present danger that such a contingency will happen having discover that my recommendation would not be sustain by congress the next alternative be to accomplish in some degree if possible the same object by treaty stipulation with the constitutional government such treaty be accordingly conclude by our late able and excellent minister to mexico and on the 4th of january last be submit to the senate for ratification as these have not yet receive the final action of that body it would be improper for i to present a detailed statement of their provision still i may be permit to express the opinion in advance that they be calculate to promote the agricultural manufacturing and commercial interest of the country and to secure our just influence with an adjoining republic as to whose fortune and fate we can never feel indifferent whilst at the same time they provide for the payment of a considerable amount toward the satisfaction of the claim of our injure fellow citizen at the period of my inauguration i be confront in kansas by a revolutionary government exist under what be call the topeka constitution its avowed object be to subdue the territorial government by force and to inaugurate what be call the topeka government in its stead to accomplish this object an extensive military organization be form and its command intrust to the most violent revolutionary leader under these circumstance it become my imperative duty to exert the whole constitutional power of the executive to prevent the flame of civil war from again rage in kansas which in the excited state of the public mind both north and south might have extend into the neighboring state the hostile party in kansas have be inflame against each other by emissary both from the north and the south to a degree of malignity without parallel in our history to prevent actual collision and to assist the civil magistrate in enforce the law a strong detachment of the army be station in the territory ready to aid the marshal and his deputy when lawfully call upon as a posse comitatus in the execution of civil and criminal process still the trouble in kansas could not have be permanently settle without an election by the people the ballot box be the sure arbiter of dispute among freeman under this conviction every proper effort be employ to induce the hostile party to vote at the election of delegate to frame a state constitution and afterwards at the election to decide whether kansas should be a slave or free state the insurgent party refuse to vote at either lest this might be consider a recognition on their part of the territorial government establish by congress a well spirit however seem soon after to prevail and the two party meet face to face at the third election hold on the first monday of january 1858 for member of the legislature and state officer under the lecompton constitution the result be the triumph of the antislavery party at the poll this decision of the ballot box prove clearly that this party be in the majority and remove the danger of civil war from that time we have hear little or nothing of the topeka government and all serious danger of revolutionary trouble in kansas be then at an end the lecompton constitution which have be thus recognize at this state election by the vote of both political party in kansas be transmit to i with the request that i should present it to congress this i could not have refuse to do without violate my clear and strong conviction of duty the constitution and all the proceeding which precede and follow its formation be fair and regular on their face i then believe and experience have prove that the interest of the people of kansas would have be well consult by its admission as a state into the union especially as the majority within a brief period could have amend the constitution accord to their will and pleasure if fraud exist in all or any of these proceeding it be not for the president but for congress to investigate and determine the question of fraud and what ought to be its consequence if at the first two election the majority refuse to vote it can not be pretend that this refusal to exercise the elective franchise could invalidate an election fairly hold under lawful authority even if they have not subsequently vote at the third election it be true that the whole constitution have not be submit to the people as i always desire but the precedent be numerous of the admission of states into the union without such submission it would not comport with my present purpose to review the proceeding of congress upon the lecompton constitution it be sufficient to observe that their final action have remove the last vestige of serious revolutionary trouble the desperate hand recently assemble under a notorious outlaw in the southern portion of the territory to resist the execution of the law and to plunder peaceful citizen will i doubt not be speedily subdue and bring to justice have i treat the lecompton constitution as a nullity and refuse to transmit it to congress it be not difficult to imagine whilst recall the position of the country at that moment what would have be the disastrous consequence both in and out of the territory from such a dereliction of duty on the part of the executive peace have also be restore within the territory of utah which at the commencement of my administration be in a state of open rebellion this be the more dangerous as the people animate by a fanatical spirit and intrench within their distant mountain fastness might have make a long and formidable resistance cost what it might it be necessary to bring they into subjection to the constitution and the law sound policy therefore as well as humanity require that this object should if possible be accomplish without the effusion of blood this could only be effect by send a military force into the territory sufficiently strong to convince the people that resistance would be hopeless and at the same time to offer they a pardon for past offense on condition of immediate submission to the government this policy be pursue with eminent success and the only cause for regret be the heavy expenditure require to march a large detachment of the army to that remote region and to furnish it subsistence utah be now comparatively peaceful and quiet and the military force have be withdraw except that portion of it necessary to keep the indians in check and to protect the emigrant train on their way to our pacific possession in my first annual message i promise to employ my good exertion in cooperation with congress to reduce the expenditure of the government within the limit of a wise and judicious economy an overflowing treasury have produce habit of prodigality and extravagance which could only be gradually correct the work require both time and patience i apply myself diligently to this task from the beginning and be aid by the able and energetic effort of the head of the different executive departments the result of our labor in this good cause do not appear in the sum total of our expenditure for the first two year mainly in consequence of the extraordinary expenditure necessarily incur in the utah expedition and the very large amount of the contingent expense of congress during this period these greatly exceed the pay and mileage of the member for the year end june 30 1858 whilst the pay and mileage amount to $ 1,490,214 the contingent expense rise to $ 2,093,309.79 and for the year end june 30 1859 whilst the pay and mileage amount to $ 859,093.66 the contingent expense amount to $ 1,431,565.78 i be happy however to be able to inform you that during the last fiscal year end june 30 1860 the total expenditure of the government in all its branch legislative executive and judicial exclusive of the public debt be reduce to the sum of $ 55,402,465.46 this conclusively appear from the book of the treasury in the year end june 30 1858 the total expenditure exclusive of the public debt amount to $ 71,901,129.77 and that for the year end june 30 1859 to $ 66,346,226.13 whilst the book of the treasury show an actual expenditure of $ 59,848,474.72 for the year end june 30 1860 include $ 1,040,667.71 for the contingent expense of congress there must be deduct from this amount the sum of $ 4,296,009.26 with the interest upon it of $ 150,000 appropriate by the act of february 15 1860 for the purpose of supply the deficiency in the revenue and defray the expense of the post office department for the year end june 30 1859 this sum therefore justly chargeable to the year 1859 must be deduct from the sum of $ 59,848,474.72 in order to ascertain the expenditure for the year end june 30 1860 which leave a balance for the expenditure of that year of $ 55,402,465.46 the interest on the public debt include treasury note for the same fiscal year end june 30 1860 amount to $ 3,177,314.62 which add to the above sum of $ 55,402,465.46 make the aggregate of $ 58,579,780.08.it ought in justice to be observe that several of the estimate from the departments for the year end june 30 1860 be reduce by congress below what be and still be deem compatible with the public interest allow a liberal margin of $ 2,500,000 for this reduction and for other cause it may be safely assert that the sum of $ 61,000,000 or at the most $ 62,000,000 be amply sufficient to administer the government and to pay the interest on the public debt unless contingent event should hereafter render extraordinary expenditure necessary this result have be attain in a considerable degree by the care exercise by the appropriate departments in enter into public contract i have myself never interfere with the award of any such contract except in a single case with the colonization society deem it advisable to cast the whole responsibility in each case on the proper head of the department with the general instruction that these contract should always be give to the low and good bidder it have ever be my opinion that public contract be not a legitimate source of patronage to be confer upon personal or political favorite but that in all such case a public officer be bind to act for the government as a prudent individual would act for himself it be with great satisfaction i communicate the fact that since the date of my last annual message not a single slave have be import into the united states in violation of the law prohibit the african slave trade this statement be round upon a thorough examination and investigation of the subject indeed the spirit which prevail some time since among a portion of our fellow citizen in favor of this trade seem to have entirely subside i also congratulate you upon the public sentiment which now exist against the crime of set on foot military expedition within the limit of the united states to proceed from thence and make war upon the people of unoffending states with whom we be at peace in this respect a happy change have be effect since the commencement of my administration it surely ought to be the prayer of every christian and patriot that such expedition may never again receive countenance in our country or depart from our shore it would be a useless repetition to do more than refer with earnest commendation to my former recommendation in favor of the pacific railroad of the grant of power to the president to employ the naval force in the vicinity for the protection of the life and property of our fellow citizen pass in transit over the different central american route against sudden and lawless outbreak and depredation and also to protect american merchant vessel their crew and cargo against violent and unlawful seizure and confiscation in the port of mexico and the south american republics when these may be in a disturbed and revolutionary condition it be my settle conviction that without such a power we do not afford that protection to those engage in the commerce of the country which they have a right to demand i again recommend to congress the passage of a law in pursuance of the provision of the constitution appoint a day certain previous to the 4th march in each year of an odd number for the election of representatives throughout all the states a similar power have already be exercise with general approbation in the appointment of the same day throughout the union for hold the election of elector for president and vice president of the united states my attention be earnestly direct to this subject from the fact that the thirty fifth congress terminate on the 3d march 1859 without make the necessary appropriation for the service of the post office department i be then force to consider the good remedy for this omission and an immediate call of the present congress be the natural resort upon inquiry however i ascertain that fifteen out of the thirty three states compose the confederacy be without representatives and that consequently these fifteen state would be disfranchise by such a call these fifteen states will be in the same condition on the 4th march next ten of they can not elect representatives accord to exist state law until different period extend from the beginning of august next until the month of october and november in my last message i gave warn that in a time of sudden and alarming danger the salvation of our institution might depend upon the power of the president immediately to assemble a full congress to meet the emergency it be now quite evident that the financial necessity of the government will require a modification of the tariff during your present session for the purpose of increase the revenue in this aspect i desire to reiterate the recommendation contain in my last two annual message in favor of impose specific instead of ad valorem duty on all import article to which these can be properly apply from long observation and experience i be convinced that specific duty be necessary both to protect the revenue and to secure to our manufacturing interest that amount of incidental encouragement which unavoidably result from a revenue tariff as an abstract proposition it may be admit that ad valorem duty would in theory be the most just and equal but if the experience of this and of all other commercial nation have demonstrate that such duty can not be assess and collect without great fraud upon the revenue then it be the part of wisdom to resort to specific duty indeed from the very nature of an ad valorem duty this must be the result under it the inevitable consequence be that foreign good will be enter at less than their true value the treasury will therefore lose the duty on the difference between their real and fictitious value and to this extent we be defraud the temptation which ad valorem duty present to a dishonest importer be irresistible his object be to pass his good through the custom house at the very low valuation necessary to save they from confiscation in this he too often succeed in spite of the vigilance of the revenue officer hence the resort to false invoice one for the purchaser and another for the custom house and to other expedient to defraud the government the honest importer produce his invoice to the collector state the actual price at which he purchase the article abroad not so the dishonest importer and the agent of the foreign manufacturer and here it may be observe that a very large proportion of the manufacture import from abroad be consign for sale to commission merchant who be mere agent employ by the manufacturer in such case no actual sale have be make to fix their value the foreign manufacturer if he be dishonest prepare an invoice of the good not at their actual value but at the very low rate necessary to escape detection in this manner the dishonest importer and the foreign manufacturer enjoy a decide advantage over the honest merchant they be thus enable to undersell the fair trader and drive he from the market in fact the operation of this system have already drive from the pursuit of honorable commerce many of that class of regular and conscientious merchant whose character throughout the world be the pride of our country the remedy for these evil be to be find in specific duty so far as this may be practicable they dispense with any inquiry at the custom house into the actual cost or value of the article and it pay the precise amount of duty previously fix by law they present no temptation to the appraiser of foreign good who receive but small salary and might by undervaluation in a few case render themselves independent besides specific duty well conform to the requisition in the constitution that no preference shall be give by any regulation of commerce or revenue to the port of one state over those of another under our ad valorem system such preference be to some extent inevitable and complaint have often be make that the spirit of this provision have p.3183 be violate by a low appraisement of the same article at one port than at another an impression strangely enough prevail to some extent that specific duty be necessarily protective duty nothing can be more fallacious great britain glory in free trade and yet her whole revenue from import be at the present moment collect under a system of specific duty it be a striking fact in this connection that in the commercial treaty of january 23 1860 between france and england one of the article provide that the ad valorem duty which it impose shall be convert into specific duty within six month from its date and these be to be ascertain by make an average of the price for six month previous to that time the reverse of the proposition would be near to the truth because a much large amount of revenue would be collect by merely convert the ad valorem duty of a tariff into equivalent specific duty to this extent the revenue would be increase and in the same proportion the specific duty might be diminish specific duty would secure to the american manufacturer the incidental protection to which he be fairly entitle under a revenue tariff and to this surely no person would object the framer of the exist tariff have go far and in a liberal spirit have discriminate in favor of large and useful branch of our manufacture not by raise the rate of duty upon the importation of similar article from abroad but what be the same in effect by admit article free of duty which enter into the composition of their fabric under the present system it have be often truly remark that this incidental protection decrease when the manufacturer need it most and increase when he need it least and constitute a slide scale which always operate against he the revenue of the country be subject to similar fluctuation instead of approach a steady standard as would be the case under a system of specific duty they sink and rise with the sinking and rise price of article in foreign country it would not be difficult for congress to arrange a system of specific duty which would afford additional stability both to our revenue and our manufacture and without injury or injustice to any interest of the country this might be accomplish by ascertain the average value of any give article for a series of year at the place of exportation and by simply convert the rate of ad valorem duty upon it which might be deem necessary for revenue purpose into the form of a specific duty such an arrangement could not injure the consumer if he should pay a great amount of duty one year this would be counterbalance by a less amount the next and in the end the aggregate would be the same i desire to call your immediate attention to the present condition of the treasury so ably and clearly present by the secretary in his report to p.3184 congress and to recommend that measure be promptly adopt to enable it to discharge its press obligation the other recommendation of the report be well worthy of your favorable consideration i herewith transmit to congress the report of the secretaries of war of the navy of the interior and of the postmaster general the recommendation and suggestion which they contain be highly valuable and deserve your careful attention the report of the postmaster general detail the circumstance under which cornelius vanderbilt on my request agree in the month of july last to carry the ocean mail between our atlantic and pacific coast have he not thus act this important intercommunication must have be suspend at least for a season the postmaster general have no power to make he any other compensation than the postage on the mail matter which he might carry it be know at the time that these postage would fall far short of an adequate compensation as well as of the sum which the same service have previously cost the government mr. vanderbilt in a commendable spirit be willing to rely upon the justice of congress to make up the deficiency and i therefore recommend that an appropriation may be grant for this purpose i should do great injustice to the attorney general be i to omit the mention of his distinguished service in the measure adopt and prosecute by he for the defense of the government against numerous and unfounded claim to land in california purport to have be make by the mexican government previous to the treaty of cession the successful opposition to these claim have save the united states public property worth many million of dollar and to individual hold title under they to at least an equal amount it have be represent to i from source which i deem reliable that the inhabitant in several portion of kansas have be reduce nearly to a state of starvation on account of the almost total failure of their crop whilst the harvest in every other portion of the country have be abundant the prospect before they for the approach winter be well calculate to enlist the sympathy of every heart the destitution appear to be so general that it can not be relieve by private contribution and they be in such indigent circumstance as to be unable to purchase the necessary of life for themselves i refer the subject to congress if any constitutional measure for their relief can be devise i would recommend its adoption i cordially commend to your favorable regard the interest of the people of this district they be eminently entitle to your consideration especially since unlike the people of the states they can appeal to no government except that of the union
at the opening of your present session i call your attention to the danger which threaten the existence of the union i express my opinion freely concern the original cause of those danger and recommend such measure as i believe would have the effect of tranquilize the country and save it from the peril in which it have be needlessly and most unfortunately involve those opinion and recommendation i do not propose now to repeat my own conviction upon the whole subject remain unchanged
 the fact that a great calamity be impend over the nation be even at that time acknowledge by every intelligent citizen it have already make itself feel throughout the length and breadth of the land the necessary consequence of the alarm thus produce be most deplorable the import fall off with a rapidity never know before except in time of war in the history of our foreign commerce the treasury be unexpectedly leave without the mean which it have reasonably count upon to meet the public engagement trade be paralyze manufacture be stop the good public security suddenly sink in the market every specie of property depreciate more or less and thousand of poor man who depend upon their daily labor for their daily bread be turn out of employment
 i deeply regret that i be not able to give you any information upon the state of the union which be more satisfactory than what i be then oblige to communicate on the contrary matter be still bad at present than they then be when congress meet a stronge hope pervade the whole public mind that some amicable adjustment of the subject would speedily be make by the representative of the states and of the people which might restore peace between the conflict section of the country that hope have be diminish by every hour of delay and as the prospect of a bloodless settlement fade away the public distress become more and more aggravate as evidence of this it be only necessary to say that the treasury note authorize by the act of 17th of december last be advertise accord to the law and that no responsible bidder offer to take any considerable sum at par at a low rate of interest than 12 per cent from these fact it appear that in a government organize like ours domestic strife or even a well ground fear of civil hostility be more destructive to our public and private interest than the most formidable foreign war
 in my annual message i express the conviction which i have long deliberately hold and which recent reflection have only tend to deepen and confirm that no state have a right by its own act to secede from the union or throw off its federal obligation at pleasure i also declare my opinion to be that even if that right exist and should be exercise by any state of the confederacy the executive department of this government have no authority under the constitution to recognize its validity by acknowledge the independence of such state this leave i no alternative as the chief executive officer under the constitution of the united states but to collect the public revenue and to protect the public property so far as this might be practicable under exist law this be still my purpose my province be to execute and not to make the law it belong to congress exclusively to repeal to modify or to enlarge their provision to meet exigency as they may occur i possess no dispense power
 i certainly have no right to make aggressive war upon any state and i be perfectly satisfied that the constitution have wisely withhold that power even from congress but the right and the duty to use military force defensively against those who resist the federal officer in the execution of their legal function and against those who assail the property of the federal government be clear and undeniable
 but the dangerous and hostile attitude of the states toward each other have already far transcend and cast in the shade the ordinary executive duty already provide for by law and have assume such vast and alarming proportion as to place the subject entirely above and beyond executive control the fact can not be disguise that we be in the midst of a great revolution in all its various bearing therefore i commend the question to congress as the only human tribunal under providence possess the power to meet the exist emergency to they exclusively belong the power to declare war or to authorize the employment of military force in all case contemplate by the constitution and they alone possess the power to remove grievance which might lead to war and to secure peace and union to this distracted country on they and on they alone rest the responsibility
 the union be a sacred trust leave by our revolutionary father to their descendant and never do any other people inherit so rich a legacy it have render we prosperous in peace and triumphant in war the national flag have float in glory over every sea under its shadow american citizen have find protection and respect in all land beneath the sun if we descend to consideration of purely material interest when in the history of all time have a confederacy be bind together by such strong tie of mutual interest each portion of it be dependent on all and all upon each portion for prosperity and domestic security free trade throughout the whole supply the want of one portion from the production of another and scatter wealth everywhere the great planting and farming states require the aid of the commercial and navigate states to send their production to domestic and foreign market and to furnish the naval power to render their transportation secure against all hostile attack
 should the union perish in the midst of the present excitement we have already have a sad foretaste of the universal suffering which would result from its destruction the calamity would be severe in every portion of the union and would be quite as great to say the least in the southern as in the northern states the great aggravation of the evil and that which would place we in the most unfavorable light both before the world and posterity be as i be firmly convinced that the secession movement have be chiefly base upon a misapprehension at the south of the sentiment of the majority in several of the northern states let the question be transfer from political assembly to the ballot box and the people themselves would speedily redress the serious grievance which the south have suffer but in heaven&#39;s name let the trial be make before we plunge into armed conflict upon the mere assumption that there be no other alternative time be a great conservative power let we pause at this momentous point and afford the people both north and south an opportunity for reflection would that south carolina have be convince of this truth before her precipitate action i therefore appeal through you to the people of the country to declare in their might that the union must and shall be preserve by all constitutional mean i most earnestly recommend that you devote yourself exclusively to the question how this can be accomplish in peace all other question when compare to this sink into insignificance the present be no time for palliation action prompt action be require a delay in congress to prescribe or to recommend a distinct and practical proposition for conciliation may drive we to a point from which it will be almost impossible to recede
 a common ground on which conciliation and harmony can be produce be surely not unattainable the proposition to compromise by let the north have exclusive control of the territory above a certain line and to give southern institution protection below that line ought to receive universal approbation in itself indeed it may not be entirely satisfactory but when the alternative be between a reasonable concession on both side and a destruction of the union it be an imputation upon the patriotism of congress to assert that its member will hesitate for a moment
 even now the danger be upon we in several of the states which have not yet secede the fort arsenal and magazine of the united states have be seize this be by far the most serious step which have be take since the commencement of the trouble this public property have long be leave without garrison and troop for its protection because no person doubt its security under the flag of the country in any state of the union besides our small army have scarcely be sufficient to guard our remote frontier against indian incursion the seizure of this property from all appearance have be purely aggressive and not in resistance to any attempt to coerce a state or states to remain in the union
 at the beginning of these unhappy trouble i determine that no act of mine should increase the excitement in either section of the country if the political conflict be to end in a civil war it be my determined purpose not to commence it nor even to furnish an excuse for it by any act of this government my opinion remain unchanged that justice as well as sound policy require we still to seek a peaceful solution of the question at issue between the north and the south entertain this conviction i refrain even from send reenforcement to major anderson who command the fort in charleston harbor until an absolute necessity for do so should make itself apparent lest it might unjustly be regard as a menace of military coercion and thus furnish if not a provocation at least a pretext for an outbreak on the part of south carolina no necessity for these reenforcement seem to exist i be assure by distinguished and upright gentleman of south carolina that no attack upon major anderson be intend but that on the contrary it be the desire of the state authority as much as it be my own to avoid the fatal consequence which must eventually follow a military collision
 and here i deem it proper to submit for your information copy of a communication date december 28 1860 address to i by r.w. barnwell j. h. adams and james l. orr commissioner from south carolina with the accompany document and copy of my answer thereto date december 31
 in further explanation of major anderson&#39;s removal from fort moultrie to fort sumter it be proper to state that after my answer to the south carolina commissioner the war department receive a letter from that gallant officer date on the 27th of december 1860 the day after this movement from which the following be an extract
 i will add as my opinion that many thing convince i that the authority of the state design to proceed to a hostile act
 evidently refer to the order date december 11 of the late secretary of war
 under this impression i could not hesitate that it be my solemn duty to move my command from a fort which we could not probably have hold long than forty eight or sixty hour to this one where my power of resistance be increase to a very great degree
 it will be recollect that the conclude part of these order be in the following term
 the smallness of your force will not permit you perhaps to occupy more than one of the three fort but an attack on or attempt to take possession of either one of they will be regard as an act of hostility and you may then put your command into either of they which you may deem most proper to increase its power of resistance you be also authorize to take similar defensive step whenever you have tangible evidence of a design to proceed to a hostile act

to the senate and house of representatives of the united states
 i deem it my duty to submit to congress a series of resolution adopt by the legislature of virginia on the 19th instant have in view a peaceful settlement of the exciting question which now threaten the union they be deliver to i on thursday the 24th instant by ex president tyler who have leave his dignified and honor retirement in the hope that he may render service to his country in this its hour of peril these resolution it will be perceive extend an invitation to all such states whether slaveholde or nonslaveholde as be willing to unite with virginia in an earnest effort to adjust the present unhappy controversy in the spirit in which the constitution be originally form and consistently with its principle so as to afford to the people of the slaveholde states adequate guaranty for the security of their right to appoint commissioner to meet on the 4th day of february next in the city of washington similar commissioner appoint by virginia to consider and if practicable agree upon some suitable adjustment
 i confess i hail this movement on the part of virginia with great satisfaction from the past history of this ancient and renowned commonwealth we have the full assurance that what she have undertake she will accomplish if it can be do by able enlighten and persevere effort it be highly gratifying to know that other patriotic states have appoint and be appoint commissioner to meet those of virginia in council when assemble they will constitute a body entitle in an eminent degree to the confidence of the country
 the general assembly of virginia have also resolved--
 that ex president john tyler be hereby appoint by the concurrent vote of each branch of the general assembly a commissioner to the president of the united states and judge john robertson be hereby appoint by a like vote a commissioner to the state of south carolina and the other states that have secede or shall secede with instruction respectfully to request the president of the united states and the authority of such state to agree to abstain pende the proceeding contemplate by the action of this general assembly from any and all act calculate to produce a collision of arm between the states and the government of the united states
 however strong may be my desire to enter into such an agreement i be convinced that i do not possess the power congress and congress alone under the war make power can exercise the discretion of agree to abstain from any and all act calculate to produce a collision of arm between this and any other government it would therefore be a usurpation for the executive to attempt to restrain their hand by an agreement in regard to matter over which he have no constitutional control if he be thus to act they might pass law which he should be bind to obey though in conflict with his agreement
 under exist circumstance my present actual power be confine within narrow limit it be my duty at all time to defend and protect the public property within the secede states so far as this may be practicable and especially to employ all constitutional mean to protect the property of the united states and to preserve the public peace at this the seat of the federal government if the secede state abstain from any and all act calculate to produce a collision of arm then the danger so much to be deprecate will no long exist defense and not aggression have be the policy of the administration from the beginning
 but whilst i can enter into no engagement such as that propose i cordially commend to congress with much confidence that it will meet their approbation to abstain from pass any law calculate to produce a collision of arm pende the proceeding contemplate by the action of the general assembly of virginia i be one of those who will never despair of the republic i yet cherish the belief that the american people will perpetuate the union of the states on some term just and honorable for all section of the country i trust that the mediation of virginia may be the destine mean under providence of accomplish this inestimable benefit glorious as be the memory of her past history such an achievement both in relation to her own fame and the welfare of the whole country would surpass they all

my friend no one not in my situation can appreciate my feeling of sadness at this parting to this place and the kindness of these people i owe every thing here i have live a quarter of a century and have pass from a young to an old man here my child have be bear and one be bury i now leave not know when or whether ever i may return with a task before i great than that which rest upon washington without the assistance of that divine being who ever attend he i can not succeed with that assistance i can not fail trust in him who can go with i and remain with you and be every where for good let we confidently hope that all will yet be well to his care commend you as i hope in your prayer you will commend i i bid you an affectionate farewell
in answer to their resolution of the 11th instant ultimo that the president of the united states furnish to the house if not incompatible with the public service the reason that have induce he to assemble so large a number of troop in this city and why they be keep here and whether he have any information of a conspiracy upon the part of any portion of the citizen of this country to seize upon the capital and prevent the inauguration of the president elect the president submit that the number of troop assemble in this city be not large as the resolution presuppose its total amount be 653 man exclusive of the marine who be of course at the navy yard as their appropriate station these troop be order here to act as a posse comitatus in strict subordination to the civil authority for the purpose of present peace and order in the city of washington should this be necessary before or at the period of the inauguration of the president elect
 since the date of the resolution hon mr. howard from the select committee have make a report to the house on this subject it be thoroughly investigate by the committee and although they have express the opinion that the evidence before they do not prove the existence of a secret organization here or elsewhere hostile to the government that have for its object upon its own responsibility an attack upon the capital or any of the public property here or an interruption of any of the function of the government yet the house lay upon the table by a very large majority a resolution express the opinion that the regular troop now in this city ought to be forthwith remove therefrom this of itself be a sufficient reason for not withdraw the troop
 but what be the duty of the president at the time the troop be order to this city ought he to have wait before this precautionary measure be adopt until he could obtain proof that a secret organization exist to seize the capital in the language of the select committee this be in a time of high excitement consequent upon revolutionary event transpire all around we the very air fill with rumor and individual indulge in the most extravagant expression of fear and threat under these and other circumstance which i need not detail but which appear in the testimony before the select committee i be convince that i ought to act the safety of the immense amount of public property in this city and that of the archive of the government in which all the states and especially the new states in which the public land be situate have a deep interest the peace and order of the city itself and the security of the inauguration of the president elect be object of such vast importance to the whole country that i could not hesitate to adopt precautionary defensive measure at the present moment when all be quiet it be difficult to realize the state of alarm which prevail when the troop be first order to this city this almost instantly subside after the arrival of the first company and a feeling of comparative peace and security have since exist both in washington and throughout the country have i refuse to adopt this precautionary measure and evil consequence which many good man at the time apprehend have follow i should never have forgive myself

  fellow citizen of the united states in compliance with a custom as old as the government itself i appear before you to address you briefly and to take in your presence the oath prescribe by the constitution of the united states to be take by the president before he enter on the execution of his office "i do not consider it necessary at present for i to discuss those matter of administration about which there be no special anxiety or excitement apprehension seem to exist among the people of the southern states that by the accession of a republican administration their property and their peace and personal security be to be endanger there have never be any reasonable cause for such apprehension indeed the most ample evidence to the contrary have all the while exist and be open to their inspection it be find in nearly all the publish speech of he who now address you i do but quote from one of those speech when i declare that i have no purpose directly or indirectly to interfere with the institution of slavery in the states where it exist i beheve i have no lawful right to do so and i have no inclination to do so those who nominate and elect i do so with full knowledge that i have make this and many similar declaration and have never recant they and more than this they place in the platform for my acceptance and as a law to themselves and to i the clear and emphatic resolution which i now read resolved that the maintenance inviolate of the right of the states and especially the right of each state to order and control its own domestic institution accord to its own judgment exclusively be essential to that balance of power on which the perfection and endurance of our political fabric depend and we denounce the lawless invasion by armed force of the soil of any state or territory no matter under what pretext as among the gravest of crime i now reiterate these sentiment and in do so i only press upon the public attention the most conclusive evidence of which the case be susceptible that the property peace and security of no section be to be in any wise endanger by the now incoming administration i add too that all the protection which consistently with the constitution and the law can be give will be cheerfully give to all the states when lawfully demand for whatever cause&mdash;as cheerfully to one section as to another there be much controversy about the delivering up of fugitive from service or labor the clause i now read be as plainly write in the constitution as any other of its provision no person hold to service or labor in one state under the law thereof escape into another shall in consequence of any law or regulation therein be discharge from such service or labor but shall be deliver up on claim of the party to whom such service or labor may be due it be scarcely question that this provision be intend by those who make it for the reclaiming of what we call fugitive slave and the intention of the lawgiver be the law all member of congress swear their support to the whole constitution&mdash;to this provision as much as to any other to the proposition then that slave whose case come within the term of this clause shall be deliver up their oath be unanimous now if they would make the effort in good temper could they not with nearly equal unanimity frame and pass a law by mean of which to keep good that unanimous oath?there be some difference of opinion whether this clause should be enforce by national or by state authority but surely that difference be not a very material one if the slave be to be surrender it can be of but little consequence to he or to other by which authority it be do and should anyone in any case be content that his oath shall go unkept on a merely unsubstantial controversy as to how it shall be kept?again in any law upon this subject ought not all the safeguard of liberty know in civilized and humane jurisprudence to be introduce so that a free man be not in any case surrender as a slave and might it not be well at the same time to provide by law for the enforcement of that clause in the constitution which guarantee that the citizen of each state shall be entitle to all privilege and immunity of citizen in the several states "i take the official oath to day with no mental reservation and with no purpose to construe the constitution or law by any hypercritical rule and while i do not choose now to specify particular act of congress as proper to be enforce i do suggest that it will be much safe for all both in official and private station to conform to and abide by all those act which stand unrepealed than to violate any of they trust to find impunity in have they hold to be unconstitutional it be seventy two year since the first inauguration of a president under our national constitution during that period fifteen different and greatly distinguished citizen have in succession administer the executive branch of the government they have conduct it through many peril and generally with great success yet with all this scope of precedent i now enter upon the same task for the brief constitutional term of four year under great and peculiar difficulty a disruption of the federal union heretofore only menace be now formidably attempt i hold that in contemplation of universal law and of the constitution the union of these states be perpetual perpetuity be imply if not express in the fundamental law of all national government it be safe to assert that no government proper ever have a provision in its organic law for its own termination continue to execute all the express provision of our national constitution and the union will endure forever&mdash;it be impossible to destroy it except by some action not provide for in the instrument itself again if the united states be not a government proper but an association of states in the nature of contract merely can it as a contract be peaceably unmade by less than all the party who make it one party to a contract may violate it&mdash;break it so to speak but do it not require all to lawfully rescind it?descende from these general principle we find the proposition that in legal contemplation the union be perpetual confirm by the history of the union itself the union be much old than the constitution it be form in fact by the articles of association in 1774 it be mature and continue by the declaration of independence in 1776 it be far mature and the faith of all the then thirteen state expressly plight and engage that it should be perpetual by the articles of confederation in 1778 and finally in 1787 one of the declare object for ordain and establish the constitution be to form a more perfect union "but if the destruction of the union by one or by a part only of the states be lawfully possible the union be less perfect than before the constitution having lose the vital element of perpetuity it follow from these view that no state upon its own mere motion can lawfully get out of the union that resolve and ordinance to that effect be legally void and that act of violence within any state or states against the authority of the united states be insurrectionary or revolutionary accord to circumstance i therefore consider that in view of the constitution and the law the union be unbroken and to the extent of my ability i shall take care as the constitution itself expressly enjoin upon i that the law of the union be faithfully execute in all the states do this i deem to be only a simple duty on my part and i shall perform it so far as practicable unless my rightful master the american people shall withhold the requisite mean or in some authoritative manner direct the contrary i trust this will not be regard as a menace but only as the declare purpose of the union that it will constitutionally defend and maintain itself in do this there need to be no bloodshed or violence and there shall be none unless it be force upon the national authority the power confide to i will be use to hold occupy and possess the property and place belong to the government and to collect the duty and impost but beyond what may be necessary for these object there will be no invasion no using of force against or among the people anywhere where hostility to the united states in any interior locality shall be so great and universal as to prevent competent resident citizen from hold the federal office there will be no attempt to force obnoxious stranger among the people for that object while the strict legal right may exist in the government to enforce the exercise of these office the attempt to do so would be so irritate and so nearly impracticable withal that i deem it well to forego for the time the use of such office the mail unless repel will continue to be furnish in all part of the union so far as possible the people everywhere shall have that sense of perfect security which be most favorable to calm thought and reflection the course here indicate will be follow unless current event and experience shall show a modification or change to be proper and in every case and exigency my good discretion will be exercise accord to circumstance actually exist and with a view and a hope of a peaceful solution of the national trouble and the restoration of fraternal sympathy and affection that there be person in one section or another who seek to destroy the union at all event and be glad of any pretext to do it i will neither affirm nor deny but if there be such i need address no word to they to those however who really love the union may i not speak?before enter upon so grave a matter as the destruction of our national fabric with all its benefit its memory and its hope would it not be wise to ascertain precisely why we do it will you hazard so desperate a step while there be any possibility that any portion of the ill you fly from have no real existence will you while the certain ill you fly to be great than all the real one you fly from&mdash;will you risk the commission of so fearful a mistake?all profess to be content in the union if all constitutional right can be maintain be it single instance in which a plainly write provision of the constitution have ever be deny if by the mere force of number a majority should deprive a minority of any clearly write constitutional right it might in a moral point of view justify revolution&mdash;certainly would if such a right be a vital one but such be not our case all the vital right of minority and of individual be so plainly assure to they by affirmation and negation guarantee and prohibition in the constitution that controversy never arise concern they but no organic law can ever be frame with a provision specifically all who cherish disunion sentiment be now be educate to the exact temper of do this be there such perfect identity of interest among the states to compose a new union as to produce harmony only and  at the beginning of the present presidential term four month ago the function of the federal government be find to be generally suspend within the several states of south carolina georgia alabama mississippi louisiana and florida except only those of the post office department

 find this condition of thing and believe it to be an imperative duty upon the incoming executive to prevent if possible the consummation of such attempt to destroy the federal union a choice of mean to that end become indispensable this choice be make and be declare in the inaugural address the policy choose look to the exhaustion of all peaceful measure before a resort to any strong one it seek only to hold the public place and property not already wrest from the government and to collect the revenue rely for the rest on time discussion and the ballot box it promise a continuance of the mail at government expense to the very people who be resist the government and it give repeat pledge against any disturbance to any of the people or any of their right of all that which a president might constitutionally and justifiably do in such a case everything be forborne without which it be believe possible to keep the government on foot

 on the 5th of march the present incumbent&#39; first full day in office a letter of major anderson command at fort sumter write on the 28th of february and receive at the war department on the 4th of march be by that department place in his hand this letter express the professional opinion of the writer that reenforcement could not be throw into that fort within the time for his relief render necessary by the limited supply of provision and with a view of hold possession of the same with a force of less than 20,000 good and well discipline man this opinion be concur in by all the officer of his command and their memoranda on the subject be make inclosure of major anderson&#39;s letter the whole be immediately lay before lieutenant general scott who at once concur with major anderson in opinion on reflection however he take full time consult with other officer both of the army and the navy and at the end of four day come reluctantly but decidedly to the same conclusion as before he also state at the same time that no such sufficient force be then at the control of the government or could be raise and bring to the ground within the time when the provision in the fort would be exhaust in a purely military point of view this reduce the duty of the administration in the case to the mere matter of get the garrison safely out of the fort

 and this issue embrace more than the fate of these united states it present to the whole family of man the question whether a constitutional republic or democracy a government of the people by the same people can or can not maintain its territorial integrity against its own domestic foe it present the question whether discontent individual too few in number to control administration accord to organic law in any case can always upon the pretense make in this case or on any other pretense or arbitrarily without any pretense break up their government and thus practically put an end to free government upon the earth it force we to ask be there in all republic this inherent and fatal weakness must a government of necessity be too strong for the liberty of its own people or too weak to maintain its own existence

 it might seem at first think to be of little difference whether the present movement at the south be call secession or rebellion the mover however well understand the difference at the beginning they know they could never raise their treason to any respectable magnitude by any name which imply violation of law they know their people possess as much of moral sense as much of devotion to law and order and as much pride in and reverence for the history and government of their common country as any other civilized and patriotic people they know they could make no advancement directly in the tooth of these strong and noble sentiment accordingly they commence by an insidious debauching of the public mind they invent an ingenious sophism which if concede be follow by perfectly logical step through all the incident to the complete destruction of the union the sophism itself be that any state of the union may consistently with the national constitution and therefore lawfully and peacefully withdraw from the union without the consent of the union or of any other state the little disguise that the suppose right be to be exercise only for just cause themselves to be the sole judge of its justice be too thin to merit any notice
