will be give he the confidence and cordial support thus by fair implication promise and without which he can not with so full efficiency serve the country it have be say that one bad general be well than two good one and the saying be true if take to mean no more than that an army be well direct by a single mind though inferior than by two superior one at variance and cross purpose with each other and the same be true in all joint operation wherein those engage can have none but a common end in view and can differ only as to the choice of mean in a storm at sea no one on board can wish the ship to sink and yet not unfrequently all go down together because too many will direct and no single mind can be allow to control it continue to develop that the insurrection be largely if not exclusively a war upon the first principle of popular government the right of the people conclusive evidence of this be find in the most grave and maturely consider public document as well as in the general tone of the insurgent in those document we find the abridgment of the exist right of suffrage and the denial to the people of all right to participate in the selection of public officer except the legislative boldly advocate with labored argument to prove that large control of the people in government be the source of all political evil monarchy itself be sometimes hint at as a possible refuge from the power of the people in my present position i could scarcely be justify be i to omit raise a warning voice against this approach of return despotism it be not need nor fitting here that a general argument should be make in favor of popular institution but there be one point with its connection not so hackneyed as most other to which i ask a brief attention it be the effort to place capital on an equal footing with if not above labor in the structure of government it be assume that labor be available only in connection with capital that nobody labor unless somebody else own capital somehow by the use of it induce he to labor this assume it be next consider whether it be good that capital shall hire laborer and thus induce they to work by their own consent or buy they and drive they to it without their consent having proceed so far it be naturally conclude that all laborer be either hire laborer or what we call slave and far it be assume that whoever be once a hire laborer be fix in that condition for life now there be no such relation between capital and labor as assume nor be there any such thing as a free man be fix for life in the condition of a hire laborer both these assumption be false and all inference from they be groundless labor be prior to and independent of capital capital be only the fruit of labor and could never have exist if labor have not first exist labor be the superior of capital and deserve much the high consideration capital have its right which be as worthy of protection as any other right nor be it deny that there be and probably always will be a relation between labor and capital produce mutual benefit the error be in assume that the whole labor of community exist within that relation a few man own capital and that few avoid labor themselves and with their capital hire or buy another few to labor for they a large majority belong to neither class neither work for other nor have other work for they in most of the southern states a majority of the whole people of all color be neither slave nor master while in the northern a large majority be neither hirer nor hire man with their family wife son and daughter work for themselves on their farm in their house and in their shop take the whole product to themselves and ask no favor of capital on the one hand nor of hire laborer or slave on the other it be not forget that a considerable number of person mingle their own labor with capital that is they labor with their own hand and also buy or hire other to labor for they but this be only a mixed and not a distinct class no principle state be disturb by the existence of this mixed class again as have already be say there be not of necessity any such thing as the free hire laborer be fix to that condition for life many independent man everywhere in these state a few year back in their life be hire laborer the prudent penniless beginner in the world labor for wage awhile save a surplus with which to buy tool or land for himself then labor on his own account another while and at length hire another new beginner to help he this be the just and generous and prosperous system which open the way to all give hope to all and consequent energy and progress and improvement of condition to all no man live be more worthy to be trust than those who toil up from poverty none less inclined to take or touch aught which they have not honestly earn let they beware of surrender a political power which they already possess and which if surrender will surely be use to close the door of advancement against such as they and to fix new disability and burden upon they till all of liberty shall be lose from the first taking of our national census to the last be seventy year and we find our population at the end of the period eight time as great as it be at the beginning the increase of those other thing which man deem desirable have be even great we thus have at one view what the popular principle apply to government through the machiney of the states and the union have produce in a give time and also what if firmly maintain it promise for the future there be already among we those who if the union be preserve will live to see it contain 250,000,000 the struggle of to day be not altogether for to day it be for a vast future also with a reliance on providence all the more firm and earnest let we proceed in the great task which event have devolve upon we
fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives

 since your last annual assemble another year of health and bountiful harvest have pass and while it have not please the almighty to bless we with a return of peace we can but press on guide by the good light he give we trust that in his own good time and wise way all will yet be well

 the correspondence touch foreign affair which have take place during the last year be herewith submit in virtual compliance with a request to that effect make by the house of representatives near the close of the last session of congress if the condition of our relation with other nation be less gratifying than it have usually be at former period it be certainly more satisfactory than a nation so unhappily distract as we be might reasonably have apprehend in the month of june last there be some ground to expect that the maritime power which at the beginning of our domestic difficulty so unwisely and unnecessarily as we think recognize the insurgent as a belligerent would soon recede from that position which have prove only less injurious to themselves than to our own country but the temporary reverse which afterwards befell the national arm and which be exaggerate by our own disloyal citizen abroad have hitherto delay that act of simple justice

 the civil war which have so radically change for the moment the occupation and habit of the american people have necessarily disturb the social condition and affect very deeply the prosperity of the nation with which we have carry on a commerce that have be steadily increase throughout a period of half a century it have at the same time excite political ambition and apprehension which have produce a profound agitation throughout the civilized world in this unusual agitation we have forbear from take part in any controversy between foreign state and between party or faction in such state we have attempt no propagandism and acknowledge no revolution but we have leave to every nation the exclusive conduct and management of its own affair our struggle have be of course contemplate by foreign nation with reference less to its own merit than to its suppose and often exaggerated effect and consequence result to those nation themselves nevertheless complaint on the part of this government even if it be just would certainly be unwise the treaty with great britain for the suppression of the slave trade have be put into operation with a good prospect of complete success it be an occasion of special pleasure to acknowledge that the execution of it on the part of her majesty&#39;s government have be mark with a jealous respect for the authority of the united states and the right of their moral and loyal citizen

 the convention with hanover for the abolition of the stade due have be carry into full effect under the act of congress for that purpose a blockade of 3,000 mile of seacoast could not be establish and vigorously enforce in a season of great commercial activity like the present without commit occasional mistake and inflict unintentional injury upon foreign nation and their subject a civil war occur in a country where foreigner reside and carry on trade under treaty stipulation be necessarily fruitful of complaint of the violation of neutral right all such collision tend to excite misapprehension and possibly to produce mutual reclamation between nation which have a common interest in preserve peace and friendship in clear case of these kind i have so far as possible heard and redress complaint which have be present by friendly power there be still however a large and an augment number of doubtful case upon which the government be unable to agree with the government whose protection be demand by the claimant there be moreover many case in which the united states or their citizen suffer wrong from the naval or military authority of foreign nation which the government of those state be not at once prepared to redress i have propose to some of the foreign state thus interested mutual convention to examine and adjust such complaint this proposition have be make especially to great britain to france to spain and to prussia in each case it have be kindly receive but have not yet be formally adopt

 i deem it my duty to recommend an appropriation in behalf of the owner of the norwegian bark admiral p. tordenskiold which vessel be in may 1861 prevent by the commander of the blockade force off charleston from leave that port with cargo notwithstanding a similar privilege have shortly before be grant to an english vessel i have direct the secretary of state to cause the paper in the case to be communicate to the proper committee

 application have be make to i by many free americans of african descent to favor their emigration with a view to such colonization as be contemplate in recent act of congress other party at home and abroad some from interested motive other upon patriotic consideration and still other influence by philanthropic sentiment have suggest similar measure while on the other hand several of the spanish american republics have protest against the sending of such colony to their respective territory under these circumstance i have decline to move any such colony to any state without first obtain the consent of its government with an agreement on its part to receive and protect such emigrant in all the right of freeman and i have at the same time offer to the several states situate within the tropics or have colony there to negotiate with they subject to the advice and consent of the senate to favor the voluntary emigration of person of that class to their respective territory upon condition which shall be equal just and humane liberia and hayti be as yet the only country to which colonist of african descent from here could go with certainty of be receive and adopt as citizen and i regret to say such person contemplate colonization do not seem so willing to migrate to those country as to some other nor so willing as i think their interest demand i believe however opinion among they in this respect be improve and that ere long there will be an augmented and considerable migration to both these country from the united states

 the new commercial treaty between the united states and the sultan of turkey have be carry into execution

 a commercial and consular treaty have be negotiate subject to the senate&#39;s consent with liberia and a similar negotiation be now pende with the republic of hayti a considerable improvement of the national commerce be expect to result from these measure our relation with great britain france spain portugal russia prussia denmark sweden austria the netherlands italy rome and the other european states remain undisturbed very favorable relation also continue to be maintain with turkey morocco china and japan

 during the last year there have not only be no change of our previous relation with the independent states of our own continent but more friendly sentiment than have heretofore exist be believe to be entertain by these neighbor whose safety and progress be so intimately connect with our own this statement especially apply to mexico nicaragua costa rica honduras peru and chile the commission under the convention with the republic of new granada close its session without having audit and pass upon all the claim which be submit to it a proposition be pende to revive the convention that it may be able to do more complete justice the joint commission between the united states and the republic of costa rica have complete its labor and submit its report i have favor the project for connect the united states with europe by an atlantic telegraph and a similar project to extend the telegraph from san francisco to connect by a pacific telegraph with the line which be be extend across the russian empire the territories of the united states with unimportant exception have remain undisturbed by the civil war and they be exhibit such evidence of prosperity as justifie an expectation that some of they will soon be in a condition to be organize as states and be constitutionally admit into the federal union

 the immense mineral resource of some of those territories ought to be develop as rapidly as possible every step in that direction would have a tendency to improve the revenue of the government and diminish the burden of the people it be worthy of your serious consideration whether some extraordinary measure to promote that end can not be adopt the mean which suggest itself as most likely to be effective be a scientific exploration of the mineral region in those territories with a view to the publication of its result at home and in foreign country result which can not fail to be auspicious

 the condition of the finance will claim your most diligent consideration the vast expenditure incident to the military and naval operation require for the suppression of the rebellion have hitherto be meet with a promptitude and certainty unusual in similar circumstance and the public credit have be fully maintain the continuance of the war however and the increase disbursement make necessary by the augment force now in the field demand your good reflection as to the good mode of provide the necessary revenue without injury to business and with the least possible burden upon labor

 the suspension of specie payment by the bank soon after the commencement of your last session make large issue of united states note unavoidable in no other way could the payment of the troop and the satisfaction of other just demand be so economically or so well provide for the judicious legislation of congress secure the receivability of these note for loan and internal duty and make they a legal tender for other debt have make they an universal currency and have satisfy partially at least and for the time the long feel want of an uniform circulate medium save thereby to the people immense sum in discount and exchange

 a return to specie payment however at the early period compatible with due regard to all interest concern should ever be keep in view fluctuation in the value of currency be always injurious and to reduce these fluctuation to the low possible point will always be a lead purpose in wise legislation convertibility prompt and certain convertibility into coin be generally acknowledge to be the good and sure safeguard against they and it be extremely doubtful whether a circulation of united states note payable in coin and sufficiently large for the want of the people can be permanently usefully and safely maintain

 be there then any other mode in which the necessary provision for the public want can be make and the great advantage of a safe and uniform currency secure

 i know of none which promise so certain result and be at the same time so unobjectionable as the organization of banking association under a general act of congress well guard in its provision to such association the government might furnish circulate note on the security of united states bond deposit in the treasury these note prepare under the supervision of proper officer be uniform in appearance and security and convertible always into coin would at once protect labor against the evil of a vicious currency and facilitate commerce by cheap and safe exchange

 a moderate reservation from the interest on the bond would compensate the united states for the preparation and distribution of the note and a general supervision of the system and would lighten the burden of that part of the public debt employ as security the public credit moreover would be greatly improve and the negotiation of new loan greatly facilitate by the steady market demand for government bond which the adoption of the propose system would create it be an additional recommendation of the measure of considerable weight in my judgment that it would reconcile as far as possible all exist interest by the opportunity offer to exist institution to reorganize under the act substitute only the secured uniform national circulation for the local and various circulation secure and unsecured now issue by they

 the receipt into the treasury from all source include loan and balance from the precede year for the fiscal year end on the 30th june 1862 be $ 583,885,247.06 of which sum $ 49,056,397.62 be derive from custom $ 1,795,331.73 from the direct tax from public land $ 152,203.77 from miscellaneous source $ 931,787.64 from loan in all form $ 529,692,460.50 the remainder $ 2,257,065.80 be the balance from last year

 the disbursement during the same period be for congressional executive and judicial purpose $ 5,939.009.29 for foreign intercourse $ 1,339,710.35 for miscellaneous expense include the mint loan post office deficiency collection of revenue and other like charge $ 14,129,771.50 for expense under the interior department 985.52 under the war department $ 394,368,407.36 under the navy department $ 42,674,569.69 for interest on public debt $ 13,190,324.45 and for payment of public debt include reimbursement of temporary loan and redemption $ 96,096,922.09 make an aggregate of $ 570,841,700.25 and leave a balance in the treasury on the 1st day of july 1862 of $ 13,043,546.81

 it should be observe that the sum of $ 96,096,922.09 expend for reimbursement and redemption of public debt be include also in the loan make may be properly deduct both from receipt and expenditure leave the actual receipt for the year $ 487,788,324.97 and the expenditure $ 474,744,778.16

 other information on the subject of the finance will be find in the report of the secretary of the treasury to whose statement and view i invite your most candid and considerate attention

 the report of the secretaries of war and of the navy be herewith transmit these report though lengthy be scarcely more than brief abstract of the very numerous and extensive transaction and operation conduct through those department nor could i give a summary of they here upon any principle which would admit of its be much short than the report themselves i therefore content myself with lay the report before you and ask your attention to they

 it give i pleasure to report a decide improvement in the financial condition of the post office department as compare with several precede year the receipt for the fiscal year 1861 amount to $ 8,349,296.40 which embrace the revenue from all the states of the union for three quarter of that year notwithstanding the cessation of revenue from the so call secede states during the last fiscal year the increase of the correspondence of the loyal states have be sufficient to produce a revenue during the same year of $ 8,299,820.90 be only $ 50,000 less than be derive from all the states of the union during the previous year the expenditure show a still more favorable result the amount expend in 1861 be $ 13,606,759.11 for the last year the amount have be reduce to $ 11,125,364.13 show a decrease of about $ 2,481,000 in the expenditure as compare with the precede year and about $ 3,750,000 as compare with the fiscal year 1860 the deficiency in the department for the previous year be $ 4,551,966.98 for the last fiscal year it be reduce to $ 2,112,814.57 these favorable result be in part owe to the cessation of mail service in the insurrectionary states and in part to a careful review of all expenditure in that department in the interest of economy the efficiency of the postal service it be believe have also be much improve the postmaster general have also open a correspondence through the department of state with foreign government propose a convention of postal representative for the purpose of simplify the rate of foreign postage and to expedite the foreign mail this proposition equally important to our adopt citizen and to the commercial interest of this country have be favorably entertain and agree to by all the government from whom reply have be receive

 i ask the attention of congress to the suggestion of the postmaster general in his report respect the further legislation require in his opinion for the benefit of the postal service

 the secretary of the interior report as follow in regard to the public land

 the public land have cease to be a source of revenue from the 1st july 1861 to the 30th september 1862 the entire cash receipt from the sale of land be $ 137,476.26&mdash;a sum much less than the expense of our land system during the same period the homestead law which will take effect on the 1st of january next offer such inducement to settler that sale for cash can not be expect to an extent sufficient to meet the expense of the general land office and the cost of survey and bring the land into market the discrepancy between the sum here state as arise from the sale of the public land and the sum derive from the same source as report from the treasury department arise as i understand from the fact that the period of time though apparently be not really coincident at the beginning point the treasury report include a considerable sum now which have previously be report from the interior sufficiently large to greatly overreach the sum derive from the three month now report upon by the interior and not by the treasury

 the indian tribe upon our frontier have during the past year manifest a spirit of insubordination and at several point have engage in open hostility against the white settlement in their vicinity the tribe occupy the indian country south of kansas renounce their allegiance to the united states and enter into treaty with the insurgent those who remain loyal to the united states be drive from the country the chief of the cherokees have visit this city for the purpose of restore the former relation of the tribe with the united states he allege that they be constrain by superior force to enter into treaty with the insurgent and that the united states neglect to furnish the protection which their treaty stipulation require

 in the month of august last the sioux indians in minnesota attack the settlement in their vicinity with extreme ferocity kill indiscriminately man woman and child this attack be wholly unexpected and therefore no mean of defense have be prod it be estimate that not less than 800 person be kill by the indians and a large amount of property be destroy how this outbreak be induce be not definitely know and suspicion which may be unjust need not to be state information be receive by the indian bureau from different source about the time hostility be commence that a simultaneous attack be to be make upon the white settlement by all the tribe between the mississippi river and the rocky mountains the state of minnesota have suffer great injury from this indian war a large portion of her territory have be depopulate and a severe loss have be sustain by the destruction of property the people of that state manifest much anxiety for the removal of the tribe beyond the limit of the state as a guaranty against future hostility the commissioner of indian affairs will furnish full detail i submit for your especial consideration whether our indian system shall not be remodel many wise and good man have impress i with the belief that this can be profitably do

 i submit a statement of the proceeding of commissioner which show the progress that have be make in the enterprise of construct the pacific railroad and this suggest the early completion of this road and also the favorable action of congress upon the project now pende before they for enlarge the capacity of the great canal in new york and illinois as be of vital and rapidly increase importance to the whole nation and especially to the vast interior region hereinafter to be notice at some great length i purpose having prepare and lay before you at an early day some interesting and valuable statistical information upon this subject the military and commercial importance of enlarge the illinois and michigan canal and improve the illinois river be present in the report of colonel webster to the secretary of war and now transmit to congress i respectfully ask attention to it

 to carry out the provision of the act of congress of the 15th of may last i have cause the department of agriculture of the united states to be organize

 the commissioner inform i that within the period of a few month this department have establish an extensive system of correspondence and exchange both at home and abroad which promise to effect highly beneficial result in the development of a correct knowledge of recent improvement in agriculture in the introduction of new product and in the collection of the agricultural statistic of the different states

 also that it will soon be prepared to distribute largely seed cereal plant and cutting and have already publish and liberally diffuse much valuable information in anticipation of a more elaborate report which will in due time be furnish embrace some valuable test in chemical science now in progress in the laboratory

 the creation of this department be for the more immediate benefit of a large class of our most valuable citizen and i trust that the liberal basis upon which it have be organize will not only meet your approbation but that it will realize at no distant day all the fond anticipation of its most sanguine friend and become the fruitful source of advantage to all our people

 on the 22d day of september last a proclamation be issue by the executive a copy of which be herewith submit in accordance with the purpose express in the second paragraph of that paper i now respectfully recall your attention to what may be call compensate emancipation

 a nation may be say to consist of its territory its people and its law the territory be the only part which be of certain durability one generation passeth away and another generation cometh but the earth abideth forever it be of the first importance to duly consider and estimate this ever endure part that portion of the earth&#39;s surface which be own and inhabit by the people of the united states be well adapt to be the home of one national family and it be not well adapt for two or more its vast extent and its variety of climate and production be of advantage in this age for one people whatever they might have be in former age steam telegraphs and intelligence have bring these to be an advantageous combination for one united people

 in the inaugural address i briefly point out the total inadequacy of disunion as a remedy for the difference between the people of the two section i do so in language which i can not improve and which therefore i beg to repeat

 one section of our country believe slavery be right and ought to be extend while the other believe it be wrong and ought not to be extend this be the only substantial dispute the fugitive slave clause of the constitution and the law for the suppression of the foreign slave trade be each as well enforce perhaps as any law can ever be in a community where the moral sense of the people imperfectly support the law itself the great body of the people abide by the dry legal obligation in both case and a few break over in each this i think can not be perfectly cure and it would be bad in both case after the separation of the section than before the foreign slave trade now imperfectly suppress would be ultimately revive without restriction in one section while fugitive slave now only partially surrender would not be surrender at all by the other physically speak we can not separate we can not remove our respective section from each other nor build an impassable wall between they a husband and wife may be divorce and go out of the presence and beyond the reach of each other but the different part of our country can not do this they can not but remain face to face and intercourse either amicable or hostile must continue between they be it possible then to make that intercourse more advantageous or more satisfactory after separation than before can alien make treaty easy than friend can make law can treaty be more faithfully enforce between alien than law can among friend suppose you go to war you can not fight always and when after much loss on both side and no gain on either you cease fighting the identical old question as to term of intercourse be again upon you

 there be no line straight or crooked suitable for a national boundary upon which to divide trace through from east to west upon the line between the free and slave country and we shall find a little more than one third of its length be river easy to be cross and populate or soon to be populate thickly upon both side while nearly all its remain length be merely surveyors&#39 line over which people may walk back and forth without any consciousness of their presence no part of this line can be make any more difficult to pass by write it down on paper or parchment as a national boundary the fact of separation if it come give up on the part of the seceding section the fugitive slave clause along with all other constitutional obligation upon the section secede from while i should expect no treaty stipulation would ever be make to take its place

 but there be another difficulty the great interior region bound east by the alleghanies north by the british dominion west by the rocky mountains and south by the line along which the culture of corn and cotton meet and which include part of virginia part of tennessee all of kentucky ohio indiana michigan wisconsin illinois missouri kansas iowa minnesota and the territories of dakota nebraska and part of colorado already have above 10,000,000 people and will have 50,000,000 within fifty year if not prevent by any political folly or mistake it contain more than one third of the country own by the united states certainly more than 1,000,000 square mile once half as populous as massachusetts already be it would have more than 75,000,000 people a glance at the map show that territorially speak it be the great body of the republic the other part be but marginal border to it the magnificent region slope west from the rocky mountains to the pacific be the deep and also the rich in undeveloped resource in the production of provision grain grass and all which proceed from they this great interior region be naturally one of the most important in the world ascertain from the statistic the small proportion of the region which have as yet be bring into cultivation and also the large and rapidly increase amount of its product and we shall be overwhelm with the magnitude of the prospect present and yet this region have no seacoast touch no ocean anywhere as part of one nation its people now find and may forever find their way to europe by new york to south america and africa by new orleans and to asia by san francisco but separate our common country into two nation as design by the present rebellion and every man of this great interior region be thereby cut off from some one or more of these outlet not perhaps by a physical barrier but by embarrassing and onerous trade regulation

 and this be true wherever a dividing or boundary line may be fix place it between the now free and slave country or place it south of kentucky or north of ohio and still the truth remain that none south of it can trade to any port or place north of it and none north of it can trade to any port or place south of it except upon term dictate by a government foreign to they these outlet east west and south be indispensable to the well being of the people inhabit and to inhabit this vast interior region which of the three may be the good be no proper question all be well than either and all of right belong to that people and to their successor forever true to themselves they will not ask where a line of separation shall be but will vow rather that there shall be no such line nor be the marginal region less interested in these communication to and through they to the great outside world they too and each of they must have access to this egypt of the west without pay toll at the crossing of any national boundary

 our national strife spring not from our permanent part not from the land we inhabit not from our national homestead there be no possible severing of this but would multiply and not mitigate evil among we in all its adaptation and aptitude it demand union and abhor separation in fact it would ere long force reunion however much of blood and treasure the separation might have cost our strife pertain to ourselves&mdash;to the pass generation of men&mdash;and it can without convulsion be hush forever with the passing of one generation

 in this view i recommend the adoption of the follow resolution and article amendatory to the constitution of the united states

 resolve by the senate and house of representatives of the united states of america in congress assemble two third of both houses
 concur that the follow article be propose to the legislature or convention of the several states as amendment to the
 constitution of the united states all or any of which article when ratify by three fourth of the say legislature or convention to be
 valid as part or part of the said constitution viz

 art.&mdash every state wherein slavery now exist which shall abolish the same therein at any time or time before the 1st day of january a.d. 1900 shall receive compensation from the united states as follow to wit

 the president of the united states shall deliver to every such state bond of the united states bear interest at the rate of per cent per annum to an amount equal to the aggregate sum of____for each slave show to have be therein by the eighth census of the united states say bond to be deliver to such state by installment or in one parcel at the completion of the abolishment accordingly as the same shall have be gradual or at one time within such state and interest shall begin to run upon any such bond only from the proper time of its delivery as aforesaid any state having receive bond as aforesaid and afterwards reintroduce or tolerate slavery therein shall refund to the united states the bond so receive or the value thereof and all interest pay thereon

 art&mdash;all slave who shall have enjoy actual freedom by the chance of the war at any time before the end of the rebellion shall be forever free but all owner of such who shall not have be disloyal shall be compensate for they at the same rate as be provide for states adopt abolishment of slavery but in such way that no slave shall be twice account for

 art.&mdash;congress may appropriate money and otherwise provide for colonize free colored person with their own consent at any place or place without the united states

 i beg indulgence to discuss these propose article at some length without slavery the rebellion could never have exist without slavery it could not continue

 among the friend of the union there be great diversity of sentiment and of policy in regard to slavery and the african race amongst we some would perpetuate slavery some would abolish it suddenly and without compensation some would abolish it gradually and with compensation some would remove the freed people from we and some would retain they with we and there be yet other minor diversity because of these diversity we waste much strength in struggle among ourselves by mutual concession we should harmonize and act together this would be compromise but it would be compromise among the friend and not with the enemy of the union these article be intend to embody a plan of such mutual concession if the plan shall be adopt it be assume that emancipation will follow at least in several of the states

 as to the first article the main point be first the emancipation secondly the length of time for consummate it thirty seven year and thirdly the compensation

 the emancipation will be unsatisfactory to the advocate of perpetual slavery but the length of time should greatly mitigate their dissatisfaction the time spare both race from the evil of sudden derangement&mdash;in fact from the necessity of any derangement&mdash;while most of those whose habitual course of thought will be disturb by the measure will have pass away before its consummation they will never see it another class will hail the prospect of emancipation but will deprecate the length of time they will feel that it give too little to the now live slave but it really give they much it save they from the vagrant destitution which must largely attend immediate emancipation in locality where their number be very great and it give the inspire assurance that their posterity shall be free forever the plan leave to each state choose to act under it to abolish slavery now or at the end of the century or at any intermediate time or by degree extend over the whole or any part of the period and it oblige no two state to proceed alike it also provide for compensation and generally the mode of make it this it would seem must far mitigate the dissatisfaction of those who favor perpetual slavery and especially of those who be to receive the compensation doubtless some of those who be to pay and not to receive will object yet the measure be both just and economical in a certain sense the liberation of slave be the destruction of property&mdash;property acquire by descent or by purchase the same as any other property it be no less true for having be often say that the people of the south be not more responsible for the original introduction of this property than be the people of the north and when it be remember how unhesitatingly we all use cotton and sugar and share the profit of deal in they it may not be quite safe to say that the south have be more responsible than the north for its continuance if then for a common object this property be to be sacrifice be it not just that it be do at a common charge

 and if with less money or money more easily pay we can preserve the benefit of the union by this mean than we can by the war alone be it not also economical to do it let we consider it then let we ascertain the sum we have expend in the war since compensate emancipation be propose last march and consider whether if that measure have be promptly accept by even some of the slave states the same sum would not have do more to close the war than have be otherwise do if so the measure would save money and in that view would be a prudent and economical measure certainly it be not so easy to pay something as it be to pay nothing but it be easy to pay a large sum than it be to pay a large one and it be easy to pay any sum when we be able than it be to pay it before we be able the war require large sum and require they at once the aggregate sum necessary for compensate emancipation of course would be large but it would require no ready cash nor the bond even any fast than the emancipation progress this might not and probably would not close before the end of the thirty seven year at that time we shall probably have a hundred million of people to share the burden instead of thirty one million as now and not only so but the increase of our population may be expect to continue for a long time after that period as rapidly as before because our territory will not have become full i do not state this inconsiderately at the same ratio of increase which we have maintain on an average from our first national census in 1790 until that of 1860 we should in 1900 have a population of 103,208,415 and why may we not continue that ratio far beyond that period our abundant room our broad national homestead be our ample resource be our territory as limit as be the british isles very certainly our population could not expand as state instead of receive the foreign bear as now we should be compel to send part of the native bear away but such be not our condition we have 2,963,000 square mile europe have 3,800,000 with a population average 73 1/3 person to the square mile why may not our country at some time average as many be it less fertile have it more waste surface by mountain river lake desert or other cause be it inferior to europe in any natural advantage if then we be at some time to be as populous as europe how soon as to when this may be we can judge by the past and the present as to when it will be if ever depend much on whether we maintain the union several of our states be already above the average of europe 73 1/3 to the square mile massachusetts have 157 rhode island 133 connecticut 99 new york and new jersey each 80 also two other great states pennsylvania and ohio be not far below the former have 63 and the latter 59 the state already above the european average except new york have increase in as rapid a ratio since pass that point as ever before while no one of they be equal to some other part of our country in natural capacity for sustain a dense population

 take the nation in the aggregate and we find its population and ratio of increase for the several decennial period to be as follow

 year population ratio of increase percent
 1790 3,929,827
 1800 5,304,937 35.02
 1810 7,239,814 36.45
 1820 9,638,131 36.45
 1830 12,866,020 33.49
 1840 17,069,453 32.67
 1850 23,191,876 35.87
 1860 31,443,790 35.58

 this show an average decennial increase of 34.60 per cent in population through the seventy year from our first to our last census vet take it be see that the ratio of increase at no one of these seven period be either 2 per cent below or 2 per cent above the average thus show how inflexible and consequently how reliable the law of increase in our case be assume that it will continue it give the follow result

 year population
 1870 42,323,341
 1880 56,967,216
 1890 76,677,872
 1900 103,208,415
 1910 138,918,526
 1920 186,984,335
 1930 251,680,914

 these figure show that our country may be as populous as europe now be at some point between 1920 and 1930&mdash;say about 1925&mdash;our territory at 73 1/3 person to the square mile be of capacity to contain 217,186,000

 and we will reach this too if we do not ourselves relinquish the chance by the folly and evil of disunion or by long and exhaust war spring from the only great element of national discord among we while it can not be foresee exactly how much one huge example of secession breed less one indefinitely would retard population civilization and prosperity no one can doubt that the extent of it would be very great and injurious

 the propose emancipation would shorten the war perpetuate peace insure this increase of population and proportionately the wealth of the country with these we should pay all the emancipation would cost together with our other debt easy than we should pay our other debt without it if we have allow our old national debt to run at 6 per cent per annum simple interest from the end of our revolutionary struggle until to day without pay anything on either principal or interest each man of we would owe less upon that debt now than each man owe upon it then and this because our increase of man through the whole period have be great than 6 per cent&mdash;ha run fast than the interest upon the debt thus time alone relieve a debtor nation so long as its population increase fast than unpaid interest accumulate on its debt

 this fact would be no excuse for delay payment of what be justly due but it show the great importance of time in this connection&mdash;the great advantage of a policy by which we shall not have to pay until we number 100,000,000 what by a different policy we would have to pay now when we number but 31,000,000 in a word it show that a dollar will be much hard to pay for the war than will be a dollar for emancipation on the propose plan and then the latter will cost no blood no precious life it will be a saving of both

 as to the second article i think it would be impracticable to return to bondage the class of person therein contemplated some of they doubtless in the property sense belong to loyal owner and hence provision be make in this article for compensate such the third article relate to the future of the freed people it do not oblige but merely authorize congress to aid in colonizing such as may consent this ought not to be regard as objectionable on the one hand or on the other insomuch as it come to nothing unless by the mutual consent of the people to be deport and the american voter through their representative in congress

 i can not make it well know than it already be that i strongly favor colonization and yet i wish to say there be an objection urge against free colored person remain in the country which be largely imaginary if not sometimes malicious

 it be insist that their presence would injure and displace white labor and white laborer if there ever could be a proper time for mere catch argument that time surely be not now in time like the present man should utter nothing for which they would not willingly be responsible through time and in eternity be it true then that colored people can displace any more white labor by be free than by remain slave if they stay in their old place they jostle no white laborer if they leave their old place they leave they open to white laborer logically there be neither more nor less of it emancipation even without deportation would probably enhance the wage of white labor and very surely would not reduce they thus the customary amount of labor would still have to be performed&mdash;the freed people would surely not do more than their old proportion of it and very probably for a time would do less leave an increase part to white laborer bring their labor into great demand and consequently enhance the wage of it with deportation even to a limited extent enhance wage to white labor be mathematically certain labor be like any other commodity in the market&mdash;increase the demand for it and you increase the price of it reduce the supply of black labor by colonize the black laborer out of the country and by precisely so much you increase the demand for and wage of white labor

 but it be dread that the freed people will swarm forth and cover the whole land be they not already in the land will liberation make they any more numerous equally distribute among the white of the whole country and there would be but one color to seven white could the one in any way greatly disturb the seven there be many community now have more than one free colored person to seven white and this without any apparent consciousness of evil from it the district of columbia and the states of maryland and delaware be all in this condition the district have more than one free color to six white and yet in its frequent petition to congress i believe it have never present the presence of free colored person as one of its grievance but why should emancipation south send the free people north people of any color seldom run unless there be something to run from hertofore color people to some extent have flee north from bondage and now perhaps from both bondage and destitution but if gradual emancipation and deportation be adopt they will have neither to flee from their old master will give they wage at least until new laborer can be procure and the freedman in turn will gladly give their labor for the wage till new home can be find for they in congenial clime and with people of their own blood and race this proposition can be trust on the mutual interest involve and in any event can not the north decide for itself whether to receive they

 again as practice prove more than theory in any case have there be any irruption of colored people northward because of the abolishment of slavery in this district last spring

 what i have say of the proportion of free colored person to the white in the district be from the census of 1860 have no reference to person call contraband nor to those make free by the act of congress abolish slavery here

 the plan consist of these article be recommend not but that a restoration of the national authority would be accept without its adoption

 nor will the war nor proceeding under the proclamation of september 22 1862 be stay because of the recommendation of this plan its timely adoption i doubt not would bring restoration and thereby stay both

 and notwithstanding this plan the recommendation that congress provide by law for compensate any state which may adopt emancipation before this plan shall have be act upon be hereby earnestly renew such would be only an advance part of the plan and the same argument apply to both

 this plan be recommend as a means not in exclusion of but additional to all other for restore and preserve the national authority throughout the union the subject be present exclusively in its economical aspect the plan would i be confident secure peace more speedily and maintain it more permanently than can be do by force alone while all it would cost consider amount and manner of payment and time of payment would be easier pay than will be the additional cost of the war if we rely solely upon force it be much very much that it would cost no blood at all

 the plan be propose as permanent constitutional law it can not become such without the concurrence of first two third of congress and afterwards three fourth of the states the requisite three fourth of the states will necessarily include seven of the slave states their concurrence if obtain will give assurance of their severally adopt emancipation at no very distant day upon the new constitutional term this assurance would end the struggle now and save the union forever

 i do not forget the gravity which should characterize a paper address to the congress of the nation by the chief magistrate of the nation nor do i forget that some of you be my senior nor that many of you have more experience than i in the conduct of public affair yet i trust that in view of the great responsibility rest upon i you will perceive no want of respect to yourself in any undue earnestness i may seem to display

 be it doubted then that the plan i propose if adopt would shorten the war and thus lessen its expenditure of money and of blood be it doubted that it would restore the national authority and national prosperity and perpetuate both indefinitely be it doubted that we here&mdash;congress and executive can secure its adoption will not the good people respond to a united and earnest appeal from we can we can they by any other mean so certainly or so speedily assure these vital object we can succeed only by concert it be not can any of we imagine well but can we all do well object whatsoever be possible still the question recur can we do well the dogma of the quiet past be inadequate to the stormy present the occasion be pile high with difficulty and we must rise with the occasion as our case be new so we must think anew and act anew we must disenthrall ourselves and then we shall save our country

 fellow citizen we can not escape history we of this congress and this administration will be remember in spite of ourselves no personal significance or insignificance can spare one or another of we the fiery trial through which we pass will light we down in honor or dishonor to the late generation we say we be for the union the world will not forget that we say this we know how to save the union the world know we do know how to save it we even we here hold the power and bear the responsibility in give freedom to the slave we assure freedom to the free&mdash;honorable alike in what we give and what we preserve we shall nobly save or meanly lose the last good hope of earth other mean may succeed this could not fail the way be plain peaceful generous just&mdash;a way which if follow the world will forever applaud and god must forever bless
by the president of the united states of america          a proclamation          whereas on the twentysecond day of september in the year of our lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty two a proclamation be issue by the president of the united states contain among other thing the following towit        ` ` that on the first day of january in the year of our lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty three all person hold as slave within any state or designate part of a state the people whereof shall then be in rebellion against the united states shall be then thenceforward and forever free and the executive government of the united states include the military and naval authority thereof will recognize and maintain the freedom of such person and will do no act or act to repress such person or any of they in any effort they may make for their actual freedom          ` ` that the executive will on the first day of january aforesaid by proclamation designate the states and part of states if any in which the people thereof respectively shall then be in rebellion against the united states and the fact that any state or the people thereof shall on that day be in good faith represent in the congress of the united states by member choose thereto at election wherein a majority of the qualified voter of such state shall have participate shall in the absence of strong countervail testimony be deem conclusive evidence that such state and the people thereof be not then in rebellion against the united states          now therefore i abraham lincoln president of the united states by virtue of the power in i vest as commander in chief of the army and navy of the united states in time of actual armed rebellion against authority and government of the united states and as a fit and necessary war measure for suppress say rebellion do on this first day of january in the year of our lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty three and in accordance with my purpose so to do publicly proclaim for the full period of one hundred day from the day first above mention order and designate as the states and part of states wherein the people thereof respectively be this day in rebellion against the united states the following towit          arkansas texas louisiana except the parishes of st. bernard plaquemines jefferson st. johns st. charles st. james ascension assumption terrebonne lafourche st. mary st. martin and orleans include the city of new orleans mississippi alabama florida georgia south carolina north carolina and virginia except the fortyeight county designate as west virginia and also the county of berkley accomac northampton elizabeth city york princess ann and norfolk include the city of norfolk amp portsmouth and which except part be for the present leave precisely as if this proclamation be not issue          and by virtue of the power and for the purpose aforesaid i do order and declare that all person hold as slave within say designate states and part of states be and henceforward shall be free and that the executive government of the united states include the military and naval authority thereof will recognize and maintain the freedom of say person          and i hereby enjoin upon the people so declare to be free to abstain from all violence unless in necessary self defence and i recommend to they that in all case when allow they labor faithfully for reasonable wage          and i far declare and make know that such person of suitable condition will be receive into the armed service of the united states to garrison fort position station and other place and to man vessel of all sort in say service          and upon this act sincerely believe to be an act of justice warrant by the constitution upon military necessity i invoke the considerate judgment of mankind and the gracious favor of almighty god          in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix          do at the city of washington this first day of january in the year of our lord one thousand eight hundred and sixty three and of the independence of the united states of america   executive mansion washington august 26 1863.hon james c. conkle my dear sir your letter invite i to attend a mass meeting of unconditional union man to be hold at the capital of illinois on the 3d day of september have be receive it would be very agreeable to i to thus meet my old friend at my own home but i can not just now be absent from here so long as a visit there would require the meeting be to be of all those who maintain unconditional devotion to the union and i be sure my old political friend will thank i for tender as i do the nation 's gratitude to those other noble man whom no partizan malice or partizan hope can make false to the nation 's life there be those who be dissatisfied with i to such i would say you desire peace and you blame i that we do not have it but how can we attain it there be but three conceivable way first to suppress the rebellion by force of arm this i be try to do be you for it if you be so far we be agree if you be not for it a second way be to give up the union i be against this be you for it if you be you should say so plainly if you be not for force nor yet for dissolution there only remain some imaginable compromise i do not believe any compromise embrace the maintenance of the union be now possible all i learn lead to a directly opposite belief the strength of the rebellion be its military its army that army dominate all the country and all the people within its range any offer of term make by any man or man within that range in opposition to that army be simply nothing for the present because such man or man have no power whatever to enforce their side of a compromise if one be make with they to illustrate suppose refugee from the south and peace man of the north get together in convention and frame and proclaim a compromise embrace a restoration of the union in what way can that compromise be use to keep lee 's army out of pennsylvania meade 's army can keep lee 's army out of pennsylvania and i think can ultimately drive it out of existence but no paper compromise to which the controller of lee 's army be not agree can at all affect that army in an effort at such compromise we should waste time which the enemy would improve to our disadvantage and that would be all a compromise to be effective must be make either with those who control the rebel army or with the people first liberate from the domination of that army by the success of our own army now allow i to assure you that no word or intimation from that rebel army or from any of the man control it in relation to any peace compromise have ever come to my knowledge or belief all charge and insinuation to the contrary be deceptive and groundless and i promise you that if any such proposition shall hereafter come it shall not be reject and keep a secret from you i freely acknowledge myself the servant of the people accord to the bond of service the united states constitution and that as such i be responsible to they but to be plain you be dissatisfied with i about the negro quite likely there be a difference of opinion between you and myself upon that subject i certainly wish that all man could be free while i suppose you do not yet i have neither adopt nor propose any measure which be not consistent with even your view provide you be for the union i suggest compensate emancipation to which you reply you wish not to be tax to buy negro but i have not ask you to be tax to buy negro except in such way as to save you from great taxation to save the union exclusively by other mean you dislike the emancipation proclamation and perhaps would have it retract you say it be unconstitutional i think differently i think the constitution invest its commander in chief with the law of war in time of war the most that can be say if so much be that slave be property be there have there ever be any question that by the law of war property both of enemy and friend may be take when need and be it not need whenever take it help we or hurt the enemy army the world over destroy enemy property when they can not use it and even destroy their own to keep it from the enemy civilized belligerent do all in their power to help themselves or hurt the enemy except a few thing regard as barbarous or cruel among the exception be the massacre of vanquished foe and non combatant male and female but the proclamation as law either be valid or be not valid if it be not valid it need no retraction if it be valid it can not be retract any more than the dead can be bring to life some of you profess to think its retraction would operate favorably for the union why well after the retraction than before the issue there be more than a year and a half of trial to suppress the rebellion before the proclamation issue the last one hundred day of which pass under an explicit notice that it be come unless avert by those in revolt return to their allegiance the war have certainly progress as favorably for we since the issue of the proclamation as before i know as fully as one can know the opinion of other that some of the commander of our army in the field who have give we our most important success believe the emancipation policy and the use of colored troop constitute the heavy blow yet deal to the rebellion and that at least one of those important success could not have be achieve when it be but for the aid of black soldier among the commander hold these view be some who have never have any affinity with what be call abolitionism or with republican party politic but who hold they purely as military opinion i submit these opinion as be entitle to some weight against the objection often urge that emancipation and arm the black be unwise as military measure and be not adopt as such in good faith you say you will not fight to free negro some of they seem willing to fight for you but no matter fight you then exclusively to save the union i issue the proclamation on purpose to aid you in save the union whenever you shall have conquer all resistance to the union if i shall urge you to continue fight it will be an apt time then for you to declare you will not fight to free negro i think that in your struggle for the union to whatever extent the negro should cease help the enemy to that extent it weaken the enemy in his resistance to you do you think differently i think that whatever negro can be get to do as soldier leave just so much less for white soldier to do in save the union do it appear otherwise to you but negro like other people act upon motive why should they do any thing for we if we will do nothing for they if they stake their life for we they must be prompt by the strong motive even the promise of freedom and the promise be make must be keep the sign look well the father of waters again go unvexed to the sea thank to the great north west for it nor yet wholly to they three hundred mile up they meet new england empire key stone and jersey hew their way right and leave the sunny south too in more color than one also lend a hand on the spot their part of the history be jot down in black and white the job be a great national one and let none be ban who bear an honorable part in it and while those who have clear the great river may well be proud even that be not all it be hard to say that anything have be more bravely and well do than at antietam murfreesboro gettysburg and on many field of less note nor must uncle sam 's web foot be forget at all the watery margin they have be present not only on the deep sea the broad bay and the rapid river but also up the narrow muddy bayou and wherever the ground be a little damp they have be and make their track thank to all for the great republic for the principle it live by and keep alive for man 's vast future,--- thank to all peace do not appear so distant as it do i hope it will come soon and come to stay and so come as to be worth the keeping in all future time it will then have be prove that among free man there can be no successful appeal from the ballot to the bullet and that they who take such appeal be sure to lose their case and pay the cost and then there will be some black man who can remember that with silent tongue and clench tooth and steady eye and well poise bayonet they have help mankind on to this great consummation while i fear there will be some white one unable to forget that with malignant heart and deceitful speech they have strive to hinder it still let we not be over sanguine of a speedy final triumph let we be quite sober let we diligently apply the mean never doubt that a just god in his own good time will give we the rightful result your very truly a. lincoln executive mansion washington august 26 1863.hon james c. conkle my dear sir your letter invite i to attend a mass meeting of unconditional union man to be hold at the capital of illinois on the 3d day of september have be receive it would be very agreeable to i to thus meet my old friend at my own home but i can not just now be absent from here so long as a visit there would require the meeting be to be of all those who maintain unconditional devotion to the union and i be sure my old political friend will thank i for tender as i do the nation 's gratitude to those other noble man whom no partizan malice or partizan hope can make false to the nation 's life there be those who be dissatisfied with i to such i would say you desire peace and you blame i that we do not have it but how can we attain it there be but three conceivable way first to suppress the rebellion by force of arm this i be try to do be you for it if you be so far we be agree if you be not for it a second way be to give up the union i be against this be you for it if you be you should say so plainly if you be not for force nor yet for dissolution there only remain some imaginable compromise i do not believe any compromise embrace the maintenance of the union be now possible all i learn lead to a directly opposite belief the strength of the rebellion be its military&mdash;it army that army dominate all the country and all the people within its range any offer of term make by any man or man within that range in opposition to that army be simply nothing for the present because such man or man have no power whatever to enforce their side of a compromise if one be make with they to illustrate&mdash;suppose refugee from the south and peace man of the north get together in convention and frame and proclaim a compromise embrace a restoration of the union in what way can that compromise be use to keep lee 's army out of pennsylvania meade 's army can keep lee 's army out of pennsylvania and i think can ultimately drive it out of existence but no paper compromise to which the controller of lee 's army be not agree can at all affect that army in an effort at such compromise we should waste time which the enemy would improve to our disadvantage and that would be all a compromise to be effective must be make either with those who control the rebel army or with the people first liberate from the domination of that army by the success of our own army now allow i to assure you that no word or intimation from that rebel army or from any of the man control it in relation to any peace compromise have ever come to my knowledge or belief all charge and insinuation to the contrary be deceptive and groundless and i promise you that if any such proposition shall hereafter come it shall not be reject and keep a secret from you i freely acknowledge myself the servant of the people accord to the bond of service&mdash;the united states constitution and that as such i be responsible to they but to be plain you be dissatisfied with i about the negro quite likely there be a difference of opinion between you and myself upon that subject i certainly wish that all man could be free while i suppose you do not yet i have neither adopt nor propose any measure which be not consistent with even your view provide you be for the union i suggest compensate emancipation to which you reply you wish not to be tax to buy negro but i have not ask you to be tax to buy negro except in such way as to save you from great taxation to save the union exclusively by other mean you dislike the emancipation proclamation and perhaps would have it retract you say it be unconstitutional&mdash;i think differently i think the constitution invest its commander in chief with the law of war in time of war the most that can be say if so much be that slave be property be there&mdash;ha there ever been&mdash;any question that by the law of war property both of enemy and friend may be take when need and be it not need whenever take it help we or hurt the enemy army the world over destroy enemy property when they can not use it and even destroy their own to keep it from the enemy civilized belligerent do all in their power to help themselves or hurt the enemy except a few thing regard as barbarous or cruel among the exception be the massacre of vanquished foe and non combatant male and female but the proclamation as law either be valid or be not valid if it be not valid it need no retraction if it be valid it can not be retract any more than the dead can be bring to life some of you profess to think its retraction would operate favorably for the union why well after the retraction than before the issue there be more than a year and a half of trial to suppress the rebellion before the proclamation issue the last one hundred day of which pass under an explicit notice that it be come unless avert by those in revolt return to their allegiance the war have certainly progress as favorably for we since the issue of the proclamation as before i know as fully as one can know the opinion of other that some of the commander of our army in the field who have give we our most important success believe the emancipation policy and the use of colored troop constitute the heavy blow yet deal to the rebellion and that at least one of those important success could not have be achieve when it be but for the aid of black soldier among the commander hold these view be some who have never have any affinity with what be call abolitionism or with republican party politic but who hold they purely as military opinion i submit these opinion as be entitle to some weight against the objection often urge that emancipation and arm the black be unwise as military measure and be not adopt as such in good faith you say you will not fight to free negro some of they seem willing to fight for you but no matter fight you then exclusively to save the union i issue the proclamation on purpose to aid you in save the union whenever you shall have conquer all resistance to the union if i shall urge you to continue fight it will be an apt time then for you to declare you will not fight to free negro i think that in your struggle for the union to whatever extent the negro should cease help the enemy to that extent it weaken the enemy in his resistance to you do you think differently i think that whatever negro can be get to do as soldier leave just so much less for white soldier to do in save the union do it appear otherwise to you but negro like other people act upon motive why should they do any thing for we if we will do nothing for they if they stake their life for we they must be prompt by the strong motive&mdash;even the promise of freedom and the promise be make must be keep the sign look well the father of waters again go unvexed to the sea thank to the great north west for it nor yet wholly to they three hundred mile up they meet new england empire key stone and jersey hew their way right and leave the sunny south too in more color than one also lend a hand on the spot their part of the history be jot down in black and white the job be a great national one and let none be ban who bear an honorable part in it and while those who have clear the great river may well be proud even that be not all it be hard to say that anything have be more bravely and well do than at antietam murfreesboro gettysburg and on many field of less note nor must uncle sam 's web foot be forget at all the watery margin they have be present not only on the deep sea the broad bay and the rapid river but also up the narrow muddy bayou and wherever the ground be a little damp they have be and make their track thank to all for the great republic&mdash;for the principle it live by and keep alive&mdash;for man 's vast future,&mdash;thank to all peace do not appear so distant as it do i hope it will come soon and come to stay and so come as to be worth the keeping in all future time it will then have be prove that among free man there can be no successful appeal from the ballot to the bullet and that they who take such appeal be sure to lose their case and pay the cost and then there will be some black man who can remember that with silent tongue and clench tooth and steady eye and well poise bayonet they have help mankind on to this great consummation while i fear there will be some white one unable to forget that with malignant heart and deceitful speech they have strive to hinder it still let we not be over sanguine of a speedy final triumph let we be quite sober let we diligently apply the mean never doubt that a just god in his own good time will give we the rightful result your very truly a. lincoln
four score and seven year ago our father bring forth on this continent a new nation conceive in liberty and dedicate to the proposition that all man be create equal now we be engage in a great civil war test whether that nation or any nation so conceived and so dedicated can long endure we be meet on a great battle field of that war we have come to dedicate a portion of that field as a final resting place for those who here give their life that that nation might live it be altogether fitting and proper that we should do this but in a large sense we can not dedicate&mdash;we can not consecrate&mdash;we can not hallow&mdash;this ground the brave man living and dead who struggle here have consecrate it far above our poor power to add or detract the world will little note nor long remember what we say here but it can never forget what they do here it be for we the living rather to be dedicate here to the unfinished work which they who fight here have thus far so nobly advanced it be rather for we to be here dedicate to the great task remain before us&mdash;that from these honor dead we take increase devotion to that cause for which they give the last full measure of devotion&mdash;that we here highly resolve that these dead shall not have die in vain&mdash;that this nation under god shall have a new birth of freedom&mdash;and that government of the people by the people for the people shall not perish from the earth
