 so that over this vast domain of criminal jurisprudence provide by each state for the protection of its own citizen and for the punishment of all person who violate its criminal law federal law whenever it can be make to apply displace state law the question here naturally arise from what source congress derive the power to transfer to federal tribunal certain class of case embrace in this section the constitution expressly declare that the judicial power of the united states shall extend to all case in law and equity arise under this constitution the law of the united states and treaty make or which shall be make under their authority to all case affect ambassador other public minister and consul to all case of admiralty and maritime jurisdiction to controversy to which the united states shall be a party to controversy between two or more state between a state and citizen of another state between citizen of different states between citizen of the same state claim land under grant of different states and between a state or the citizen thereof and foreign state citizen or subject here the judicial power of the united states be expressly set forth and define and the act of september 24 1789 establish the judicial court of the united states in confer upon the federal court jurisdiction over case originate in state tribunal be careful to confine they to the class enumerate in the above recite clause of the constitution this section of the bill undoubtedly comprehend case and authorize the exercise of power that be not by the constitution within the jurisdiction of the court of the united states to transfer they to those court would be an exercise of authority well calculate to excite distrust and alarm on the part of all the states for the bill apply alike to all of they as well to those that have as to those that have not be engage in rebellion

 it may be assume that this authority be incident to the power grant to congress by the constitution as recently amend to enforce by appropriate legislation the article declare that

 neither slavery nor involuntary servitude except as a punishment for crime whereof the party shall have be duly convict shall exist within the united states or any place subject to their jurisdiction

 it can not however be justly claim that with a view to the enforcement of this article of the constitution there be at present any necessity for the exercise of all the power which this bill confer slavery have be abolish and at present nowhere exist within the jurisdiction of the united states nor have there be nor be it likely there will be any attempt to revive it by the people or the states if however any such attempt shall be make it will then become the duty of the general government to exercise any and all incidental power necessary and proper to maintain inviolate this great constitutional law of freedom

 the fourth section of the bill provide that officer and agent of the freedmen 's bureau shall be empower to make arrest and also that other officer may be specially commission for that purpose by the president of the united states it also authorize circuit court of the united states and the superior court of the territories to appoint without limitation commissioner who be to be charge with the performance of quasi judicial duty

 the fifth section empower the commissioner so to be select by the court to appoint in writing under their hand one or more suitable person from time to time to execute warrant and other process describe by the bill these numerous official agent be make to constitute a sort of police in addition to the military and be authorize to summon a posse comitatus and even to call to their aid such portion of the land and naval force of the united states or of the militia as may be necessary to the performance of the duty with which they be charge this extraordinary power be to be confer upon agent irresponsible to the government and to the people to whose number the discretion of the commissioner be the only limit and in whose hand such authority might be make a terrible engine of wrong oppression and fraud the general statute regulate the land and naval force of the united states the militia and the execution of the law be believe to be adequate for every emergency which can occur in time of peace if it should prove otherwise congress can at any time amend those law in such manner as while subserve the public welfare not to jeopard the right interest and liberty of the people

 the seventh section provide that a fee of $ 10 shall be pay to each commissioner in every case bring before he and a fee of $ 5 to his deputy or deputy for each person he or they may arrest and take before any such commissioner with such other fee as may be deem reasonable by such commissioner in general for perform such other duty as may be require in the premise all these fee be to be pay out of the treasury of the united states whether there be a conviction or not but in case of conviction they be to be recoverable from the defendant it seem to i that under the influence of such temptation bad man might convert any law however beneficent into an instrument of persecution and fraud

 by the eighth section of the bill the united states court which sit only in one place for white citizen must migrate with the marshal and district attorney and necessarily with the clerk although he be not mention to any part of the district upon the order of the president and there hold a court for the purpose of the more speedy arrest and trial of person charge with a violation of this act and there the judge and officer of the court must remain upon the order of the president for the time therein designated

 the ninth section authorize the president or such person as he may empower for that purpose to employ such part of the land or naval force of the united states or of the militia as shall be necessary to prevent the violation and enforce the due execution of this act this language seem to imply a permanent military force that be to be always at hand and whose only business be to be the enforcement of this measure over the vast region where it be intend to operate

 i do not propose to consider the policy of this bill to i the detail of the bill seem fraught with evil the white race and the black race of the south have hitherto live together under the relation of master and slave capital own labor now suddenly that relation be change and as to ownership capital and labor be divorce they stand now each master of itself in this new relation one be necessary to the other there will be a new adjustment which both be deeply interested in make harmonious each have equal power in settle the term and if leave to the law that regulate capital and labor it be confidently believe that they will satisfactorily work out the problem capital it be true have more intelligence but labor be never so ignorant as not to understand its own interest not to know its own value and not to see that capital must pay that value

 this bill frustrate this adjustment it intervene between capital and labor and attempt to settle question of political economy through the agency of numerous official whose interest it will be to foment discord between the two race for as the breach widen their employment will continue and when it be close their occupation will terminate

 in all our history in all our experience as a people live under federal and state law no such system as that contemplate by the detail of this bill have ever before be propose or adopt they establish for the security of the colored race safeguard which go infinitely beyond any that the general government have ever provide for the white race in fact the distinction of race and color be by the bill make to operate in favor of the colored and against the white race they interfere with the municipal legislation of the states with the relation exist exclusively between a state and its citizen or between inhabitant of the same state an absorption and assumption of power by the general government which if acquiesce in must sap and destroy our federative system of limited power and break down the barrier which preserve the right of the states it be another step or rather stride toward centralization and the concentration of all legislative power in the national government the tendency of the bill must be to resuscitate the spirit of rebellion and to arrest the progress of those influence which be more closely draw around the states the bond of union and peace

 my lamented predecessor in his proclamation of the 1st of january 1863 order and declare that all person hold as slave within certain states and part of states therein designate be and thenceforward should be free and far that the executive government of the united states include the military and naval authority thereof would recognize and maintain the freedom of such person this guaranty have be render especially obligatory and sacred by the amendment of the constitution abolishing slavery throughout the united states i therefore fully recognize the obligation to protect and defend that class of our people whenever and wherever it shall become necessary and to the full extent compatible with the constitution of the united states

 entertain these sentiment it only remain for i to say that i will cheerfully cooperate with congress in any measure that may be necessary for the protection of the civil right of the freedman as well as those of all other class of person throughout the united states by judicial process under equal and impartial law in conformity with the provision of the federal constitution

 i now return the bill to the senate and regret that in consider the bill and joint resolution forty two in number which have be thus far submit for my approval i be compel to withhold my assent from a second measure that have receive the sanction of both houses of congress

by the president of the united states of america

 a proclamation

 whereas by proclamation of the 15th and 19th of april 1861 the president of the united states in virtue of the power vest in he by the constitution and the law declare that the law of the united states be oppose and the execution thereof obstruct in the states of south carolina georgia alabama florida mississippi louisiana and texas by combination too powerful to be suppress by the ordinary course of judicial proceeding or by the power vest in the marshal by law and

 whereas by another proclamation make on the 16th day of august in the same year in pursuance of an act of congress approve july 13 1861 the inhabitant of the states of georgia south carolina virginia north carolina tennessee alabama louisiana texas arkansas mississippi and florida except the inhabitant of that part of the state of virginia lie west of the alleghany mountains and of such other part of that state and the other states before name as might maintain a loyal adhesion to the union and the constitution or might be from time to time occupy and control by force of the united states engage in the dispersion of insurgent be declare to be in a state of insurrection against the united states and

 whereas by another proclamation of the 1st day of july 1862 issue in pursuance of an act of congress approve june 7 in the same year the insurrection be declare to be still exist in the states aforesaid with the exception of certain specify county in the state of virginia and

 whereas by another proclamation make on the 2d day of april 1863 in pursuance of the act of congress of july 13 1861 the exception name in the proclamation of august 16 1861 be revoke and the inhabitant of the states of georgia south carolina north carolina tennessee alabama louisiana texas arkansas mississippi florida and virginia except the forty eight county of virginia designate as west virginia and the port of new orleans key west port royal and beaufort in north carolina be declare to be still in a state of insurrection against the united states and

 whereas the house of representatives on the 22d day of july 1861 adopt a resolution in the word follow namely

 resolve by the house of representatives of the congress of the united states that the present deplorable civil war have be force upon the country by the disunionist of the southern states now in revolt against the constitutional government and in arm around the capital that in this national emergency congress banish all feeling of mere passion or resentment will recollect only its duty to the whole country that this war be not wage upon our part in any spirit of oppression nor for any purpose of conquest or subjugation nor purpose of overthrow interfere with the right or establish institution of those states but to defend and maintain the supremacy of the constitution and to preserve the union with all the dignity equality and right of the several states unimpaire and that as soon as these object be accomplish the war ought to cease

 and whereas the senate of the united states on the 25th day of july 1861 adopt a resolution in the word follow to wit

 resolved that the present deplorable civil war have be force upon the country by the disunionist of the southern states now in revolt against the constitutional government and in arm around the capital that in this national emergency congress banish all feeling of mere passion or resentment will recollect only its duty to the whole country that this war be not prosecute upon our part in any spirit of oppression nor for any purpose of conquest or subjugation nor purpose of overthrow or interfere with the right or establish institution of those states but to defend and maintain the supremacy of the constitution and all law make in pursuance thereof and to preserve the union with all the dignity equality and right of the several states unimpaire that as soon as these object be accomplish the war ought to cease

 and whereas these resolution though not joint or concurrent in form be substantially identical and as such may be regard as having express the sense of congress upon the subject to which they relate and

 whereas by my proclamation of the 13th day of june last the insurrection in the state of tennessee be declare to have be suppress the authority of the united states therein to be undisputed and such united states officer as have be duly commission to be in the undisturbed exercise of their official function and

 whereas there now exist no organized armed resistance of misguided citizen or other to the authority of the united states in the states of georgia south carolina virginia north carolina tennessee alabama louisiana arkansas mississippi and florida and the law can be sustain and enforce therein by the proper civil authority state or federal and the people of say states be well and loyally dispose and have conform or will conform in their legislation to the condition of affair grow out of the amendment to the constitution of the united states prohibit slavery within the limit and jurisdiction of the united states and

 whereas in view of the before recite premise it be the manifest determination of the american people that no state of its own will have the right or the power to go out of or separate itself from or be separate from the american union and that therefore each state ought to remain and constitute an integral part of the united states and

 whereas the people of the several before mention states have in the manner aforesaid give satisfactory evidence that they acquiesce in this sovereign and important resolution of national unity and

 whereas it be believe to be a fundamental principle of government that people who have revolt and who have be overcome and subdue must either be deal with so as to induce they voluntarily to become friend or else they must be hold by absolute military power or devastate so as to prevent they from ever again do harm as enemy which last name policy be abhorrent to humanity and to freedom and

 whereas the constitution of the united states provide for constituent community only as states and not as territories dependency province or protectorate and

 whereas such constituent states must necessarily be and by the constitution and law of the united states be make equal and place upon a like footing as to political right immunity dignity and power with the several states with which they be unite and

 whereas the observance of political equality as a principle of right and justice be well calculate to encourage the people of the aforesaid states to be and become more and more constant and persevere in their renew allegiance and

 whereas stand army military occupation martial law military tribunal and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus be in time of peace dangerous to public liberty incompatible with the individual right of the citizen contrary to the genius and spirit of our free institution and exhaustive of the national resource and ought not therefore to be sanction or allow except in case of actual necessity for repel invasion or suppress insurrection or rebellion and

 whereas the policy of the government of the united states from the beginning of the insurrection to its overthrow and final suppression have be in conformity with the principle herein set forth and enumerate

 now therefore i andrew johnson president of the united states do hereby proclaim and declare that the insurrection which heretofore exist in the states of georgia south carolina virginia north carolina tennessee alabama louisiana arkansas mississippi and florida be at an end and be henceforth to be so regard

 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix

 do at the city of washington this 2d day of april a. d. 1866 and of the independence of the united states of america the ninetieth

 andrew johnson
 by the president
 william h. seward
 secretary of state

to the house of representatives

 the follow joint resolution restore tennessee to her relation in the union be last evening present for my approval

 whereas in the year 1861 the government of the state of tennessee be seize upon and take possession of by person in hostility to the united states and the inhabitant of say state in pursuance of an act of congress be declare to be in a state of insurrection against the united states and

 whereas say state government can only be restore to its former political relation in the union by the consent of the lawmaking power of the united states and

 whereas the people of say state do on the 22d day of february 1865 by a large popular vote adopt and ratify a constitution of government whereby slavery be abolish and all ordinance and law of secession and debt contract under the same be declare void and

 whereas a state government have be organize under say constitution which have ratify the amendment to the constitution of the united states abolish slavery also the amendment propose by the thirty ninth congress and have do other act proclaim and denote loyalty therefore

 be it resolve by the senate and house of representatives of the united states in congress assemble that the state of tennessee be hereby restore to her former proper practical relation to the union and be again entitle to be represent by senator and representatives in congress

 the preamble simply consist of statement some of which be assume while the resolution be merely a declaration of opinion it comprise no legislation nor do it confer any power which be bind upon the respective houses the executive or the states it do not admit to their seat in congress the senators and representatives from the state of tennessee for notwithstanding the passage of the resolution each house in the exercise of the constitutional right to judge for itself of the election return and qualification of its member may at its discretion admit they or continue to exclude they if a joint resolution of this kind be necessary and binding as a condition precedent to the admission of member of congress it would happen in the event of a veto by the executive that senators and representatives could only be admit to the hall of legislation by a two third vote of each of the houses

 among other reason recite in the preamble for the declaration contain in the resolution be the ratification by the state government of tennessee of the amendment to the constitution of the united states abolish slavery also the amendment propose by the thirty ninth congress if as be also declare in the preamble say state government can only be restore to its former political relation in the union by the consent of the lawmaking power of the united states it would really seem to follow that the joint resolution which at this late day have receive the sanction of congress should have be pass approve and place on the statute book before any amendment to the constitution be submit to the legislature of tennessee for ratification otherwise the inference be plainly deducible that while in the opinion of congress the people of a state may be too strongly disloyal to be entitle to representation they may nevertheless during the suspension of their former proper practical relation to the union have an equally potent voice with other and loyal states in proposition to amend the constitution upon which so essentially depend the stability prosperity and very existence of the nation

 a brief reference to my annual message of the 4th of december last will show the step take by the executive for the restoration to their constitutional relation to the union of the states that have be affect by the rebellion upon the cessation of active hostility provisional governor be appoint convention call governor elect by the people legislature assemble and senators and representatives choose to the congress of the united states

 at the same time the court of the united states be reopen the blockade remove the custom house reestablish and postal operation resume the amendment to the constitution abolishing slavery forever within the limit of the country be also submit to the states and they be thus invite to and do participate in its ratification thus exercise the high function pertain to a state in addition nearly all of these states through their convention and legislature have adopt and ratify constitution of government whereby slavery be abolish and all ordinance and law of secession and debt contract under the same be declare void so far then the political existence of the states and their relation to the federal government have be fully and completely recognize and acknowledge by the executive department of the government and the completion of the work of restoration which have progress so favorably be submit to congress upon which devolve all question pertain to the admission to their seat of the senators and representatives choose from the states whose people have engage in the rebellion

 all these step have be take when on the 4th day of december 1865 the thirty ninth congress assemble nearly eight month have elapse since that time and no other plan of restoration having be propose by congress for the measure institute by the executive it be now declare in the joint resolution submit for my approval that the state of tennessee be hereby restore to her former proper practical relation to the union and be again entitle to be represent by senator and representatives in congress thus after the lapse of nearly eight month congress propose to pave the way to the admission to representation of one of the eleven states whose people array themselves in rebellion against the constitutional authority of the federal government

 earnestly desire to remove every cause of further delay whether real or imaginary on the part of congress to the admission to seat of loyal senators and representatives from the state of tennessee i have notwithstanding the anomalous character of this proceeding affix my signature to the resolution my approval however be not to be construe as an acknowledgment of the right of congress to pass law preliminary to the admission of duly qualified representatives from any of the states neither be it to be consider as commit i to all the statement make in the preamble some of which be in my opinion without foundation in fact especially the assertion that the state of tennessee have ratify the amendment to the constitution of the united states propose by the thirty ninth congress no official notice of such ratification have be receive by the executive or file in the department of state on the contrary unofficial information from the most reliable source induce the belief that the amendment have not yet be constitutionally sanction by the legislature of tennessee the right of each house under the constitution to judge of the election return and qualification of its own member be undoubted and my approval or disapproval of the resolution could not in the slight degree increase or diminish the authority in this respect confer upon the two branch of congress

 in conclusion i can not too earnestly repeat my recommendation for the admission of tennessee and all other states to a fair and equal participation in national legislation when they present themselves in the person of loyal senators and representatives who can comply with all the requirement of the constitution and the law by this mean harmony and reconciliation will be effect the practical relation of all the states to the federal government reestablish and the work of restoration inaugurate upon the termination of the war successfully complete

by the president of the united states of america

 a proclamation

 whereas by proclamation of the 15th and 19th of april 1861 the president of the united states in virtue of the power vest in he by the constitution and the law declare that the law of the united states be oppose and the execution thereof obstruct in the states of south carolina georgia alabama florida mississippi louisiana and texas by combination too powerful to be suppress by the ordinary course of judicial proceeding or by the power vest in the marshal by law and

 whereas by another proclamation make on the 16th day of august in the same year in pursuance of an act of congress approve july 13 1861 the inhabitant of the states of georgia south carolina virginia north carolina tennessee alabama louisiana texas arkansas mississippi and florida except the inhabitant of that part of the state of virginia lie west of the alleghany mountains and except also the inhabitant of such other part of that state and the other states before name as might maintain a loyal adhesion to the union and the constitution or might be from time to time occupy and control by force of the united states engage in the dispersion of insurgent be declare to be in a state of insurrection against the united states and
 whereas by another proclamation of the 1st day of july 1862 issue in pursuance of an act of congress approve june 7 in the same year the insurrection be declare to be still exist in the states aforesaid with the exception of certain specify county in the state of virginia and

 whereas by another proclamation make on the 2d day of april 1863 in pursuance of the act of congress of july 13 1861 the exception name in the proclamation of august 16 1861 be revoke and the inhabitant of the states of georgia south carolina north carolina tennessee alabama louisiana texas arkansas mississippi florida and virginia except the forty eight county of virginia designate as west virginia and the port of new orleans key west port royal and beaufort in north carolina be declare to be still in a state of insurrection against the united states and

 whereas by another proclamation of the 15th day of september 1863 make in pursuance of the act of congress approve march 3 1863 the rebellion be declare to be still exist and the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus be in certain specify case suspend throughout the united states say suspension to continue throughout the duration of the rebellion or until say proclamation should by a subsequent one to be issue by the president of the united states be modify or revoke and

 whereas the house of representatives on the 22d day of july 1861 adopt a resolution in the word follow namely

 resolve by the house of representatives of the congress of the united states that the present deplorable civil war have be force upon the country by the di unionist of the southern states now in revolt against the constitutional government and in arm around the capital that in this national emergency congress banish all feeling of mere passion or resentment will recollect only its duty to the whole country that this war be not wage upon our part in any spirit of oppression nor for any purpose of conquest or subjugation nor purpose of overthrow or interfere with the right or establish institution of those states but to defend and maintain the supremacy of the constitution and to preserve the union with all the dignity equality and right of the several states unimpaire and that as soon as these object be accomplish the war ought to cease

 and whereas the senate of the united states on the 25th day of july 1861 adopt a resolution in the word follow to wit

 resolved that the present deplorable civil war have be force upon the country by the disunionist of the southern states now in revolt against the constitutional government and in arm around the capital that in this national emergency congress banish all feeling of mere passion or resentment will recollect only its duty to the whole country that this war be not prosecute upon our part in any spirit of oppression nor for any purpose of conquest or subjugation nor purpose of overthrow or interfere with the right or establish institution of those states but to defend and maintain the supremacy of the constitution and all law make in pursuance thereof and to preserve the union with all the dignity equality and right of the several states unimpaire that as soon as these object be accomplish the war ought to cease

 and whereas these resolution though not joint or concurrent in form be substantially identical and as such have hitherto be and yet be regard as having express the sense of congress upon the subject to which they relate and

 whereas the president of the united states by proclamation of the 13th of june 1865 declare that the insurrection in the state of tennessee have be suppress and that the authority of the united states therein be undisputed and that such united states officer as have be duly commission be in the undisturbed exercise of their official function and

 whereas the president of the united states by further proclamation issue on the 2d day of april 1866 do promulgate and declare that there no long exist any armed resistance of misguided citizen or other to the authority of the united states in any or in all the states before mention except only the state of texas and do far promulgate and declare that the law could be sustain and enforce in the several states before mention except texas by the proper civil authority state or federal and that the people of the say states except texas be well and loyally dispose and have conform or will conform in their legislation to the condition of affair grow out of the amendment to the constitution of the united states prohibit slavery within the limit and jurisdiction of the united states

 and do far declare in the same proclamation that it be the manifest determination of the american people that no state of its own will have a right or power to go out of or separate itself from or be separate from the american union and that therefore each state ought to remain and constitute an integral part of the united states

 and do far declare in the same last mention proclamation that the several aforementioned state except texas have in the manner aforesaid give satisfactory evidence that they acquiesce in this sovereign and important resolution of national unity and

 whereas the president of the united states in the same proclamation do far declare that it be believe to be a fundamental principle of government that the people who have revolt and who have be overcome and subdue must either be deal with so as to induce they voluntarily to become friend or else they must be hold by absolute military power or devastate so as to prevent they from ever again do harm as enemy which last name policy be abhorrent to humanity and to freedom and

 whereas the president do in the same proclamation further declare that the constitution of the united states provide for constituent community only as states and not as territories dependency province or protectorate

 and far that such constituent states must necessarily be and by the constitution and law of the united states be make equal and place upon a like footing as to political right immunity dignity and power with the several states with which they be unite

 and do far declare that the observance of political equality as a principle of right and justice be well calculate to encourage the people of the before name states except texas to be and to become more and more constant and persevere in their renew allegiance and

 whereas the president do far declare that stand army military occupation martial law military tribunal and the suspension of the writ of habeas corpus be in time of peace dangerous to public liberty incompatible with the individual right of the citizen contrary to the genius and spirit of our free institution and exhaustive of the national resource and ought not therefore to be sanction or allow except in case of actual necessity for repel invasion or suppress insurrection or rebellion

 and the president do far in the same proclamation declare that the policy of the government of the united states from the beginning of the insurrection to its overthrow and final suppression have be conduct in conformity with the principle in the last name proclamation recite and

 whereas the president in the say proclamation of the 13th of june 1865 upon the ground therein state and hereinbefore recite do then and thereby proclaim and declare that the insurrection which heretofore exist in the several states before name except in texas be at an end and be henceforth to be so regard and

 whereas subsequently to the said 2d day of april 1866 the insurrection in the state of texas have be completely and everywhere suppress and end and the authority of the united states have be successfully and completely establish in the said state of texas and now remain therein unresisted and undisputed and such of the proper united states officer as have be duly commission within the limit of the say state be now in the undisturbed exercise of their official function and

 whereas the law can now be sustain and enforce in the said state of texas by the proper civil authority state or federal and the people of the said state of texas like the people of the other states before name be well and loyally dispose and have conform or will conform in their legislation to the condition of affair grow out of the amendment of the constitution of the united states prohibit slavery within the limit and jurisdiction of the united states and

 whereas all the reason and conclusion set forth in regard to the several states therein specially name now apply equally and in all respect to the state of texas as well as to the other states which have be involve in insurrection and

 whereas adequate provision have be make by military order to enforce the execution of the act of congress aid the civil authority and secure obedience to the constitution and law of the united states within the state of texas if a resort to military force for such purpose should at any time become necessary

 now therefore i andrew johnson president of the united states do hereby proclaim and declare that the insurrection which heretofore exist in the state of texas be at an end and be to be henceforth so regard in that state as in the other states before name in which the say insurrection be proclaim to be at an end by the aforesaid proclamation of the 2d day of april 1866

 and i do far proclaim that the say insurrection be at an end and that peace order tranquillity and civil authority now exist in and throughout the whole of the united states of america

 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix

 do at the city of washington this 20th day of august a.d. 1866 and of the independence of the united states of america the ninety first

 andrew johnson
 by the president
 william h. seward
 secretary of state

fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives
 after a brief interval the congress of the united states resume its annual legislative labor an all wise and merciful providence have abate the pestilence which visit our shore leave its calamitous trace upon some portion of our country peace order tranquillity and civil authority have be formally declare to exist throughout the whole of the united states in all of the states civil authority have supersede the coercion of arm and the people by their voluntary action be maintain their government in full activity and complete operation the enforcement of the law be no long obstruct in any state by combination too powerful to be suppress by the ordinary course of judicial proceeding and the animosity engender by the war be rapidly yield to the beneficent influence of our free institution and to the kindly effect of unrestricted social and commercial intercourse an entire restoration of fraternal feeling must be the earnest wish of every patriotic heart and we will have accomplish our grand national achievement when forget the sad event of the past and remember only their instructive lesson we resume our onward career as a free prosperous and united people
 in my message of the 4th of december 1865 congress be inform of the measure which have be institute by the executive with a view to the gradual restoration of the states in which the insurrection occur to their relation with the general government provisional governor have be appoint convention call governor elect legislature assemble and senators and representatives choose to the congress of the united states court have be open for the enforcement of law long in abeyance the blockade have be remove custom house reestablish and the internal revenue law put in force in order that the people might contribute to the national income postal operation have be renew and effort be be make to restore they to their former condition of efficiency the states themselves have be ask to take dart in the high function of amend the constitution and of thus sanction the extinction of african slavery as one of the legitimate result of our internecine struggle
 having progress thus far the executive department find that it have accomplish nearly all that be within the scope of its constitutional authority one thing however yet remain to be do before the work of restoration could be complete and that be the admission to congress of loyal senators and representatives from the states whose people have rebel against the lawful authority of the general government this question devolve upon the respective houses which by the constitution be make the judge of the election return and qualification of their own member and its consideration at once engage the attention of congress
 in the meantime the executive department no other plan having be propose by congress continue its effort to perfect as far as be practicable the restoration of the proper relation between the citizen of the respective states the states and the federal government extend from time to time as the public interest seem to require the judicial revenue and postal system of the country with the advice and consent of the senate the necessary officer be appoint and appropriation make by congress for the payment of their salary the proposition to amend the federal constitution so as to prevent the existence of slavery within the united states or any place subject to their jurisdiction be ratify by the requisite number of states and on the 18th day of december 1865 it be officially declare to have become valid as a part of the constitution of the united states all of the states in which the insurrection have exist promptly amend their constitution so as to make they conform to the great change thus effect in the organic law of the land declare null and void all ordinance and law of secession repudiate all pretend debt and obligation create for the revolutionary purpose of the insurrection and proceed in good faith to the enactment of measure for the protection and amelioration of the condition of the colored race congress however yet hesitate to admit any of these states to representation and it be not until toward the close of the eighth month of the session that an exception be make in favor of tennessee by the admission of her senators and representatives
 i deem it a subject of profound regret that congress have thus far fail to admit to seat loyal senators and representatives from the other states whose inhabitant with those of tennessee have engage in the rebellion ten state more than one fourth of the whole number remain without representation the seat of fifty member in the house of representatives and of twenty member in the senate be yet vacant not by their own consent not by a failure of election but by the refusal of congress to accept their credential their admission it be believe would have accomplish much toward the renewal and strengthening of our relation as one people and remove serious cause for discontent on the part of the inhabitant of those states it would have accord with the great principle enunciate in the declaration of american independence that no people ought to bear the burden of taxation and yet be deny the right of representation it would have be in consonance with the express provision of the constitution that each state shall have at least one representative and that no state without its consent shall be deprive of its equal suffrage in the senate these provision be intend to secure to every state and to the people of every state the right of representation in each house of congress and so important be it deem by the framer of the constitution that the equality of the states in the senate should be preserve that not even by an amendment of the constitution can any state without its consent be deny a voice in that branch of the national legislature
 it be true it have be assume that the existence of the states be terminate by the rebellious act of their inhabitant and that the insurrection having be suppress they be thenceforward to be consider merely as conquer territory the legislative executive and judicial department of the government have however with heat distinctness and uniform consistency refuse to sanction an assumption so incompatible with the nature of our republican system and with the profess object of the war throughout the recent legislation of congress the undeniable fact make itself apparent that these ten political community be nothing less than state of this union at the very commencement of the rebellion each house declare with a unanimity as remarkable as it be significant that the war be not wage upon our part in any spirit of oppression nor for any purpose of conquest or subjugation nor purpose of overthrow or interfere with the right or establish institution of those states but to defend and maintain the supremacy of the constitution and all law make in pursuance thereof and to preserve the union with all the dignity equality and right of the several states unimpaire and that as soon as these object be accomplish the war ought to cease in some instance senators be permit to continue their legislative function while in other instance representatives be elect and admit to seat after their states have formally declare their right to withdraw from the union and be endeavor to maintain that right by force of arm all of the states whose people be in insurrection as states be include in the apportionment of the direct tax of $ 20,000,000 annually lay upon the united states by the act approve 5th august 1861 congress by the act of march 4 1862 and by the apportionment of representation thereunder also recognize their presence as states in the union and they have for judicial purpose be divide into district as states alone can be divide the same recognition appear in the recent legislation in reference to tennessee which evidently rest upon the fact that the function of the state be not destroy by the rebellion but merely suspend and that principle be of course applicable to those states which like tennessee attempt to renounce their place in the union
 the action of the executive department of the government upon this subject have be equally definite and uniform and the purpose of the war be specifically state in the proclamation issue by my predecessor on the 22d day of september 1862 it be then solemnly proclaim and declare that hereafter as heretofore the war will be prosecute for the object of practically restore the constitutional relation between the united states and each of the states and the people thereof in which state that relation be or may be suspend or disturb
 the recognition of the states by the judicial department of the government have also be dear and conclusive in all proceeding affect they as states have in the supreme circuit and district court in the admission of senators and representatives from any and all of the states there can be no just ground of apprehension that person who be disloyal will be clothe with the power of legislation for this could not happen when the constitution and the law be enforce by a vigilant and faithful congress each house be make the judge of the election return and qualification of its own member and may with the concurrence of two third expel a member when a senator or representative present his certificate of election he may at once be admit or reject or should there be any question as to his eligibility his credential may be refer for investigation to the appropriate committee if admit to a seat it must be upon evidence satisfactory to the house of which he thus become a member that he possess the requisite constitutional and legal qualification if refuse admission as a member for want of due allegiance to the government and return to his constituent they be admonish that none but person loyal to the united states will be allow a voice in the legislative council of the nation and the political power and moral influence of congress be thus effectively exert in the interest of loyalty to the government and fidelity to the union upon this question so vitally affect the restoration of the union and the permanency of our present form of government my conviction heretofore express have undergo no change but on the contrary their correctness have be confirm by reflection and time if the admission of loyal member to seat in the respective houses of congress be wise and expedient a year ago it be no less wise and expedient now if this anomalous condition be right now if in the exact condition of these states at the present time it be lawful to exclude they from representation i do not see that the question will be change by the efflux of time ten year hence if these state remain as they be the right of representation will be no strong the right of exclusion will be no weak
 the constitution of the united states make it the duty of the president to recommend to the consideration of congress such measure as he shall judge necessary and expedient i know of no measure more imperatively demand by every consideration of national interest sound policy and equal justice than the admission of loyal member from the now unrepresented states this would consummate the work of restoration and exert a most salutary influence in the reestablishment of peace harmony and fraternal feeling it would tend greatly to renew the confidence of the american people in the vigor and stability of their institution it would bind we more closely together as a nation and enable we to show to the world the inherent and recuperative power of a government found upon the will of the people and establish upon the principle of liberty justice and intelligence our increased strength and enhanced prosperity would irrefragably demonstrate the fallacy of the argument against free institution draw from our recent national disorder by the enemy of republican government the admission of loyal member from the states now exclude from congress by allay doubt and apprehension would turn capital now await an opportunity for investment into the channel of trade and industry it would alleviate the present troubled condition of those states and by induce emigration aid in the settlement of fertile region now uncultivated and lead to an increase production of those staple which have add so greatly to the wealth of the nation and commerce of the world new field of enterprise would be open to our progressive people and soon the devastation of war would be repair and all trace of our domestic difference efface from the mind of our countryman
 in our effort to preserve the unity of government which constitute as one people by restore the states to the condition which they hold prior to the rebellion we should be cautious lest having rescue our nation from peril of threatened disintegration we resort to consolidation and in the end absolute despotism as a remedy for the recurrence of similar trouble the war having terminate and with it all occasion for the exercise of power of doubtful constitutionality we should hasten to bring legislation within the boundary prescribe by the constitution and to return to the ancient landmark establish by our father for the guidance of succeed generation
 the constitution which at any time exist till change by an explicit and authentic act of the whole people be sacredly obligatory upon all if in the opinion of the people the distribution or modification of the constitutional power be in any particular wrong let it be correct by an amendment in the way which the constitution designate but let there be no change by usurpation for it be the customary weapon by which free government be destroy
 washington speak these word to his countryman when follow by their love and gratitude he voluntarily retire from the care of public life to keep in all thing within the pale of our constitutional power and cherish the federal union as the only rock of safety be prescribe by jefferson as rule of action to endear to his countryman the true principle of their constitution and promote a union of sentiment and action equally auspicious to their happiness and safety jackson hold that the action of the general government should always be strictly confine to the sphere of its appropriate duty and justly and forcibly urge that our government be not to be maintain nor our union preserve by invasion of the right and power of the several states in thus attempt to make our general government strong we make it weak its true strength consist in leave individual and states as much as possible to themselves in make itself feel not in its power but in its beneficence not in its control but in its protection not in bind the states more closely to the center but leave each to move unobstructed in its proper constitutional orbit these be the teaching of man whose deed and service have make they illustrious and who long since withdraw from the scene of life have leave to their country the rich legacy of their example their wisdom and their patriotism draw fresh inspiration from their lesson let we emulate they in love of country and respect for the constitution and the law
 the report of the secretary of the treasury afford much information respect the revenue and commerce of the country his view upon the currency and with reference to a proper adjustment of our revenue system internal as well as impost be commend to the careful consideration of congress in my last annual message i express my general view upon these subject i need now only call attention to the necessity of carry into every department of the government a system of rigid accountability thorough retrenchment and wise economy with no exceptional nor unusual expenditure the oppressive burden of taxation can be lessen by such a modification of our revenue law as will be consistent with the public faith and the legitimate and necessary want of the government
 the report present a much more satisfactory condition of our finance than one year ago the most sanguine could have anticipate during the fiscal year end the 30th june 1865 the last year of the war the public debt be increase $ 941,902,537 and on the 31st of october 1865 it amount to $ 2,740,854,750 on the 31st day of october 1866 it have be reduce to $ 2,552,310,006 the diminution during a period of fourteen month commence september 1 1865 and end october 31 1866 having be $ 206,379,565 in the last annual report on the state of the finance it be estimate that during the three quarter of the fiscal year end the 30th of june last the debt would be increase $ 112,194,947 during that period however it be reduce $ 31,196,387 the receipt of the year having be $ 89,905,905 more and the expenditure $ 200,529,235 less than the estimate nothing could more clearly indicate than these statement the extent and availability of the national resource and the rapidity and safety with which under our form of government great military and naval establishment can be disband and expense reduce from a war to a peace footing
 during the fiscal year end june 30 1866 the receipt be $ 558,032,620 and the expenditure $ 520,750,940 leave an available surplus of $ 37,281,680 it be estimate that the receipt for the fiscal year end the 30th june 1867 will be $ 475,061.386 and that the expenditure will reach the sum of $ 316,428,078 leave in the treasury a surplus of $ 158,633,308 for the fiscal year end june 30 1886 it be estimate that the receipt will amount to $ 436,000,000 and that the expenditure will be $ 350,247,641 show an excess of $ 85,752,359 in favor of the government these estimate receipt may be diminish by a reduction of excise and import duty but after all necessary reduction shall have be make the revenue of the present and of follow year will doubtless be sufficient to cover all legitimate charge upon the treasury and leave a large annual surplus to be apply to the payment of the principal of the debt there seem now to be no good reason why taxis may not be reduce as the country advance in population and wealth and yet the debt be extinguish within the next quarter of a century
 the report of the secretary of war furnish valuable and important information in reference to the operation of his department during the past year few volunteer now remain in the service and they be be discharge as rapidly as they can be replace by regular troop the army have be promptly pay carefully provide with medical treatment well shelter and subsist and be to be furnish with breech load small arm the military strength of the nation have be unimpaire by the discharge of volunteer the disposition of unserviceable or perishable store and the retrenchment of expenditure sufficient war material to meet any emergency have be retain and from the disband volunteer stand ready to respond to the national call large army can be rapidly organize equip and concentrate fortification on the coast and frontier have receive or be be prepare for more powerful armament lake survey and harbor and river improvement be in course of energetic prosecution preparation have be make for the payment of the additional bounty authorize during the recent session of congress under such regulation as will protect the government from fraud and secure to the honorably discharge soldier the well earn reward of his faithfulness and gallantry more than 6,000 maim soldier have receive artificial limb or other surgical apparatus and 41 national cemetery contain the remain of 104,526 union soldier have already be establish the total estimate of military appropriation be $ 25,205,669
 it be state in the report of the secretary of the navy that the naval force at this time consist of 278 vessel arm with 2,351 gun of these 115 vessel carry 1,029 gun be in commission distribute chiefly among seven squadron the number of man in the service be 13,600 great activity and vigilance have be display by all the squadron and their movement have be judiciously and efficiently arrange in such manner as would well promote american commerce and protect the right and interest of our countryman abroad the vessel unemployed be undergo repair or be lay up until their service may be require most of the ironclad fleet be at league island in the vicinity of philadelphia a place which until decisive action should be take by congress be select by the secretary of the navy as the most eligible location for that class of vessel it be important that a suitable public station should be provide for the ironclad fleet it be intend that these vessel shall be in proper condition for any emergency and it be desirable that the bill accept league island for naval purpose which pass the house of representatives at its last session should receive final action at an early period in order that there may be a suitable public station for this class of vessel as well as a navy yard of area sufficient for the want of the service on the delaware river the naval pension fund amount to $ 11,750,000 having be increase $ 2,750,000 during the year the expenditure of the department for the fiscal year end 30th june last be $ 43,324,526 and the estimate for the coming year amount to $ 23,568,436 attention be invite to the condition of our seaman and the importance of legislative measure for their relief and improvement the suggestion in behalf of this deserve class of our fellow citizen be earnestly recommend to the favorable attention of congress

 the report of the secretary of the interior exhibit the condition of those branch of the public service which be commit to his supervision during the last fiscal year 4,629,312 acre of public land be dispose of 1,892,516 acre of which be enter under the homestead act the policy originally adopt relative to the public land have undergo essential modification immediate revenue and not their rapid settlement be the cardinal feature of our land system long experience and earnest discussion have result in the conviction that the early development of our agricultural resource and the diffusion of an energetic population over our vast territory be object of far great importance to the national growth and prosperity than the proceed of the sale of the land to the high bidder in open market the preemption law confer upon the pioneer who comply with the term they impose the privilege of purchase a limited portion of unoffered land at the minimum price the homestead enactment relieve the settler from the payment of purchase money and secure he a permanent home upon the condition of residence for a term of year this liberal policy invite emigration from the old and from the more crowded portion of the new world its propitious result be undoubted and will be more signally manifest when time shall have give to it a wide development
 congress have make liberal grant of public land to corporation in aid of the construction of railroad and other internal improvement should this policy hereafter prevail more stringent provision will be require to secure a faithful application of the fund the title to the land should not pass by patent or otherwise but remain in the government and subject to its control until some portion of the road have be actually build portion of they might then from time to time be convey to the corporation but never in a great ratio to the whole quantity embrace by the grant than the complete part bear to the entire length of the project improvement this restriction would not operate to the prejudice of any undertaking conceive in good faith and execute with reasonable energy as it be the settle practice to withdraw from market the land fall within the operation of such grant and thus to exclude the inception of a subsequent adverse right a breach of the condition which congress may deem proper to impose should work a forfeiture of claim to the land so withdraw but unconveye and of title to the land convey which remain unsold
 operation on the several line of the pacific railroad have be prosecute with unexampled vigor and success should no unforeseen cause of delay occur it be confidently anticipate that this great thoroughfare will be complete before the expiration of the period designate by congress
 during the last fiscal year the amount pay to pensioner include the expense of disbursement be $ 13,459,996 and 50,177 name be add to the pension roll the entire number of pensioner june 30 1866 be 126,722 this fact furnish melancholy and striking proof of the sacrifice make to vindicate the constitutional authority of the federal government and to maintain inviolate the integrity of the union they impose upon we correspond obligation it be estimate that $ 33,000,000 will be require to meet the exigency of this branch of the service during the next fiscal year

 as a subject upon which depend an immense amount of the production and commerce of the country i recommend to congress such legislation as may be necessary for the preservation of the levee of the mississippi river it be a matter of national importance that early step should be take not only to add to the efficiency of these barrier against destructive inundation but for the removal of all obstruction to the free and safe navigation of that great channel of trade and commerce
 the district of columbia under exist law be not entitle to that representation in the national council which from our early history have be uniformly accord to each territory establish from time to time within our limit it maintain peculiar relation to congress to whom the constitution have grant the power of exercise exclusive legislation over the seat of government our fellow citizen reside in the district whose interest be thus confide to the special guardianship of congress exceed in number the population of several of our territories and no just reason be perceive why a delegate of their choice should not be admit to a seat in the house of representatives no mode seem so appropriate and effectual of enable they to make known their peculiar condition and want and of secure the local legislation adapt to they i therefore recommend the passage of a law authorize the elector of the district of columbia to choose a delegate to be allow the same right and privilege as a delegate represent a territory the increase enterprise and rapid progress of improvement in the district be highly gratifying and i trust that the effort of the municipal authority to promote the prosperity of the national metropolis will receive the efficient and generous cooperation of congress

 in the month of april last as congress be aware a friendly arrangement be make between the emperor of france and the president of the united states for the withdrawal from mexico of the french expeditionary military force this withdrawal be to be effect in three detachment the first of which it be understand would leave mexico in november now past the second in march next and the third and last in november 1867 immediately upon the completion of the evacuation the french government be to assume the same attitude of nonintervention in regard to mexico as be hold by the government of the united states repeat assurance have be give by the emperor since that agreement that he would complete the promise evacuation within the period mention or soon
 it be reasonably expect that the proceeding thus contemplate would produce a crisis of great political interest in the republic of mexico the newly appoint minister of the united states mr. campbell be therefore send forward on the 9th day of november last to assume his proper function as minister plenipotentiary of the united states to that republic it be also think expedient that he should be attend in the vicinity of mexico by the lieutenant general of the army of the united states with the view of obtain such information as might be important to determine the course to be pursue by the united states in reestablish and maintain necessary and proper intercourse with the republic of mexico deeply interested in the cause of liberty and humanity it seem an obvious duty on our part to exercise whatever influence we possess for the restoration and permanent establishment in that country of a domestic and republican form of government
 such be the condition of our affair in regard to mexico when on the 22d of november last official information be receive from paris that the emperor of france have some time before decide not to withdraw a detachment of his force in the month of november past accord to engagement but that this decision be make with the purpose of withdraw the whole of those force in the ensue spring of this determination however the united states have not receive any notice or intimation and so soon as the information be receive by the government care be take to make known its dissent to the emperor of france
 i can not forego the hope that france will reconsider the subject and adopt some resolution in regard to the evacuation of mexico which will conform as nearly as practicable with the exist engagement and thus meet the just expectation of the united states the paper relate to the subject will be lay before you it be believe that with the evacuation of mexico by the expeditionary force no subject for serious difference between france and the united states would remain the expression of the emperor and people of france warrant a hope that the traditionary friendship between the two country might in that case be renew and permanently restore
 a claim of a citizen of the united states for indemnity for spoliation commit on the high sea by the french authority in the exercise of a belligerent power against mexico have be meet by the government of france with a proposition to defer settlement until a mutual convention for the adjustment of all claim of citizen and subject of both country arise out of the recent war on this continent shall be agree upon by the two country the suggestion be not deem unreasonable but it belong to congress to direct the manner in which claim for indemnity by foreigner as well as by citizen of the united states arise out of the late civil war shall be adjudicate and determine i have no doubt that the subject of all such claim will engage your attention at a convenient and proper time
 it be a matter of regret that no considerable advance have be make toward an adjustment of the difference between the united states and great britain arise out of the depredation upon our national commerce and other trespass commit during our civil war by british subject in violation of international law and treaty obligation the delay however may be believe to have result in no small degree from the domestic situation of great britain an entire change of ministry occur in that country during the last session of parliament the attention of the new ministry be call to the subject at an early day and there be some reason to expect that it will now be consider in a become and friendly spirit the importance of an early disposition of the question can not be exaggerated whatever might be the wish of the two government it be manifest that good will and friendship between the two country can not be establish until a reciprocity in the practice of good faith and neutrality shall be restore between the respective nation
 on the 6th of june last in violation of our neutrality law a military expedition and enterprise against the british north american colony be project and attempt to be carry on within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states in obedience to the obligation impose upon the executive by the constitution to see that the law be faithfully execute all citizen be warn by proclamation against take part in or aid such unlawful proceeding and the proper civil military and naval officer be direct to take all necessary measure for the enforcement of the law the expedition fail but it have not be without its painful consequence some of our citizen who it be allege be engage in the expedition be capture and have be bring to trial as for a capital offense in the province of canada judgment and sentence of death have be pronounce against some while other have be acquit fully believe in the maxim of government that severity of civil punishment for misguided person who have engage in revolutionary attempt which have disastrously fail be unsound and unwise such representation have be make to the british government in behalf of the convict person as be sustain by an enlightened and humane judgment will it be hope induce in their case an exercise of clemency and a judicious amnesty to all who be engage in the movement counsel have be employ by the government to defend citizen of the united states on trial for capital offense in canada and a discontinuance of the prosecution which be institute in the court of the united states against those who take part in the expedition have be direct
 i have regard the expedition as not only political in its nature but as also in a great measure foreign from the united states in its cause character and object the attempt be understand to be make in sympathy with an insurgent party in ireland and by strike at a british province on this continent be design to aid in obtain redress for political grievance which it be assume the people of ireland have suffer at the hand of the british government during a period of several century the person engage in it be chiefly native of that country some of whom have while other have not become citizen of the united states under our general law of naturalization complaint of misgovernment in ireland continually engage the attention of the british nation and so great an agitation be now prevail in ireland that the british government have deem it necessary to suspend the writ of habeas corpus in that country these circumstance must necessarily modify the opinion which we might otherwise have entertain in regard to an expedition expressly prohibit by our neutrality law so long as those law remain upon our statute book they should be faithfully execute and if they operate harshly unjustly or oppressively congress alone can apply the remedy by their modification or repeal
 political and commercial interest of the united states be not unlikely to be affect in some degree by event which be transpire in the eastern region of europe and the time seem to have come when our government ought to have a proper diplomatic representation in greece
 this government have claim for all person not convict or accuse or suspect of crime an absolute political right of self expatriation and a choice of new national allegiance most of the european states have dissent from this principle and have claim a right to hold such of their subject as have emigrate to and be naturalize in the united states and afterwards return on transient visit to their native country to the performance of military service in like manner as resident subject complaint arise from the claim in this respect make by foreign state have heretofore be matter of controversy between the united states and some of the european power and the irritation consequent upon the failure to settle this question increase during the war in which prussia italy and austria be recently engage while great britain have never acknowledge the right of expatriation she have not for some year past practically insist upon the opposite doctrine france have be equally forbear and prussia have propose a compromise which although evince increase liberality have not be accept by the united states peace be now prevail everywhere in europe and the present seem to be a favorable time for an assertion by congress of the principle so long maintain by the executive department that naturalization by one state fully exempt the native bear subject of any other state from the performance of military service under any foreign government so long as he do not voluntarily renounce its right and benefit
 in the performance of a duty impose upon i by the constitution i have thus submit to the representative of the states and of the people such information of our domestic and foreign affair as the public interest seem to require our government be now undergo its most try ordeal and my earnest prayer be that the peril may be successfully and finally pass without impair its original strength and symmetry the interest of the nation be good to be promote by the revival of fraternal relation the complete obliteration of our past difference and the reinauguration of all the pursuit of peace direct our effort to the early accomplishment of these great end let we endeavor to preserve harmony between the coordinate department of the government that each in its proper sphere may cordially cooperate with the other in secure the maintenance of the constitution the preservation of the union and the perpetuity of our free institution

to the senate of the united states
 i return to the senate in which house it originate a bill entitle an act to admit the state of colorado into the union to which i can not consistently with my sense of duty give my approval with the exception of an additional section contain new provision it be substantially the same as the bill of a similar title pass by congress during the last session submit to the president for his approval return with the objection contain in a message beating date the 15th of may last and yet await the reconsideration of the senate
 a second bill have in view the same purpose have now pass both houses of congress and be present for my signature having again carefully consider the subject i have be unable to perceive any reason for change the opinion which have already be communicate to congress i find on the contrary that there be many objection to the propose legislation of which i be not at that time aware and that while several of those which i then assign have in the interval gain in strength yet other have be create by the altered character of the measure now submit
 the constitution under which the state government be propose to be form very properly contain a provision that all law in force at the time of its adoption and the admission of the state into the union shall continue as if the constitution have not be adopt among those law be one absolutely prohibit negro and mulatto from vote at the recent session of the territorial legislature a bill for the repeal of this law introduce into the council be almost unanimously reject and at the very time when congress be engage in enact the bill now under consideration the legislature pass an act exclude negro and mulatto from the right to sit as juror this bill be veto by the governor of the territory who hold that by the law of the united states negro and mulatto be citizen and subject to the duty as well as entitle to the right of citizenship the bill however be pass the objection of the governor to the contrary notwithstanding and be now a law of the territory yet in the bill now before i by which it be propose to admit the territory as a state it be provide that there shall be no denial of the elective franchise or any other right to any person by reason of race or color except indians not tax
 the incongruity thus exhibit between the legislation of congress and that of the territory take in connection with the protest against the admission of the state hereinafter refer to would seem clearly to indicate the impolicy and injustice of the propose enactment
 it might indeed be a subject of grave inquiry and doubtless will result in such inquiry if this bill become a law whether it do not attempt to exercise a power not confer upon congress by the federal constitution that instrument simply declare that congress may admit new states into the union it nowhere say that congress may make new states for the purpose of admit they into the union or for any other purpose and yet this bill be as clear an attempt to make the institution as any in which the people themselves could engage
 in view of this action of congress the house of representative of the territory have earnestly protest against be force into the union without first have the question submit to the people nothing would be more reasonable than the position which they thus assume and it certainly can not be the purpose of congress to force upon a community against their will a government which they do not believe themselves capable of sustain
 the following be a copy of the protest allude to as officially transmit to i
 whereas it be announce in the public print that it be the intention of congress to admit colorado as a state into the union therefore
 resolve by the house of representative of the territory that represent as we do the last and only legal expression of public opinion on this question we earnestly protest against the passage of a law admit the state without first have the question submit to a vote of the people for the reason first that we have a right to a voice in the selection of the character of our government second that we have not a sufficient population to support the expense of a state government for these reason we trust that congress will not force upon we a government against our will
 upon information which i consider reliable i assume in my message of the 15th of may last that the population of colorado be not more than 30,000 and express the opinion that this number be entirely too small either to assume the responsibility or to enjoy the privilege of a state
 it appear that previous to that time the legislature with a view to ascertain the exact condition of the territory have pass a law authorize a census of the population to be take the law make it the duty of the assessor in the several county to take the census in connection with the annual assessment and in order to secure a correct enumeration of the population allow they a liberal compensation for the service by pay they for every name return and add to their previous oath of office an oath to perform this duty with fidelity
 from the accompany official report it appear that return have be receive from fifteen of the eighteen county into which the state be divide and that their population amount in the aggregate to 24,909 the three remain county be estimate to contain 3,000 make a total population of 27,909
 this census be take in the summer season when it be claim that the population be much large than at any other period as in the autumn miner in large number leave their work and return to the east with the result of their summer enterprise
 the population it will be observe be but slightly in excess of one fifth of the number require as the basis of representation for a single congressional district in any of the states the number be 127,000
