 i be unable to perceive any good reason for such great disparity in the right of representation give as it would to the people of colorado not only this vast advantage in the house of representatives but an equality in the senate where the other states be represent by million with perhaps a single exception no such inequality as this have ever before be attempt i know that it be claim that the population of the different states at the time of their admission have vary at different period but it have not vary much more than the population of each decade and the corresponding basis of representation for the different period
 the obvious intent of the constitution be that no state should be admit with a less population than the ratio for a representative at the time of application the limitation in the second section of the first article of the constitution declare that each state shall have at least one representative be manifestly design to protect the states which originally compose the union from be deprive in the event of a wane population of a voice in the popular branch of congress and be never intend as a warrant to force a new state into the union with a representative population far below that which might at the time be require of sister member of the confederacy this bill in view of the prohibition of the same section which declare that the number of representatives shall not exceed one for every 30,000 be at least a violation of the spirit if not the letter of the constitution
 it be respectfully submit that however congress under the pressure of circumstance may have admit two or three states with less than a representative population at the time there have be no instance in which an application for admission have ever be entertain when the population as officially ascertain be below 30,000
 be there any doubt of this be the true construction of the constitution it would be dispel by the early and long continue practice of the federal government for nearly sixty year after the adoption of the constitution no state be admit with a population believe at the time to be less than the current ratio for a representative and the first instance in which there appear to have be a departure from the principle be in 1845 in the case of florida obviously the result of sectional strife we would do well to regard it as a warning of evil rather than as be example for imitation and i think candid man of all party will agree that the inspiring cause of the violation of this wholesome principle of restraint be to be find in a vain attempt to balance these antagonism which refuse to be reconcile except through the bloody arbitrament of arm the plain fact of our history will attest that the great and leading states admit since 1845 viz iowa wisconsin california minnesota and kansas include texas which be admit that year have all come with an ample population for one representative and some of they with nearly or quite enough for two
 to demonstrate the correctness of my view on this question i subjoin a table contain a list of the states admit since the adoption of the federal constitution with the date of admission the ratio of representation and the representative population when admit deduce from the united states census table the calculation be make for the period of the decade correspond with the date of admission
 colorado which it be now propose to admit as a state contain as have already be state a population less than 28,000 while the present ratio of representation be 127,000
 there can be no reason that i can perceive for the admission of colorado that would not apply with equal force to nearly every other territory now organize and i submit whether if this bill become a law it will be possible to resist the logical conclusion that such territories as dakota montana and idaho must be receive as states whenever they present themselves without regard to the number of inhabitant they may respectively contain eight or ten new senators and four or five new member of the house of representatives would thus be admit to represent a population scarcely exceed that which in any other portion of the nation be entitle to but a single member of the house of representatives while the average for two senators in the union as now constitute be at least 1,000,000 people it would surely be unjust to all other section of the union to enter upon a policy with regard to the admission of new states which might result in confer such a disproportionate share of influence in the national legislature upon community which in pursuance of the wise policy of our father should for some year to come be retain under the foster care and protection of the national government if it be deem just and expedient now to depart from the settle policy of the nation during all its history and to admit all the territories to the right and privilege of states irrespective of their population or fitness for such government it be submit whether it would not be well to devise such measure as will bring the subject before the country for consideration and decision this would seem to be eminently wise because as have already be state if it be right to admit colorado now there be no reason for the exclusion of the other territories
 it be no answer to these suggestion that an enable act be pass authorize the people of colorado to take action on this subject it be well know that that act be pass in consequence of representation that the population reach accord to some statement as high as 80,000 and to none less than 50,000 and be grow with a rapidity which by the time the admission could be consummate would secure a population of over 100,000 these representation prove to have be wholly fallacious and in addition the people of the territory by a deliberate vote decide that they would not assume the responsibility of a state government by that decision they utterly exhaust all power that be confer by the enable act and there have be no step take since in relation to the admission that have have the slight sanction or warrant of law
 the proceeding upon which the present application be base be in the utter absence of all law in relation to it and there be no evidence that the vote on the question of the formation of a state government bear any relation whatever to the sentiment of the territory the protest of the house of representatives previously quote be conclusive evidence to the contrary
 but if none of these reason exist against this propose enactment the bill itself besides be inconsistent in its provision in confer power upon a person unknown to the law and who may never have a legal existence be so frame as to render its execution almost impossible it be indeed a question whether it be not in itself a nullity to say the least it be of exceedingly doubtful propriety to confer the power propose in this bill upon the governor elect for as by its own term the constitution be not to take effect until after the admission of the state he in the meantime have no more authority than any other private citizen but even suppose he to be clothe with sufficient authority to convene the legislature what constitute the state legislature to which be to be refer the submission of the condition impose by congress be it a new body to be elect and convene by proclamation of the governor elect or be it that body which meet more than a year ago under the provision of the state constitution by reference to the second section of the schedule and to the eighteenth section of the fourth article of the state constitution it will be see that the term of the member of the house of representative and that of one half of the member of the senate expire on the first monday of the present month it be clear that if there be no intrinsic objection to the bill itself in relation to purpose to be accomplish this objection would be fatal as it be apparent that the provision of the third section of the bill to admit colorado have reference to a period and a state of fact entirely different from the present and affair as they now exist and if carry into effect must necessarily lead to confusion
 even if it be settle that the old and not a new body be to act it would be find impracticable to execute the law because a considerable number of the member as i be inform have cease to be resident of the territory and in the sixty day within which the legislature be to be convene after the passage of the act there would not be sufficient time to fill the vacancy by new election be there any authority under which they could be hold
 it may not be improper to add that if these proceeding be all regular and the result to be obtain be desirable simple justice to the people of the territory would require a long period than sixty day within which to obtain action on the condition propose by the third section of the bill there be as be well know large portion of the territory with which there be and can be no general communication there be several county which from november to may can only be reach by person travel on foot while with other region of the territory occupy by a large portion of the population there be very little more freedom of access thus if this bill should become a law it would be impracticable to obtain any expression of public sentiment in reference to its provision with a view to enlighten the legislature if the old body be call together and of course equally impracticable to procure the election of a new body this defect might have be remedie by an extension of the time and a submission of the question to the people with a fair opportunity to enable they to express their sentiment
 the admission of a new state have generally be regard as an epoch in our history mark the onward progress of the nation but after the most careful and anxious inquiry on the subject i can not perceive that the propose proceeding be in conformity with the policy which from the origin of the government have uniformly prevail in the admission of new states i therefore return the bill to the senate without my signature

to the senate of the united states
 i return for reconsideration a bill entitle an act for the admission of the state of nebraska into the union which originate in the senate and have receive the assent of both houses of congress a bill have in view the same object be present for my approval a few hour prior to the adjournment of the last session but submit at a time when there be no opportunity for a proper consideration of the subject i withhold my signature and the measure fail to become a law
 it appear by the preamble of this bill that the people of nebraska avail themselves of the authority confer upon they by the act pass on the 19th day of april 1864 have adopt a constitution which upon due examination be find to conform to the provision and comply with the condition of say act and to be republican in its form of government and that they now ask for admission into the union this propose law would therefore seem to be base upon the declaration contain in the enable act that upon compliance with its term the people of nebraska should be admit into the union upon an equal footing with the original states reference to the bill however show that while by the first section congress distinctly accept ratifie and confirm the constitution and state government which the people of the territory have form for themselves declare nebraska to be one of the united states of america and admit she into the union upon an equal footing with the original states in all respect whatsoever the third section provide that this measure shall not take effect except upon the fundamental condition that within the state of nebraska there shall be no denial of the elective franchise or of any other right to any person by reason of race or color except indians not tax and upon the further fundamental condition that the legislature of say state by a solemn public act shall declare the assent of say state to the say fundamental condition and shall transmit to the president of the united states an authentic copy of say act upon receipt whereof the president by proclamation shall forthwith announce the fact whereupon say fundamental condition shall be hold as a part of the organic law of the state and thereupon and without any further proceeding on the part of congress the admission of say state into the union shall be consider as complete this condition be not mention in the original enable act be not contemplate at the time of its passage be not seek by the people themselves have not heretofore be apply to the inhabitant of any state ask admission and be in direct conflict with the constitution adopt by the people and declare in the preamble to be republican in its form of government for in that instrument the exercise of the elective franchise and the right to hold office be expressly limit to white citizen of the united states congress thus undertake to authorize and compel the legislature to change a constitution which it be declare in the preamble have receive the sanction of the people and which by this bill be accept ratify and confirm by the congress of the nation
 the first and third section of the bill exhibit yet further incongruity by the one nebraska be admit into the union upon an equal footing with the original states in all respect whatsoever while by the other congress demand as a condition precedent to her admission requirement which in our history have never be ask of any people when present a constitution and state government for the acceptance of the lawmaking power it be expressly declare by the third section that the bill shall not take effect except upon the fundamental condition that within the state of nebraska there shall be no denial of the elective franchise or of any other right to any person by reason of race or color except indians not tax neither more nor less than the assertion of the right of congress to regulate the elective franchise of any state hereafter to be admit this condition be in clear violation of the federal constitution under the provision of which from the very foundation of the government each state have be leave free to determine for itself the qualification necessary for the exercise of suffrage within its limit without precedent in our legislation it be in mark contrast with those limitation which impose upon states that from time to time have become member of the union have for their object the single purpose of prevent any infringement of the constitution of the country
 if congress be satisfied that nebraska at the present time possess sufficient population to entitle she to full representation in the council of the nation and that her people desire an exchange of a territorial for a state government good faith would seem to demand that she should be admit without further requirement than those express in the enable act with all of which it be assert in the preamble her inhabitant have comply congress may under the constitution admit new states or reject they but the people of a state can alone make or change their organic law and prescribe the qualification requisite for elector congress however in pass the bill in the shape in which it have be submit for my approval do not merely reject the application of the people of nebraska for present admission as a state into the union on the ground that the constitution which they have submit restrict the exercise of the elective franchise to the white population but impose condition which if accept by the legislature may without the consent of the people so change the organic law as to make elector of all person within the state without distinction of race or color in view of this fact i suggest for the consideration of congress whether it would not be just expedient and in accordance with the principle of our government to allow the people by popular vote or through a convention choose by themselves for that purpose to declare whether or not they will accept the term upon which it be now propose to admit they into the union this course would not occasion much great delay than that which the bill contemplate when it require that the legislature shall be convene within thirty day after this measure shall have become a law for the purpose of consider and decide the condition which it impose and gain additional force when we consider that the proceeding attend the formation of the state constitution be not in conformity with the provision of the enable act that in an aggregate vote of 7,776 the majority in favor of the constitution do not exceed 100 and that it be allege that in consequence of fraud even this result can not be receive as a fair expression of the wish of the people as upon they must fall the burden of a state organization it be but just that they should be permit to determine for themselves a question which so materially affect their interest possess a soil and a climate admirably adapt to those industrial pursuit which bring prosperity and greatness to a people with the advantage of a central position on the great highway that will soon connect the atlantic and pacific states nebraska be rapidly gain in number and wealth and may within a very brief period claim admission on ground which will challenge and secure universal assent she can therefore wisely and patiently afford to wait her population be say to be steadily and even rapidly increase be now generally concede as high as 40,000 and estimate by some whose judgment be entitle to respect at a still great number at her present rate of growth she will in a very short time have the requisite population for a representative in congress and what be far more important to her own citizen will have realize such an advance in material wealth as will enable the expense of a state government to be bear without oppression to the taxpayer of new community it may be say with special force and it be true of old one that the inducement to emigrant other thing be equal be in almost the precise ratio of the rate of taxation the great states of the northwest owe their marvelous prosperity largely to the fact that they be continue as territories until they have grow to be wealthy and populous community
 andrew johnson

to the house of representatives
 i have examine the bill to provide for the more efficient government of the rebel states with the care and anxiety which its transcendent importance be calculate to awaken i be unable to give it my assent for reason so grave that i hope a statement of they may have some influence on the mind of the patriotic and enlighten man with whom the decision must ultimately rest
 the bill place all the people of the ten states therein name under the absolute domination of military ruler and the preamble undertake to give the reason upon which the measure be base and the ground upon which it be justify it declare that there exist in those state no legal government and no adequate protection for life or property and assert the necessity of enforce peace and good order within their limit be this true as matter of fact
 it be not deny that the states in question have each of they an actual government with all the power executive judicial and legislative which properly belong to a free state they be organize like the other states of the union and like they they make administer and execute the law which concern their domestic affair an exist de facto government exercise such function as these be itself the law of the state upon all matter within its jurisdiction to pronounce the supreme lawmaking power of an establish state illegal be to say that law itself be unlawful
 the provision which these government have make for the preservation of order the suppression of crime and the redress of private injury be in substance and principle the same as those which prevail in the northern states and in other civilized country they certainly have not succeed in prevent the commission of all crime nor have this be accomplish anywhere in the world there as well as elsewhere offender sometimes escape for want of vigorous prosecution and occasionally perhaps by the inefficiency of court or the prejudice of juror it be undoubtedly true that these evil have be much increase and aggravate north and south by the demoralize influence of civil war and by the rancorous passion which the contest have engender but that these people be maintain local government for themselves which habitually defeat the object of all government and render their own life and property insecure be in itself utterly improbable and the averment of the bill to that effect be not support by any evidence which have come to my knowledge all the information i have on the subject convince i that the masse of the southern people and those who control their public act while they entertain diverse opinion on question of federal policy be completely unite in the effort to reorganize their society on the basis of peace and to restore their mutual prosperity as rapidly and as completely as their circumstance will permit
 the bill however would seem to show upon its face that the establishment of peace and good order be not its real object the fifth section declare that the precede section shall cease to operate in any state where certain event shall have happen these event be first the selection of delegate to a state convention by an election at which negro shall be allow to vote second the formation of a state constitution by the convention so choose third the insertion into the state constitution of a provision which will secure the right of voting at all election to negro and to such white man as may not be disfranchise for rebellion or felony fourth the submission of the constitution for ratification to negro and white man not disfranchise and its actual ratification by their vote fifth the submission of the state constitution to congress for examination and approval and the actual approval of it by that body sixth the adoption of a certain amendment to the federal constitution by a vote of the legislature elect under the new constitution seventh the adoption of say amendment by a sufficient number of other states to make it a part of the constitution of the united states all these condition must be fulfil before the people of any of these states can be relieve from the bondage of military domination but when they be fulfil then immediately the pain and penalty of the bill be to cease no matter whether there be peace and order or not and without any reference to the security of life or property the excuse give for the bill in the preamble be admit by the bill itself not to be real the military rule which it establish be plainly to be use not for any purpose of order or for the prevention of crime but solely as a means of coerce the people into the adoption of principle and measure to which it be know that they be opposed and upon which they have an undeniable right to exercise their own judgment
 i submit to congress whether this measure be not in its whole character scope and object without precedent and without authority in palpable conflict with the plain provision of the constitution and utterly destructive to those great principle of liberty and humanity for which our ancestor on both side of the atlantic have shed so much blood and expend so much treasure
 the ten states name in the bill be divide into five district for each district an officer of the army not below the rank of a brigadier general be to be appoint to rule over the people and he be to be support with an efficient military force to enable he to perform his duty and enforce his authority those duty and that authority as define by the third section of the bill be to protect all person in their right of person and property to suppress insurrection disorder and violence and to punish or cause to be punish all disturber of the public peace or criminal the power thus give to the command officer over all the people of each district be that of an absolute monarch his mere will be to take the place of all law the law of the states be now the only rule applicable to the subject place under his control and that be completely displace by the clause which declare all interference of state authority to be null and void he alone be permit to determine what be right of person or property and he may protect they in such way as in his discretion may seem proper it place at his free disposal all the land and good in his district and he may distribute they without let or hindrance to whom he please be bind by no state law and there be no other law to regulate the subject he may make a criminal code of his own and he can make it as bloody as any record in history or he can reserve the privilege of act upon the impulse of his private passion in each case that arise he be bind by no rule of evidence there be indeed no provision by which he be authorize or require to take any evidence at all everything be a crime which he choose to call so and all person be condemn whom he pronounce to be guilty he be not bind to keep any record or make any report of his proceeding he may arrest his victim wherever he find they without warrant accusation or proof of probable cause if he give they a trial before he inflict the punishment he give it of his grace and mercy not because he be command so to do
 to a casual reader of the bill it might seem that some kind of trial be secure by it to person accuse of crime but such be not the case the officer may allow local civil tribunal to try offender but of course this do not require that he shall do so if any state or federal court presume to exercise its legal jurisdiction by the trial of a malefactor without his special permission he can break it up and punish the judge and juror as be themselves malefactor he can save his friend from justice and despoil his enemy contrary to justice
 it be also provide that he shall have power to organize military commission or tribunal but this power he be not command to exercise it be merely permissive and be to be use only when in his judgment it may be necessary for the trial of offender even if the sentence of a commission be make a prerequisite to the punishment of a party it would be scarcely the slight check upon the officer who have authority to organize it as he please prescribe its mode of proceeding appoint its member from his own subordinate and revise all its decision instead of mitigate the harshness of his single rule such a tribunal would be use much more probably to divide the responsibility of make it more cruel and unjust
 several provision dictate by the humanity of congress have be insert in the bill apparently to restrain the power of the command officer but it seem to i that they be of no avail for that purpose the fourth section provide first that trial shall not be unnecessarily delay but i think i have show that the power be give to punish without trial and if so this provision be practically inoperative second cruel or unusual punishment be not to be inflict but who be to decide what be cruel and what be unusual the word have acquire a legal meaning by long use in the court can it be expect that military officer will understand or follow a rule express in language so purely technical and not pertain in the least degree to their profession if not then each officer may define cruelty accord to his own temper and if it be not usual he will make it usual corporal punishment imprisonment the gag the ball and chain and all the almost insupportable form of torture invent for military punishment lie within the range of choice third the sentence of a commission be not to be execute without be approve by the commander if it affect life or liberty and a sentence of death must be approve by the president this apply to ease in which there have be a trial and sentence i take it to be clear under this bill that the military commander may condemn to death without even the form of a trial by a military commission so that the life of the condemn may depend upon the will of two man instead of one
 it be plain that the authority here give to the military officer amount to absolute despotism but to make it still more unendurable the bill provide that it may be delegate to as many subordinate as he choose to appoint for it declare that he shall punish or cause to be punish such a power have not be wield by any monarch in england for more than five hundred year in all that time no people who speak the english language have bear such servitude it reduce the whole population of the ten states all person of every color sex and condition and every stranger within their limit to the most abject and degrading slavery no master ever have a control so absolute over the slave as this bill give to the military officer over both white and colored person
 it may be answer to this that the officer of the army be too magnanimous just and humane to oppress and trample upon a subjugate people i do not doubt that army officer be as well entitled to this kind of confidence as any other class of man but the history of the world have be write in vain if it do not teach we that unrestrained authority can never be safely trust in human hand it be almost sure to be more or less abuse under any circumstance and it have always result in gross tyranny where the ruler who exercise it be stranger to their subject and come among they as the representative of a distant power and more especially when the power that send they be unfriendly government closely resemble that here propose have be fairly try in hungary and poland and the suffering endure by those people rouse the sympathy of the entire world it be try in ireland and though temper at first by principle of english law it give birth to cruelty so atrocious that they be never recount without just indignation the french convention arm its deputy with this power and send they to the southern department of the republic the massacre murder and other atrocity which they commit show what the passion of the able man in the most civilized society will tempt they to do when wholly unrestrained by law
 the man of our race in every age have struggle to tie up the hand of their government and keep they within the law because their own experience of all mankind teach they that ruler could not be rely on to concede those right which they be not legally bind to respect the head of a great empire have sometimes govern it with a mild and paternal sway but the kindness of an irresponsible deputy never yield what the law do not extort from he between such a master and the people subject to his domination there can be nothing but enmity he punish they if they resist his authority and if they submit to it he hate they for their servility
 i come now to a question which be if possible still more important have we the power to establish and carry into execution a measure like this i answer certainly not if we derive our authority from the constitution and if we be bind by the limitation which it impose
 this proposition be perfectly clear that no branch of the federal government executive legislative or judicial can have any just power except those which it derive through and exercise under the organic law of the union outside of the constitution we have no legal authority more than private citizen and within it we have only so much as that instrument give we this broad principle limit all our function and apply to all subject it protect not only the citizen of states which be within the union but it shield every human being who come or be bring under our jurisdiction we have no right to do in one place more than in another that which the constitution say we shall not do at all if therefore the southern states be in truth out of the union we could not treat their people in a way which the fundamental law forbid
 some person assume that the success of our arm in crush the opposition which be make in some of the states to the execution of the federal law reduce those states and all their people the innocent as well as the guilty to the condition of vassalage and give we a power over they which the constitution do not bestow or define or limit no fallacy can be more transparent than this our victory subject the insurgent to legal obedience not to the yoke of an arbitrary despotism when an absolute sovereign reduce his rebellious subject he may deal with they accord to his pleasure because he have that power before but when a limited monarch put down an insurrection he must still govern accord to law if an insurrection should take place in one of our states against the authority of the state government and end in the overthrow of those who plan it would that take away the right of all the people of the county where it be favor by a part or a majority of the population could they for such a reason be wholly outlawed and deprive of their representation in the legislature i have always contend that the government of the united states be sovereign within its constitutional sphere that it execute its law like the states themselves by apply its coercive power directly to individual and that it could put down insurrection with the same effect as a state and no other the opposite doctrine be the bad heresy of those who advocate secession and can not be agree to without admit that heresy to be right
 invasion insurrection rebellion and domestic violence be anticipate when the government be frame and the mean of repel and suppress they be wisely provide for in the constitution but it be not think necessary to declare that the states in which they might occur should be expel from the union rebellion which be invariably suppress occur prior to that out of which these question grow but the states continue to exist and the union remain unbroken in massachusetts in pennsylvania in rhode island and in new york at different period in our history violent and armed opposition to the united states be earn on but the relation of those states with the federal government be not suppose to be interrupt or change thereby after the rebellion portion of their population be defeat and put down it be true that in these early case there be no formal expression of a determination to withdraw from the union but it be also true that in the southern states the ordinance of secession be treat by all the friend of the union as mere nullity and be now acknowledge to be so by the states themselves if we admit that they have any force or validity or that they do in fact take the states in which they be pass out of the union we sweep from under our foot all the ground upon which we stand in justify the use of federal force to maintain the integrity of the government
 this be a bill pass by congress in time of peace there be not in any one of the states bring under its operation either war or insurrection the law of the states and of the federal government be all in undisturbed and harmonious operation the court state and federal be open and in the full exercise of their proper authority over every state comprise in these five military district life liberty and property be secure by state law and federal law and the national constitution be everywhere in force and everywhere obey what then be the ground on which this bill proceed the title of the bill announce that it be intend for the more efficient government of these ten state it be recite by way of preamble that no legal state government nor adequate protection for life or property exist in those states and that peace and good order should be thus enforce the first thing which arrest attention upon these recital which prepare the way for martial law be this that the only foundation upon which martial law can exist under our form of government be not state or so much as pretend actual war foreign invasion domestic insurrection none of these appear and none of these in fact exist it be not even recite that any sort of war or insurrection be threaten let we pause here to consider upon this question of constitutional law and the power of congress a recent decision of the supreme court of the united states in ex parte milligan
 i will first quote from the opinion of the majority of the court
 martial law can not arise from a threatened invasion the necessity must be actual and present the invasion real such as effectually close the court and depose the civil administration
 we see that martial law come in only when actual war close the court and depose the civil authority but this bill in time of peace make martial law operate as though we be in actual war and become the cause instead of the consequence of the abrogation of civil authority one more quotation
 it follow from what have be say on this subject that there be occasion when martial law can be properly apply if in foreign invasion or civil war the court be actually closed and it be impossible to administer criminal justice accord to law then on the theater of active military operation where war really prevail there be a necessity to furnish a substitute for the civil authority thus overthrow to preserve the safety of the army and society and as no power be leave but the military it be allow to govern by martial rule until the law can have their free course
 i now quote from the opinion of the minority of the court deliver by chief justice chase
 we by no mean assert that congress can establish and apply the law of war where no war have be declare or exist where peace exist the law of peace must prevail
 this be sufficiently explicit peace exist in all the territory to which this bill apply it assert a power in congress in time of peace to set aside the law of peace and to substitute the law of war the minority concur with the majority declare that congress do not possess that power again and if possible more emphatically the chief justice with remarkable clearness and condensation sum up the whole matter as follow
 there be under the constitution three kind of military jurisdiction one to be exercise both in peace and war another to be exercise in time of foreign war without the boundary of the united states or in time of rebellion and civil war within states or district occupy by rebel treat as belligerent and a third to be exercise in time of invasion or insurrection within the limit of the united states or during rebellion within the limit of the state maintain adhesion to the national government when the public danger require its exercise the first of these may be call jurisdiction under military law and be find in act of congress prescribing rule and article of war or otherwise provide for the government of the national force the second may be distinguish as military government supersede as far as may be deem expedient the local law and exercise by the military commander under the direction of the president with the express or imply sanction of congress while the third may be denominate martial law proper and be call into action by congress or temporarily when the action of congress can not be invite and in the case of justify or excuse peril by the president in time of insurrection or invasion or of civil or foreign war within district or locality where ordinary law no long adequately secure public safety and private right
 it will be observe that of the three kind of military jurisdiction which can be exercise or create under our constitution there be but one that can prevail in time of peace and that be the code of law enact by congress for the government of the national force that body of military law have no application to the citizen nor even to the citizen soldier enrol in the militia in time of peace but this bill be not a part of that sort of military law for that apply only to the soldier and not to the citizen whilst contrariwise the military law provide by this bill apply only to the citizen and not to the soldier
 i need not say to the representative of the american people that their constitution forbid the exercise of judicial power in any way but one that be by the ordain and established court it be equally well know that in all criminal case a trial by jury be make indispensable by the express word of that instrument i will not enlarge on the inestimable value of the right thus secure to every freeman or speak of the danger to public liberty in all part of the country which must ensue from a denial of it anywhere or upon any pretense a very recent decision of the supreme court have trace the history vindicate the dignity and make known the value of this great privilege so clearly that nothing more be need to what extent a violation of it might be excuse in time of war or public danger may admit of discussion but we be provide now for a time of profound peace when there be not an armed soldier within our border except those who be in the service of the government it be in such a condition of thing that an act of congress be propose which if carry out would deny a trial by the lawful court and jury to 9,000,000 american citizen and to their posterity for an indefinite period it seem to be scarcely possible that anyone should seriously believe this consistent with a constitution which declare in simple plain and unambiguous language that all person shall have that right and that no person shall ever in any case be deprive of it the constitution also forbid the arrest of the citizen without judicial warrant round on probable cause this bill authorize an arrest without warrant at the pleasure of a military commander the constitution declare that no person shall be hold to answer for a capital or otherwise infamous crime unless on presentment by a grand jury this bill hold every person not a soldier answerable for all crime and all charge without any presentment the constitution declare that no person shall be deprive of life liberty or property without due process of law this bill set aside all process of law and make the citizen answerable in his person and property to the will of one man and as to his life to the will of two finally the constitution declare that the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus shall not be suspend unless when in case of rebellion or invasion the public safety may require it whereas this bill declare martial law which of itself suspend this great writ in time of peace and authorize the military to make the arrest and give to the prisoner only one privilege and that be a trial without unnecessary delay he have no hope of release from custody except the hope such as it be of release by acquittal before a military commission
 the united states be bind to guarantee to each state a republican form of government can it be pretend that this obligation be not palpably break if we carry out a measure like this which wipe away every vestige of republican government in ten state and put the life property liberty and honor of all the people in each of they under the domination of a single person clothe with unlimited authority
 the parliament of england exercise the omnipotent power which it claim be accustom to pass bill of attainder that be to say it would convict man of treason and other crime by legislative enactment the person accuse have a hearing sometimes a patient and fair one but generally party prejudice prevail instead of justice it often become necessary for parliament to acknowledge its error and reverse its own action the father of our country determine that no such thing should occur here they withhold the power from congress and thus forbid its exercise by that body and they provide in the constitution that no state should pass any bill of attainder it be therefore impossible for any person in this country to be constitutionally convict or punish for any crime by a legislative proceeding of any sort nevertheless here be a bill of attainder against 9,000,000 people at once it be base upon an accusation so vague as to be scarcely intelligible and find to be true upon no credible evidence not one of the 9,000,000 be hear in his own defense the representative of the doomed party be exclude from all participation in the trial the conviction be to be follow by the most ignominious punishment ever inflict on large masse of man it disfranchise they by hundred of thousand and degrade they all even those who be admit to be guiltless from the rank of freeman to the condition of slave
 the purpose and object of the bill the general intent which pervade it from begin to end be to change the entire structure and character of the state government and to compel they by force to the adoption of organic law and regulation which they be unwilling to accept if leave to themselves the negro have not ask for the privilege of voting the vast majority of they have no idea what it mean this bill not only thrust it into their hand but compel they as well as the white to use it in a particular way if they do not form a constitution with prescribe article in it and afterwards elect a legislature which will act upon certain measure in a prescribed way neither black nor white can be relieve from the slavery which the bill impose upon they without pause here to consider the policy or impolicy of africanize the southern part of our territory i would simply ask the attention of congress to that manifest well know and universally acknowledge rule of constitutional law which declare that the federal government have no jurisdiction authority or power to regulate such subject for any state to force the right of suffrage out of the hand of the white people and into the hand of the negro be an arbitrary violation of this principle
 this bill impose martial law at once and its operation will begin so soon as the general and his troop can be put in place the dread alternative between its harsh rule and compliance with the term of this measure be not suspend nor be the people afford any time for free deliberation the bill say to they take martial law first then deliberate and when they have do all that this measure require they to do other condition and contingency over which they have no control yet remain to be fulfil before they can be relieve from martial law another congress must first approve the constitution make in conformity with the will of this congress and must declare these states entitle to representation in both houses the whole question thus remain open and unsettled and must again occupy the attention of congress and in the meantime the agitation which now prevail will continue to disturb all portion of the people
 the bill also deny the legality of the government of ten of the states which participate in the ratification of the amendment to the federal constitution abolishing slavery forever within the jurisdiction of the united states and practically exclude they from the union if this assumption of the bill be correct their concurrence can not be consider as having be legally give and the important fact be make to appear that the consent of three fourth of the states the requisite number have not be constitutionally obtain to the ratification of that amendment thus leave the question of slavery where it stand before the amendment be officially declare to have become a part of the constitution
 that the measure propose by this bill do violate the constitution in the particular mention and in many other way which i forbear to enumerate be too clear to admit of the least doubt it only remain to consider whether the injunction of that instrument ought to be obey or not i think they ought to be obey for reason which i will proceed to give as briefly as possible
 in the first place it be the only system of free government which we can hope to have as a nation when it cease to be the rule of our conduct we may perhaps take our choice between complete anarchy a consolidated despotism and a total dissolution of the union but national liberty regulate by law will have pass beyond our reach
 it be the good frame of government the world ever see no other be or can be so well adapt to the genius habit or want of the american people combine the strength of a great empire with unspeakable blessing of local self government have a central power to defend the general interest and recognize the authority of the states as the guardian of industrial right it be the sheet anchor of our safety abroad and our peace at home it be ordain to form a more perfect union establish justice insure domestic tranquillity promote the general welfare provide for the common defense and secure the blessing of liberty to ourselves and to our posterity these great end have be attain heretofore and will be again by faithful obedience to it but they be certain to be lose if we treat with disregard its sacred obligation
 it be to punish the gross crime of defy the constitution and to vindicate its supreme authority that we carry on a bloody war of four years&#39 duration shall we now acknowledge that we sacrifice a million of life and expend billion of treasure to enforce a constitution which be not worthy of respect and preservation
 those who advocate the right of secession allege in their own justification that we have no regard for law and that their right of property life and liberty would not be safe under the constitution as administer by we if we now verify their assertion we prove that they be in truth and in fact fight for their liberty and instead of brand their leader with the dishonor name of traitor against a righteous and legal government we elevate they in history to the rank of self sacrifice patriot consecrate they to the admiration of the world and place they by the side of washington hampden and sidney no let we leave they to the infamy they deserve punish they as they should be punish accord to law and take upon ourselves no share of the odium which they should bear alone
 it be a part of our public history which can never be forget that both houses of congress in july 1861 declare in the form of a solemn resolution that the war be and should be carry on for no purpose of subjugation but solely to enforce the constitution and law and that when this be yield by the party in rebellion the contest should cease with the constitutional right of the states and of individual unimpaire this resolution be adopt and send forth to the world unanimously by the senate and with only two dissent voice in the house it be accept by the friend of the union in the south as well as in the north as express honestly and truly the object of the war on the faith of it many thousand of person in both section give their life and their fortune to the cause to repudiate it now by refuse to the states and to the individual within they the right which the constitution and law of the union would secure to they be a breach of our plight honor for which i can imagine no excuse and to which i can not voluntarily become a party
 the evil which spring from the unsettled state of our government will be acknowledge by all commercial intercourse be impede capital be in constant peril public security fluctuate in value peace itself be not secure and the sense of moral and political duty be impaired to avert these calamity from our country it be imperatively require that we should immediately decide upon some course of administration which can be steadfastly adhere to i be thoroughly convinced that any settlement or compromise or plan of action which be inconsistent with the principle of the constitution will not only be unavaile but mischievous that it will but multiply the present evil instead of remove they the constitution in its whole integrity and vigor throughout the length and breadth of the land be the good of all compromise besides our duty do not in my judgment leave we a choice between that and any other i believe that it contain the remedy that be so much need and that if the coordinate branch of the government would unite upon its provision they would be find broad enough and strong enough to sustain in time of peace the nation which they bear safely through the ordeal of a protract civil war among the most sacred guaranty of that instrument be those which declare that each state shall have at least one representative and that no state without its consent shall be deprive of its equal suffrage in the senate each house be make the judge of the election return and qualification of its own member and may with the concurrence of two third expel a member thus as heretofore urge in the admission of senators and representatives from any and all of the states there can be no just ground of apprehension that person who be disloyal will be clothe with the power of legislation for this could not happen when the constitution and the law be enforce by a vigilant and faithful congress when a senator or representative present his certificate of election he may at once be admit or reject or should there be any question as to his eligibility his credential may be refer for investigation to the appropriate committee if admit to a seat it must be upon evidence satisfactory to the house of which he thus become a member that he possess the requisite constitutional and legal qualification if refuse admission as a member for want of due allegiance to the government and return to his constituent they be admonish that none but person loyal to the united states will be allow a voice in the legislative council of the nation and the political power and moral influence of congress be thus effectively exert in the interest of loyalty to the government and fidelity to the union and be it not far well that the work of restoration should be accomplish by simple compliance with the plain requirement of the constitution than by a recourse to measure which in effect destroy the states and threaten the subversion of the general government all that be necessary to settle this simple but important question without further agitation or delay be a willingness on the part of all to sustain the constitution and carry its provision into practical operation if to morrow either branch of congress would declare that upon the presentation of their credential member constitutionally elect and loyal to the general government would be admit to seat in congress while all other would be exclude and their place remain vacant until the selection by the people of loyal and qualified person and if at the same time assurance be give that this policy would be continue until all the states be represent in congress it would send a thrill of joy throughout the entire land as indicate the inauguration of a system which must speedily bring tranquillity to the public mind
 while we be legislate upon subject which be of great importance to the whole people and which must affect all part of the country not only during the life of the present generation but for age to come we should remember that all man be entitle at least to a hearing in the council which decide upon the destiny of themselves and their child at present ten state be deny representation and when the fortieth congress assemble on the 4th day of the present month sixteen state will be without a voice in the house of representatives this grave fact with the important question before we should induce we to pause in a course of legislation which look solely to the attainment of political end fail to consider the right it transgress the law which it violate or the institution which it imperil

to the house of representatives
 i have consider the bill entitle an act supplementary to an act entitle 39;an act to provide for the more efficient government of the rebel states,&#39 pass march 2 1867 and to facilitate restoration and now return it to the house of representatives with my objection
 this bill provide for election in the ten states bring under the operation of the original act to which it be supplementary its detail be principally direct to the election for the formation of the state constitution but by the sixth section of the bill all election in these states occur while the original act remain in force be bring within its purview refer to these detail it will be find that first of all there be to be a registration of the voter no one whose name have not be admit on the list be to be allow to vote at any of these election to ascertain who be entitle to registration reference be make necessary by the express language of the supplement to the original act and to the pende bill the fifth section of the original act provide as to voter that they shall be male citizen of the state 21 year old and upward of whatever race color or previous condition who have be resident of say state for one year this be the general qualification follow however by many exception no one can be register accord to the original act who may be disfranchise for participation in the rebellion"--a provision which leave undetermine the question as to what amount to disfranchisement and whether without a judicial sentence the act itself produce that effect this supplemental bill superadd an oath to be take by every person before his name can be admit upon the registration that he have not be disfranchise for participation in any rebellion or civil war against the united states it thus impose upon every person the necessity and responsibility of decide for himself under the peril of punishment by a military commission if he make a mistake what work disfranchisement by participation in rebellion and what amount to such participation almost every man the negro as well as the white above 21 year of age who be resident in these ten state during the rebellion voluntarily or involuntarily at some time and in some way do participate in resistance to the lawful authority of the general government the question with the citizen to whom this oath be to be propose must be a fearful one for while the bill do not declare that perjury may be assign for such false swearing nor fix any penalty for the offense we must not forget that martial law prevail that every person be answerable to a military commission without previous presentment by a grand jury for any charge that may be make against he and that the supreme authority of the military commander determine the question as to what be an offense and what be to be the measure of punishment
 the fourth section of the bill provide that the command general of each district shall appoint as many board of registration as may be necessary consist of three loyal officer or person the only qualification state for these officer be that they must be loyal they may be person in the military service or civilian resident of the state or stranger yet these person be to exercise most important duty and be vest with unlimited discretion they be to decide what name shall be place upon the register and from their decision there be to be no appeal they be to superintend the election and to decide all question which may arise they be to have the custody of the ballot and to make return of the person elect whatever fraud or error they may commit must pass without redress all that be leave for the command general be to receive the return of the election open the same and ascertain who be choose accord to the return of the officer who conduct say election by such mean and with this sort of agency be the convention of delegate to be constitute
 as the delegate be to speak for the people common justice would seem to require that they should have authority from the people themselves no convention so constitute will in any sense represent the wish of the inhabitant of these states for under the all embrace exception of these law by a construction which the uncertainty of the clause as to disfranchisement leave open to the board of officer the great body of the people may be exclude from the poll and from all opportunity of express their own wish or vote for delegate who will faithfully reflect their sentiment
 i do not deem it necessary far to investigate the detail of this bill no consideration could induce i to give my approval to such an election law for any purpose and especially for the great purpose of frame the constitution of a state if ever the american citizen should be leave to the free exercise of his own judgment it be when he be engage in the work of form the fundamental law under which he be to live that work be his work and it can not properly be take out of his hand all this legislation proceed upon the contrary assumption that the people of each of these states shall have no constitution except such as may be arbitrarily dictate by congress and form under the restraint of military rule a plain statement of fact make this evident
 in all these state there be exist constitution frame in the accustomed way by the people congress however declare that these constitution be not loyal and republican and require the people to form they anew what then in the opinion of congress be necessary to make the constitution of a state loyal and republican the original act answer the question it be universal negro suffrage a question which the federal constitution leave exclusively to the states themselves all this legislative machinery of martial law military coercion and political disfranchisement be avowedly for that purpose and none other the exist constitution of the ten states conform to the acknowledge standard of loyalty and republicanism indeed if there be degree in republican form of government their constitution be more republican now than when these states four of which be member of the original thirteen first become member of the union
 congress do not now demand that a single provision of their constitution be change except such as confine suffrage to the white population it be apparent therefore that these provision do not conform to the standard of republicanism which congress seek to establish that there may be no mistake it be only necessary that reference should be make to the original act which declare such constitution shall provide that the elective franchise shall be enjoy by all such person as have the qualification herein state for elector of delegate what class of person be here mean clearly appear in the same section that be to say the male citizen of say state 21 year old and upward of whatever race color or previous condition who have be resident in say state for one year previous to the day of such election
 without these provision no constitution which can be frame in any one of the ten states will be of any avail with congress this then be the test of what the constitution of a state of this union must contain to make it republican measure by such a standard how few of the states now compose the union have republican constitution if in the exercise of the constitutional guaranty that congress shall secure to every state a republican form of government universal suffrage for black as well as white be a sine qua non the work of reconstruction may as well begin in ohio as in virginia in pennsylvania as in north carolina
 when i contemplate the million of our fellow citizen of the south with no alternative leave but to impose upon themselves this fearful and untried experiment of complete negro enfranchisement and white disfranchisement it may be almost as complete or submit indefinitely to the rigor of martial law without a single attribute of freeman deprive of all the sacred guaranty of our federal constitution and threaten with even bad wrong if any bad be possible it seem to i their condition be the most deplorable to which any people can be reduce it be true that they have be engage in rebellion and that their object be a separation of the states and a dissolution of the union there be an obligation rest upon every loyal citizen to treat they as enemy and to wage war against their cause
 inflexibly oppose to any movement imperil the integrity of the government i do not hesitate to urge the adoption of all measure necessary for the suppression of the insurrection after a long and terrible struggle the effort of the government be triumphantly successful and the people of the south submit to the stern arbitrament yield forever the issue of the contest hostility terminate soon after it become my duty to assume the responsibility of the chief executive officer of the republic and i at once endeavor to repress and control the passion which our civil strife have engender and no long regard these err million as enemy again acknowledge they as our friend and our countryman the war have accomplish its object the nation be save and that seminal principle of mischief which from the birth of the government have gradually but inevitably bring on the rebellion be totally eradicate then it seem to i be the auspicious time to commence the work of reconciliation then when these people seek once more our friendship and protection i consider it our duty generously to meet they in the spirit of charity and forgiveness and to conquer they even more effectually by the magnanimity of the nation than by the force of its arm i yet believe that if the policy of reconciliation then inaugurate and which contemplate an early restoration of these people to all their political right have receive the support of congress every one of these ten states and all their people would at this moment be fast anchor in the union and the great work which give the war all its sanction and make it just and holy would have be accomplish then over all the vast and fruitful region of the south peace and its blessing would have prevail while now million be deprive of right guarantee by the constitution to every citizen and after nearly two year of legislation find themselves place under an absolute military despotism a military republic a government round on mock election and support only by the sword be nearly a quarter of a century since pronounce by daniel webster when speak of the south american states as a movement indeed but a retrograde and disastrous movement from the regular and old fashioned monarchical system and he add
 if man would enjoy the blessing of republican government they must govern themselves by reason by mutual counsel and consultation by a sense and feeling of general interest and by the acquiescence of the minority in the will of the majority properly express and above all the military must be keep accord to the language of our bill of right in strict subordination to the civil authority wherever this lesson be not both learn and practice there can be no political freedom absurd preposterous be it a scoff and a satire on free form of constitutional liberty for frame of government to be prescribe by military leader and the right of suffrage to be exercise at the point of the sword
 i confidently believe that a time will come when these states will again occupy their true position in the union the barrier which now seem so obstinate must yield to the force of an enlightened and just public opinion and soon or later unconstitutional and oppressive legislation will be efface from our statute book when this shall have be consummate i pray god that the error of the past may be forget and that once more we shall be a happy united and prosperous people and that at last after the bitter and eventful experience through which the nation have pass we shall all come to know that our only safety be in the preservation of our federal constitution and in accord to every american citizen and to every state the right which that constitution secure

war department
 adjutant general&#39;s office
 whereas several commander of military district create by the act of congress know as the reconstruction act have express doubt as to the proper construction thereof and in respect to some of their power and duty under say act and have apply to the executive for information in relation thereto and
 whereas the say act of congress have be refer to the attorney general for his opinion thereon and the say act and the opinion of the attorney general have be fully and carefully consider by the president in conference with the head of the respective departments
 the president accept the following as a practical interpretation of the aforesaid act of congress on the point therein present and direct the same to be transmit to the respective military commander for their information in order that there may be uniformity in the execution of say act
 1 the oath prescribe in the supplemental act define all the qualification require and every person who can take that oath be entitle to have his name enter upon the list of voter
 2 the board of registration have no authority to administer any other oath to the person apply for registration than this prescribed oath nor to administer an oath to any other person touch the qualification of the applicant or the falsity of the oath so take by he the act to guard against falsity in the oath provide that if false the person take it shall be try and punish for perjury
 no provision be make for challenge the qualification of the applicant or enter upon any trial or investigation of his qualification either by witness or any other form of proof
 3 as to citizenship and residence
 the applicant for registration must be a citizen of the state and of the united states and must be a resident of a county or parish include in the election district he may be register if he have be such citizen for a period less than twelve month at the time he apply for registration but he can not vote at any election unless his citizenship have then extend to the full term of one year as to such a person the exact length of his citizenship should be note opposite his name on the list so that it may appear on the day of election upon reference to the list whether the full term have then be accomplish
 4 an unnaturalized person can not take this oath but an alien who have be naturalize can take it and no other proof of naturalization can be require from he
 5 no one who be not 21 year of age at the time of registration can take the oath for he must swear that he have then attain that age
 6 no one who have be disfranchise for participation in any rebellion against the united states or for felony commit against the law of any state or of the united states can take this oath
 the actual participation in a rebellion or the actual commission of a felony do not amount to disfranchisement the sort of disfranchisement here mean be that which be declare by law pass by competent authority or which have be fix upon the criminal by the sentence of the court which try he for the crime
 no law of the united states have declare the penalty of disfranchisement for participation in rebellion alone nor be it know that any such law exist in either of these ten states except perhaps virginia as to which state special instruction will be give
 7 as to disfranchisement arise from have hold office follow by participation in rebellion
 this be the most important part of the oath and require strict attention to arrive at its meaning the applicant must swear or affirm as follow
 that i have never be a member of any state legislature nor hold any executive or judicial office in any state and afterwards engage in an insurrection or rebellion against the united states or give aid or comfort to the enemy thereof that i have never take an oath as a member of congress of the united states or as an officer of the united states or as a member of any state legislature or as an executive or judicial officer of any state to support the constitution of the united states and afterwards engage in insurrection or rebellion against the united states or give aid or comfort to the enemy thereof
 two element must concur in order to disqualify a person under these clause first the office and official oath to support the constitution of the united states second engage afterwards in rebellion both must exist to work disqualification and must happen in the order of time mention
 a person who have hold an office and take the oath to support the federal constitution and have not afterwards engage in rebellion be not disqualify so too a person who have engage in rebellion but have not theretofore hold an office and take that oath be not disqualify
 8 officer of the united states
 as to these the language be without limitation the person who have at any time prior to the rebellion hold an office civil or military under the united states and have take an official oath to support the constitution of the united states be subject to disqualification
 9 militia officer of any state prior to the rebellion be not subject to disqualification
 10 municipal officer --that be to say officer of incorporated city town and village such as mayor aldermen town council police and other city or town officer be not subject to disqualification
 11 person who have prior to the rebellion be member of the congress of the united states or member of a state legislature be subject to disqualification but those who have be member of convention frame or amend the constitution of a state prior to the rebellion be not subject to disqualification
 12 all the executive or judicial officer of any state who take an oath to support the constitution of the united states be subject to disqualification include county officer they be subject to disqualification if they be require to take as a part of their official oath the oath to support the constitution of the united states
 13 person who exercise mere employment under state authority be not disqualify such as commissioner to lay out road commissioner of public work visitor of state institution director of state institution examiner of bank notary public and commissioner to take acknowledgment of deed
 engage in rebellion
 having specify what office hold by anyone prior to the rebellion come within the meaning of the law it be necessary next to set forth what subsequent conduct fix upon such person the offense of engage in rebellion two thing must exist as to any person to disqualify he from voting first the office hold prior to the rebellion and afterwards participation in the rebellion
 14 an act to fix upon a person the offense of engage in the rebellion under this law must be an overt and voluntary act do with the intent of aid or further the common unlawful purpose a person force into the rebel service by conscription or under a paramount authority which he could not safely disobey and who would not have enter such service if leave to the free exercise of his own will can not be hold to be disqualify from vote
 15 mere act of charity where the intent be to relieve the want of the object of such charity and not do in aid of the cause in which he may have be engage do not disqualify but organize contribution of food and clothing for the general relief of person engage in the rebellion and not of a merely sanitary character but contribute to enable they to perform their unlawful object may be class with act which do disqualify
 force contribution to the rebel cause in the form of taxis or military assessment which a person be compel to pay or contribute do not disqualify but voluntary contribution to the rebel cause even such indirect contribution as arise from the voluntary loan of money to rebel authority or purchase of bond or security create to afford the mean of carry on the rebellion will work disqualification
 16 all those who in legislative or other official capacity be engage in the furtherance of the common unlawful purpose where the duty of the office necessarily have relation to the support of the rebellion such as member of the rebel convention congress and legislature diplomatic agent of the rebel confederacy and other official whose office be create for the purpose of more effectually carry on hostility or whose duty appertain to the support of the rebel cause must be hold to be disqualify
 but officer who during the rebellion discharge official duty not incident to war but only such duty as belong even to a state of peace and be necessary to the preservation of order and the administration of law be not to be consider as thereby engage in rebellion or as disqualify disloyal sentiment opinion or sympathy would not disqualify but where a person have by speech or by write incite other to engage in rebellion he must come under the disqualification
 17 the duty of the board appoint to superintend the election
 this board have the custody of the list of register voter in the district for which it be constitute must see that the name of the person offer to vote be find upon the registration list and if such prof to be the fact it be the duty of the board to receive his vote if then qualify by residence they can not receive the vote of any person whose name be not upon the list though he may be ready to take the registration oath and although he may satisfy they that he be unable to have his name register at the proper time in consequence of absence sickness or other cause
 the board can not enter into any inquiry as to the qualification of any person whose name be not on the registration list or as to the qualification of any person whose name be on the list
 18 the mode of voting be provide in the act to be by ballot the board will keep a record and poll book of the election show the vote list of voter and the person elect by a plurality of the vote cast at the election and make return of these to the command general of the district
 19 the board appoint for registration and for superintend the election must take the oath prescribe by the act of congress approve july 2 1862 entitle an act to prescribe an oath of office
 by order of the president
 e.d. townsend
 assistant adjutant general

to the house of representatives of the united states
 i return herewith the bill entitle an act supplementary to an act entitle 39;an act to provide for the more efficient government of the rebel states,&#39 pass on the 2d day of march 1867 and the act supplementary thereto pass on the 23d day of march 1867 and will state as briefly as possible some of the reason which prevent i from give it my approval
 this be one of a series of measure pass by congress during the last four month on the subject of reconstruction the message return the act of the 2d of march last state at length my objection to the passage of that measure they apply equally well to the bill now before i and i be content merely to refer to they and to reiterate my conviction that they be sound and unanswerable
 there be some point peculiar to this bill which i will proceed at once to consider
 the first section purport to declare the true intent and meaning in some particular of the two prior act upon this subject
 it be declare that the intent of those act be first that the exist government in the ten rebel states be not legal state government and second that thereafter say government if continue be to be continue subject in all respect to the military commander of the respective district and to the paramount authority of congress
