 congress may by a declaratory act fix upon a prior act a construction altogether at variance with its apparent meaning and from the time at least when such a construction be fix the original act will be construe to mean exactly what it be state to mean by the declaratory statute there will be then from the time this bill may become a law no doubt no question as to the relation in which the exist government in those states call in the original act the provisional government stand toward the military authority as those relation stand before the declaratory act these government it be true be make subject to absolute military authority in many important respect but not in all the language of the act be subject to the military authority of the united states as hereinafter prescribe by the sixth section of the original act these government be make in all respect subject to the paramount authority of the united states
 now by this declaratory act it appear that congress do not by the original act intend to limit the military authority to any particular or subject therein prescribe but mean to make it universal thus over all of these ten states this military government be now declare to have unlimited authority it be no long confine to the preservation of the public peace the administration of criminal law the registration of voter and the superintendence of election but in all respect be assert to be paramount to the exist civil government
 it be impossible to conceive any state of society more intolerable than this and yet it be to this condition that 12,000,000 american citizen be reduce by the congress of the united states over every foot of the immense territory occupy by these american citizen the constitution of the united states be theoretically in full operation it bind all the people there and should protect they yet they be deny every one of its sacred guaranty
 of what avail will it be to any one of these southern people when seize by a file of soldier to ask for the cause of arrest or for the production of the warrant of what avail to ask for the privilege of bail when in military custody which know no such thing as bail of what avail to demand a trial by jury process for witness a copy of the indictment the privilege of counsel or that great privilege the writ of habeas corpus
 the veto of the original bill of the 2d of march be base on two distinct ground the interference of congress in matter strictly appertain to the reserved power of the states and the establishment of military tribunal for the trial of citizen in time of peace the impartial reader of that message will understand that all that it contain with respect to military despotism and martial law have reference especially to the fearful power confer on the district commander to displace the criminal court and assume jurisdiction to try and to punish by military board that potentially the suspension of the habeas corpus be martial law and military despotism the act now before i not only declare that the intent be to confer such military authority but also to confer unlimited military authority over all the other court of the state and over all the office of the state legislative executive and judicial not content with the general grant of power congress in the second section of this bill specifically give to each military commander the power to suspend or remove from office or from the performance of official duty and the exercise of official power any officer or person hold or exercise or profess to hold or exercise any civil or military office or duty in such district under any power election appointment or authority derive from or grant by or claim under any so call state or the government thereof or any municipal or other division thereof
 a power that hitherto all the department of the federal government act in concert or separately have not dare to exercise be here attempt to be confer on a subordinate military officer to he as a military officer of the federal government be give the power support by a sufficient military force to remove every civil officer of the state what next the district commander who have thus displace the civil officer be authorize to fill the vacancy by the detail of an officer or soldier of the army or by the appointment of some other person
 this military appointee whether an officer a soldier or some other person be to perform the duty of such officer or person so suspend or remove in other word an officer or soldier of the army be thus transform into a civil officer he may be make a governor a legislator or a judge however unfit he may deem himself for such civil duty he must obey the order the officer of the army must if detailed go upon the supreme bench of the state with the same prompt obedience as if he be detailed to go upon a court martial the soldier if detail to act as a justice of the peace must obey as quickly as if he be detail for picket duty
 what be the character of such a military civil officer this bill declare that he shall perform the duty of the civil office to which he be detail it be clear however that he do not lose his position in the military service he be still an officer or soldier of the army he be still subject to the rule and regulation which govern it and must yield due deference respect and obedience toward his superior
 the clear intent of this section be that the officer or soldier detail to fill a civil office must execute its duty accord to the law of the state if he be appoint a governor of a state he be to execute the duty as provide by the law of that state and for the time be his military character be to be suspend in his new civil capacity if he be appoint a state treasurer he must at once assume the custody and disbursement of the fund of the state and must perform those duty precisely accord to the law of the state for he be intrust with no other official duty or other official power hold the office of treasurer and intrust with fund it happen that he be require by the state law to enter into bond with security and to take an oath of office yet from the beginning of the bill to the end there be no provision for any bond or oath of office or for any single qualification require under the state law such as residence citizenship or anything else the only oath be that provide for in the ninth section by the term of which everyone detail or appoint to any civil office in the state be require to take and to subscribe the oath of office prescribe by law for officer of the united states thus an officer of the army of the united states detail to fill a civil office in one of these states give no official bond and take no official oath for the performance of his new duty but as a civil officer of the state only take the same oath which he have already take as a military officer of the united states he be at last a military officer perform civil duty and the authority under which he act be federal authority only and the inevitable result be that the federal government by the agency of its own sworn officer in effect assume the civil government of the state
 a singular contradiction be apparent here congress declare these local state government to be illegal government and then provide that these illegal government shall be carry on by federal officer who be to perform the very duty impose on its own officer by this illegal state authority it certainly would be a novel spectacle if congress should attempt to carry on a legal state government by the agency of its own officer it be yet more strange that congress attempt to sustain and carry on an illegal state government by the same federal agency
 in this connection i must call attention to the tenth and eleventh section of the bill which provide that none of the officer or appointee of these military commander shall be bind in his action by any opinion of any civil officer of the united states and that all the provision of the act shall be construe liberally to the end that all the intent thereof may be fully and perfectly carry out
 it seem congress suppose that this bill might require construction and they fix therefore the rule to be apply but where be the construction to come from certainly no one can be more in want of instruction than a soldier or an officer of the army detail for a civil service perhaps the most important in a state with the duty of which he be altogether unfamiliar this bill say he shall not be bind in his action by the opinion of any civil officer of the united states the duty of the office be altogether civil but when he ask for an opinion he can only ask the opinion of another military officer who perhaps understand as little of his duty as he do himself and as to his action he be answerable to the military authority and to the military authority alone strictly no opinion of any civil officer other than a judge have a bind force
 but these military appointee would not be bind even by a judicial opinion they might very well say even when their action be in conflict with the supreme court of the united states that court be compose of civil officer of the united states and we be not bind to conform our action to any opinion of any such authority
 this bill and the act to which it be supplementary be all round upon the assumption that these ten community be not states and that their exist government be not legal throughout the legislation upon this subject they be call rebel states and in this particular bill they be denominate so call state and the vice of illegality be declare to pervade all of they the obligation of consistency bind a legislative body as well as the individual who compose it it be now too late to say that these ten political community be not state of this union declaration to the contrary make in these three act be contradict again and again by repeated act of legislation enact by congress from the year 1861 to the year 1867
 during that period while these state be in actual rebellion and after that rebellion be bring to a close they have be again and again recognize as states of the union representation have be apportion to they as states they have be divide into judicial district for the holding of district and circuit court of the united states as states of the union only can be district the last act on this subject be pass july 23 1866 by which every one of these ten states be arrange into district and circuit
 they have be call upon by congress to act through their legislature upon at least two amendment to the constitution of the united states as states they have ratify one amendment which require the vote of twenty seven states of the thirty six then compose the union when the requisite twenty seven vote be give in favor of that amendment seven of which vote be give by seven of these ten states it be proclaim to be a part of the constitution of the united states and slavery be declare no long to exist within the united states or any place subject to their jurisdiction if these seven state be not legal states of the union it follow as an inevitable consequence that in some of the states slavery yet exist it do not exist in these seven states for they have abolish it also in their state constitution but kentucky not having do so it would still remain in that state but in truth if this assumption that these states have no legal state government be true then the abolition of slavery by these illegal government bind no one for congress now deny to these states the power to abolish slavery by deny to they the power to elect a legal state legislature or to frame a constitution for any purpose even for such a purpose as the abolition of slavery
 as to the other constitutional amendment have reference to suffrage it happen that these states have not accept it the consequence be that it have never be proclaim or understand even by congress to be a part of the constitution of the united states the senate of the united states have repeatedly give its sanction to the appointment of judge district attorney and marshal for every one of these states yet if they be not legal state not one of these judge be authorize to hold a court so too both houses of congress have pass appropriation bill to pay all these judge attorney and officer of the united states for exercise their function in these states again in the machinery of the internal revenue law all these state be district not as territories but as states
 so much for continuous legislative recognition the instance cite however fall far short of all that might be enumerate executive recognition as be well know have be frequent and unwavering the same may be say as to judicial recognition through the supreme court of the united states that august tribunal from first to last in the administration of its duty in banc and upon the circuit have never fail to recognize these ten community as legal states of the union the case depend in that court upon appeal and writ of error from these states when the rebellion begin have not be dismiss upon any idea of the cessation of jurisdiction they be carefully continue from term to term until the rebellion be entirely subdue and peace reestablish and then they be call for argument and consideration as if no insurrection have intervene new case occur since the rebellion have come from these states before that court by writ of error and appeal and even by original suit where only a state can bring such a suit these case be entertain by that tribunal in the exercise of its acknowledge jurisdiction which could not attach to they if they have come from any political body other than a state of the union finally in the allotment of their circuit make by the judge at the december term 1865 every one of these states be put on the same footing of legality with all the other states of the union virginia and north carolina be a part of the fourth circuit be allot to the chief justice south carolina georgia alabama mississippi and florida constitute the fifth circuit and be allot to the late mr. justice wayne louisiana arkansas and texas be allot to the sixth judicial circuit as to which there be a vacancy on the bench
 the chief justice in the exercise of his circuit duty have recently hold a circuit court in the state of north carolina if north carolina be not a state of this union the chief justice have no authority to hold a court there and every order judgment and decree render by he in that court be coram non judice and void
 another ground on which these reconstruction act be attempt to be sustain be this that these ten state be conquer territory that the constitutional relation in which they stand as states toward the federal government prior to the rebellion have give place to a new relation that their territory be a conquered country and their citizen a conquered people and that in this new relation congress can govern they by military power
 a title by conquest stand on clear ground it be a new title acquire by war it apply only to territory for good or movable thing regularly capture in war be call booty or if take by individual soldier plunder
 there be not a foot of the land in any one of these ten states which the united states hold by conquest save only such land as do not belong to either of these states or to any individual owner i mean such land as do belong to the pretended government call the confederate states these land we may claim to hold by conquest as to all other land or territory whether belong to the states or to individual the federal government have now no more title or right to it than it have before the rebellion our own fort arsenal navy yard custom house and other federal property situate in those state we now hold not by the title of conquest but by our old title acquire by purchase or condemnation for public use with compensation to former owner we have not conquer these place but have simply repossess they
 if we require more site for fort custom house or other public use we must acquire the title to they by purchase or appropriation in the regular mode at this moment the united states in the acquisition of site for national cemetery in these states acquire title in the same way the federal court sit in court house own or lease by the united states not in the court house of the states the united states pay each of these states for the use of its jail finally the united states levy its direct taxis and its internal revenue upon the property in these state include the production of the land within their territorial limit not by way of levy and contribution in the character of a conqueror but in the regular way of taxation under the same law which apply to all the other states of the union
 from first to last during the rebellion and since the title of each of these states to the land and public building own by they have never be disturb and not a foot of it have ever be acquire by the united states even under a title by confiscation and not a foot of it have ever be tax under federal law
 in conclusion i must respectfully ask the attention of congress to the consideration of one more question arise under this bill it vest in the military commander subject only to the approval of the general of the army of the united states an unlimited power to remove from office any civil or military officer in each of these ten states and the further power subject to the same approval to detail or appoint any military officer or soldier of the united states to perform the duty of the officer so removed and to fill all vacancy occur in those states by death resignation or otherwise
 the military appointee thus require to perform the duty of a civil office accord to the law of the state and as such require to take an oath be for the time be a civil officer what be his character be he a civil officer of the state or a civil officer of the united states if he be a civil officer of the state where be the federal power under our constitution which authorize his appointment by any federal officer if however he be to be consider a civil officer of the united states as his appointment and oath would seem to indicate where be the authority for his appointment vest by the constitution the power of appointment of all officer of the united states civil or military where not provide for in the constitution be vest in the president by and with the advice and consent of the senate with this exception that congress may by law vest the appointment of such inferior officer as they think proper in the president alone in the court of law or in the head of department but this bill if these be to be consider inferior officer within the meaning of the constitution do not provide for their appointment by the president alone or by the court of law or by the head of departments but vest the appointment in one subordinate executive officer subject to the approval of another subordinate executive officer so that if we put this question and fix the character of this military appointee either way this provision of the bill be equally opposed to the constitution
 take the case of a soldier or officer appoint to perform the office of judge in one of these states and as such to administer the proper law of the state where be the authority to be find in the constitution for vest in a military or an executive officer strict judicial function to be exercise under state law it have be again and again decide by the supreme court of the united states that act of congress which have attempt to vest executive power in the judicial court or judge of the united states be not warrant by the constitution if congress can not clothe a judge with merely executive duty how can they clothe an officer or soldier of the army with judicial duty over citizen of the united states who be not in the military or naval service so too it have be repeatedly decide that congress can not require a state officer executive or judicial to perform any duty enjoin upon he by a law of the united states how then can congress confer power upon an executive officer of the united states to perform such duty in a state if congress could not vest in a judge of one of these states any judicial authority under the united states by direct enactment how can it accomplish the same thing indirectly by remove the state judge and put an officer of the united states in his place
 to i these consideration be conclusive of the unconstitutionality of this part of the bill now before i and i earnestly commend their consideration to the deliberate judgment of congress
 within a period less than a year the legislation of congress have attempt to strip the executive department of the government of some of its essential power the constitution and the oath provide in it devolve upon the president the power and duty to see that the law be faithfully execute the constitution in order to carry out this power give he the choice of the agent and make they subject to his control and supervision but in the execution of these law the constitutional obligation upon the president remain but the power to exercise that constitutional duty be effectually take away the military commander be as to the power of appointment make to take the place of the president and the general of the army the place of the senate and any attempt on the part of the president to assert his own constitutional power may under pretense of law be meet by official insubordination it be to be fear that these military officer look to the authority give by these law rather than to the letter of the constitution will recognize no authority but the commander of the district and the general of the army
 if there be no other objection than this to this propose legislation it would be sufficient whilst i hold the chief executive authority of the united states whilst the obligation rest upon i to see that all the law be faithfully execute i can never willingly surrender that trust or the power give for its execution i can never give my assent to be make responsible for the faithful execution of law and at the same time surrender that trust and the power which accompany it to any other executive officer high or low or to any number of executive officer if this executive trust vest by the constitution in the president be to be take from he and vest in a subordinate officer the responsibility will be with congress in clothing the subordinate with unconstitutional power and with the officer who assume its exercise
 this interference with the constitutional authority of the executive department be an evil that will inevitably sap the foundation of our federal system but it be not the bad evil of this legislation it be a great public wrong to take from the president power confer on he alone by the constitution but the wrong be more flagrant and more dangerous when the power so take from the president be confer upon subordinate executive officer and especially upon military officer over nearly one third of the states of the union military power regulate by no fix law rule supreme each one of the five district commander though not choose by the people or responsible to they exercise at this hour more executive power military and civil than the people have ever be willing to confer upon the head of the executive department though choose by and responsible to themselves the remedy must come from the people themselves they know what it be and how it be to be apply at the present time they can not accord to the form of the constitution repeal these law they can not remove or control this military despotism the remedy be nevertheless in their hand it be to be find in the ballot and be a sure one if not control by fraud overawe by arbitrary power or from apathy on their part too long delay with abide confidence in their patriotism wisdom and integrity i be still hopeful of the future and that in the end the rod of despotism will be break the armed heel of power lift from the neck of the people and the principle of a violate constitution preserve

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas in the month of july a. d. 1861 the two houses of congress with extraordinary unanimity solemnly declare that the war then exist be not wage on the part of the government in any spirit of oppression nor for any purpose of conquest or subjugation nor purpose of overthrow or interfere with the right or establish institution of the states but to defend and maintain the supremacy of the constitution and to preserve the union with all the dignity equality and right of the several states unimpaire and that as soon as these object should be accomplish the war ought to cease and
 whereas the president of the united states on the 8th day of december a. d. 1863 and on the 26th day of march a. d. 1864 do with the object of suppress the then exist rebellion of induce all person to return to their loyalty and of restore the authority of the united states issue proclamation offer amnesty and pardon to all person who have directly or indirectly participate in the then exist rebellion except as in those proclamation be specify and reserve and
 whereas the president of the united states do on the 29th day of may a. d. 1865 issue a further proclamation with the same object before mention and to the end that the authority of the government of the united states might be restore and that peace order and freedom might be establish and the president do by the say last mention proclamation proclaim and declare that he thereby grant to all person who have directly or indirectly participate in the then exist rebellion except as therein excepted amnesty and pardon with restoration of all right of property except as to slave and except in certain case where legal proceeding have be institute but upon condition that such person should take and subscribe an oath therein prescribed which oath should be register for permanent preservation and
 whereas in and by the say last mention proclamation of the 29th day of may a. d. 1865 fourteen extensive class of person therein specially describe be altogether except and exclude from the benefit thereof and
 whereas the president of the united states do on the 2d day of april a. d. 1866 issue a proclamation declare that the insurrection be at an end and be thenceforth to be so regard and
 whereas there now exist no organized armed resistance of misguided citizen or other to the authority of the united states in the states of georgia south carolina virginia north carolina tennessee alabama louisiana arkansas mississippi florida and texas and the law can be sustain and enforce therein by the proper civil authority state or federal and the people of say states be well and loyally dispose and have conform or if permit to do so will conform in their legislation to the condition of affair grow out of the amendment to the constitution of the united states prohibit slavery within the limit and jurisdiction of the united states and
 whereas there no long exist any reasonable ground to apprehend within the states which be involve in the late rebellion any renewal thereof or any unlawful resistance by the people of say states to the constitution and law of the united states and
 whereas large stand army military occupation martial law military tribunal and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus and the right of trial by jury be in time of peace dangerous to public liberty incompatible with the individual right of the citizen contrary to the genius and spirit of our free institution and exhaustive of the national resource and ought not therefore to be sanction or allow except in case of actual necessity for repel invasion or suppress insurrection or rebellion and
 whereas a retaliatory or vindictive policy attend by unnecessary disqualification pain penalty confiscation and disfranchisement now as always could only tend to hinder reconciliation among the people and national restoration while it must seriously embarrass obstruct and repress popular energy and national industry and enterprise and
 whereas for these reason it be now deem essential to the public welfare and to the more perfect restoration of constitutional law and order that the say last mention proclamation so as aforesaid issue on the 29th day of may a. d. 1865 should be modify and that the full and beneficent pardon concede thereby should be open and far extend to a large number of the person who by its aforesaid exception have be hitherto exclude from executive clemency
 now therefore be it know that i andrew johnson president of the united states do hereby proclaim and declare that the full pardon describe in the say proclamation of the 29th day of may a. d. 1865 shall henceforth be open and extend to all person who directly or indirectly participate in the late rebellion with the restoration of all privilege immunity and right of property except as to property with regard to slave and except in case of legal proceeding under the law of the united states but upon this condition nevertheless that every such person who shall seek to avail himself of this proclamation shall take and subscribe the follow oath and shall cause the same to be register for permanent preservation in the same manner and with the same effect as with the oath prescribed in the say proclamation of the 29th day of may 1865 namely
 i do solemnly swear or affirm in presence of almighty god that i will henceforth faithfully support protect and defend the constitution of the united states and the union of the states thereunder and that i will in like manner abide by and faithfully support all law and proclamation which have be make during the late rebellion with reference to the emancipation of slave so help i god
 the follow person and no other be exclude from the benefit of this proclamation and of the say proclamation of the 29th day of may 1865 namely
 first the chief or pretended chief executive officer include the president the vice president and all head of department of the pretend confederate or rebel government and all who be agent thereof in foreign state and country and all who hold or pretend to hold in the service of the say pretend confederate government a military rank or title above the grade of brigadier general or naval rank or title above that of captain and all who be or pretend to be governor of states while maintain aid abet or submit to and acquiesce in the rebellion
 second all person who in any way treat otherwise than as lawful prisoner of war person who in any capacity be employ or engage in the military or naval service of the united states
 third all person who at the time they may seek to obtain the benefit of this proclamation be actually in civil military or naval confinement or custody or legally hold to bail either before or after conviction and all person who be engage directly or indirectly in the assassination of the late president of the united states or in any plot or conspiracy in any manner therewith connect
 in testimony whereof i have sign these present with my hand and have cause the seal of the united states to be hereunto affix
 do at the city of washington the 7th day of september a. d. 1867 and of the independence of the united states of america the ninety second
 andrew johnson
 by the president
 william h. seward
 secretary of state

fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives
 the continue disorganization of the union to which the president have so often call the attention of congress be yet a subject of profound and patriotic concern we may however find some relief from that anxiety in the reflection that the painful political situation although before untried by ourselves be not new in the experience of nation political science perhaps as highly perfect in our own time and country as in any other have not yet disclose any mean by which civil war can be absolutely prevent an enlightened nation however with a wise and beneficent constitution of free government may diminish their frequency and mitigate their severity by direct all its proceeding in accordance with its fundamental law
 when a civil war have be bring to a close it be manifestly the first interest and duty of the state to repair the injury which the war have inflict and to secure the benefit of the lesson it teach as fully and as speedily as possible this duty be upon the termination of the rebellion promptly accept not only by the executive department but by the insurrectionary states themselves and restoration in the first moment of peace be believe to be as easy and certain as it be indispensable the expectation however then so reasonably and confidently entertain be disappoint by legislation from which i feel constrain by my obligation to the constitution to withhold my assent
 it be therefore a source of profound regret that in comply with the obligation impose upon the president by the constitution to give to congress from time to time information of the state of the union i be unable to communicate any definitive adjustment satisfactory to the american people of the question which since the close of the rebellion have agitate the public mind on the contrary candor compel i to declare that at this time there be no union as our father understand the term and as they mean it to be understand by we the union which they establish can exist only where all the states be represent in both houses of congress where one state be as free as another to regulate its internal concern accord to its own will and where the law of the central government strictly confine to matter of national jurisdiction apply with equal force to all the people of every section that such be not the present state of the union be a melancholy fact and we must all acknowledge that the restoration of the states to their proper legal relation with the federal government and with one another accord to the term of the original compact would be the great temporal blessing which god in his kind providence could bestow upon this nation it become our imperative duty to consider whether or not it be impossible to effect this most desirable consummation
 the union and the constitution be inseparable as long as one be obey by all party the other will be preserve and if one be destroy both must perish together the destruction of the constitution will be follow by other and still great calamity it be ordain not only to form a more perfect union between the states but to establish justice insure domestic tranquillity provide for the common defense promote the general welfare and secure the blessing of liberty to ourselves and our posterity nothing but implicit obedience to its requirement in all part of the country will accomplish these great end without that obedience we can look forward only to continual outrage upon individual right incessant breach of the public peace national weakness financial dishonor the total loss of our prosperity the general corruption of moral and the final extinction of popular freedom to save our country from evil so appalling as these we should renew our effort again and again
 to i the process of restoration seem perfectly plain and simple it consist merely in a faithful application of the constitution and law the execution of the law be not now obstruct or oppose by physical force there be no military or other necessity real or pretend which can prevent obedience to the constitution either north or south all the right and all the obligation of states and individual can be protect and enforce by mean perfectly consistent with the fundamental law the court may be everywhere open and if open their process would be unimpeded crime against the united states can be prevent or punish by the proper judicial authority in a manner entirely practicable and legal there be therefore no reason why the constitution should not be obey unless those who exercise its power have determine that it shall be disregard and violate the mere naked will of this government or of some one or more of its branch be the only obstacle that can exist to a perfect union of all the states
 on this momentous question and some of the measure grow out of it i have have the misfortune to differ from congress and have express my conviction without reserve though with become deference to the opinion of the legislative department those conviction be not only unchanged but strengthen by subsequent event and further reflection the transcendent importance of the subject will be a sufficient excuse for call your attention to some of the reason which have so strongly influence my own judgment the hope that we may all finally concur in a mode of settlement consistent at once with our true interest and with our sworn duty to the constitution be too natural and too just to be easily relinquish
 it be clear to my apprehension that the states lately in rebellion be still member of the national union when do they cease to be so the ordinance of secession adopt by a portion in most of they a very small portion of their citizen be mere nullity if we admit now that they be valid and effectual for the purpose intend by their author we sweep from under our foot the whole ground upon which we justify the war be those states afterwards expel from the union by the war the direct contrary be aver by this government to be its purpose and be so understand by all those who give their blood and treasure to aid in its prosecution it can not be that a successful war wage for the preservation of the union have the legal effect of dissolve it the victory of the nation&#39;s arm be not the disgrace of her policy the defeat of secession on the battlefield be not the triumph of its lawless principle nor could congress with or without the consent of the executive do anything which would have the effect directly or indirectly of separate the states from each other to dissolve the union be to repeal the constitution which hold it together and that be a power which do not belong to any department of this government or to all of they unite
 this be so plain that it have be acknowledge by all branch of the federal government the executive my predecessor as well as myself and the head of all the departments have uniformly act upon the principle that the union be not only undissolve but indissoluble congress submit an amendment of the constitution to be ratify by the southern states and accept their act of ratification as a necessary and lawful exercise of their high function if they be not states or be states out of the union their consent to a change in the fundamental law of the union would have be nugatory and congress in ask it commit a political absurdity the judiciary have also give the solemn sanction of its authority to the same view of the case the judge of the supreme court have include the southern states in their circuit and they be constantly in banc and elsewhere exercise jurisdiction which do not belong to they unless those state be states of the union
 if the southern states be component part of the union the constitution be the supreme law for they as it be for all the other states they be bind to obey it and so be we the right of the federal government which be clear and unquestionable to enforce the constitution upon they imply the correlative obligation on our part to observe its limitation and execute its guaranty without the constitution we be nothing by through and under the constitution we be what it make we we may doubt the wisdom of the law we may not approve of its provision but we can not violate it merely because it seem to confine our power within limit narrower than we could wish it be not a question of individual or class or sectional interest much less of party predominance but of duty of high and sacred duty which we be all swear to perform if we can not support the constitution with the cheerful alacrity of those who love and believe in it we must give to it at least the fidelity of public servant who act under solemn obligation and command which they dare not disregard

 at the beginning of the rebellion the bank note circulation of the country amount to not much more than $ 200,000,000 now the circulation of national bank note and those know as legal tender be nearly seven hundred million while it be urge by some that this amount should be increase other contend that a decide reduction be absolutely essential to the good interest of the country in view of these diverse opinion it may be well to ascertain the real value of our paper issue when compare with a metallic or convertible currency for this purpose let we inquire how much gold and silver could be purchase by the seven hundred million of paper money now in circulation probably not more than half the amount of the latter show that when our paper currency be compare with gold and silver its commercial value be compress into three hundred and fifty million this striking fact make it the obvious duty of the government as early as may be consistent with the principle of sound political economy to take such measure as will enable the holder of its note and those of the national bank to convert they without loss into specie or its equivalent a reduction of our paper circulate medium need not necessarily follow this however would depend upon the law of demand and supply though it should be bear in mind that by make legal tender and bank note convertible into coin or its equivalent their present specie value in the hand of their holder would be enhance 100 per cent

 the feasibility of make our currency correspond with the constitutional standard may be see by reference to a few fact derive from our commercial statistic
 the production of precious metal in the united states from 1849 to 1857 inclusive amount to $ 579,000,000 from 1858 to 1860 inclusive to $ 137,500,000 and from 1861 to 1867 inclusive to $ 457,500,000 -making the grand aggregate of product since 1849 $ 1,174,000,000 the amount of specie coin from 1849 to 1857 inclusive be $ 439,000,000 from 1858 to 1860 inclusive $ 125,000,000 and from 1861 to 1867 inclusive $ 310,000,000 -making the total coinage since 1849 $ 874,000,000 from 1849 to 1857 inclusive the net export of specie amount to $ 271,000,000 from 1858 to 1860 inclusive to $ 148,000,000 and from 1861 to 1867 inclusive $ 322,000,000 -making the aggregate of net export since 1849 $ 741,000,000 these figure show an excess of product over net export of $ 433,000,000 there be in the treasury $ 111,000,000 in coin something more than $ 40,000,000 in circulation on the pacific coast and a few million in the national and other bank in all about $ 160,000,000 this however take into account the specie in the country prior to 1849 leave more than $ 300,000,000 which have not be account for by exportation and therefore may yet remain in the country
 these be important fact and show how completely the inferior currency will supersede the well force it from circulation among the masse and cause it to be export as a mere article of trade to add to the money capital of foreign land they show the necessity of retire our paper money that the return of gold and silver to the avenue of trade may be invite and a demand create which will cause the retention at home of at least so much of the production of our rich and inexhaustible gold bear field as may be sufficient for purpose of circulation it be unreasonable to expect a return to a sound currency so long as the government by continue to issue irredeemable note fill the channel of circulation with depreciated paper notwithstanding a coinage by our mint since 1849 of $ 874,000,000 the people be now stranger to the currency which be design for their use and benefit and specimen of the precious metal bear the national device be seldom see except when produce to gratify the interest excite by their novelty if depreciated paper be to be continue as the permanent currency of the country and all our coin be to become a mere article of traffic and speculation to the enhancement in price of all that be indispensable to the comfort of the people it would be wise economy to abolish our mint thus save the nation the care and expense incident to such establishment and let all our precious metal be export in bullion the time have come however when the government and national bank should be require to take the most efficient step and make all necessary arrangement for a resumption of specie payment at the early practicable period specie payment having be once resume by the government and bank all note or bill of paper issue by either of a less denomination than $ 20 should by law be exclude from circulation so that the people may have the benefit and convenience of a gold and silver currency which in all their business transaction will be uniform in value at home and abroad
 every man of property or industry every man who desire to preserve what he honestly possess or to obtain what he can honestly earn have a direct interest in maintain a safe circulate medium such a medium as shall be real and substantial not liable to vibrate with opinion not subject to be blow up or blow down by the breath of speculation but to be make stable and secure a disordered currency be one of the great political evil it undermine the virtue necessary for the support of the social system and encourage propensity destructive of its happiness it war against industry frugality and economy and it foster the evil spirit of extravagance and speculation
 it have be assert by one of our profound and most gifted statesman that--
 of all the contrivance for cheat the labor class of mankind none have be more effectual than that which delude they with paper money this be the most effectual of invention to fertilize the rich man&#39;s field by the sweat of the poor man&#39;s brow ordinary tyranny oppression excessive taxation these bear lightly on the happiness of the mass of the community compare with a fraudulent currency and the robbery commit by depreciated paper our own history have record for our instruction enough and more than enough of the demoralizing tendency the injustice and the intolerable oppression on the virtuous and well disposed of a degraded paper currency authorize by law or in any way countenance by government
 it be one of the most successful device in time of peace or war expansion or revulsion to accomplish the transfer of all the precious metal from the great mass of the people into the hand of the few where they be hoard in secret place or deposit in strong box under bolt and bar while the people be leave to endure all the inconvenience sacrifice and demoralization result from the use of a depreciated and worthless paper money
 the condition of our finance and the operation of our revenue system be set forth and fully explain in the able and instructive report of the secretary of the treasury on the 30th of june 1866 the public debt amount to $ 2,783,425,879 on the 30th of june last it be $ 2,692,199,215 show a reduction during the fiscal year of $ 91,226,664 during the fiscal year end june 30 1867 the receipt be $ 490,634,010 and the expenditure $ 346,729,129 leave an available surplus of $ 143,904,880 it be estimate that the receipt for the fiscal year end june 30 1868 will be $ 417,161,928 and that the expenditure will reach the sum of $ 393,269,226 leave in the treasury a surplus of $ 23,892,702 for the fiscal year end june 30 1869 it be estimate that the receipt will amount to $ 381,000,000 and that the expenditure will be $ 372,000,000 show an excess of $ 9,000,000 in favor of the government
 the attention of congress be earnestly invite to the necessity of a thorough revision of our revenue system our internal revenue law and impost system should be so adjusted as to bear most heavily on article of luxury leave the necessary of life as free from taxation as may be consistent with the real want of the government economically administer taxation would not then fall unduly on the man of moderate mean and while none would be entirely exempt from assessment all in proportion to their pecuniary ability would contribute toward the support of the state a modification of the internal revenue system by a large reduction in the number of article now subject to tax would be follow by result equally advantageous to the citizen and the government it would render the execution of the law less expensive and more certain remove obstruction to industry lessen the temptation to evade the law diminish the violation and fraud perpetrate upon its provision make its operation less inquisitorial and greatly reduce in number the army of taxgatherer create by the system who take from the mouth of honest labor the bread it have earn retrenchment reform and economy should be carry into every branch of the public service that the expenditure of the government may be reduce and the people relieve from oppressive taxation a sound currency should be restore and the public faith in regard to the national debt sacredly observe the accomplishment of these important result together with the restoration of the union of the states upon the principle of the constitution would inspire confidence at home and abroad in the stability of our institution and bring to the nation prosperity peace and good will
