 the reestablishment of peace at home and the resumption of extended trade travel and commerce abroad have serve to increase the number and variety of question in the department for foreign affairs none of these question however have seriously disturb our relation with other state
 the republic of mexico having be relieve from foreign intervention be earnestly engage in effort to reestablish her constitutional system of government a good understanding continue to exist between our government and the republics of hayti and san domingo and our cordial relation with the central and south american states remain unchanged the tender make in conformity with a resolution of congress of the good office of the government with a view to an amicable adjustment of peace between brazil and her ally on one side and paraguay on the other and between chile and her ally on the one side and spain on the other though kindly receive have in neither case be fully accept by the belligerent the war in the valley of the parana be still vigorously maintain on the other hand actual hostility between the pacific states and spain have be more than a year suspend i shall on any proper occasion that may occur renew the conciliatory recommendation which have be already make brazil with enlightened sagacity and comprehensive statesmanship have open the great channel of the amazon and its tributary to universal commerce one thing more seem needful to assure a rapid and cheer progress in south america i refer to those peaceful habit without which state and nation can not in this age well expect material prosperity or social advancement
 the exposition of universal industry at paris have pass and seem to have fully realize the high expectation of the french government if due allowance be make for the recent political derangement of industry here the part which the united states have bear in this exhibition of invention and art may be regard with very high satisfaction during the exposition a conference be hold of delegate from several nation the united states be one in which the inconvenience of commerce and social intercourse result from the diverse standard of money value be very fully discuss and plan be develop for establish by universal consent a common principle for the coinage of gold these conference be expect to be renew with the attendance of many foreign state not hitherto represent a report of these interesting proceeding will be submit to congress which will no doubt justly appreciate the great object and be ready to adopt any measure which may tend to facilitate its ultimate accomplishment
 on the 25th of february 1862 congress declare by law that treasury note without interest authorize by that act should be legal tender in payment of all debt public and private within the united states an annual remittance of $ 30,000 less stipulate expense accrue to claimant under the convention make with spain in 1834 these remittance since the passage of that act have be pay in such note the claimant insist that the government ought to require payment in coin the subject may be deem worthy of your attention
 no arrangement have yet be reach for the settlement of our claim for british depredation upon the commerce of the united states i have feel it my duty to decline the proposition of arbitration make by her majesty&#39;s government because it have hitherto be accompany by reservation and limitation incompatible with the right interest and honor of our country it be not to be apprehend that great britain will persist in her refusal to satisfy these just and reasonable claim which involve the sacred principle of nonintervention a principle henceforth not more important to the united states than to all other commercial nation
 the west india island be settle and colonize by european states simultaneously with the settlement and colonization of the american continent most of the colony plant here become independent nation in the close of the last and the beginning of the present century our own country embrace community which at one period be colony of great britain france spain holland sweden and russia the people in the west indies with the exception of those of the island of hayti have neither attain nor aspire to independence nor have they become prepared for self defense although possess considerable commercial value they have be hold by the several european states which colonize or at some time conquer they chiefly for purpose of military and naval strategy in carry out european policy and design in regard to this continent in our revolutionary war port and harbor in the west india island be use by our enemy to the great injury and embarrassment of the united states we have the same experience in our second war with great britain the same european policy for a long time exclude we even from trade with the west indies while we be at peace with all nation in our recent civil war the rebel and their piratical and blockade break ally find facility in the same port for the work which they too successfully accomplish of injure and devastate the commerce which we be now engage in rebuilding we labor especially under this disadvantage that european steam vessel employ by our enemy find friendly shelter protection and supply in west indian port while our naval operation be necessarily carry on from our own distant shore there be then a universal feeling of the want of an advanced naval outpost between the atlantic coast and europe the duty of obtain such an outpost peacefully and lawfully while neither do nor menacing injury to other state earnestly engage the attention of the executive department before the close of the war and it have not be lose sight of since that time a not entirely dissimilar naval want reveal itself during the same period on the pacific coast the require foothold there be fortunately secure by our late treaty with the emperor of russia and it now seem imperative that the more obvious necessity of the atlantic coast should not be less carefully provide for a good and convenient port and harbor capable of easy defense will supply that want with the possession of such a station by the united states neither we nor any other american nation need long apprehend injury or offense from any transatlantic enemy i agree with our early statesman that the west indies naturally gravitate to and may be expect ultimately to be absorb by the continental states include our own i agree with they also that it be wise to leave the question of such absorption to this process of natural political gravitation the island of st. thomas and st. john which constitute a part of the group call the virgin islands seem to offer we advantage immediately desirable while their acquisition could be secure in harmony with the principle to which i have allude a treaty have therefore be conclude with the king of denmark for the cession of those island and will be submit to the senate for consideration
 it will hardly be necessary to call the attention of congress to the subject of provide for the payment to russia of the sum stipulate in the treaty for the cession of alaska possession having be formally deliver to our commissioner the territory remain for the present in care of a military force await such civil organization as shall be direct by congress
 the annexation of many small german states to prussia and the reorganization of that country under a new and liberal constitution have induce i to renew the effort to obtain a just and prompt settlement of the long vex question concern the claim of foreign state for military service from their subject naturalize in the united states
 in connection with this subject the attention of congress be respectfully call to a singular and embarrassing conflict of law the executive department of this government have hitherto uniformly hold as it now hold that naturalization in conformity with the constitution and law of the united states absolve the recipient from his native allegiance the court of great britain hold that allegiance to the british crown be indefensible and be not absolve by our law of naturalization british judge cite court and law authority of the united states in support of that theory against the position hold by the executive authority of the united states this conflict perplex the public mind concern the right of naturalized citizen and impairs the national authority abroad i call attention to this subject in my last annual message and now again respectfully appeal to congress to declare the national will unmistakably upon this important question
 the abuse of our law by the clandestine prosecution of the african slave trade from american port or by american citizen have altogether cease and under exist circumstance no apprehension of its renewal in this part of the world be entertain under these circumstance it become a question whether we shall not propose to her majesty&#39;s government a suspension or discontinuance of the stipulation for maintain a naval force for the suppression of that trade

to the senate of the united states
 on the 12th of august last i suspend mr. stanton from the exercise of the office of secretary of war and on the same day designate general grant to act as secretary of war ad interim
 the follow be copy of the executive order
 executive mansion
 washington august 12 1867
 hon edwin m. stanton
 secretary of war
 sir by virtue of the power and authority vest in i as president by the constitution and law of the united states you be hereby suspend from office as secretary of war and will cease to exercise any and all function pertain to the same
 you will at once transfer to general ulysses s. grant who have this day be authorize and empower to act as secretary of war ad interim all record book and other property now in your custody and charge
 executive mansion
 washington d.c. august 12 1867
 general ulysses s. grant
 washington d.c.
 sir the hon edwin m. stanton having be this day suspend as secretary of war you be hereby authorize and empower to act as secretary of war ad interim and will at once enter upon the discharge of the duty of the office
 the secretary of war have be instruct to transfer to you all the record book paper and other public property now in his custody and charge
 the follow communication be receive from mr. stanton
 war department
 august 12 1867
 the president
 sir your note of this date have be receive inform i that by virtue of the power and authority vest in you as president by the constitution and law of the united states i be suspend from office as secretary of war and will cease to exercise any and all function pertain to the same and also direct i at once to transfer to general ulysses s. grant who have this day be authorize and empower to act as secretary of war ad interim all record book paper and other public property now in my custody and charge
 under a sense of public duty i be compel to deny your right under the constitution and law of the united states without the advice and consent of the senate and without any legal cause to suspend i from office as secretary of war or the exercise of any or all function pertain to the same or without such advice and consent to compel i to transfer to any person the record book paper and public property in my custody as secretary
 but inasmuch as the general command the army of the united states have be appoint ad interim and have notify i that he have accept the appointment i have no alternative but to submit under protest to superior force
 to the president
 the suspension have not be revoke and the business of the war department be conduct by the secretary ad interim
 prior to the date of this suspension i have come to the conclusion that the time have arrive when it be proper mr. stanton should retire from my cabinet the mutual confidence and general accord which should exist in such a relation have cease i suppose that mr. stanton be well advise that his continuance in the cabinet be contrary to my wish for i have repeatedly give he so to understand by every mode short of an express request that he should resign having wait full time for the voluntary action of mr. stanton and see no manifestation on his part of an intention to resign i address he the follow note on the 5th of august
 sir public consideration of a high character constrain i to say that your resignation as secretary of war will be accept
 to this note i receive the follow reply
 war department
 august 5 1867
 sir your note of this day have be receive state that public consideration of a high character constrain you to say that my resignation as secretary of war will be accept
 in reply i have the honor to say that public consideration of a high character which alone have induce i to continue at the head of this department constrain i not to resign the office of secretary of war before the next meeting of congress
 edwin m. stanton
 secretary of war
 this reply of mr. stanton be not merely a disinclination of compliance with the request for his resignation it be a defiance and something more mr. stanton do not content himself with assume that public consideration bear upon his continuance in office form as fully a rule of action for himself as for the president and that upon so delicate a question as the fitness of an officer for continuance in his office the officer be as competent and as impartial to decide as his superior who be responsible for his conduct but he go far and plainly intimate what he mean by public consideration of a high character and this be nothing else than his loss of confidence in his superior he say that these public consideration have alone induce i to continue at the head of this department and that they constrain i not to resign the office of secretary of war before the next meeting of congress
 this language be very significant mr. stanton hold the position unwillingly he continue in office only under a sense of high public duty he be ready to leave when it be safe to leave and as the danger he apprehend from his removal then will not exist when congress be here he be constrain to remain during the interim what then be that danger which can only be avert by the presence of mr. stanton or of congress mr. stanton do not say that public consideration of a high character constrain he to hold on to the office indefinitely he do not say that no one other than himself can at any time be find to take his place and perform its duty on the contrary he express a desire to leave the office at the early moment consistent with these high public consideration he say in effect that while congress be away he must remain but that when congress be here he can go in other word he have lose confidence in the president he be unwilling to leave the war department in his hand or in the hand of anyone the president may appoint or designate to perform its duty if he resign the president may appoint a secretary of war that mr. stanton do not approve therefore he will not resign but when congress be in session the president can not appoint a secretary of war which the senate do not approve consequently when congress meet mr. stanton be ready to resign
 whatever cogency these consideration may have have on mr. stanton whatever right he may have have to entertain such consideration whatever propriety there might be in the expression of they to other one thing be certain it be official misconduct to say the least of it to parade they before his superior officer
 upon the receipt of this extraordinary note i only delay the order of suspension long enough to make the necessary arrangement to fill the office if this be the only cause for his suspension it would be ample necessarily it must end our most important official relation for i can not imagine a degree of effrontery which would embolden the head of a department to take his seat at the council table in the executive mansion after such an act nor can i imagine a president so forgetful of the proper respect and dignity which belong to his office as to submit to such intrusion i will not do mr. stanton the wrong to suppose that he entertain any idea of offer to act as one of my constitutional adviser after that note be write there be an interval of a week between that date and the order of suspension during which two cabinet meeting be hold mr. stanton do not present himself at either nor be he expect
 on the 12th of august mr. stanton be notify of his suspension and that general grant have be authorize to take charge of the department in his answer to this notification of the same date mr. stanton express himself as follow
 ldquo;under a sense of public duty i be compel to deny your fight under the constitution and law of the united states without the advice and consent of the senate and without any legal cause to suspend i from office as secretary of war or the exercise of any or all function pertain to the same or without such advice and consent to compel i to transfer to any person the record book paper and public property in my custody as secretary
 but inasmuch as the general command the army of the united states have be appoint ad interim and have notify i that he have accept the appointment i have no alternative but to submit under protest to superior force.&rdquo
 it will not escape attention that in his note of august 5 mr. stanton state that he have be constrain to continue in the office even before he be request to resign by consideration of a high public character in this note of august 12 a new and different sense of public duty compel he to deny the president&#39;s right to suspend he from office without the consent of the senate this last be the public duty of resist an act contrary to law and he charge the president with violation of the law in order his suspension
 mr. stanton refer generally to the constitution and law of the united states and say that a sense of public duty under these compel he to deny the right of the president to suspend he from office as to his sense of duty under the constitution that will be consider in the sequel as to his sense of duty under the law of the united states he certainly can not refer to the law which create the war department for that expressly confer upon the president the unlimited right to remove the head of the department the only other law bear upon the question be the tenure of office act pass by congress over the presidential veto march 2 1867 this be the law which under a sense of public duty mr. stanton volunteer to defend
 there be no provision in this law which compel any officer come within its provision to remain in office it forbid removal not resignation mr. stanton be perfectly free to resign at any moment either upon his own motion or in compliance with a request or an order it be a matter of choice or of taste there be nothing compulsory in the nature of legal obligation nor do he put his action upon that imperative ground he say he act under a sense of public duty not of legal obligation compel he to hold on and leave he no choice the public duty which be upon he arise from the respect which he owe to the constitution and the law violate in his own case he be therefore compel by this sense of public duty to vindicate violate law and to stand as its champion
 this be not the first occasion in which mr. stanton in discharge of a public duty be call upon to consider the provision of that law that tenure of office law do not pass without notice like other act it be send to the president for approval as be my custom i submit its consideration to my cabinet for their advice upon the question whether i should approve it or not it be a grave question of constitutional law in which i would of course rely most upon the opinion of the attorney general and of mr. stanton who have once be attorney general
 every member of my cabinet advise i that the propose law be unconstitutional all speak without doubt or reservation but mr. stanton&#39;s condemnation of the law be the most elaborate and emphatic he refer to the constitutional provision the debate in congress especially to the speech of mr. buchanan when a senator to the decision of the supreme court and to the usage from the beginning of the government through every successive administration all concur to establish the right of removal as vest by the constitution in the president to all these he add the weight of his own deliberate judgment and advise i that it be my duty to defend the power of the president from usurpation and to veto the law
 i do not know when a sense of public duty be more imperative upon a head of department than upon such an occasion as this he act then under the grave obligation of law for when he be call upon by the president for advice it be the constitution which speak to he all his other duty be leave by the constitution to be regulate by statute but this duty be deem so momentous that it be impose by the constitution itself
 after all this i be not prepare for the ground take by mr. stanton in his note of august 12 i be not prepared to find he compel by a new and indefinite sense of public duty under the constitution to assume the vindication of a law which under the solemn obligation of public duty impose by the constitution itself he advise i be a violation of that constitution i make great allowance for a change of opinion but such a change as this hardly fall within the limit of great indulgence
 where our opinion take the shape of advice and influence the action of other the utmost stretch of charity will scarcely justify we in repudiate they when they come to be apply to ourselves
 but to proceed with the narrative i be so much strike with the full mastery of the question manifest by mr. stanton and be at the time so fully occupy with the preparation of another veto upon the pende reconstruction act that i request he to prepare the veto upon this tenure of office bill this he decline on the ground of physical disability to undergo at the time the labor of writing but state his readiness to furnish what aid might be require in the preparation of material for the paper
 at the time this subject be before the cabinet it seem to be take for grant that as to those member of the cabinet who have be appoint by mr. lincoln their tenure of office be not fix by the provision of the act i do not remember that the point be distinctly decide but i well recollect that it be suggest by one member of the cabinet who be appoint by mr. lincoln and that no dissent be express
 whether the point be well take or not do not seem to i of any consequence for the unanimous expression of opinion against the constitutionality and policy of the act be so decide that i feel no concern so far as the act have reference to the gentleman then present that i would be embarrassed in the future the bill have not then become a law the limitation upon the power of removal be not yet impose and there be yet time to make any change if any one of these gentleman have then say to i that he would avail himself of the provision of that bill in case it become a law i should not have hesitate a moment as to his removal no pledge be then expressly give or require but there be circumstance when to give an express pledge be not necessary and when to require it be an imputation of possible bad faith i feel that if these gentleman come within the purview of the bill it be as to they a dead letter and that none of they would ever take refuge under its provision
 i now pass to another subject when on the 15th of april 1865 the duty of the presidential office devolve upon i i find a full cabinet of seven member all of they select by mr. lincoln i make no change on the contrary i shortly afterwards ratify a change determine upon by mr. lincoln but not perfect at his death and admit his appointee mr. harlan in the place of mr. usher who be in office at the time
 the great duty of the time be to reestablish government law and order in the insurrectionary states congress be then in recess and the sudden overthrow of the rebellion require speedy action this grave subject have engage the attention of mr. lincoln in the last day of his life and the plan accord to which it be to be manage have be prepare and be ready for adoption a lead feature of that plan be that it should be carry out by the executive authority for so far as i have be inform neither mr. lincoln nor any member of his cabinet doubt his authority to act or propose to call an extra session of congress to do the work the first business transact in cabinet after i become president be this unfinished business of my predecessor a plan or scheme of reconstruction be produce which have be prepare for mr. lincoln by mr. stanton his secretary of war it be approve and at the early moment practicable be apply in the form of a proclamation to the state of north carolina and afterwards become the basis of action in turn for the other states
 upon the examination of mr. stanton before the impeachment committee he be ask the follow question
 ldquo;did any one of the cabinet express a doubt of the power of the executive branch of the government to reorganize state government which have be in rebellion without the aid of congress?&rdquo
 he answer
 ldquo;none whatever i have myself entertain no doubt of the authority of the president to take measure for the organization of the rebel states on the plan propose during the vacation of congress and agree in the plan specify in the proclamation in the case of north carolina.&rdquo
 there be perhaps no act of my administration for which i have be more denounced than this it be not originate by i but i shrink from no responsibility on that account for the plan approve itself to my own judgment and i do not hesitate to carry it into execution
 thus far and upon this vital policy there be perfect accord between the cabinet and myself and i see no necessity for a change as time pass on there be develop an unfortunate difference of opinion and of policy between congress and the president upon this same subject and upon the ultimate basis upon which the reconstruction of these states should proceed especially upon the question of negro suffrage upon this point three member of the cabinet find themselves to be in sympathy with congress they remain only long enough to see that the difference of policy could not be reconcile they feel that they should remain no long and a high sense of duty and propriety constrain they to resign their position we part with mutual respect for the sincerity of each other in opposite opinion and mutual regret that the difference be on point so vital as to require a severance of official relation this be in the summer of 1866 the subsequent session of congress develop new complication when the suffrage bill for the district of columbia and the reconstruction act of march 2 and march 23 1867 all pass over the veto it be in cabinet consultation upon these bill that a difference of opinion upon the most vital point be develop upon these question there be perfect accord between all the member of the cabinet and myself except mr. stanton he stand alone and the difference of opinion could not be reconcile that unity of opinion which upon great question of public policy or administration be so essential to the executive be go
 i do not claim that a head of department should have no other opinion than those of the president he have the same right in the conscientious discharge of duty to entertain and express his own opinion as have the president what i do claim be that the president be the responsible head of the administration and when the opinion of a head of department be irreconcilably oppose to those of the president in grave matter of policy and administration there be but one result which can solve the difficulty and that be a severance of the official relation this in the past history of the government have always be the rule and it be a wise one for such difference of opinion among its member must impair the efficiency of any administration
 i have now refer to the general ground upon which the withdrawal of mr. stanton from my administration seem to i to be proper and necessary but i can not omit to state a special ground which if it stand alone would vindicate my action
 the sanguinary riot which occur in the city of new orleans on the 30th of august 1866 justly arouse public indignation and public inquiry not only as to those who be engage in it but as to those who more or less remotely might be hold to responsibility for its occurrence i need not remind the senate of the effort make to fix that responsibility on the president the charge be openly make and again and again reiterate all through the land that the president be warn in time but refuse to interfere
 by telegram from the lieutenant governor and attorney general of louisiana date the 27th and 28th of august i be advise that a body of delegate claim to be a constitutional convention be about to assemble in new orleans that the matter be before the grand jury but that it would be impossible to execute civil process without a riot and this question be ask
 ldquo;is the military to interfere to prevent process of court?&rdquo
 this question be ask at a time when the civil court be in the full exercise of their authority and the answer send by telegraph on the same 28th of august be this
 ldquo;the military will be expect to sustain and not to interfere with the proceeding of the courts.&rdquo
 on the same 28th of august the follow telegram be send to mr. stanton by major general baird then owe to the absence of general sheridan in command of the military at new orleans
 hon edwin m. stanton
 secretary of war
 a convention have be call with the sanction of governor wells to meet here on monday the lieutenant governor and city authority think it unlawful and propose to break it up by arrest the delegate i have give no order on the subject but have warn the party that i could not countenance or permit such action without instruction to that effect from the president please instruct i at once by telegraph
 the 28th of august be on saturday the next morning the 29th this dispatch be receive by mr. stanton at his residence in this city he take no action upon it and neither send instruction to general baird himself nor present it to i for such instruction on the next day monday the riot occur i never see this dispatch from general baird until some ten day or two week after the riot when upon my call for all the dispatch with a view to their publication mr. stanton send it to i
 these fact all appear in the testimony of mr. stanton before the judiciary committee in the impeachment investigation
 on the 30th the day of the riot and after it be suppress general baird write to mr. stanton a long letter from which i make the follow extract
 ldquo;sir i have the honor to inform you that a very serious riot have occur here to day i have not be apply to by the convention for protection but the lieutenant governor and the mayor have freely consult with i and i be so fully convinced that it be so strongly the intent of the city authority to preserve the peace in order to prevent military interference that i do not regard an outbreak as a thing to be apprehend the lieutenant governor have assure i that even if a writ of arrest be issue by the court the sheriff would not attempt to serve it without my permission and for to day they design to suspend it i inclose herewith copy of my correspondence with the mayor and of a dispatch which the lieutenant governor claim to have receive from the president i regret that no reply to my dispatch to you of saturday have yet reach i general sheridan be still absent in texas.&rdquo
 the dispatch of general baird of the 28th ask for immediate instruction and his letter of the 30th after detail the terrible riot which have just happen end with the expression of regret that the instruction which he ask for be not send it be not the fault or the error or the omission of the president that this military commander be leave without instruction but for all omission for all error for all failure to instruct when instruction might have avert this calamity the president be openly and persistently hold responsible instantly without wait for proof the delinquency of the president be herald in every form of utterance mr. stanton know then that the president be not responsible for this delinquency the exculpation be in his power but it be not give by he to the public and only to the president in obedience to a requisition for all the dispatch
 no one regret more than myself that general baird&#39;s request be not bring to my notice it be clear from his dispatch and letter that if the secretary of war have give he proper instruction the riot which arise on the assembling of the convention would have be avert
 there may be those ready to say that i would have give no instruction even if the dispatch have reach i in time but all must admit that i ought to have have the opportunity
 the following be the testimony give by mr. stanton before the impeachment investigation committee as to this dispatch
 q. refer to the dispatch of the 28th of july by general baird i ask you whether that dispatch on its receipt be communicate
 a. i receive that dispatch on sunday forenoon i examine it carefully and consider the question present i do not see that i could give any instruction different from the line of action which general baird propose and make no answer to the dispatch
 q. i see it state that this be receive at 10.20 p.m. be that the hour at which it be receive by you
 a. that be the date of its reception in the telegraph office saturday night i receive it on sunday forenoon at my residence a copy of the dispatch be furnish to the president several day afterwards along with all the other dispatch and communication on that subject but it be not furnish by i before that time i suppose it may have be ten or fifteen day afterwards
 o. the president himself be in correspondence with those party upon the same subject would it not have be proper to have advise he of the reception of that dispatch
 a. i know nothing about his correspondence and know nothing about any correspondence except this one dispatch we have intelligence of the riot on thursday morning the riot have take place on monday
 it be a difficult matter to define all the relation which exist between the head of departments and the president the legal relation be well enough define the constitution place these officer in the relation of his adviser when he call upon they for advice the act of congress go far take for example the act of 1789 create the war department it provide that--
 ldquo;there shall be a principal officer therein to be call the secretary for the department of war who shall perform and execute such duty as shall from time to time be enjoin on or intrust to he by the president of the united states&rdquo and furthermore ldquo;the say principal officer shall conduct the business of the said department in such manner as the president of the united states shall from time to time order and instruct.&rdquo
 provision be also make for the appointment of an inferior officer by the head of the department to be call the chief clerk who whenever say principal officer shall be remove from office by the president of the united states shall have the charge and custody of the book record and paper of the department
 the legal relation be analogous to that of principal and agent it be the president upon whom the constitution devolve as head of the executive department the duty to see that the law be faithfully execute but as he can not execute they in person he be allow to select his agent and be make responsible for their act within just limit so complete be this presume delegation of authority in the relation of a head of department to the president that the supreme court of the united states have decide that an order make by a head of department be presume to be make by the president himself
 the principal upon whom such responsibility be place for the act of a subordinate ought to be leave as free as possible in the matter of selection and of dismissal to hold he to responsibility for an officer beyond his control to leave the question of the fitness of such an agent to be decide for he and not by he to allow such a subordinate when the president move by public consideration of a high character request his resignation to assume for himself an equal right to act upon his own view of public consideration and to make his own conclusion paramount to those of the president to allow all this be to reverse the just order of administration and to place the subordinate above the superior
 there be however other relation between the president and a head of department beyond these define legal relation which necessarily attend they though not express chief among these be mutual confidence this relation be so delicate that it be sometimes hard to say when or how it cease a single flagrant act may end it at once and then there be no difficulty but confidence may be just as effectually destroy by a series of cause too subtle for demonstration as it be a plant of slow growth so too it may be slow in decay such have be the process here i will not pretend to say what act or omission have break up this relation they be hardly susceptible of statement and still less of formal proof nevertheless no one can read the correspondence of the 5th of august without be convince that this relation be effectually go on both side and that while the president be unwilling to allow mr. stanton to remain in his administration mr. stanton be equally unwilling to allow the president to carry on his administration without his presence
 in the great debate which take place in the house of representatives in 1789 in the first organization of the principal departments mr. madison speak as follow
 ldquo;it be evidently the intention of the constitution that the first magistrate should be responsible for the executive department so far therefore as we do not make the officer who be to aid he in the duty of that department responsible to he he be not responsible to the country again be there no danger that an officer when he be appoint by the concurrence of the senate and have friend in that body may choose rather to risk his establishment on the favor of that branch than rest it upon the discharge of his duty to the satisfaction of the executive branch which be constitutionally authorize to inspect and control his conduct and if it should happen that the officer connect themselves with the senate they may mutually support each other and for want of efficacy reduce the power of the president to a vapor in which case his responsibility would be annihilate and the expectation of it be unjust the high executive officer join in cabal with the senate would lay the foundation of discord and end in an assumption of the executive power only to be remove by a revolution in the government.&rdquo
 mr. sedgwick in the same debate refer to the proposition that a head of department should only be remove or suspend by the concurrence of the senate use this language
 ldquo;but if proof be necessary what be then the consequence why in nine case out of ten where the case be very dear to the mind of the president that the man ought to be remove the effect can not be produce because it be absolutely impossible to produce the necessary evidence be the senate to proceed without evidence some gentleman contend not then the object will be lose shall a man under these circumstance be saddle upon the president who have be appoint for no other purpose but to aid the president in perform certain duty shall he be continue i ask again against the will of the president if he be where be the responsibility be you to look for it in the president who have no control over the officer no power to remove he if he act unfeelingly or unfaithfully without you make he responsible you weaken and destroy the strength and beauty of your system what be to be do in case which can only be know from a long acquaintance with the conduct of an officer?&rdquo
 i have indulge the hope that upon the assembling of congress mr. stanton would have end this unpleasant complication accord to his intimation give in his note of august 12 the duty which i have feel myself call upon to perform be by no mean agreeable but i feel that i be not responsible for the controversy or for the consequence
 unpleasant as this necessary change in my cabinet have be to i upon personal consideration i have the consolation to be assure that so far as the public interest be involve there be no cause for regret
 salutary reform have be introduce by the secretary ad interim and great reduction of expense have be effect under his administration of the war department to the saving of million to the treasury

 general the extraordinary character of your letter of the 3d instant would seem to preclude any reply on my part but the manner in which publicity have be give to the correspondence of which that letter form a part and the grave question which be involve induce i to take this mode of give as a proper sequel to the communication which have pass between we the statement of the five member of the cabinet who be present on the occasion of our conversation on the 14th ultimo copy of the letter which they have address to i upon the subject be accordingly herewith inclose
 you speak of my letter of the 31st ultimo as a reiteration of the many and gross misrepresentation contain in certain newspaper article and reassert the correctness of the statement contain in your communication of the 28th ultimo add and here i give your own words--"anything in yours in reply to it to the contrary notwithstanding
 when a controversy upon matter of fact reach the point to which this have be bring further assertion or denial between the immediate party should cease especially where upon either side it lose the character of the respectful discussion which be require by the relation in which the party stand to each other and degenerate in tone and temper in such a case if there be nothing to rely upon but the oppose statement conclusion must be draw from those statement alone and from whatever intrinsic probability they afford in favor of or against either of the party i should not shrink from this test in this controversy but fortunately it be not leave to this test alone there be five cabinet officer present at the conversation the detail of which in my letter of the 28th 31st ultimo you allow yourself to say contain many and gross misrepresentation these gentleman hear that conversation and have read my statement they speak for themselves and i leave the proof without a word of comment

 you say that a performance of the promise allege to have be make by you to the president would have involve a resistance to law and an inconsistency with the whole history of my connection with the suspension of mr. stanton you then state that you have fear the president would on the removal of mr. stanton appoint someone in his place who would embarrass the army in carry out the reconstruction act and add

 first of all you here admit that from the very beginning of what you term the whole history of your connection with mr. stanton&#39;s suspension you intend to circumvent the president it be to carry out that intent that you accept the appointment this be in your mind at the time of your acceptance it be not then in obedience to the order of your superior as have heretofore be suppose that you assume the duty of the office you know it be the president&#39;s purpose to prevent mr. stanton from resume the office of secretary of war and you intend to defeat that purpose you accept the office not in the interest of the president but of mr. stanton if this purpose so entertain by you have be confine to yourself if when accept the office you have do so with a mental reservation to frustrate the president it would have be a tacit deception in the ethic of some person such a course be allowable but you can not stand even upon that questionable ground the history of your connection with this transaction as write by yourself place you in a different predicament and show that you not only conceal your design from the president but induce he to suppose that you would carry out his purpose to keep mr. stanton out of office by retain it yourself after an attempt restoration by the senate so as to require mr. stanton to establish his right by judicial decision
 i now give that part of this history as write by yourself in your letter of the 28th ultimo
 some time after i assume the duty of secretary of war ad interim the president ask i my view as to the course mr. stanton would have to pursue in case the senate should not concur in his suspension to obtain possession of his office my reply be in substance that mr. stanton would have to appeal to the court to reinstate he illustrate my position by cite the ground i have take in the case of the baltimore police commissioner
 now at that time as you admit in your letter of the 3d instant you hold the office for the very object of defeat an appeal to the court in that letter you say that in accept the office one motive be to prevent the president from appoint some other person who would retain possession and thus make judicial proceeding necessary you know the president be unwilling to trust the office with anyone who would not by hold it compel mr. stanton to resort to the court you perfectly understand that in this interview some time after you accept the office the president not content with your silence desire an expression of your view and you answer he that mr. stanton would have to appeal to the court if the president repose confidence before he know your view and that confidence have be violate it might have be say he make a mistake but a violation of confidence repose after that conversation be no mistake of his nor of your it be the fact only that need be state that at the date of this conversation you do not intend to hold the office with the purpose of force mr. stanton into court but do hold it then and have accept it to prevent that course from be carry out in other word you say to the president that be the proper course and you say to yourself i have accept this office and now hold it to defeat that course the excuse you make in a subsequent paragraph of that letter of the 28th ultimo that afterwards you change your view as to what would be a proper course have nothing to do with the point now under consideration the point be that before you change your view you have secretly determine to do the very thing which at last you do surrender the office to mr. stanton you may have change your view as to the law but you certainly do not change your view as to the course you have mark out for yourself from the beginning
 i will only notice one more statement in your letter of the 3d instant that the performance of the promise which it be allege be make by you would have involve you in the resistance of law i know of no statute that would have be violate have you carry out your promise in good faith tender your resignation when you conclude not to be make a party in any legal proceeding you add
 i be in a measure confirm in this conclusion by your recent order direct i to disobey order from the secretary of war my superior and your subordinate without having countermand his authority to issue the order i be to disobey
 on the 24th ultimo you address a note to the president request in write an order give to you verbally five day before to disregard order from mr. stanton as secretary of war until you know from the president himself that they be his order
 on the 29th in compliance with your request i do give you instruction in write not to obey any order from the war department assume to be issue by the direction of the president unless such order be know by the general command the army of the united states to have be authorize by the executive
 there be some order which a secretary of war may issue without the authority of the president there be other which he issue simply as the agent of the president and which purport to be by direction of the president for such order the president be responsible and he should therefore know and understand what they be before give such direction mr. stanton state in his letter of the 4th instant which accompany the publish correspondence that he have have no correspondence with the president since the 12th of august last and he far say that since he resume the duty of the office he have continue to discharge they without any personal or write communication with the president and he add no order have be issue from this department in the name of the president with my knowledge and i have receive no order from he
 it thus seem that mr. stanton now discharge the duty of the war department without any reference to the president and without use his name

 in reply i submit the following statement at the cabinet meeting on tuesday the 14th of january 1868 general grant appear and take his accustomed seat at the board when he have be reach in the order of business the president ask he as usual if he have anything to present
 in reply the general after refer to a note which he have that morning address to the president inclose a copy of the resolution of the senate refuse to concur in the reason for the suspension of mr. stanton proceed to say that he regard his duty as secretary of war ad interim terminate by that resolution and that he could not lawfully exercise such duty for a moment after the adoption of the resolution by the senate that the resolution reach he last night and that this morning he have go to the war department enter the secretary&#39;s room bolt one door on the inside lock the other on the outside deliver the key to the adjutant general and proceed to the headquarters of the army and address the note above mention to the president inform he that he general grant be no long secretary of war ad interim
 the president express great surprise at the course which general grant have think proper to pursue and address himself to the general proceed to say in substance that he have anticipate such action on the part of the senate and be very desirous to have the constitutionality of the tenure of office bill test and his fight to suspend or remove a member of the cabinet decide by the judicial tribunal of the country he have some time ago and shortly after general grant&#39;s appointment as secretary of war ad interim ask the general what his action would be in the event that the senate should refuse to concur in the suspension of mr. stanton and that the general have then agree either to remain at the head of the war department till a decision could be obtain from the court or resign the office into the hand of the president before the case be act upon by the senate so as to place the president in the same situation he occupy at the time of his grant&#39;s appointment
 the president far say that the conversation be renew on the precede saturday at which time he ask the general what he intend to do if the senate should undertake to reinstate mr. stanton in reply to which the general refer to their former conversation upon the same subject and say you understand my position and my conduct will be conformable to that understanding that he the general then express a repugnance to be make a party to a judicial proceeding say that he would expose himself to fine and imprisonment by do so as his continue to discharge the duty of secretary of war ad interim after the senate should have refuse to concur in the suspension of mr. stanton would be a violation of the tenure of office bill that in reply to this he the president inform general grant he have not suspend mr. stanton under the tenure of office bill but by virtue of the power confer on he by the constitution and that as to the fine and imprisonment he the president would pay whatever fine be impose and submit to whatever imprisonment might be adjudge against he the general that they continue the conversation for some time discuss the law at length and that they finally separate without having reach a definite conclusion and with the understanding that the general would see the president again on monday

 now for reason for give that interpretation it be clear to i before my letter of january 30 be write that i the person have more public business to transact with the secretary of war than any other of the president&#39;s subordinate be the only one who have be instruct to disregard the authority of mr. stanton where his authority be derive as agent of the president
