to the senate of the united states
 i have receive a copy of the resolution adopt by the senate on the 21st instant as follow
 whereas the senate have receive and consider the communication of the president state that he have remove edwin m. stanton secretary of war and have designate the adjutant general of the army to act as secretary of war ad interim therefore
 resolve by the senate of the united states that under the constitution and law of the united states the president have no power to remove the secretary of war and designate any other officer to perform the duty of that office ad interim
 this resolution be confine to the power of the president to remove the secretary of war and to designate another officer to perform the duty of the office ad interim and by its preamble be make expressly applicable to the removal of mr. stanton and the designation to act ad interim of the adjutant general of the army without therefore attempt to discuss the general power of removal as to all officer upon which subject no expression of opinion be contain in the resolution i shall confine myself to the question as thus limited the power to remove the secretary of war
 it be declare in the resolution--
 that under the constitution and law of the united states the president have no power to remove the secretary of war and designate any other officer to perform the duty of that office ad interim
 as to the question of power under the constitution i do not propose at present to enter upon its discussion
 the uniform practice from the beginning of the government as establish by every president who have exercise the office and the decision of the supreme court of the united states have settle the question in favor of the power of the president to remove all officer except a class hold appointment of a judicial character no practice nor any decision have ever except a secretary of war from this general power of the president to make removal from office
 it be only necessary then that i should refer to the power of the executive under the law of the united states to remove from office a secretary of war the resolution deny that under these law this power have any existence in other word it affirm that no such authority be recognize or give by the statute of the country
 what then be the law of the united states which deny the president the power to remove that officer i know but two law which bear upon this question the first in order of time be the act of august 7 1789 create the department of war which after provide for a secretary as its principal officer proceed as follow
 sec 2 and be it far enact that there shall be in the say department an inferior officer to be appoint by the say principal officer to be employ therein as he shall deem proper and to be call the chief clerk in the department of war and who whenever the say principal officer shall be remove from office by the president of the united states or in any other case of vacancy shall during such vacancy have the charge and custody of all record book and paper appertain to the said department
 it be clear that this act pass by a congress many of whose member participate in the formation of the constitution so far from deny the power of the president to remove the secretary of war recognize it as exist in the executive alone without the concurrence of the senate or of any other department of the government furthermore this act do not purport to confer the power by legislative authority nor in fact be there any other exist legislation through which it be bestow upon the executive the recognition of the power by this act be therefore complete as a recognition under the constitution itself for there be no other source or authority from which it could be derive
 the other act which refer to this question be that regulate the tenure of certain civil office pass by congress on the 2d day of march 1867 the first section of that act be in the follow word
 that every person hold any civil office to which he have be appoint by and with the advice and consent of the senate and every person who shall hereafter be appoint to any such office and shall become duly qualified to act therein be and shall be entitle to hold such office until a successor shall have be in like manner appoint and duly qualify except as herein otherwise provide provide that the secretaries of state of the treasury of war of the navy and of the interior the postmaster general and the attorney general shall hold their office respectively for and during the term of the president by whom they may have be appoint and for one month thereafter subject to removal by and with the advice and consent of the senate
 the fourth section of the same act restrict the term of office to the limit prescribe by the law create they
 that part of the first section which precede the proviso declare that every person hold a civil office to which he have be or may be appoint by and with the advice and consent of the senate shall hold such office until a successor shall have be in like manner appoint it purport to take from the executive during the fix time establish for the tenure of the office the independent power of removal and to require for such removal the concurrent action of the president and the senate
 the proviso that follow proceed to fix the term of office of the seven head of departments whose tenure never have be define before by prescribe that they shall hold their office respectively for and during the term of the president by whom they may have be appoint and for one month thereafter subject to removal by and with the advice and consent of the senate
 thus as to these enumerate officer the proviso take from the president the power of removal except with the advice and consent of the senate by its term however before he can be deprive of the power to displace they it must appear that he himself have appoint they it be only in that case that they have any tenure of office or any independent right to hold during the term of the president and for one month after the cessation of his official function the proviso therefore give no tenure of office to any one of these officer who have be appoint by a former president beyond one month after the accession of his successor
 in the case of mr. stanton the only appointment under which he hold the office of secretary of war be that confer upon he by my immediate predecessor with the advice and consent of the senate he have never hold from i any appointment as the head of the war department whatever fight he have to hold the office be derive from that original appointment and my own sufferance the law be not intend to protect such an incumbent of the war department by take from the president the power to remove he this in my judgment be perfectly clear and the law itself admit of no other just construction we find in all that portion of the first section which precede the proviso that as to civil officer generally the president be deprive of the power of removal and it be plain that if there have be no proviso that power would just as clearly have be take from he so far as it apply to the seven head of department but for reason which be no doubt satisfactory to congress these principal officer be specially provide for and as to they the express and only requirement be that the president who have appoint they shall not without the advice and consent of the senate remove they from office the consequence be that as to my cabinet embrace the seven officer designate in the first section the act take from i the power without the concurrence of the senate to remove any one of they that i have appoint but it do not protect such of they as i do not appoint nor give to they any tenure of office beyond my pleasure
 an examination of this act then show that while in one part of the section provision be make for officer generally in another clause there be a class of officer designate by their official title who be except from the general term of the law and in reference to whom a clear distinction be make as to the general power of removal limit in the first clause of the section
 this distinction be that as to such of these enumerate officer as hold under the appointment of the president the power of removal can only be exercise by he with the consent of the senate while as to those who have not be appoint by he there be no like denial of his power to displace they it would be a violation of the plain meaning of this enactment to place mr. stanton upon the same footing as those head of departments who have be appoint by myself as to he this law give he no tenure of office the member of my cabinet who have be appoint by i be by this act entitle to hold for one month after the term of my office shall cease but mr. stanton could not against the wish of my successor hold a moment thereafter if he be permit by that successor to hold for the first two week would that successor have no power to remove he but the power of my successor over he could be no great than my own if my successor would have the power to remove mr. stanton after permit he to remain a period of two week because he be not appoint by he but by his predecessor i who have tolerate mr. stanton for more than two year certainly have the same right to remove he and upon the same ground namely that he be not appoint by i but by my predecessor
 under this construction of the tenure of office act i have never doubt my power to remove mr. stanton
 whether the act be constitutional or not it be always my opinion that it do not secure he from removal i be however aware that there be doubt as to the construction of the law and from the first i deem it desirable that at the early possible moment those doubt should be settle and the true construction of the act fix by decision of the supreme court of the united states my order of suspension in august last be intend to place the case in such a position as would make a resort to a judicial decision both necessary and proper my understanding and wish however under that order of suspension be frustrate and the late order for mr. stanton&#39;s removal be a further step toward the accomplishment of that purpose
 i repeat that my own conviction as to the true construction of the law and as to its constitutionality be well settle and be sustain by every member of my cabinet include mr. stanton himself upon the question of constitutionality each one in turn deliberately advise i that the tenure of office act be unconstitutional upon the question whether as to those member who be appoint by my predecessor that act take from i the power to remove they one of those member emphatically state in the presence of the other sit in cabinet that they do not come within the provision of the act and it be no protection to they no one dissent from this construction and i understand they all to acquiesce in its correctness in a matter of such grave consequence i be not disposed to rest upon my own opinion though fortify by my constitutional adviser i have therefore seek to bring the question at as early a day as possible before the supreme court of the united states for final and authoritative decision
 in respect to so much of the resolution as relate to the designation of an officer to act as secretary of war ad interim i have only to say that i have exercise this power under the provision of the first section of the act of february 13 1795 which so far as they be applicable to vacancy cause by removal i understand to be still in force
 the legislation upon the subject of ad interim appointment in the executive departments stand as to the war office as follow
 the second section of the act of the 7th of august 1789 make provision for a vacancy in the very case of a removal of the head of the war department and upon such a vacancy give the charge and custody of the record book and paper to the chief clerk next by the act of the 8th of may 1792 section 8 it be provide that in case of a vacancy occasion by death absence from the seat of government or sickness of the head of the war department the president may authorize a person to perform the duty of the office until a successor be appoint or the disability remove the act it will be observe do not provide for the case of a vacancy cause by removal then by the first section of the act of february 13 1795 it be provide that in case of any vacancy the president may appoint a person to perform the duty while the vacancy exist
 these act be follow by that of the 20th of february 1863 by the first section of which provision be again make for a vacancy cause by death resignation absence from the seat of government or sickness of the head of any executive department of the government and upon the occurrence of such a vacancy power be give to the president--
 to authorize the head of any other executive department or other officer in either of say departments whose appointment be vest in the president at his discretion to perform the duty of the say respective office until a successor be appoint or until such absence or inability by sickness shall cease provide that no one vacancy shall be supply in manner aforesaid for a long term than six month
 this law with some modification reenact the act of 1792 and provide as do that act for the sort of vacancy so to be fill but like the act of 1792 it make no provision for a vacancy occasion by removal it have reference altogether to vacancy arise from other cause
 accord to my construction of the act of 1863 while it impliedly repeal the act of 1792 regulate the vacancy therein describe it have no bearing whatever upon so much of the act of 1795 as apply to a vacancy cause by removal the act of 1795 therefore furnish the rule for a vacancy occasion by removal one of the vacancy expressly refer to in the act of the 7th of august 1789 create the department of war certainly there be no express repeal by the act of 1863 of the act of 1795 the repeal if there be any be by implication and can only be admit so far as there be a clear inconsistency between the two act the act of 1795 be inconsistent with that of 1863 as to a vacancy occasion by death resignation absence or sickness but not at all inconsistent as to a vacancy cause by removal
 it be assuredly proper that the president should have the same power to fill temporarily a vacancy occasion by removal as he have to supply a place make vacant by death or the expiration of a term if for instance the incumbent of an office should be find to be wholly unfit to exercise its function and the public service should require his immediate expulsion a remedy should exist and be at once apply and time be allow the president to select and appoint a successor as be permit he in case of a vacancy cause by death or the termination of an official term
 the necessity therefore for an ad interim appointment be just as great and indeed may be great in case of removal than in any other before it be hold therefore that the power give by the act of 1795 in case of removal be abrogate by succeed legislation an express repeal ought to appear so wholesome a power should certainly not be take away by loose implication
 it may be however that in this as in other case of imply repeal doubt may arise it be confessedly one of the most subtle and debatable question which arise in the construction of statute if upon such a question i have fall into an erroneous construction i submit whether it should be characterize as a violation of official duty and of law
 i have deem it proper in vindication of the course which i have consider it my duty to take to place before the senate the reason upon which i have base my action although i have be advise by every member of my cabinet that the entire tenure of office act be unconstitutional and therefore void and although i have expressly concur in that opinion in the veto message which i have the honor to submit to congress when i return the bill for reconsideration i have refrain from make a removal of any officer contrary to the provision of the law and have only exercise that power in the case of mr. stanton which in my judgment do not come within its provision i have endeavor to proceed with the great circumspection and have act only in an extreme and exceptional case carefully follow the course which i have mark out for myself as a general rule faithfully to execute all law though pass over my objection on the score of constitutionality in the present instance i have appeal or seek to appeal to that final arbiter fix by the constitution for the determination of all such question to this course i have be impel by the solemn obligation which rest upon i to sustain inviolate the power of the high office commit to my hand
 whatever may be the consequence merely personal to myself i could not allow they to prevail against a public duty so clear to my own mind and so imperative if what be possible have be certain if i have be fully advise when i remove mr. stanton that in thus defend the trust commit to my hand my own removal be sure to follow i could not have hesitate actuate by public consideration of the high character i earnestly protest against the resolution of the senate which charge i in what i have do with a violation of the constitution and law of the united states

to the senate of the united states
 i have consider with such care as the pressure of other duty have permit a bill entitle an act to amend an act entitle 39;an act to amend the judiciary act pass the 24th of september 1789.&#39 not be able to approve all of its provision i herewith return it to the senate in which house it originate with a brief statement of my objection
 the first section of the bill meet my approbation as for the purpose of protect the right of property from the erroneous decision of inferior judicial tribunal it provide mean for obtain uniformity by appeal to the supreme court of the united states in case which have now become very numerous and of much public interest and in which such remedy be not now allow the second section however take away the right of appeal to that court in case which involve the life and liberty of the citizen and leave they expose to the judgment of numerous interior tribunal it be apparent that the two section be conceive in a very different spirit and i regret that my objection to one impose upon i the necessity of withhold my sanction from the other
 i can not give my assent to a measure which propose to deprive any person restrain of his or her liberty in violation of the constitution or of any treaty or law of the united states from the right of appeal to the high judicial authority know to our government to secure the blessing of liberty to ourselves and our posterity be one of the declare object of the federal constitution to assure these guaranty be provide in the same instrument as well against unreasonable search and seizure as against the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus unless when in case of rebellion or invasion the public safety may require it it be doubtless to afford the people the mean of protect and enforce these inestimable privilege that the jurisdiction which this bill propose to take away be confer upon the supreme court of the nation the act confer that jurisdiction be approve on the 5th day of february 1867 with a full knowledge of the motive that prompt its passage and because it be believe to be necessary and right nothing have since occur to disprove the wisdom and justness of the measure and to modify it as now propose would be to lessen the protection of the citizen from the exercise of arbitrary power and to weaken the safeguard of life and liberty which can never be make too secure against illegal encroachment
 the bill not only prohibit the adjudication by the supreme court of case in which appeal may hereafter be take but interdict its jurisdiction on appeal which have already be make to that high judicial body if therefore it should become a law it will by its retroactive operation wrest from the citizen a remedy which he enjoy at the time of his appeal it will thus operate most harshly upon those who believe that justice have be deny they in the inferior court
 the legislation propose in the second section it seem to i be not in harmony with the spirit and intention of the constitution it can not fail to affect most injuriously the just equipoise of our system of government for it establish a precedent which if follow may eventually sweep away every check on arbitrary and unconstitutional legislation thus far during the existence of the government the supreme court of the united states have be view by the people as the true expounder of their constitution and in the most violent party conflict its judgment and decree have always be seek and defer to with confidence and respect in public estimation it combine judicial wisdom and impartiality in a great degree than any other authority know to the constitution and any act which may be construe into or mistaken for an attempt to prevent or evade its decision on a question which affect the liberty of the citizen and agitate the country can not fail to be attend with unpropitious consequence it will be justly hold by a large portion of the people as an admission of the unconstitutionality of the act on which its judgment may be forbid or forestall and may interfere with that willing acquiescence in its provision which be necessary for the harmonious and efficient execution of any law
 for these reason thus briefly and imperfectly state and for other of which want of time forbid the enumeration i deem it my duty to withhold my assent from this bill and to return it for the reconsideration of congress

to the house of representatives
 i return without my signature a bill entitle an act to admit the state of arkansas to representation in congress
 the approval of this bill would be an admission on the part of the executive that the act for the more efficient government of the rebel state pass march 2 1867 and the act supplementary thereto be proper and constitutional my opinion however in reference to those measure have undergo no change but on the contrary have be strengthen by the result which have attend their execution even be this not the case i could not consent to a bill which be base upon the assumption either that by an act of rebellion of a portion of its people the state of arkansas secede from the union or that congress may at its pleasure expel or exclude a state from the union or interrupt its relation with the government by arbitrarily deprive it of representation in the senate and house of representatives if arkansas be a state not in the union this bill do not admit it as a state into the union if on the other hand arkansas be a state in the union no legislation be necessary to declare it entitle to representation in congress as one of the states of the union the constitution already declare that each state shall have at least one representative that the senate shall be compose of two senator from each state and that no state without its consent shall be deprive of its equal suffrage in the senate
 that instrument also make each house the judge of the election return and qualification of its own member and therefore all that be now necessary to restore arkansas in all its constitutional relation to the government be a decision by each house upon the eligibility of those who present their credential claim seat in the respective houses of congress this be the plain and simple plan of the constitution and believe that have it be pursue when congress assemble in the month of december 1865 the restoration of the states would long since have be complete i once again earnestly recommend that it be adopt by each house in preference to legislation which i respectfully submit be not only of at least doubtful constitutionality and therefore unwise and dangerous as a precedent but be unnecessary not so effective in its operation as the mode prescribe by the constitution involve additional delay and from its term may be take rather as applicable to a territory about to be admit as one of the united states than to a state which have occupy a place in the union for upward of a quarter of a century
 the bill declare the state of arkansas entitle and admit to representation in congress as one of the states of the union upon the follow fundamental condition
 that the constitution of arkansas shall never be so amend or change as to deprive any citizen or class of citizen of the united states of the right to vote who be entitle to vote by the constitution herein recognize except as a punishment for such crime as be now felony at common law whereof they shall have be duly convict under law equally applicable to all the inhabitant of say state provide that any alteration of said constitution prospective in its effect may be make in regard to the time and place of residence of voter
 i have be unable to find in the constitution of the united states any warrant for the exercise of the authority thus claim by congress in assume the power to impose a fundamental condition upon a state which have be duly admit into the union upon an equal footing with the original states in all respect whatever congress assert a right to enter a state as it may a territory and to regulate the high prerogative of a free people the elective franchise this question be reserve by the constitution to the states themselves and to concede to congress the power to regulate the subject would be to reverse the fundamental principle of the republic and to place in the hand of the federal government which be the creature of the states the sovereignty which justly belong to the states or the people the true source of all political power by whom our federal system be create and to whose will it be subordinate
 the bill fail to provide in what manner the state of arkansas be to signify its acceptance of the fundamental condition which congress endeavor to make unalterable and irrevocable nor do it prescribe the penalty to be impose should the people of the state amend or change the particular portion of the constitution which it be one of the purpose of the bill to perpetuate but as to the consequence of such action leave they in uncertainty and doubt when the circumstance under which this constitution have be bring to the attention of congress be consider it be not unreasonable to suppose that effort will be make to modify its provision and especially those in respect to which this measure prohibit any alteration it be seriously question whether the constitution have be ratify by a majority of the person who under the act of march 2 1867 and the act supplementary thereto be entitle to registration and to vote upon that issue section 10 of the schedule provide that--
 no person disqualify from vote or register under this constitution shall vote for candidate for any office nor shall be permit to vote for the ratification or rejection of the constitution at the poll herein authorize
 assume to be in force before its adoption in disregard of the law of congress the constitution undertake to impose upon the elector other and further condition the fifth section of the eighth article provide that all person before register or voting must take and subscribe an oath which among other contain the follow clause
 that i accept the civil and political equality of all man and agree not to attempt to deprive any person or person on account of race color or previous condition of any political or civil right privilege or immunity enjoy by any other class of man
 it be well know that a very large portion of the elector in all the states if not a large majority of all of they do not believe in or accept the political equality of indians mongolians or negroes with the race to which they belong if the voter in many of the states of the north and west be require to take such an oath as a test of their qualification there be reason to believe that a majority of they would remain from the poll rather than comply with its degrading condition how far and to what extent this test oath prevent the registration of those who be qualified under the law of congress it be not possible to know but that such be its effect at least sufficient to overcome the small and doubtful majority in favor of this constitution there can be no reasonable doubt should the people of arkansas therefore desire to regulate the elective franchise so as to make it conform to the constitution of a large proportion of the states of the north and west modify the provision refer to in the fundamental condition what be to be the consequence be it intend that a denial of representation shall follow and if so may we not dread at some future day a recurrence of the trouble which have so long agitate the country would it not be the part of wisdom to take for our guide the federal constitution rather than resort to measure which look only to the present may in a few year renew in an aggravate form the strife and bitterness cause by legislation which have prove to be so ill timed and unfortunate

to the senate and house of representatives
 experience have fully demonstrate the wisdom of the framer of the federal constitution under all circumstance the result of their labor be as near an approximation to perfection as be compatible with the fallibility of man such be the estimation in which the constitution be and have ever be hold by our countryman it be not surprising that any proposition for its alteration or amendment should be receive with reluctance and distrust while this sentiment deserve commendation and encouragement as a useful preventive of unnecessary attempt to change its provision it must be concede that time have develop imperfection and omission in the constitution the reformation of which have be demand by the good interest of the country some of these have be remedie in the manner provide in the constitution itself there be other which although heretofore bring to the attention of the people have never be so present as to enable the popular judgment to determine whether they should be correct by mean of additional amendment my object in this communication be to suggest certain defect in the constitution which seem to i to require correction and to recommend that the judgment of the people be take on the amendment propose
 the first of the defect to which i desire to direct attention be in that clause of the constitution which provide for the election of president and vice president through the intervention of elector and not by an immediate vote of the people the importance of so amend this clause as to secure to the people the election of president and vice president by their direct vote be urge with great earnestness and ability by president jackson in his first annual message and the recommendation be repeat in five of his subsequent communication to congress extend through the eight year of his administration in his message of 1829 he say
 ldquo;to the people belong the fight of elect their chief magistrate it be never design that their choice should in any case be defeat either by the intervention of electoral college or by the agency confide under certain contingency to the house of representatives.&rdquo
 he then proceed to state the objection to an election of president by the house of representatives the most important of which be that the choice of a clear majority of the people might be easily defeat he then close the argument with the following communication
 ldquo;i would therefore recommend such an amendment of the constitution as may remove all intermediate agency in the election of the president and vice president the mode may be so regulated as to preserve to each state its present relative weight in the election and a failure in the first attempt may be provide for by confine the second to a choice between the two high candidate in connection with such an amendment it would seem advisable to limit the service of the chief magistrate to a single term of either four or six year if however it should not be adopt it be worthy of consideration whether a provision disqualify for office the representatives in congress on whom such an election may have devolve would not be proper.&rdquo
 although this recommendation be repeat with undiminished earnestness in several of his succeed message yet the propose amendment be never adopt and submit to the people by congress the danger of a defeat of the people&#39; choice in an election by the house of representatives remain unprovided for in the constitution and would be greatly increase if the house of representatives should assume the power arbitrarily to reject the vote of a state which might not be cast in conformity with the wish of the majority in that body
 but if president jackson fail to secure the amendment to the constitution which he urge so persistently his argument contribute largely to the formation of party organization which have effectually avoid the contingency of an election by the house of representatives these organization first by a resort to the caucus system of nominating candidate and afterwards to state and national convention have be successful in so limit the number of candidate as to escape the danger of an election by the house of representatives
 it be clear however that in thus limit the number of candidate the true object and spirit of the constitution have be evade and defeat it be an essential feature in our republican system of government that every citizen possess the constitutional qualification have a right to become a candidate for the office of president and vice president and that every qualified elector have a right to cast his vote for any citizen whom he may regard as worthy of these office but under the party organization which have prevail for year these assert right of the people have be as effectually cut off and destroy as if the constitution itself have inhibit their exercise
 the danger of a defeat of the popular choice in an election by the house of representatives be no great than in an election make nominally by the people themselves when by the law of party organization and by the constitutional provision require the people to vote for elector instead of for the president or vice president it be make impracticable for any citizen to be a candidate except through the process of a party nomination and for any voter to cast his suffrage for any other person than one thus bring forward through the manipulation of a nominate convention it be thus apparent that by mean of party organization that provision of the constitution which require the election of president and vice president to be make through the electoral college have be make instrumental and potential in defeat the great object of confer the choice of these officer upon the people it may be concede that party organization be inseparable from republican government and that when form and manage in subordination to the constitution they may be valuable safeguard of popular liberty but when they be pervert to purpose of bad ambition they be liable to become the dangerous instrument of overthrow the constitution itself strongly impress with the truth of these view i feel call upon by an imperative sense of duty to revive substantially the recommendation so often and so earnestly make by president jackson and to urge that the amendment to the constitution herewith present or some similar proposition may be submit to the people for their ratification or rejection
 recent event have show the necessity of an amendment to the constitution distinctly define the person who shall discharge the duty of president of the united states in the event of a vacancy in that office by the death resignation or removal of both the president and vice president it be clear that this should be fix by the constitution and not be leave to repealable enactment of doubtful constitutionality it occur to i that in the event of a vacancy in the office of president by the death resignation disability or removal of both the president and vice president the duty of the office should devolve upon an officer of the executive department of the government rather than one connect with the legislative or judicial department the objection to designate either the president pro tempore of the senate or the chief justice of the supreme court especially in the event of a vacancy produce by removal be so obvious and so unanswerable that they need not be state in detail it be enough to state that they be both interested in produce a vacancy and accord to the provision of the constitution be member of the tribunal by whose decree a vacancy may be produce
 under such circumstance the impropriety of designate either of these officer to succeed the president so removed be palpable the framer of the constitution when they refer to congress the settlement of the succession to the office of president in the event of a vacancy in the office of both president and vice president do not in my opinion contemplate the designation of any other than an officer of the executive department on whom in such a contingency the power and duty of the president should devolve until recently the contingency have be remote and serious attention have not be call to the manifest incongruity between the provision of the constitution on this subject and the act of congress of 1792 have however be bring almost face to face with this important question it seem an eminently proper time for we to make the legislation conform to the language intent and theory of the constitution and thus place the executive department beyond the reach of usurpation and remove from the legislative and judicial department every temptation to combine for the absorption of all the power of government
 it have occur to i that in the event of such a vacancy the duty of president would devolve most appropriately upon some one of the head of the several executive departments and under this conviction i present for your consideration an amendment to the constitution on this subject with the recommendation that it be submit to the people for their action
 experience seem to have establish the necessity of an amendment of that clause of the constitution which provide for the election of senator to congress by the legislature of the several states it would be more consistent with the genius of our form of government if the senators be choose directly by the people of the several states the objection to the election of senators by the legislature be so palpable that i deem it unnecessary to do more than submit the proposition for such an amendment with the recommendation that it be open to the people for their judgment
 it be strongly impressed on my mind that the tenure of office by the judiciary of the united states during good behavior for life be incompatible with the spirit of republican government and in this opinion i be fully sustain by the evidence of popular judgment upon this subject in the different states of the union
 i therefore deem it my duty to recommend an amendment to the constitution by which the term of the judicial officer would be limit to a period of year and i herewith present it in the hope that congress will submit it to the people for their decision
 the foregoing view have long be entertain by i in 1845 in the house of representatives and afterwards in 1860 in the senate of the united states i submit substantially the same proposition as those to which the attention of congress be herein invite time observation and experience have confirm these conviction and as a matter of public duty and a deep sense of my constitutional obligation to recommend to the consideration of congress such measure as i deem necessary and expedient i submit the accompany proposition and urge their adoption and submission to the judgment of the people
 andrew johnson
 joint resolution propose amendment to the constitution of the united states
 whereas the fifth article of the constitution of the united states provide for amendment thereto in the manner follow viz
 the congress whenever two third of both houses shall deem it necessary shall propose amendment to this constitution or on the application of the legislature of two third of the several states shall call a convention for propose amendment which in either case shall be valid to all intent and purpose as part of this constitution when ratify by the legislature of three fourth of the several states or by convention in three fourth thereof as the one or the other mode of ratification may be propose by the congress provide that no amendment which may be make prior to the year 1808 shall in any manner affect the first and fourth clause in the ninth section of the first article and that no state without its consent shall be deprive of its equal suffrage in the senate
 therefore
 be it resolve by the senate and house of representatives of the united states of america in congress assemble two third of both houses concur that the follow amendment to the constitution of the united states be propose to the legislature of the several states which when ratify by the legislature of three fourth of the states shall be valid to all intent and purpose as part of the constitution
 that hereafter the president and vice president of the united states shall be choose for the term of six year by the people of the respective states in the manner follow each state shall be divide by in the great number of states shall be president the person have the great number of vote for vice president at the first election shall be vice president if such number be equal to a majority of the
