to the senate of the united states
 i have give to the joint resolution entitle a resolution exclude from the electoral college the vote of states lately in rebellion which shall not have be reorganize as careful examination as i have be able to bestow upon the subject during the few day that have intervene since the measure be submit for my approval
 feel constrain to withhold my consent i herewith return the resolution to the senate in which house it originate with a brief statement of the reason which have induce my action this joint resolution be base upon the assumption that some of the states whose inhabitant be lately in rebellion be not now entitle to representation in congress and participation in the election of president and vice president of the united states
 have heretofore have occasion to give in detail my reason for dissent from this view it be not necessary at this time to repeat they it be sufficient to state that i continue strong in my conviction that the act of secession by which a number of the states seek to dissolve their connection with the other states and to subvert the union be unauthorized by the constitution and in direct violation thereof be from the beginning absolutely null and void it follow necessarily that when the rebellion terminate the several states which have attempt to secede continue to be state in the union and all that be require to enable they to resume their relation to the union be that they should adopt the measure necessary to their practical restoration as states such measure be adopt and the legitimate result be that those state having conform to all the requirement of the constitution resume their former relation and become entitled to the exercise of all the right guarantee to they by its provision
 the joint resolution under consideration however seem to assume that by the insurrectionary act of their respective inhabitant those states forfeit their right as such and can never again exercise they except upon readmission into the union on the term prescribe by congress if this position be correct it follow that they be take out of the union by virtue of their act of secession and hence that the war wage upon they be illegal and unconstitutional we would thus be place in this inconsistent attitude that while the war be commence and carry on upon the distinct ground that the southern states be component part of the union be in rebellion against the lawful authority of the united states upon its termination we resort to a policy of reconstruction which assume that it be not in fact a rebellion but that the war be wage for the conquest of territory assume to be outside of the constitutional union
 the mode and manner of receive and count the electoral vote for president and vice president of the united states be in plain and simple term prescribe by the constitution that instrument imperatively require that the president of the senate shall in the presence of the senate and house of representatives open all the certificate and the vote shall then be count congress have therefore no power under the constitution to receive the electoral vote or reject they the whole power be exhaust when in the presence of the two houses the vote be count and the result declare in this respect the power and duty of the president of the senate be under the constitution purely ministerial when therefore the joint resolution declare that no electoral vote shall be receive or count from states that since the 4th of march 1867 have not adopt a constitution of state government under which a state government shall have organize a power be assume which be nowhere delegate to congress unless upon the assumption that the state government organize prior to the 4th of march 1867 be illegal and void
 the joint resolution by implication at least concede that these states be states by virtue of their organization prior to the 4th of march 1867 but deny to they the right to vote in the election of president and vice president of the united states it follow either that this assumption of power be wholly unauthorized by the constitution or that the states so exclude from voting be out of the union by reason of the rebellion and have never be legitimately restore be fully satisfied that they be never out of the union and that their relation thereto have be legally and constitutionally restore i be force to the conclusion that the joint resolution which deprive they of the right to have their vote for president and vice president receive and count be in conflict with the constitution and that congress have no more power to reject their vote than those of the states which have be uniformly loyal to the federal union
 it be worthy of remark that if the states whose inhabitant be recently in rebellion be legally and constitutionally organize and restore to their right prior to the 4th of march 1867 as i be satisfied they be the only legitimate authority under which the election for president and vice president can be hold therein must be derive from the government institute before that period it clearly follow that all the state government organize in those states under act of congress for that purpose and under military control be illegitimate and of no validity whatever and in that view the vote cast in those states for president and vice president in pursuance of act pass since the 4th of march 1867 and in obedience to the so call reconstruction act of congress can not be legally receive and count while the only vote in those states that can be legally cast and count will be those cast in pursuance of the law in force in the several states prior to the legislation by congress upon the subject of reconstruction
 i can not refrain from direct your special attention to the declaration contain in the joint resolution that none of the states whose inhabitant be lately in rebellion shall be entitle to representation in the electoral college etc if it be mean by this declaration that no state be to be allow to vote for president and vice president all of whose inhabitant be engage in the late rebellion it be apparent that no one of the states will be exclude from voting since it be well know that in every southern state there be many inhabitant who not only do not participate m the rebellion but who actually take part in the suppression or refrain from give it any aid or countenance i therefore conclude that the true meaning of the joint resolution be that no state a portion of whose inhabitant be engage in the rebellion shall be permit to participate in the presidential election except upon the term and condition therein prescribed
 assume this to be the true construction of the resolution the inquiry become pertinent may those northern states a portion of whose inhabitant be actually in the rebellion be prevent at the discretion of congress from have their electoral vote count it be well know that a portion of the inhabitant of new york and a portion of the inhabitant of virginia be alike engage in the rebellion yet it be equally well known that virginia as well as new york be at all time during the war recognize by the federal government as a state in the union so clearly that upon the termination of hostility it be not even deem necessary for her restoration that a provisional governor should be appoint yet accord to this joint resolution the people of virginia unless they comply with the term it prescribe be deny the right of voting for president while the people of new york a portion of the inhabitant of which state be also in rebellion be permit to have their electoral vote count without undergo the process of reconstruction prescribe for virginia new york be no more a state than virginia the one be as much entitle to representation in the electoral college as the other if congress have the power to deprive virginia of this right it can exercise the same authority with respect to new york or any other of the states thus the result of the presidential election may be control and determine by congress and the people be deprive of their right under the constitution to choose a president and vice president of the united states
 if congress be to provide by law that the vote of none of the states should be receive and count if cast for a candidate who differ in political sentiment with a majority of the two houses such legislation would at once be condemn by the country as an unconstitutional and revolutionary usurpation of power it would however be exceedingly difficult to find in the constitution any more authority for the passage of the joint resolution under consideration than for an enactment look directly to the rejection of all vote not in accordance with the political preference of a majority of congress no power exist in the constitution authorize the joint resolution or the suppose law the only difference be that one would be more palpably unconstitutional and revolutionary than the other both would rest upon the radical error that congress have the power to prescribe term and condition to the right of the people of the states to cast their vote for president and vice president
 for the reason thus indicate i be constrain to return the joint resolution to the senate for such further action thereon as congress may deem necessary

fellow citizen of the senate and house of representatives

 upon the reassembling of congress it again become my duty to call your attention to the state of the union and to its continue disorganized condition under the various law which have be pass upon the subject of reconstruction

 it may be safely assume as an axiom in the government of state that the great wrong inflict upon a people be cause by unjust and arbitrary legislation or by the unrelenting decree of despotic ruler and that the timely revocation of injurious and oppressive measure be the great good that can be confer upon a nation the legislator or ruler who have the wisdom and magnanimity to retrace his step when convince of error will soon or later be reward with the respect and gratitude of an intelligent and patriotic people

 our own history although embrace a period less than a century afford abundant proof that most if not all of our domestic trouble be directly traceable to violation of the organic law and excessive legislation the most striking illustration of this fact be furnish by the enactment of the past three year upon the question of reconstruction after a fair trial they have substantially fail and prove pernicious in their result and there seem to be no good reason why they should long remain upon the statute book state to which the constitution guarantee a republican form of government have be reduce to military dependency in each of which the people have be make subject to the arbitrary will of the command general although the constitution require that each state shall be represent in congress virginia mississippi and texas be yet exclude from the two houses and contrary to the express provision of that instrument be deny participation in the recent election for a president and vice president of the united states the attempt to place the white population under the domination of person of color in the south have impair if not destroy the kindly relation that have previously exist between they and mutual distrust have engender a feeling of animosity which lead in some instance to collision and bloodshed have prevent that cooperation between the two race so essential to the success of industrial enterprise in the southern states nor have the inhabitant of those states alone suffer from the disturbed condition of affair grow out of these congressional enactment the entire union have be agitate by grave apprehension of trouble which might again involve the peace of the nation its interest have be injuriously affect by the derangement of business and labor and the consequent want of prosperity throughout that portion of the country

 the federal constitution the magna carta of american right under whose wise and salutary provision we have successfully conduct all our domestic and foreign affair sustain ourselves in peace and in war and become a great nation among the power of the earth must assuredly be now adequate to the settlement of question grow out of the civil war wage alone for its vindication this great fact be make most manifest by the condition of the country when congress assemble in the month of december 1865 civil strife have cease the spirit of rebellion have spend its entire force in the southern states the people have warm into national life and throughout the whole country a healthy reaction in public sentiment have take place by the application of the simple yet effective provision of the constitution the executive department with the voluntary aid of the states have bring the work of restoration as near completion as be within the scope of its authority and the nation be encourage by the prospect of an early and satisfactory adjustment of all its difficulty congress however intervene and refuse to perfect the work so nearly consummate decline to admit member from the unrepresented states adopt a series of measure which arrest the progress of restoration frustrate all that have be so successfully accomplish and after three year of agitation and strife have leave the country far from the attainment of union and fraternal feeling than at the inception of the congressional plan of reconstruction it need no argument to show that legislation which have produce such baneful consequence should be abrogate or else make to conform to the genuine principle of republican government

 under the influence of party passion and sectional prejudice other act have be pass not warrant by the constitution congress have already be make familiar with my view respect the tenure of office bill experience have prove that its repeal be demand by the good interest of the country and that while it remain in force the president can not enjoin that rigid accountability of public officer so essential to an honest and efficient execution of the law its revocation would enable the executive department to exercise the power of appointment and removal in accordance with the original design of the federal constitution

 the act of march 2 1867 make appropriation for the support of the army for the year end june 30 1868 and for other purpose contain provision which interfere with the president 's constitutional function as commander in chief of the army and deny to states of the union the right to protect themselves by mean of their own militia these provision should be at once annul for while the first might in time of great emergency seriously embarrass the executive in effort to employ and direct the common strength of the nation for its protection and preservation the other be contrary to the express declaration of the constitution that a well regulate militia be necessary to the security of a free state the right of the people to keep and bear arm shall not be infringe

 it be believe that the repeal of all such law would be accept by the american people as at least a partial return to the fundamental principle of the government and an indication that hereafter the constitution be to be make the nation 's safe and unerring guide they can be productive of no permanent benefit to the country and should not be permit to stand as so many monument of the deficient wisdom which have characterize our recent legislation

 the condition of our finance demand the early and earnest consideration of congress compare with the growth of our population the public expenditure have reach an amount unprecedented in our history

 the population of the united states in 1790 be nearly 4,000,000 people increase each decade about 33 percent it reach in 1860 31,000,000 an increase of 700 percent on the population in 1790 in 1869 it be estimate that it will reach 38,000,000 or an increase of 868 percent in seventy nine year

 the annual expenditure of the federal government in 1791 be $ 4,200,000 in 1820 $ 18.200,000 in 1850 forty one million in 1860 sixty three million in 1865 nearly thirteen hundred million and in 1869 it be estimate by the secretary of the treasury in his last annual report that they will be three hundred and seventy two million

 by compare the public disbursement of 1869 as estimate with those of 1791 it will be see that the increase of expenditure since the beginning of the government have be 8,618 percent while the increase of the population for the same period be only 868 percent again the expense of the government in 1860 the year of peace immediately precede the war be only sixty three million while in 1869 the year of peace three year after the war it be estimate they will be three hundred and seventy two million an increase of 489 percent while the increase of population be only 21 percent for the same period

 these statistic far show that in 1791 the annual national expense compare with the population be little more than $ 1 per capita and in 1860 but $ 2 per capita while in 1869 they will reach the extravagant sum of $ 9.78 per capita

 it will be observe that all these statement refer to and exhibit the disbursement of peace period it may therefore be of interest to compare the expenditure of the three war period the war with great britain the mexican war and the war of the rebellion

 in 1814 the annual expense incident to the war of 1812 reach their high amount about thirty one million while our population slightly exceed 8,000,000 show an expenditure of only $ 3.80 per capita in 1847 the expenditure grow out of the war with mexico reach fifty five million and the population about 21,000,000 give only $ 2.60 per capita for the war expense of that year in 1865 the expenditure call for by the rebellion reach the vast amount of twelve hundred and ninety million which compare with a population of 34,000,000 give $ 38.20 per capita

 from the 4th day of march 1789 to the 30th of june 1861 the entire expenditure of the government be $ 1,700,000,000 during that period we be engage in war with great britain and mexico and be involve in hostility with powerful indian tribe louisiana be purchase from france at a cost of $ 15,000,000 florida be cede to we by spain for five million california be acquire from mexico for fifteen million and the territory of new mexico be obtain from texas for the sum of ten million early in 1861 the war of the rebellion commence and from the 1st of july of that year to the 30th of june 1865 the public expenditure reach the enormous aggregate of thirty three hundred million three year of peace have intervene and during that time the disbursement of the government have successively be five hundred and twenty million three hundred and forty six million and three hundred and ninety three million add to these amount three hundred and seventy two million estimate as necessary for the fiscal year end the 30th of june 1869 we obtain a total expenditure of $ 1,600,000,000 during the four year immediately succeed the war or nearly as much as be expend during the seventy two year that precede the rebellion and embrace the extraordinary expenditure already name

 these startling fact clearly illustrate the necessity of retrenchment in all branch of the public service abuse which be tolerate during the war for the preservation of the nation will not be endure by the people now that profound peace prevail the receipt from internal revenue and custom have during the past three year gradually diminish and the continuance of useless and extravagant expenditure will involve we in national bankruptcy or else make inevitable an increase of taxis already too onerous and in many respect obnoxious on account of their inquisitorial character one hundred million annually be expend for the military force a large portion of which be employ in the execution of law both unnecessary and unconstitutional one hundred and fifty million be require each year to pay the interest on the public debt an army of tax gatherer impoverish the nation and public agent place by congress beyond the control of the executive divert from their legitimate purpose large sum of money which they collect from the people in the name of the government judicious legislation and prudent economy can alone remedy defect and avert evil which if suffer to exist can not fail to diminish confidence in the public council and weaken the attachment and respect of the people toward their political institution without proper care the small balance which it be estimate will remain in the treasury at the close of the present fiscal year will not be realize and additional million be add to a debt which be now enumerate by billion

 it be show by the able and comprehensive report of the secretary of the treasury that the receipt for the fiscal year end june 30 1868 be $ 405,638,083 and that the expenditure for the same period be $ 377,340,284 leave in the treasury a surplus of $ 28,297,798 it be estimate that the receipt during the present fiscal year end june 30 1869 will be $ 341,392,868 and the expenditure $ 336,152,470 show a small balance of $ 5,240,398 in favor of the government for the fiscal year end june 30 1870 it be estimate that the receipt will amount to $ 327,000,000 and the expenditure to $ 303,000,000 leave an estimate surplus of $ 24,000,000

 it become proper in this connection to make a brief reference to our public indebtedness which have accumulate with such alarming rapidity and assume such colossal proportion

 in 1789 when the government commence operation under the federal constitution it be burden with an indebtedness of $ 75,000,000 create during the war of the revolution this amount have be reduce to $ 45,000,000 when in 1812 war be declare against great britain the three year struggle that follow largely increase the national obligation and in 1816 they have attain the sum of $ 127,000,000 wise and economical legislation however enable the government to pay the entire amount within a period of twenty year and the extinguishment of the national debt fill the land with rejoice and be one of the great event of president jackson 's administration after its redemption a large fund remain in the treasury which be deposit for safe keeping with the several states on condition that it should be return when require by the public want in 1849 the year after the termination of an expensive war with mexico we find ourselves involve in a debt of $ 64,000,000 and this be the amount owe by the government in 1860 just prior to the outbreak of the rebellion in the spring of 1861 our civil war commence each year of its continuance make an enormous addition to the debt and when in the spring of 1865 the nation successfully emerge from the conflict the obligation of the government have reach the immense sum of $ 2.873,992,909 the secretary of the treasury show that on the 1st day of november 1867 this amount have be reduce to $ 2,491,504,450 but at the same time his report exhibit an increase during the past year of $ 35,625,102 for the debt on the 1st day of november last be state to have be $ 2,527,129,552 it be estimate by the secretary that the return for the past month will add to our liability the further sum of $ 11,000,000 make a total increase during thirteen month of $ 46,500,000

 in my message to congress december 4 1865 it be suggest that a policy should be devise which without be oppressive to the people would at once begin to effect a reduction of the debt and if persist in discharge it fully within a definite number of year the secretary of the treasury forcibly recommend legislation of this character and justly urge that the long it be defer the more difficult must become its accomplishment we should follow the wise precedent establish in 1789 and 1816 and without further delay make provision for the payment of our obligation at as early a period as may be practicable the fruit of their labor should be enjoy by our citizen rather than use to build up and sustain moneyed monopoly in our own and other land our foreign debt be already compute by the secretary of the treasury at $ 850,000,000 citizen of foreign country receive interest upon a large portion of our security and american taxpayer be make to contribute large sum for their support the idea that such a debt be to become permanent should be at all time discard as involve taxation too heavy to be bear and payment once in every sixteen year at the present rate of interest of an amount equal to the original sum this vast debt if permit to become permanent and increase must eventually be gather into the hand of a few and enable they to exert a dangerous and control power in the affair of the government the borrower would become servant to the lender the lender the master of the people we now pride ourselves upon having give freedom to 4,000,000 of the colored race it will then be our shame that 40,000,000 of people by their own toleration of usurpation and profligacy have suffer themselves to become enslaved and merely exchange slave owner for new taskmaster in the shape of bondholder and tax gatherer besides permanent debt pertain to monarchical government and tend to monopoly perpetuity and class legislation be totally irreconcilable with free institution introduce into our republican system they would gradually but surely sap its foundation eventually subvert our governmental fabric and erect upon its ruin a moneyed aristocracy it be our sacred duty to transmit unimpaire to our posterity the blessing of liberty which be bequeath to we by the founder of the republic and by our example teach those who be to follow we carefully to avoid the danger which threaten a free and independent people

 various plan have be propose for the payment of the public debt however they may have vary as to the time and mode in which it should be redeem there seem to be a general concurrence as to the propriety and justness of a reduction in the present rate of interest the secretary of the treasury in his report recommend 5 percent congress in a bill pass prior to adjournment on the 27th of july last agree upon 4 and 4 1/2 percent while by many 3 percent have be hold to be an amply sufficient return for the investment the general impression as to the exorbitancy of the exist rate of interest have lead to an inquiry in the public mind respect the consideration which the government have actually receive for its bond and the conclusion be become prevalent that the amount which it obtain be in real money three or four hundred percent less than the obligation which it issue in return it can not be deny that we be pay an extravagant percentage for the use of the money borrow which be paper currency greatly depreciate below the value of coin this fact be make apparent when we consider that bondholder receive from the treasury upon each dollar they own in government security 6 percent in gold which be nearly or quite equal to 9 percent in currency that the bond be then convert into capital for the national bank upon which those institution issue their circulation bear 6 percent interest and that they be exempt from taxation by the government and the states and thereby enhance 2 percent in the hand of the holder we thus have an aggregate of 17 percent which may be receive upon each dollar by the owner of government security a system that produce such result be justly regard as favor a few at the expense of the many and have lead to the further inquiry whether our bondholder in view of the large profit which they have enjoy would themselves be averse to a settlement of our indebtedness upon a plan which would yield they a fair remuneration and at the same time be just to the taxpayer of the nation our national credit should be sacredly observe but in make provision for our creditor we should not forget what be due to the masse of the people it may be assume that the holder of our security have already receive upon their bond a large amount than their original investment measure by a gold standard upon this statement of fact it would seem but just and equitable that the 6 percent interest now pay by the government should be apply to the reduction of the principal in semiannual installment which in sixteen year and eight month would liquidate the entire national debt six percent in gold would at present rate be equal to 9 percent in currency and equivalent to the payment of the debt one and a half time in a fraction less than seventeen year this in connection with all the other advantage derive from their investment would afford to the public creditor a fair and liberal compensation for the use of their capital and with this they should be satisfy the lesson of the past admonish the lender that it be not well to be over anxious in exact from the borrower rigid compliance with the letter of the bond

 if provision be make for the payment of the indebtedness of the government in the manner suggest our nation will rapidly recover its wonte prosperity its interest require that some measure should be take to release the large amount of capital invest in the security of the government it be not now merely unproductive but in taxation annually consume $ 150,000,000 which would otherwise be use by our enterprising people in add to the wealth of the nation our commerce which at one time successfully rival that of the great maritime power have rapidly diminish and our industrial interest be in a depressed and languish condition the development of our inexhaustible resource be check and the fertile field of the south be become waste for want of mean to till they with the release of capital new life would be infuse into the paralyzed energy of our people and activity and vigor impart to every branch of industry our people need encouragement in their effort to recover from the effect of the rebellion and of injudicious legislation and it should be the aim of the government to stimulate they by the prospect of an early release from the burden which impede their prosperity if we can not take the burden from their shoulder we should at least manifest a willingness to help to bear they

 in refer to the condition of the circulate medium i shall merely reiterate substantially that portion of my last annual message which relate to that subject

 the proportion which the currency of any country should bear to the whole value of the annual produce circulate by its means be a question upon which political economist have not agree nor can it be control by legislation but must be leave to the irrevocable law which everywhere regulate commerce and trade the circulate medium will ever irresistibly flow to those point where it be in great demand the law of demand and supply be as unerring as that which regulate the tide of the ocean and indeed currency like the tide have its ebb and flow throughout the commercial world

 at the beginning of the rebellion the bank note circulation of the country amount to not much more than $ 200,000,000 now the circulation of national bank note and those know as legal tender be nearly seven hundred million while it be urge by some that this amount should be increase other contend that a decide reduction be absolutely essential to the good interest of the country in view of these diverse opinion it may be well to ascertain the real value of our paper issue when compare with a metallic or convertible currency for this purpose let we inquire how much gold and silver could be purchase by the seven hundred million of paper money now in circulation probably not more than half the amount of the latter show that when our paper currency be compare with gold and silver its commercial value be compress into three hundred and fifty million this striking fact make it the obvious duty of the government as early as may be consistent with the principle of sound political economy to take such measure as will enable the holder of its note and those of the national bank to convert they without loss into specie or its equivalent a reduction of our paper circulate medium need not necessarily follow this however would depend upon the law of demand and supply though it should be bear in mind that by make legal tender and bank note convertible into coin or its equivalent their present specie value in the hand of their holder would be enhance 100 percent



 legislation for the accomplishment of a result so desirable be demand by the high public consideration the constitution contemplate that the circulate medium of the country shall be uniform in quality and value at the time of the formation of that instrument the country have just emerge from the war of the revolution and be suffer from the effect of a redundant and worthless paper currency the sage of that period be anxious to protect their posterity from the evil which they themselves have experience hence in provide a circulate medium they confer upon congress the power to coin money and regulate the value thereof at the same time prohibit the states from make anything but gold and silver a tender in payment of debt

 the anomalous condition of our currency be in strike contrast with that which be originally design our circulation now embrace first note of the national bank which be make receivable for all due to the government exclude impost and by all its creditor except in payment of interest upon its bond and the security themselves second legal tender issue by the united states and which the law require shall be receive as well in payment of all debt between citizen as of all government due except impost and third gold and silver coin by the operation of our present system of finance however the metallic currency when collect be reserve only for one class of government creditor who hold its bond semiannually receive their interest in coin from the national treasury there be no reason which will be accept as satisfactory by the people why those who defend we on the land and protect we on the sea the pensioner upon the gratitude of the nation bear the scar and wound receive while in its service the public servant in the various department of the government the farmer who supply the soldier of the army and the sailor of the navy the artisan who toil in the nation 's workshop or the mechanic and laborer who build its edifice and construct its fort and vessel of war should in payment of their just and hard earn due receive depreciate paper while another class of their countryman no more deserving be pay in coin of gold and silver equal and exact justice require that all the creditor of the government should be pay in a currency possess a uniform value this can only be accomplish by the restoration of the currency to the standard establish by the constitution and by this mean we would remove a discrimination which may if it have not already do so create a prejudice that may become deep rooted and widespread and imperil the national credit

 the feasibility of make our currency correspond with the constitutional standard may be see by reference to a few fact derive from our commercial statistic

 the aggregate product of precious metal in the united states from 1849 to 1867 amount to $ 1,174,000,000 while for the same period the net export of specie be $ 741,000,000 this show an excess of product over net export of $ 433,000,000 there be in the treasury $ 103,407,985 in coin in circulation in the states on the pacific coast about $ 40,000,000 and a few million in the national and other bank in all less than $ 160,000,000 take into consideration the specie in the country prior to 1849 and that produce since 1867 and we have more than $ 300,000,000 not account for by exportation or by return of the treasury and therefore most probably remain in the country

 these be important fact and show how completely the inferior currency will supersede the well force it from circulation among the masse and cause it to be export as a mere article of trade to add to the money capital of foreign land they show the necessity of retire our paper money that the return of gold and silver to the avenue of trade may be invite and a demand create which will cause the retention at home of at least so much of the production of our rich and inexhaustible gold bear field as may be sufficient for purpose of circulation it be unreasonable to expect a return to a sound currency so long as the government and bank by continue to issue irredeemable note fill the channel of circulation with depreciated paper notwithstanding a coinage by our mint since 1849 of $ 874,000,000 the people be now stranger to the currency which be design for their use and benefit and specimen of the precious metal bear the national device be seldom see except when produce to gratify the interest excite by their novelty if depreciated paper be to be continue as the permanent currency of the country and all our coin be to become a mere article of traffic and speculation to the enhancement in price of all that be indispensable to the comfort of the people it would be wise economy to abolish our mint thus save the nation the care and expense incident to such establishment and let our precious metal be export in bullion the time have come however when the government and national bank should be require to take the most efficient step and make all necessary arrangement for a resumption of specie payment let specie payment once be earnestly inaugurate by the government and bank and the value of the paper circulation would directly approximate a specie standard

 specie payment having be resume by the government and bank all note or bill of paper issue by either of a less denomination than $ 20 should by law be exclude from circulation so that the people may have the benefit and convenience of a gold and silver currency which in all their business transaction will be uniform in value at home and abroad

 every man of property or industry every man who desire to preserve what he honestly possess or to obtain what he can honestly earn have a direct interest in maintain a safe circulate medium such a medium as shall be real and substantial not liable to vibrate with opinion not subject to be blow up or blow down by the breath of speculation but to be make stable and secure a disordered currency be one of the great political evil it undermine the virtue necessary for the support of the social system and encourage propensity destructive of its happiness it war against industry frugality and economy and it foster the evil spirit of extravagance and speculation

 it have be assert by one of our profound and most gifted statesman that
 of all the contrivance for cheat the labor class of mankind none have be more effectual than that which delude they with paper money this be the most effectual of invention to fertilize the rich man 's field by the sweat of the poor man 's brow ordinary tyranny oppression excessive taxation these bear lightly on the happiness of the mass of the community compare with a fraudulent currency and the robbery commit by depreciated paper our own history have record for our instruction enough and more than enough of the demoralizing tendency the injustice and the intolerable oppression on the virtuous and well dispose of a degraded paper currency authorize by law or in any way countenance by government

 it be one of the most successful device in time of peace or war of expansion or revulsion to accomplish the transfer of all the precious metal from the great mass of the people into the hand of the few where they be hoard in secret place or deposit under bolt and bar while the people be leave to endure all the inconvenience sacrifice and demoralization result from the use of depreciated and worthless paper

 on the 30th of june 1868 169,643 name be bear on the pension roll and during the year end on that day the total amount pay for pension include the expense of disbursement be $ 24,010,982 be $ 5,391,025 great than that expend for like purpose during the precede year

 treaty with various indian tribe have be conclude and will be submit to the senate for its constitutional action i cordially sanction the stipulation which provide for reserve land for the various tribe where they may be encourage to abandon their nomadic habit and engage in agricultural and industrial pursuit this policy inaugurate many year since have meet with signal success whenever it have be pursue in good faith and with become liberality by the united states the necessity for extend it as far as practicable in our relation with the aboriginal population be great now than at any precede period whilst we furnish subsistence and instruction to the indians and guarantee the undisturbed enjoyment of their treaty right we should habitually insist upon the faithful observance of their agreement to remain within their respective reservation this be the only mode by which collision with other tribe and with the white can be avoid and the safety of our frontier settlement secure

 the company construct the railway from omaha to sacramento have be most energetically engage in prosecute the work and it be believe that the line will be complete before the expiration of the next fiscal year the 6 percent bond issue to these company amount on the 5th instant to $ 44,337,000 and additional work have be perform to the extent of $ 3,200,000

 the report of the secretary of war contain information of interest and importance respect the several bureaus of the war department and the operation of the army the strength of our military force on the 30th of september last be 48,000 man and it be compute that by the 1st of january next this number will be decrease to 43,000 it be the opinion of the secretary of war that within the next year a considerable diminution of the infantry force may be make without detriment to the interest of the country and in view of the great expense attend the military peace establishment and the absolute necessity of retrenchment wherever it can be apply it be hope that congress will sanction the reduction which his report recommend while in 1860 sixteen thousand three hundred man cost the nation $ 16,472,000 the sum of $ 65,682,000 be estimate as necessary for the support of the army during the fiscal year end june 30 1870 the estimate of the war department for the last two fiscal year be for 1867 $ 33,814,461 and for 1868 $ 25,205,669 the actual expenditure during the same period be respectively $ 95,224,415 and $ 123,246,648 the estimate submit in december last for the fiscal year end june 30 1869 be $ 77,124,707 the expenditure for the first quarter end the 30th of september last be $ 27,219,117 and the secretary of the treasury give $ 66,000,000 as the amount which will probably be require during the remain three quarter if there should be no reduction of the army make its aggregate cost for the year considerably in excess of ninety three million the difference between the estimate and expenditure for the three fiscal year which have be name be thus show to be $ 175,545,343 for this single branch of the public service

 the report of the secretary of the navy exhibit the operation of that department and of the navy during the year a considerable reduction of the force have be effect there be 42 vessel carry 411 gun in the six squadron which be establish in different part of the world three of these vessel be return to the united states and 4 be use as storeship leave the actual cruise force 35 vessel carry 356 gun the total number of vessel in the navy be 206 mount 1,743 gun eighty one vessel of every description be in use arm with 696 gun the number of enlisted man in the service include apprentice have be reduce to 8,500 an increase of navy yard facility be recommend as a measure which will in the event of war be promotive of economy and security a more thorough and systematic survey of the north pacific ocean be advise in view of our recent acquisition our expand commerce and the increase intercourse between the pacific states and asia the naval pension fund which consist of a moiety of the avail of prize capture during the war amount to $ 14,000,000 exception be take to the act of 23d july last which reduce the interest on the fund loan to the government by the secretary as trustee to 3 percent instead of 6 percent which be originally stipulate when the investment be make an amendment of the pension law be suggest to remedy omission and defect in exist enactment the expenditure of the department during the last fiscal year be $ 20,120,394 and the estimate for the coming year amount to $ 20,993,414

 the postmaster general 's report furnish a full and clear exhibit of the operation and condition of the postal service the ordinary postal revenue for the fiscal year end june 30 1868 be $ 16,292,600 and the total expenditure embrace all the service for which special appropriation have be make by congress amount to $ 22,730,592 show an excess of expenditure of $ 6,437,991 deduct from the expenditure the sum of $ 1,896,525 the amount of appropriation for ocean steamship and other special service the excess of expenditure be $ 4,541,466 by use an unexpended balance in the treasury of $ 3,800,000 the actual sum for which a special appropriation be require to meet the deficiency be $ 741,466 the cause which produce this large excess of expenditure over revenue be the restoration of service in the late insurgent states and the putting into operation of new service establish by act of congress which amount within the last two year and a half to about 48,700 mile equal to more than one third of the whole amount of the service at the close of the war new postal convention with great britain north germany belgium the netherlands switzerland and italy respectively have be carry into effect under their provision important improvement have result in reduce rate of international postage and enlarge mail facility with european country the cost of the united states transatlantic ocean mail service since january 1 1868 have be largely lessen under the operation of these new convention a reduction of over one half having be effect under the new arrangement for ocean mail steamship service which go into effect on that date the attention of congress be invite to the practical suggestion and recommendation make in his report by the postmaster general

 charles a. washburn late united states minister to paraguay having resign and be desirous to return to the united states the rear admiral command the south atlantic squadron be early direct to send a ship of war to asuncion the capital of paraguay to receive mr. washburn and his family and remove they from a situation which be represent to be endanger by faction and foreign war the brazilian commander of the ally invade force refuse permission to the wasp to pass through the blockade force and that vessel return to its accustomed anchorage remonstrance having be make against this refusal it be promptly overrule and the wasp therefore resume her errand receive mr. washburn and his family and convey they to a safe and convenient seaport in the meantime an excited controversy have arise between the president of paraguay and the late united states minister which it be understand grow out of his proceeding in give asylum in the united states legation to allege enemy of that republic the question of the right to give asylum be one always difficult and often productive of great embarrassment in state well organize and establish foreign power refuse either to concede or exercise that right except as to person actually belong to the diplomatic service on the other hand all such power insist upon exercise the right of asylum in state where the law of nation be not fully acknowledge respect and obey

 the president of paraguay be understand to have oppose to mr. washburn 's proceeding the injurious and very improbable charge of personal complicity in insurrection and treason the correspondence however have not yet reach the united states

 mr. washburn in connection with this controversy represent that two united states citizen attach to the legation be arbitrarily seize at his side when leave the capital of paraguay commit to prison and there subject to torture for the purpose of procure confession of their own criminality and testimony to support the president 's allegation against the united states minister mr. mcmahon the newly appoint minister to paraguay having reach the la plata have be instruct to proceed without delay to asuncion there to investigate the whole subject the rear admiral command the united states south atlantic squadron have be direct to attend the new minister with a proper naval force to sustain such just demand as the occasion may require and to vindicate the right of the united states citizen refer to and of any other who may be expose to danger in the theater of war with these exception friendly relation have be maintain between the united states and brazil and paraguay

 our relation during the past year with bolivia ecuador peru and chile have become especially friendly and cordial spain and the republics of peru bolivia and ecuador have express their willingness to accept the mediation of the united states for terminate the war upon the south pacific coast chile have not finally declare upon the question in the meantime the conflict have practically exhaust itself since no belligerent or hostile movement have be make by either party during the last two year and there be no indication of a present purpose to resume hostility on either side great britain and france have cordially second our proposition of mediation and i do not forego the hope that it may soon be accept by all the belligerent and lead to a secure establishment of peace and friendly relation between the spanish american republics of the pacific and spain a result which would be attend with common benefit to the belligerent and much advantage to all commercial nation i communicate for the consideration of congress a correspondence which show that the bolivian republic have establish the extremely liberal principle of receive into its citizenship any citizen of the united states or of any other of the american republics upon the simple condition of voluntary registry

 the correspondence herewith submit will be find painfully replete with account of the ruin and wretchedness produce by recent earthquake of unparalleled severity in the republics of peru ecuador and bolivia the diplomatic agent and naval officer of the united states who be present in those country at the time of those disaster furnish all the relief in their power to the sufferer and be promptly reward with grateful and touching acknowledgment by the congress of peru an appeal to the charity of our fellow citizen have be answer by much liberality in this connection i submit an appeal which have be make by the swiss republic whose government and institution be kindre to our own in behalf of its inhabitant who be suffer extreme destitution produce by recent devastating inundation

 our relation with mexico during the year have be mark by an increase growth of mutual confidence the mexican government have not yet act upon the three treaty celebrate here last summer for establish the right of naturalized citizen upon a liberal and just basis for regulate consular power and for the adjustment of mutual claim

 all commercial nation as well as all friend of republican institution have occasion to regret the frequent local disturbance which occur in some of the constituent states of colombia nothing have occur however to affect the harmony and cordial friendship which have for several year exist between that youthful and vigorous republic and our own

 negotiation be pende with a view to the survey and construction of a ship canal across the isthmus of darien under the auspex of the united states i hope to be able to submit the result of that negotiation to the senate during its present session

 costa rica with the earnestness of a sincerely friendly neighbor solicit a reciprocity of trade which i commend to the consideration of congress

 the convention create by treaty between the united states and venezuela in july 1865 for the mutual adjustment of claim have be hold and its decision have be receive at the department of state the heretofore recognize government of the united states of venezuela have be subvert a provisional government having be institute under circumstance which promise durability it have be formally recognize

 i have be reluctantly oblige to ask explanation and satisfaction for national injury commit by the president of hayti the political and social condition of the republics of hayti and st. domingo be very unsatisfactory and painful the abolition of slavery which have be carry into effect throughout the island of st. domingo and the entire west indies except the spanish island of cuba and porto rico have be follow by a profound popular conviction of the rightfulness of republican institution and an intense desire to secure they the attempt however to establish republic there encounter many obstacle most of which may be suppose to result from long indulge habit of colonial supineness and dependence upon european monarchical power while the united states have on all occasion profess a decide unwillingness that any part of this continent or of its adjacent island shall be make a theater for a new establishment of monarchical power too little have be do by we on the other hand to attach the community by which we be surround to our own country or to lend even a moral support to the effort they be so resolutely and so constantly make to secure republican institution for themselves it be indeed a question of grave consideration whether our recent and present example be not calculate to check the growth and expansion of free principle and make those community distrust if not dread a government which at will consign to military domination states that be integral part of our federal union and while ready to resist any attempt by other nation to extend to this hemisphere the monarchical institution of europe assume to establish over a large portion of its people a rule more absolute harsh and tyrannical than any know to civilized power

 the acquisition of alaska be make with the view of extend national jurisdiction and republican principle in the american hemisphere believe that a further step could be take in the same direction i last year enter into a treaty with the king of denmark for the purchase of the island of st. thomas and st. john on the good term then attainable and with the express consent of the people of those island this treaty still remain under consideration in the senate a new convention have be enter into with denmark enlarge the time fix for final ratification of the original treaty

 comprehensive national policy would seem to sanction the acquisition and incorporation into our federal union of the several adjacent continental and insular community as speedily as it can be do peacefully lawfully and without any violation of national justice faith or honor foreign possession or control of those community have hitherto hinder the growth and impair the influence of the united states chronic revolution and anarchy there would be equally injurious each one of they when firmly establish as an independent republic or when incorporate into the united states would be a new source of strength and power conform my administration to these principle i have or no occasion lend support or toleration to unlawful expedition set on foot upon the plea of republican propagandism or of national extension or aggrandizement the necessity however of repress such unlawful movement clearly indicate the duty which rest upon we of adapt our legislative action to the new circumstance of a decline of european monarchical power and influence and the increase of american republican idea interest and sympathy

 it can not be long before it will become necessary for this government to lend some effective aid to the solution of the political and social problem which be continually keep before the world by the two republics of the island of st. domingo and which be now disclose themselves more distinctly than heretofore in the island of cuba the subject be commend to your consideration with all the more earnestness because i be satisfied that the time have arrive when even so direct a proceeding as a proposition for an annexation of the two republics of the island of st. domingo would not only receive the consent of the people interested but would also give satisfaction to all other foreign nation

 i be aware that upon the question of far extend our possession it be apprehend by some that our political system can not successfully be apply to an area more extended than our continent but the conviction be rapidly gain ground in the american mind that with the increase facility for intercommunication between all portion of the earth the principle of free government as embrace in our constitution if faithfully maintain and carry out would prove of sufficient strength and breadth to comprehend within their sphere and influence the civilized nation of the world

 the attention of the senate and of congress be again respectfully invite to the treaty for the establishment of commercial reciprocity with the hawaiian kingdom enter into last year and already ratify by that government the attitude of the united states toward these island be not very different from that in which they stand toward the west indies it be know and feel by the hawaiian government and people that their government and institution be feeble and precarious that the united states be so near a neighbor would be unwilling to see the island pass under foreign control their prosperity be continually disturb by expectation and alarm of unfriendly political proceeding as well from the united states as from other foreign power a reciprocity treaty while it could not materially diminish the revenue of the united states would be a guaranty of the good will and forbearance of all nation until the people of the island shall of themselves at no distant day voluntarily apply for admission into the union

 the emperor of russia have accede to the treaty negotiate here in january last for the security of trade mark in the interest of manufacturer and commerce i have invite his attention to the importance of establish now while it seem easy and practicable a fair and equal regulation of the vast fishery belong to the two nation in the water of the north pacific ocean

 the two treaty between the united states and italy for the regulation of consular power and the extradition of criminal negotiate and ratify here during the last session of congress have be accept and confirm by the italian government a liberal consular convention which have be negotiate with belgium will be submit to the senate the very important treaty which be negotiate between the united states and north germany and bavaria for the regulation of the right of naturalized citizen have be duly ratify and exchange and similar treaty have be enter into with the kingdoms of belgium and wurtemberg and with the grand duchies of baden and hesse darmstadt i hope soon to be able to submit equally satisfactory convention of the same character now in the course of negotiation with the respective governments of spain italy and the ottoman empire

 examination of claim against the united states by the hudsons bay company and the puget sound agricultural company on account of certain possessory right in the state of oregon and territory of washington allege by those company in virtue of provision of the treaty between the united states and great britain of june 15 1846 have be diligently prosecute under the direction of the joint international commission to which they be submit for adjudication by treaty between the two government of july 1 1863 and will it be expect be conclude at an early day

 no practical regulation concern colonial trade and the fishery can be accomplish by treaty between the united states and great britain until congress shall have express their judgment concern the principle involve three other question however between the united states and great britain remain open for adjustment these be the mutual right of naturalized citizen the boundary question involve the title to the island of san juan on the pacific coast and mutual claim arise since the year 1853 of the citizen and subject of the two country for injury and depredation commit under the authority of their respective government negotiation upon these subject be pende and i be not without hope of be able to lay before the senate for its consideration during the present session protocol calculate to bring to an end these justly exciting and long exist controversy

 we be not advise of the action of the chinese government upon the liberal and auspicious treaty which be recently celebrate with its plenipotentiary at this capital

 japan remain a theater of civil war mark by religious incident and political severity peculiar to that long isolate empire the executive have hitherto maintain strict neutrality among the belligerent and acknowledge with pleasure that it have be frankly and fully sustain in that course by the enlightened concurrence and cooperation of the other treaty power namely great britain france the netherlands north germany and italy

 spain having recently undergo a revolution mark by extraordinary unanimity and preservation of order the provisional government establish at madrid have be recognize and the friendly intercourse which have so long happily exist between the two country remain unchanged

 i renew the recommendation contain in my communication to congress date the 18th july last a copy of which accompany this message that the judgment of the people should be take on the propriety of so amend the federal constitution that it shall provide
 first for an election of president and vice president by a direct vote of the people instead of through the agency of elector and make they ineligible for reelection to a second term
 second for a distinct designation of the person who shall discharge the duty of president in the event of a vacancy in that office by the death resignation or removal of both the president and vice president
 third for the election of senator of the united states directly by the people of the several states instead of by the legislature and
 fourth for the limitation to a period of year of the term of federal judge

 profoundly impressed with the propriety of make these important modification in the constitution i respectfully submit they for the early and mature consideration of congress we should as far as possible remove all pretext for violation of the organic law by remedy such imperfection as time and experience may develop ever remember that the constitution which at any time exist until change by an explicit and authentic act of the whole people be sacredly obligatory upon all

 in the performance of a duty impose upon i by the constitution i have thus communicate to congress information of the state of the union and recommend for their consideration such measure as have seem to i necessary and expedient if carry into effect they will hasten the accomplishment of the great and beneficent purpose for which the constitution be ordain and which it comprehensively state be to form a more perfect union establish justice insure domestic tranquillity provide for the common defense promote the general welfare and secure the blessing of liberty to ourselves and our posterity in congress be vest all legislative power and upon they devolve the responsibility as well for frame unwise and excessive law as for neglect to devise and adopt measure absolutely demand by the want of the country let we earnestly hope that before the expiration of our respective term of service now rapidly draw to a close an all wise providence will so guide our counsel as to strengthen and preserve the federal unions inspire reverence for the constitution restore prosperity and happiness to our whole people and promote on earth peace good will toward man

citizen of the united states

 your suffrage having elect i to the office of president of the united states i have in conformity to the constitution of our country take the oath of office prescribe therein i have take this oath without mental reservation and with the determination to do to the good of my ability all that be require of i the responsibility of the position i feel but accept they without fear the office have come to i unsought i commence its duty untrammele i bring to it a conscious desire and determination to fill it to the good of my ability to the satisfaction of the people

 on all lead question agitate the public mind i will always express my view to congress and urge they accord to my judgment and when i think it advisable will exercise the constitutional privilege of interpose a veto to defeat measure which i oppose but all law will be faithfully execute whether they meet my approval or not

 i shall on all subject have a policy to recommend but none to enforce against the will of the people law be to govern all alike those oppose as well as those who favor they i know no method to secure the repeal of bad or obnoxious law so effective as their stringent execution

 the country having just emerge from a great rebellion many question will come before it for settlement in the next four year which precede administration have never have to deal with in meet these it be desirable that they should be approach calmly without prejudice hate or sectional pride remember that the great good to the great number be the object to be attain

 this require security of person property and free religious and political opinion in every part of our common country without regard to local prejudice all law to secure these end will receive my good effort for their enforcement

 a great debt have be contract in securing to we and our posterity the union the payment of this principal and interest as well as the return to a specie basis as soon as it can be accomplish without material detriment to the debtor class or to the country at large must be provide for to protect the national honor every dollar of government indebtedness should be pay in gold unless otherwise expressly stipulate in the contract let it be understand that no repudiator of one farthing of our public debt will be trust in public place and it will go far toward strengthen a credit which ought to be the good in the world and will ultimately enable we to replace the debt with bond bear less interest than we now pay to this should be add a faithful collection of the revenue a strict accountability to the treasury for every dollar collect and the great practicable retrenchment in expenditure in every department of government

 when we compare the pay capacity of the country now with the ten states in poverty from the effect of war but soon to emerge i trust into great prosperity than ever before with its pay capacity twenty five year ago and calculate what it probably will be twenty five year hence who can doubt the feasibility of pay every dollar then with more ease than we now pay for useless luxury why it look as though providence have bestow upon we a strong box in the precious metal lock up in the sterile mountain of the far west and which we be now forge the key to unlock to meet the very contingency that be now upon we

 ultimately it may be necessary to insure the facility to reach these rich and it may be necessary also that the general government should give its aid to secure this access but that should only be when a dollar of obligation to pay secure precisely the same sort of dollar to use now and not before whilst the question of specie payment be in abeyance the prudent business man be careful about contracting debt payable in the distant future the nation should follow the same rule a prostrate commerce be to be rebuild and all industry encourage

 the young man of the country those who from their age must be its ruler twenty five year hence have a peculiar interest in maintain the national honor a moment 's reflection as to what will be our command influence among the nation of the earth in their day if they be only true to themselves should inspire they with national pride all division geographical political and religious can join in this common sentiment how the public debt be to be pay or specie payment resume be not so important as that a plan should be adopt and acquiesce in a united determination to do be worth more than divided counsel upon the method of do legislation upon this subject may not be necessary now or even advisable but it will be when the civil law be more fully restore in all part of the country and trade resume its wonte channel

 it will be my endeavor to execute all law in good faith to collect all revenue assess and to have they properly account for and economically disbursed i will to the good of my ability appoint to office those only who will carry out this design

 in regard to foreign policy i would deal with nation as equitable law require individual to deal with each other and i would protect the law abide citizen whether of native or foreign birth wherever his right be jeopardize or the flag of our country float i would respect the right of all nation demand equal respect for our own if other depart from this rule in their dealing with we we may be compel to follow their precedent

 the proper treatment of the original occupant of this land the indians one deserving of careful study i will favor any course toward they which tend to their civilization and ultimate citizenship

 the question of suffrage be one which be likely to agitate the public so long as a portion of the citizen of the nation be exclude from its privilege in any state it seem to i very desirable that this question should be settle now and i entertain the hope and express the desire that it may be by the ratification of the fifteenth article of amendment to the constitution

 in conclusion i ask patient forbearance one toward another throughout the land and a determined effort on the part of every citizen to do his share toward cement a happy union and i ask the prayer of the nation to almighty god in behalf of this consummation

to the senate and house of representatives
 while i be aware that the time in which congress propose now to remain in session be very brief and that it be its desire as far as be consistent with the public interest to avoid enter upon the general business of legislation there be one subject which concern so deeply the welfare of the country that i deem it my duty to bring it before you
 i have no doubt that you will concur with i in the opinion that it be desirable to restore the states which be engage in the rebellion to their proper relation to the government and the country at as early a period as the people of those states shall be find willing to become peaceful and orderly community and to adopt and maintain such constitution and law as will effectually secure the civil and political right of all person within their border the authority of the united states which have be vindicate and establish by its military power must undoubtedly be assert for the absolute protection of all its citizen in the full enjoyment of the freedom and security which be the object of a republican government but whenever the people of a rebellious state be ready to enter in good faith upon the accomplishment of this object in entire conformity with the constitutional authority of congress it be certainly desirable that all cause of irritation should be remove as promptly as possible that a more perfect union may be establish and the country be restore to peace and prosperity
 the convention of the people of virginia which meet in richmond on tuesday december 3 1867 frame a constitution for that state which be adopt by the convention on the 17th of april 1868 and i desire respectfully to call the attention of congress to the propriety of provide by law for the holding of an election in that state at some time during the month of may and june next under the direction of the military commander of that district at which the question of the adoption of that constitution shall be submit to the citizen of the state and if this should seem desirable i would recommend that a separate vote be take upon such part as may be think expedient and that at the same time and under the same authority there shall be an election for the officer provide under such constitution and that the constitution or such part thereof as shall have be adopt by the people be submit to congress on the first monday of december next for its consideration so that if the same be then approve the necessary step will have be take for the restoration of the state of virginia to its proper relation to the union i be lead to make this recommendation from the confident hope and belief that the people of that state be now ready to cooperate with the national government in bring it again into such relation to the union as it ought as soon as possible to establish and maintain and to give to all its people those equal right under the law which be assert in the declaration of independence in the word of one of the most illustrious of its son
 i desire also to ask the consideration of congress to the question whether there be not just ground for believe that the constitution frame by a convention of the people of mississippi for that state and once reject might not be again submit to the people of that state in like manner and with the probability of the same result


 by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 in pursuance of the provision of the act of congress approve april 10 1869 i hereby designate the 6th day of july 1869 as the time for submit the constitution pass by the convention which meet in richmond va. on tuesday the 3d day of december 1867 to the voter of say state register at the date of such submission viz july 6 1869 for ratification or rejection
 and i submit to a separate vote the fourth clause of section 1 of article 3 of say constitution which be in the following word
 every person who have be a senator or representative in congress or elector of president or vice president or who hold any office civil or military under the united states or under any state who having previously take an oath as a member of congress or as an officer of the united states or as a member of any state legislature or as an executive or judicial officer of any state shall have engage in insurrection or rebellion against the same or give aid or comfort to the enemy thereof this clause shall include the follow officer governor lieutenant governor secretary of state auditor of public account second auditor register of the land office state treasurer attorney general sheriff sergeant of a city or town commissioner of the revenue county surveyor constable overseer of the poor commissioner of the hoard of public work judge of the supreme court judge of the circuit court judge of the court of husting justice of the county court mayor recorder alderman councilman of a city or town coroner escheator inspector of tobacco flour etc clerk of the supreme district circuit and county court and of the court of husting and attorney for the commonwealth provide that the legislature may by a vote of three fifth of both house remove the disability incur by this clause from any person include therein by a separate vote in each case
 and i also submit to a separate vote the seventh section of article 3 of the said constitution which be in the word follow
 in addition to the foregoing oath of office the governor lieutenant governor member of the general assembly secretary of state auditor of public account state treasurer attorney general and all person elect to any convention to frame a constitution for this state or to amend or revise this constitution in any manner and mayor and council of any city or town shall before they enter on the duty of their respective office take and subscribe the follow oath or affirmation provide the disability therein contain may be individually remove by a three fifth vote of the general assembly
 i do solemnly swear or affirm that i have never voluntarily bear arm against the united states since i have be a citizen thereof that i have voluntarily give no aid countenance counsel or encouragement to person engage in armed hostility thereto that i have never seek nor accept nor attempt to exercise the function of any office whatever under any authority or pretended authority in hostility to the united states that i have not yield a voluntary support to any pretended government authority power or constitution within the united states hostile or inimical thereto and i do far swear or affirm that to the good of my knowledge and ability i will support and defend the constitution of the united states against all enemy foreign and domestic that i will bear true faith and allegiance to the same that i take this obligation freely without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion and that i will well and faithfully discharge the duty of the office on which i be about to enter so help i god
 the above oath shall also be take by all the city and county officer before enter upon their duty and by all other state officer not include in the above provision i direct the vote to be take upon each of the above cite provision alone and upon the other portion of the say constitution in the follow manner viz
 each voter favor the ratification of the constitution exclude the provision above quote as frame by the convention of december 3 1867 shall express his judgment by vote for the constitution
 each voter favor the rejection of the constitution exclude the provision above quote shall express his judgment by vote against the constitution
 each voter will be allow to cast a separate ballot for or against either or both of the provision above quote
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 14th day of may a. d. 1869 and of the independence of the united states of america the ninety third
 u. s. grant
 by the president
 hamilton fish secretary of state

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas the act of congress approve june 25 1868 constitute on and after that date eight hour a day&#39;s work for all laborer workman and mechanic employ by or on behalf of the government of the united states and repeal all act and part of act inconsistent therewith
 now therefore i ulysses s. grant president of the united states do hereby direct that from and after this date no reduction shall be make in the wage pay by the government by the day to such laborer workman and mechanic on account of such reduction of the hour of labor
 in testimony whereof i have hereto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 19th day of may a. d. 1869 and of the independence of the united states the ninety third
