to the senate and house of representatives in come before you for the first time as chief magistrate of this great nation it be with gratitude to the giver of all good for the many benefit we enjoy we be bless with peace at home and be without entangle alliance abroad to forebode trouble with a territory unsurpasse in fertility of an area equal to the abundant support of 500,000,000 people and abound in every variety of useful mineral in quantity sufficient to supply the world for generation with exuberant crop with a variety of climate adapt to the production of every specie of earth 's rich and suit to the habit taste and requirement of every live thing with a population of 40,000,000 free people all speak one language with facility for every mortal to acquire an education with institution close to none the avenue to fame or any blessing of fortune that may be covet with freedom of the pulpit the press and the school with a revenue flow into the national treasury beyond the requirement of the government happily harmony be be rapidly restore within our own border manufacture hitherto unknown in our country be spring up in all section produce a degree of national independence unequale by that of any other power these blessing and countless other be intrust to your care and mine for safe keeping for the brief period of our tenure of office in a short time we must each of we return to the rank of the people who have confer upon we our honor and account to they for our stewardship i earnestly desire that neither you nor i may be condemn by a free and enlightened constituency nor by our own conscience emerge from a rebellion of gigantic magnitude aid as it be by the sympathy and assistance of nation with which we be at peace eleven states of the union be four year ago leave without legal state government a national debt have be contract american commerce be almost drive from the sea the industry of one half of the country have be take from the control of the capitalist and place where all labor rightfully belong in the keeping of the laborer the work of restore state government loyal to the union of protect and foster free labor and provide mean for pay the interest on the public debt have receive ample attention from congress although your effort have not meet with the success in all particular that might have be desire yet on the whole they have be more successful than could have be reasonably anticipate seven state which pass ordinance of secession have be fully restore to their place in the union the eighth georgia hold an election at which she ratify her constitution republican in form elect a governor members of congress a state legislature and all other officer require the governor be duly instal and the legislature meet and perform all the act then require of they by the reconstruction act of congress subsequently however in violation of the constitution which they have just ratify as since decide by the supreme court of the state they unseat the colored member of the legislature and admit to seat some member who be disqualify by the third clause of the fourteenth amendment to the constitution an article which they themselves have contribute to ratify under these circumstance i would submit to you whether it would not be wise without delay to enact a law authorize the governor of georgia to convene the member originally elect to the legislature require each member to take the oath prescribe by the reconstruction act and none to be admit who be ineligible under the third clause of the fourteenth amendment the freedman under the protection which they have receive be make rapid progress in learning and no complaint be hear of lack of industry on their part where they receive fair remuneration for their labor the mean provide for pay the interest on the public debt with all other expense of government be more than ample the loss of our commerce be the only result of the late rebellion which have not receive sufficient attention from you to this subject i call your earnest attention i will not now suggest plan by which this object may be effect but will if necessary make it the subject of a special message during the session of congress at the march term congress by joint resolution authorize the executive to order election in the states of virginia mississippi and texas to submit to they the constitution which each have previously in convention frame and submit the constitution either entire or in separate part to be vote upon at the discretion of the executive under this authority election be call in virginia the election take place on the 6th of july 1869 the governor and lieutenant governor elect have be instal the legislature meet and do all require by this resolution and by all the reconstruction act of congress and abstain from all doubtful authority i recommend that her senators and representatives be promptly admit to their seat and that the state be fully restore to its place in the family of states election be call in mississippi and texas to commence on the 30th of november 1869 and to last two day in mississippi and four day in texas the election have take place but the result be not know it be to be hope that the act of the legislature of these states when they meet will be such as to receive your approval and thus close the work of reconstruction among the evil grow out of the rebellion and not yet refer to be that of an irredeemable currency it be an evil which i hope will receive your most earnest attention it be a duty and one of the high duty of government to secure to the citizen a medium of exchange of fix unvarying value this imply a return to a specie basis and no substitute for it can be devise it should be commence now and reach at the early practicable moment consistent with a fair regard to the interest of the debtor class immediate resumption if practicable would not be desirable it would compel the debtor class to pay beyond their contract the premium on gold at the date of their purchase and would bring bankruptcy and ruin to thousand fluctuation however in the paper value of the measure of all value gold be detrimental to the interest of trade it make the man of business an involuntary gambler for in all sale where future payment be to be make both party speculate as to what will be the value of the currency to be pay and receive i earnestly recommend to you then such legislation as will insure a gradual return to specie payment and put an immediate stop to fluctuation in the value of currency the method to secure the former of these result be as numerous as be the speculator on political economy to secure the latter i see but one way and that be to authorize the treasury to redeem its own paper at a fix price whenever present and to withhold from circulation all currency so redeem until sell again for gold the vast resource of the nation both develop and undeveloped ought to make our credit the good on earth with a less burden of taxation than the citizen have endure for six year past the entire public debt could be pay in ten year but it be not desirable that the people should be tax to pay it in that time year by year the ability to pay increase in a rapid ratio but the burden of interest ought to be reduce as rapidly as can be do without the violation of contract the public debt be represent in great part by bond have from five to twenty and from ten to forty year to run bear interest at the rate of 6 per cent and 5 per cent respectively it be optional with the government to pay these bond at any period after the expiration of the least time mention upon their face the time have already expire when a great part of they may be take up and be rapidly approach when all may be it be believe that all which be now due may be replace by bond bear a rate of interest not exceed 4 1/2 per cent and as rapidly as the remainder become due that they may be replace in the same way to accomplish this it may be necessary to authorize the interest to be pay at either of three or four of the money center of europe or by any assistant treasurer of the united states at the option of the holder of the bond i suggest this subject for the consideration of congress and also simultaneously with this the propriety of redeem our currency as before suggest at its market value at the time the law go into effect increase the rate at which currency shall be buy and sell from day to day or week to week at the same rate of interest as government pay upon its bond the subject of tariff and internal taxation will necessarily receive your attention the revenue of the country be great than the requirement and may with safety be reduce but as the funding of the debt in a 4 or a 4 1/2 per cent loan would reduce annual current expense largely thus after funding justify a great reduction of taxation than would be now expedient i suggest postponement of this question until the next meeting of congress it may be advisable to modify taxation and tariff in instance where unjust or burdensome discrimination be make by the present law but a general revision of the law regulate this subject i recommend the postponement of for the present i also suggest the renewal of the tax on income but at a reduce rate say of 3 per cent and this tax to expire in three year with the funding of the national debt as here suggest i feel safe in say that taxis and the revenue from import may be reduce safely from sixty to eighty million per annum at once and may be still far reduce from year to year as the resource of the country be develop the report of the secretary of the treasury show the receipt of the government for the fiscal year end june 30 1869 to be $ 370,943,747 and the expenditure include interest bounty etc to be $ 321,490,597 the estimate for the ensue year be more favorable to the government and will no doubt show a much large decrease of the public debt the receipt in the treasury beyond expenditure have exceed the amount necessary to place to the credit of the sink fund as provide by law to lock up the surplus in the treasury and withhold it from circulation would lead to such a contraction of the currency as to cripple trade and seriously affect the prosperity of the country under these circumstance the secretary of the treasury and myself heartily concur in the propriety of use all the surplus currency in the treasury in the purchase of government bond thus reduce the interest bear indebtedness of the country and of submit to congress the question of the disposition to be make of the bond so purchase the bond now hold by the treasury amount to about seventy five million include those belong to the sink fund i commissioner of custom revenue for the increase of salary to certain class of official the substitution of increase national bank circulation to replace the outstanding 3 per cent certificate and most especially to his recommendation for the repeal of law allow share of fine penalty forfeiture etc to officer of the government or to informer the office of commissioner of internal revenue be one of the most arduous and responsible under the government it fall but little if any short of a cabinet position in its importance and responsibility i would ask for it therefore such legislation as in your judgment will place the office upon a footing of dignity commensurate with its importance and with the character and qualification of the class of man require to fill it properly as the united states be the free of all nation so too its people sympathize with all people struggle for liberty and self government but while so sympathize it be due to our honor that we should abstain from enforce our view upon unwilling nation and from take an interested part without invitation in the quarrel between different nation or between government and their subject our course should always be in conformity with strict justice and law international and local such have be the policy of the administration in deal with these question for more than a year a valuable province of spain and a near neighbor of ours in whom all our people can not but feel a deep interest have be struggle for independence and freedom the people and government of the united states entertain the same warm feeling and sympathy for the people of cuba in their pending struggle that they manifest throughout the previous struggle between spain and her former colony in behalf of the latter but the contest have at no time assume the condition which amount to a war in the sense of international law or which would show the existence of a de facto political organization of the insurgent sufficient to justify a government they believe to be oppressive or to independent nation at war with each other the united states have no disposition to interfere with the exist relation of spain to her colonial possession on this continent they believe that in due time spain and other european power will find their interest in terminate those relation and establish their present dependency as independent power member of the family of nation these dependency be no long regard as subject to transfer from one european power to another when the present relation of colony cease they be to become independent power settlement of the grave wrong that bad be sustain by this government as well as by its citizen the injury result to the united states by reason of the course adopt by great britain during our late civil war in the increase rate of insurance in the diminution of export and import and other obstruction to domestic industry and production in its effect upon the foreign commerce of the country in the decrease and transfer to great britain of our commercial marine in the prolongation of the war and the increase cost both in treasure and in life of its suppression could not be adjust and satisfied as ordinary commercial claim which continually arise between commercial nation and yet the convention treat they simply as such ordinary claim from which they differ more widely in the gravity of their character than in the magnitude of their amount great even as be that difference not a word be find in the treaty and not an inference could be draw from it to remove the sense of the unfriendliness of the course of great britain in our struggle for existence which have so deeply and universally impress itself upon the people of this country believe that a convention thus misconceive in its scope and inadequate in its provision would not have produce the hearty cordial settlement of pende question which alone be consistent with the relation which i desire to have firmly establish between the united states and great britain i regard the action of the senate in reject the treaty to have be wisely take in the interest of peace and as a necessary step in the direction of a perfect and cordial friendship between the two country a sensitive people conscious of their power be more at ease under a great wrong wholly unatoned than under the restraint of a settlement which satisfy neither their idea of justice nor their grave sense of the grievance they have sustain the rejection of the treaty be follow by a state of public feeling on both side which i think not favorable to an immediate attempt at renew negotiation i accordingly so instruct the minister of the united states to great britain and find that my view in this regard be share by her majesty 's minister i hope that the time may soon arrive when the two government can approach the solution of this momentous question with an appreciation of what be due to the right dignity and honor of each and with the determination not only to remove the cause of complaint in the past but to lay the foundation of a broad principle of public law which will prevent future difference and tend to to the senate and house of representatives
 it be unusual to notify the two houses of congress by message of the promulgation by proclamation of the secretary of state of the ratification of a constitutional amendment in view however of the vast importance of the fifteenth amendment to the constitution this day declare a part of that revere instrument i deem a departure from the usual custom justifiable a measure which make at once 4,000,000 people voter who be heretofore declare by the high tribunal in the land not citizen of the united states nor eligible to become so with the assertion that at the time of the declaration of independence the opinion be fix and universal in the civilized portion of the white race regard as an axiom in moral as well as in politic that black man have no right which the white man be bind to respect be indeed a measure of grander importance than any other one act of the kind from the foundation of our free government to the present day
 institution like ours in which all power be derive directly from the people must depend mainly upon their intelligence patriotism and industry i call the attention therefore of the newly enfranchised race to the importance of their strive in every honorable manner to make themselves worthy of their new privilege to the race more favor heretofore by our law i would say withhold no legal privilege of advancement to the new citizen the framer of our constitution firmly believe that a republican government could not endure without intelligence and education generally diffuse among the people the father of his country in his farewell address use this language
 promote then as an object of primary importance institution for the general diffusion of knowledge in proportion as the structure of a government give force to public opinion it be essential that public opinion should be enlighten
 in his first annual message to congress the same view be forcibly present and be again urge in his eighth message
 i repeat that the adoption of the fifteenth amendment to the constitution complete the great civil change and constitute the most important event that have occur since the nation come into life the change will be beneficial in proportion to the heed that be give to the urgent recommendation of washington if these recommendation be important then with a population of but a few million how much more important now with a population of 40,000,000 and increase in a rapid ratio i would therefore call upon congress to take all the mean within their constitutional power to promote and encourage popular education throughout the country and upon the people everywhere to see to it that all who possess and exercise political right shall have the opportunity to acquire the knowledge which will make their share in the government a blessing and not a danger by such mean only can the benefit contemplate by this amendment to the constitution be secure
 u. s. grant
 hamilton fish secretary of state of the united states
 to all to whom these present may come greet
 know ye that the congress of the united states on or about the 27th day of february in the year 1869 pass a resolution in the word and figure follow to wit
 a resolution propose an amendment to the constitution of the united states
 resolve by the senate and house of representatives of the united states of america in congress assemble two third of both houses concur that the follow article be propose to the legislature of the several states as an amendment to the constitution of the united states which when ratify by three fourth of say legislature shall be valid as a part of the constitution viz
 article xv
 section 1 the right of citizen of the united states to vote shall not be deny or abridge by the united states or by any state on account of race color or previous condition of servitude
 sec 2 the congress shall have power to enforce this article by appropriate legislation
 and far that it appear from official document on file in this department that the amendment to the constitution of the united states propose as aforesaid have be ratify by the legislature of the states of north carolina west virginia massachusetts wisconsin maine louisiana michigan south carolina pennsylvania arkansas connecticut florida illinois indiana new york new hampshire nevada vermont virginia alabama missouri mississippi ohio iowa kansas minnesota rhode island nebraska and texas in all twenty nine states
 and far that the states whose legislature have so ratify the say propose amendment constitute three fourth of the whole number of states in the united states
 and far that it appear from an official document on file in this department that the legislature of the state of new york have since pass resolution claim to withdraw the say ratification of the say amendment which have be make by the legislature of that state and of which official notice have be file in this department
 and far that it appear from an official document on file in this department that the legislature of georgia have by resolution ratify the say propose amendment
 now therefore be it know that i hamilton fish secretary of state of the united states by virtue and in pursuance of the second section of the act of congress approve the 20th day of april in the year 1818 entitle an act to provide for the publication of the law of the united states and for other purpose do hereby certify that the amendment aforesaid have become valid to all intent and purpose as part of the constitution of the united states
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the department of state to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 30th day of march a. d. 1870 and of the independence of the united states the ninety fourth
 hamilton fish


 by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas it have come to my knowledge that sundry illegal military enterprise and expedition be be set on foot within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states with a view to carry on the same from such territory and jurisdiction against the people and district of the dominion of canada within the dominion of her majesty the queen of the united kingdom of great britain and ireland with whom the united states be at peace
 now therefore i ulysses s. grant president of the united states do hereby admonish all good citizen of the united states and all person within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states against aid countenancing abetting or take part in such unlawful proceeding and i do hereby warn all person that by commit such illegal act they will forfeit all right to the protection of the government or to its interference in their behalf to rescue they from the consequence of their own act and i do hereby enjoin all officer in the service of the united states to employ all their lawful authority and power to prevent and defeat the aforesaid unlawful proceeding and to arrest and bring to justice all person who may be engage therein
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 24th day of may a. d. 1870 and of the independence of the united states the ninety fourth
 u. s. grant
 by the president
 hamilton fish
 secretary of state

to the senate of the united states
 i transmit to the senate for consideration with a view to its ratification an additional article to the treaty of the 29th of november last for the annexation of the dominican republic to the united states stipulate for an extension of the time for exchange the ratification thereof sign in this city on the 14th instant by the plenipotentiary of the party
 it be my intention to have also negotiate with the plenipotentiary of san domingo amendment to the treaty of annexation to obviate objection which may be urge against the treaty as it be now word but on reflection i deem it well to submit to the senate the propriety of their amend the treaty as follow first to specify that the obligation of this government shall not exceed the $ 1,500,000 stipulate in the treaty secondly to determine the manner of appoint the agent to receive and disburse the same thirdly to determine the class of creditor who shall take precedence in the settlement of their claim and finally to insert such amendment as may suggest themselves to the mind of senator to carry out in good faith the condition of the treaty submit to the senate of the united states in january last accord to the spirit and intent of that treaty from the most reliable information i can obtain the sum specify in the treaty will pay every just claim against the republic of san domingo and leave a balance sufficient to carry on a territorial government until such time as new law for provide a territorial revenue can be enact and put in force
 i feel an unusual anxiety for the ratification of this treaty because i believe it will redound greatly to the glory of the two country interest to civilization and to the extirpation of the institution of slavery
 the doctrine promulgate by president monroe have be adhere to by all political party and i now deem it proper to assert the equally important principle that hereaft no territory on this continent shall be regard as subject of transfer to a european power
 the government of san domingo have voluntarily seek this annexation it be a weak power number probably less than 120,000 soul and yet possess one of the rich territory under the sun capable of support a population of 10,000,000 people in luxury the people of san domingo be not capable of maintain themselves in their present condition and must look for outside support
 they yearn for the protection of our free institution and law our progress and civilization shall we refuse they
 i have information which i believe reliable that a european power stand ready now to offer $ 2,000,000 for the possession of samana bay alone if refuse by we with what grace can we prevent a foreign power from attempt to secure the prize
 the acquisition of san domingo be desirable because of its geographical position it command the entrance to the caribbean sea and the isthmus transit of commerce it possess the rich soil good and most capacious harbor most salubrious climate and the most valuable product of the forest mine and soil of any of the west india islands its possession by we will in a few year build up a coastwise commerce of immense magnitude which will go far toward restore to we our lose merchant marine it will give to we those article which we consume so largely and do not produce thus equalize our export and import
 in case of foreign war it will give we command of all the island refer to and thus prevent an enemy from ever again possess himself of rendezvous upon our very coast
 at present our coast trade between the states border on the atlantic and those border on the gulf of mexico be cut into by the bahamas and the antilles twice we must as it be pass through foreign country to get by sea from georgia to the west coast of florida
 san domingo with a stable government under which her immense resource can be develop will give remunerative wage to ten of thousand of laborer not now on the island
 this labor will take advantage of every available mean of transportation to abandon the adjacent island and seek the blessing of freedom and its sequence each inhabitant receive the reward of his own labor porto rico and cuba will have to abolish slavery as a measure of self preservation to retain their laborer
 san domingo will become a large consumer of the product of northern farm and manufactory the cheap rate at which her citizen can be furnish with food tool and machinery will make it necessary that the contiguous island should have the same advantage in order to compete in the production of sugar coffee tobacco tropical fruit etc this will open to we a still wide market for our product
 the production of our own supply of these article will cut off more than one hundred million of our annual import besides largely increase our export with such a picture it be easy to see how our large debt abroad be ultimately to be extinguish with a balance of trade against we include interest on bond hold by foreigner and money spend by our citizen travel in foreign land equal to the entire yield of the precious metal in this country it be not so easy to see how this result be to be otherwise accomplish
 the acquisition of san domingo be an adherence to the monroe doctrine it be a measure of national protection it be assert our just claim to a control influence over the great commercial traffic soon to flow from east to west by the way of the isthmus of darien it be to build up our merchant marine it be to furnish new market for the product of our farm shop and manufactory it be to make slavery insupportable in cuba and porto rico at once and ultimately so in brazil it be to settle the unhappy condition of cuba and end an exterminate conflict it be to provide honest mean of pay our honest debt without overtax the people it be to furnish our citizen with the necessary of everyday life at cheap rate than ever before and it be in fine a rapid stride toward that greatness which the intelligence industry and enterprise of the citizen of the united states entitle this country to assume among nation

to the senate and house of representatives
 in my annual message to congress at the beginning of its present session i refer to the contest which have then for more than a year exist in the island of cuba between a portion of its inhabitant and the government of spain and the feeling and sympathy of the people and government of the united states for the people of cuba as for all people struggle for liberty and self government and say that the contest have at no time assume the condition which amount to war in the sense of international law or which would show the existence of a de facto political organization of the insurgent sufficient to justify a recognition of belligerency
 during the six month which have pass since the date of that message the condition of the insurgent have not improve and the insurrection itself although not subdue exhibit no sign of advance but seem to be confine to an irregular system of hostility carry on by small and illy armed band of man roam without concentration through the wood and the sparsely populated region of the island attack from ambush convoy and small band of troop burn plantation and the estate of those not sympathize with their cause
 but if the insurrection have not gain ground it be equally true that spain have not suppress it climate disease and the occasional bullet have work destruction among the soldier of spain and although the spanish authority have possession of every seaport and every town on the island they have not be able to subdue the hostile feeling which have drive a considerable number of the native inhabitant of the island to armed resistance against spain and still lead they to endure the danger and the privation of a roam life of guerrilla warfare
 on either side the contest have be conduct and be still carry on with a lamentable disregard of human life and of the rule and practice which modern civilization have prescribe in mitigation of the necessary horror of war the torch of spaniard and of cuban be alike busy in carry devastation over fertile region murderous and revengeful decree be issue and execute by both party count valmaseda and colonel boet on the part of spain have each startled humanity and arouse the indignation of the civilized world by the execution each of a score of prisoner at a time while general quesada the cuban chief coolly and with apparent unconsciousness of aught else than a proper act have admit the slaughter by his own deliberate order in one day of upward of 650 prisoner of war
 a summary trial with few if any escape from conviction follow by immediate execution be the fate of those arrest on either side on suspicion of infidelity to the cause of the party make the arrest
 whatever may be the sympathy of the people or of the government of the united states for the cause or object for which a part of the people of cuba be understand to have put themselves in armed resistance to the government of spain there can be no just sympathy in a conflict carry on by both party alike in such barbarous violation of the rule of civilized nation and with such continued outrage upon the plain principle of humanity
 we can not discriminate in our censure of their mode of conduct their contest between the spaniards and the cubans each commit the same atrocity and outrage alike the establish rule of war
 the property of many of our citizen have be destroy or embargo the life of several have be sacrifice and the liberty of other have be restrain in every case that have come to the knowledge of the government an early and earnest demand for reparation and indemnity have be make and most emphatic remonstrance have be present against the manner in which the strife be conduct and against the reckless disregard of human life the wanton destruction of material wealth and the cruel disregard of the establish rule of civilized warfare
 i have since the beginning of the present session of congress communicate to the house of representatives upon their request an account of the step which i have take in the hope of bring this sad conflict to an end and of securing to the people of cuba the blessing and the right of independent self government the effort thus make fail but not without an assurance from spain that the good office of this government might still avail for the object to which they have be address
 during the whole contest the remarkable exhibition have be make of large number of cubans escape from the island and avoid the risk of war congregate in this country at a safe distance from the scene of danger and endeavor to make war from our shore to urge our people into the fight which they avoid and to embroil this government in complication and possible hostility with spain it can scarce be doubt that this last result be the real object of these party although carefully cover under the deceptive and apparently plausible demand for a mere recognition of belligerency
 it be state on what i have reason to regard as good authority that cuban bond have be prepare to a large amount whose payment be make dependent upon the recognition by the united states of either cuban belligerency or independence the object of make their value thus contingent upon the action of this government be a subject for serious reflection
 in determine the course to be adopt on the demand thus make for a recognition of belligerency the liberal and peaceful principle adopt by the father of his country and the eminent statesman of his day and follow by succeed chief magistrates and the man of their day may furnish a safe guide to those of we now charge with the direction and control of the public safety
 from 1789 to 1815 the dominant thought of our statesman be to keep the united states out of the war which be devastate europe the discussion of measure of neutrality begin with the state paper of mr. jefferson when secretary of state he show that they be measure of national right as well as of national duty that misguide individual citizen can not be tolerate in make war accord to their own caprice passion interest or foreign sympathy that the agent of foreign government recognize or unrecognize can not be permit to abuse our hospitality by usurp the function of enlist or equip military or naval force within our territory washington inaugurate the policy of neutrality and of absolute abstinence from all foreign entangle alliance which result in 1794 in the first municipal enactment for the observance of neutrality
 the duty of opposition to filibustering have be admit by every president washington encounter the effort of genet and of the french revolutionist john adams the project of miranda jefferson the scheme of aaron burr madison and subsequent president have to deal with the question of foreign enlistment or equipment in the united states and since the day of john quincy adams it have be one of the constant care of government in the united states to prevent piratical expedition against the feeble spanish american republics from leave our shore in no country be man want for any enterprise that hold out promise of adventure or of gain
 in the early day of our national existence the whole continent of america outside of the limit of the united states and all its island be in colonial dependence upon european power
 the revolution which from 1810 spread almost simultaneously through all the spanish american continental colony result in the establishment of new states like ourselves of european origin and interested in exclude european politic and the question of dynasty and of balance of power from further influence in the new world
 the american policy of neutrality important before become doubly so from the fact that it become applicable to the new republics as well as to the mother country
 it then devolve upon we to determine the great international question at what time and under what circumstance to recognize a new power as entitle to a place among the family of nation as well as the preliminary question of the attitude to be observe by this government toward the insurrectionary party pende the contest
 mr. monroe concisely express the rule which have control the action of this government with reference to revolt colony pende their struggle by say
 as soon as the movement assume such a steady and consistent form as to make the success of the provinces probable the right to which they be entitle by the law of nation as equal party to a civil war be extend to they
 the strict adherence to this rule of public policy have be one of the high honor of american statesmanship and have secure to this government the confidence of the feeble power on this continent which induce they to rely upon its friendship and absence of design of conquest and to look to the united states for example and moral protection it have give to this government a position of prominence and of influence which it should not abdicate but which impose upon it the most delicate duty of right and of honor regard american question whether those question affect emancipate colony or colony still subject to european dominion
 the question of belligerency be one of fact not to be decide by sympathy for or prejudice against either party the relation between the parent state and the insurgent must amount in fact to war in the sense of international law fight though fierce and protract do not alone constitute war there must be military force act in accordance with the rule and custom of war flag of truce cartel exchange of prisoner etc and to justify a recognition of belligerency there must be above all a de facto political organization of the insurgent sufficient in character and resource to constitute it if leave to itself a state among nation capable of discharge the duty of a state and of meet the just responsibility it may incur as such toward other power in the discharge of its national duty
 apply the good information which i have be enable to gather whether from official or unofficial source include the very exaggerated statement which each party give to all that may prejudice the opposite or give credit to its own side of the question i be unable to see in the present condition of the contest in cuba those element which be requisite to constitute war in the sense of international law
 the insurgent hold no town or city have no establish seat of government they have no prize court no organization for the receiving and collecting of revenue no seaport to which a prize may be carry or through which access can be have by a foreign power to the limited interior territory and mountain fastness which they occupy the existence of a legislature represent any popular constituency be more than doubtful
 in the uncertainty that hang around the entire insurrection there be no palpable evidence of an election of any delegate authority or of any government outside the limit of the camp occupy from day to day by the rove company of insurgent troop there be no commerce no trade either internal or foreign no manufacture
 the late commander in chief of the insurgent having recently come to the united states publicly declare that all commercial intercourse or trade with the exterior world have be utterly cut off and he far add today we have not 10,000 arm in cuba
 it be a well establish principle of public law that a recognition by a foreign state of belligerent right to insurgent under circumstance such as now exist in cuba if not justify by necessity be a gratuitous demonstration of moral support to the rebellion such necessity may yet hereafter arrive but it have not yet arrive nor be its probability clearly to be see
 if it be war between spain and cuba and be so recognize it be our duty to provide for the consequence which may ensue in the embarrassment to our commerce and the interference with our revenue
 if belligerency be recognize the commercial marine of the united states become liable to search and to seizure by the commission cruiser of both party they become subject to the adjudication of prize court
 our large coastwise trade between the atlantic and the gulf states and between both and the isthmus of panama and the states of south america engage the large part of our commercial marine pass of necessity almost in sight of the island of cuba under the treaty with spain of 1795 as well as by the law of nation our vessel will be liable to visit on the high sea in case of belligerency the carrying of contraband which now be lawful become liable to the risk of seizure and condemnation the parent government become relieved from responsibility for act do in the insurgent territory and acquire the right to exercise against neutral commerce all the power of a party to a maritime war to what consequence the exercise of those power may lead be a question which i desire to commend to the serious consideration of congress
 in view of the gravity of this question i have deem it my duty to invite the attention of the war make power of the country to all the relation and bearing of the question in connection with the declaration of neutrality and granting of belligerent right
 there be not a de facto government in the island of cuba sufficient to execute law and maintain just relation with other nation spain have not be able to suppress the opposition to spanish rule on the island nor to award speedy justice to other nation or citizen of other nation when their right have be invade
 there be serious complication grow out of the seizure of american vessel upon the high sea execute american citizen without proper trial and confiscate or embargo the property of american citizen solemn protest have be make against every infraction of the right either of individual citizen of the united states or the right of our flag upon the high sea and all proper step have be take and be be press for the proper reparation of every indignity complain of
 the question of belligerency however which be to be decide upon definite principle and accord to ascertained fact be entirely different from and unconnected with the other question of the manner in which the strife be carry on both side and the treatment of our citizen entitle to our protection
 the question concern our own dignity and responsibility and they have be make as i have say the subject of repeat communication with spain and of protest and demand for redress on our part it be hope that these will not be disregard but should they be these question will be make the subject of a further communication to congress

to the senate of the united states
 i transmit to the senate in answer to their resolution of the 7th instant a report from the secretary of state with accompany document
 u. s. grant
 department of state
 washington july 14 1870
 the secretary of state to whom be refer the resolution of the senate request the president to institute an inquiry by such mean as in his judgment shall be deem proper into the present condition of the commercial relation between the united states and the spanish american states on this continent and between those country and other nation and to communicate to the senate full and complete statement regard the same together with such recommendation as he may think necessary to promote the development and increase of our commerce with those region and to secure to the united states that proportionate share of the trade of this continent to which their close relation of geographical contiguity and political friendship with all the states of america justly entitle they have the honor to report
 the resolution justly regard the commercial and the political relation of the united states with the american states of spanish origin as necessarily dependent upon each other if the commerce of those country have be divert from its natural connection with the united states the fact may probably be partly trace to political cause which have be sweep away by the great civil convulsion in this country
 for the just comprehension of the position of this government in the american political system and for the cause which have fail to give it hitherto the influence to which it be properly entitle by reason of its democratic system and of the moderation and sense of justice which have distinguish its foreign policy through successive administration from the birth of the nation until now it be necessary to make a brief notice of such measure as affect our present relation to the other part of this continent
 the united states be the first of the european colony in america to arrive at maturity as a people and assume the position of an independent republic since then important change have take place in various nation and in every part of the world our own growth in power have be not the least remarkable of all the great event of modern history
 when at the conclusion of the revolutionary war having conquer by arm our right to exist as a sovereign state that right be at length recognize by treaty we occupy only a narrow belt of land along the atlantic coast hem in at the north the west and the south by the possession of european governments or by uncultivated waste beyond the alleghanies inhabit only by the aborigine but in the very infancy of the united states far sight statesman see and predict that weak in population and apparently restrict in available territory as the new republic then be it have within it the germ of colossal grandeur and would at no remote day occupy the continent of america with its institution its authority and its peaceful influence
 that expectation have be thus far signally verify the united states enter at once into the occupation of their rightful possession westward to the bank of the mississippi next by the spontaneous proffer of france they acquire louisiana and its territorial extension or right of extension north to the line of the treaty demarcation between france and great britain and west to the pacific ocean next by amicable arrangement with spain they acquire the floridas and complete southern maritime frontier upon the gulf of mexico then come the union with the independent state of texas follow by the acquisition of california and new mexico and then of arizona finally russia have cede to we alaska and the continent of north america have become independent of europe except so much of it as continue to maintain political relation with great britain
 meanwhile partly by natural increase and partly by voluntary immigration from europe our population have rise from 3,000,000 to nearly 40,000,000 the number of states and territories unite under the constitution have be augment from thirteen to forty seven the development of internal wealth and power have keep pace with political expansion we have occupy in part and people the vast interior of the continent we have bind the pacific to the atlantic by a chain of intervene states and organize territories we have deliver the republic from the anomaly and the ignominy of domestic servitude we have constitutionally fix the equality of all race and of all man before the law and we have establish at the cost of a great civil war a cost however not beyond the value of such a result the indissoluble national unity of the united states
 in all these mark stage of national progress from the declaration of independence to the recent amendment of the constitution it be impossible not to perceive a providential series and succession of event intimately attach one to the other and possess of definite character as a whole whatever incidental departure from such uniformity may have mark or seem to mark our foreign policy under the influence of temporary cause or of the conflict opinion of statesman
 in the time of washington of the first adams of jefferson and of madison the condition of europe engage in the gigantic war of the french revolution and of the empire produce its series of public question and give tone and color to our foreign policy in the time of monroe of the second adams and of jackson and subsequently thereto the independence of the spanish and portuguese colony of america produce its series of question and its apparent modification of our public policy domestic question of territorial organization of social emancipation and of national unity have also largely occupy the mind and the attention of the later administration
 the treaty of alliance and guaranty with france which contribute so much to our independence be one source of solicitude to the early administrations which be endeavor to protect our commerce from the depredation and wrong to which the maritime policy of england and the reaction of that policy on france subject it for twenty year we struggle in vain to accomplish this and at last drift into war
 the avoidance of entangle alliance the characteristic feature of the foreign policy of washington spring from this condition of thing but the entangle alliance which then exist be engagement make with france as a part of the general contract under which aid be furnish to we for the achievement of our independence france be willing to waive the letter of the obligation as to her west india possession but demand in its stead privilege in our port which the administration be unwilling to concede to make its refusal acceptable to a public which sympathize with france the cabinet of general washington exaggerate the principle into a theory tend to national isolation
 the public measure design to maintain unimpaired the domestic sovereignty and the international neutrality of the united states be independent of this policy though apparently incidental to it the municipal law enact by congress then and since have be but declaration of the law of nation they be essential to the preservation of our national dignity and honor they have for their object to repress and punish all enterprise of private war one of the last relic of mediaeval barbarism and they have descend to we from the father of the republic support and enforce by every succeed president of the united states
 the foreign policy of these early day be not a narrow one during this period we secure the evacuation by great britain of the country wrongfully occupy by she on the lakes we acquire louisiana we measure force on the sea with france and on the land and sea with england we set the example of resist and chastise the piracy of the barbary states we initiate in negotiation with prussia the long line of treaty for the liberalization of war and the promotion of international intercourse and we steadily demand and at length obtain indemnification from various government for the loss we have suffer by foreign spoliation in the war of europe
 to this point in our foreign policy we have arrive when the revolutionary movement in spanish and portuguese america compel a modification of our relation with europe in consequence of the rise of new and independent state in america
 the revolution which commence in 1810 and extend through all the spanish american continental colony after vain effort of repression on the part of spain protract through twenty year terminate in the establishment of the independent states of mexico guatemala san salvador honduras nicaragua costa rica venezuela colombia ecuador peru chile bolivia the argentine republic uruguay and paraguay to which the empire of brazil come in time to be add these event necessarily enlarge the sphere of action of the united states and essentially modify our relation with europe and our attitude to the rest of this continent
 the new states be like ourselves revolt colony they continue the precedent we have set of separate from europe their assumption of independence be stimulate by our example they professedly imitate we and copy our national constitution sometimes even to their inconvenience
 the spanish american colony have not the same preparation for independence that we have each of the british colony possess complete local autonomy its formal transition from dependence to independence consist chiefly in expel the british governor of the colony and elect a governor of the state from which to the organized union be but a step all these condition of success be want in spanish america and hence many of the difficulty in their career as independent state and far while the revolution in british america be the exclusive result of the march of opinion in the british colony the simultaneous action of the separate spanish colony though show a desire for independence be principally produce by the accident of the invasion of spain by france
 the formation of these new sovereignty in america be important to we not only because of the cessation of colonial monopoly to that extent but because of the geographical relation to we hold by so many new nation all like ourselves create from european stock and interested in exclude european politic dynastic question and balance of power from further influence in the new world
 thus the united states be force into new line of action which though apparently in some respect conflict be really in harmony with the line mark out by washington the avoidance of entangle political alliance and the maintenance of our own independent neutrality become doubly important from the fact that they become applicable to the new republics as well as to the mother country the duty of noninterference have be admit by every president the question come up in the time of the first adams on the occasion of the enlistment project of miranda it appear again under jefferson anterior to the revolt of the spanish colony in the scheme of aaron burr it be an ever present question in the administrations of madison monroe and the young adams in reference to the question of foreign enlistment or equipment in the united states and when these new republic enter the family of nation many of they very feeble and all too much subject to internal revolution and civil war a strict adherence to our previous policy and a strict enforcement of our law become essential to the preservation of friendly relation with they for since that time it have be one of the principal care of those intrust with the administration of the government to prevent piratical expedition against these sister republics from leave our port and thus the change condition of the new world make no change in the traditional and peaceful policy of the united states in this respect
 in one respect however the advent of these new states in america do compel an apparent change of foreign policy on our part it devolve upon we the determination of the great international question at what time and under what circumstance to recognize a new power as entitle to a place among the family of nation there be but little of precedent to guide we except our own case something indeed could be infer from the historical origin of the netherlands and switzerland but our own case carefully and conscientiously consider be sufficient to guide we to right conclusion we maintain our position of international friendship and of treaty obligation toward spain but we do not consider that we be bind to wait for its recognition of the new republics before admit they into treaty relation with we as sovereign state we hold that it be for we to judge whether or not they have attain to the condition of actual independence and the consequent right of recognition by we we consider this question of fact deliberately and coolly we send commissioner to spanish america to ascertain and report for our information concern their actual circumstance and in the fullness of time we acknowledge their independence we exchange diplomatic minister and make treaty of amity with they the early of which negotiate by mr. john quincy adams serve as the model for the subsequent treaty with the spanish american republics we also simultaneously therewith exert our good office with spain to induce she to submit to the inevitable result and herself to accept and acknowledge the independence of her late colony we endeavor to induce russia to join we in these representation in all this our action be positive in the direction of promote the complete political separation of america from europe
 a vast field be thus open to the statesman of the united states for the peaceful introduction the spread and the permanent establishment of the american idea of republican government of modification of the law of war of liberalization of commerce of religious freedom and toleration and of the emancipation of the new world from the dynastic and balance of power controversy of europe
 mr. john quincy adams beyond any other statesman of the time in this country have the knowledge and experience both european and american the comprehension of thought and purpose and the moral conviction which peculiarly fit he to introduce our country into this new field and to lay the foundation of an american policy the declaration know as the monroe doctrine and the object and purpose of the congress of panama both suppose to have be largely inspire by mr. adams have influence public event from that day to this as a principle of government for this continent and its adjacent island
 it be at the period of the congress of aix la chapelle and of laybach when the holy alliance be combine to arrest all political change in europe in the sense of liberty when they be intervene in southern europe for the reestablishment of absolutism and when they be meditate interference to check the progress of free government in america that mr. monroe in his annual message of december 1823 declare that the united states would consider any attempt to extend the european system to any portion of this hemisphere as dangerous to our peace and safety with the exist colony or dependency of any european power he say we have not interfere and shall not interfere but with the government who have declare their independence and maintain it and whose independence we have on great consideration and on just principle acknowledge we could not view any interposition for the purpose of oppress they or control in any other manner their destiny by any european power in any other light than as the manifestation of an unfriendly disposition toward the united states
 this declaration resolve the solution of the immediate question of the independence of the spanish american colony and be suppose to have exercise some influence upon the course of the british cabinet in regard to the absolutist scheme in europe as well as in america
 it have also exercise a permanent influence on this continent it be at once invoke in consequence of the suppose peril of cuba on the side of europe it be apply to a similar danger threaten yucatan it be embody in the treaty of the united states and great britain as to central america it produce the successful opposition of the united states to the attempt of great britain to exercise dominion in nicaragua under the cover of the mosquito indians and it operate in like manner to prevent the establishment of a european dynasty in mexico
 the united states stand solemnly commit by repeat declaration and repeat act to this doctrine and its application to the affair of this continent in his message to the two houses of congress at the commencement of the present session the president follow the teaching of all our history say that the exist dependency be no long regard as subject to transfer from one european power to another when the present relation of colony cease they be to become independent power exercise the right of choice and of self control in the determination of their future condition and relation with other power
 this policy be not a policy of aggression but it oppose the creation of european dominion on american soil or its transfer to other european power and it look hopefully to the time when by the voluntary departure of european government from this continent and the adjacent island america shall be wholly american
 it do not contemplate forcible intervention in any legitimate contest but it protest against permit such a contest to result in the increase of european power or influence and it ever impel this government as in the late contest between the south american republics and spain to interpose its good office to secure an honorable peace
 the congress of panama be plan by bolivar to secure the union of spanish america against spain it have originally military as well as political purpose in the military object the united states could take no part and indeed the necessity for such object cease when the full effect of mr. monroe&#39;s declaration be feel but the pacific object of the congress the establishment of close and cordial relation of amity the creation of commercial intercourse of interchange of political thought and of habit of good understanding between the new republics and the united states and their respective citizen might perhaps have be attain have the administration of that day receive the united support of the country unhappily they be lose the new states be remove from the sympathetic and protect influence of our example and their commerce which we might then have secure pass into other hand unfriendly to the united states
 in look back upon the panama congress from this length of time it be easy to understand why the earnest and patriotic man who endeavor to crystallize an american system for this continent fail
 mr. clay and mr. adams be far sighted statesman but unfortunately they strike against the rock of african slavery one of the question propose for discussion in the conference be the consideration of the mean to be adopt for the entire abolition of the african slave trade to which proposition the committee of the united states senate of that day reply the united states have not certainly the right and ought never to feel the inclination to dictate to other who may differ with they upon this subject nor do the committee see the expediency of insult other state with whom we be maintain relation of perfect amity by ascend the moral chair and proclaim from thence mere abstract principle of the rectitude of which each nation enjoy the perfect right of decide for itself the same committee also allude to the possibility that the condition of the island of cuba and porto rico still the possession of spain and still slaveholde might be make the subject of discussion and of contemplated action by the panama congress if ever the united states they say permit themselves to be associate with these nation in any general congress assemble for the discussion of common plan in any way affect european interest they will by such act not only deprive themselves of the ability they now possess of render useful assistance to the other american states but also produce other effect prejudicial to their own interest
 thus the necessity at that day of preserve the great interest of the southern states in african slavery and of prevent a change in the character of labor in the island of cuba and porto rico lose to the united states the opportunity of give a permanent direction to the political and commercial connection of the newly enfranchise spanish american states and their trade pass into hand unfriendly to the united states and have remain there ever since
 event subsequent to that date have tend to place we in a position to retrieve our mistake among which event may be particularly name the suppression of the rebellion the manifestation of our undeveloped and unexpected military power the retirement of the french from mexico and the abolition of slavery in the united states
 there be good reason to believe that the latter fact have have an important influence in our favor in spanish america it have cause we to be regard there with more sympathetic as well as more respectful consideration it have relieve those republic from the fear of filibusterism which have be formerly incite against central america and mexico in the interest of slave extension and it have produce an impression of the stability of our institution and of our public strength sufficient to dissipate the fear of our friend or the hope of those who wish us ill
 thus there exist in the spanish american republics confidence toward the united states on our side they find a feeling of cordial amity and friendship and a desire to cultivate and develop our common interest on this continent with some of these state our relation be more intimate than with other either by reason of close similarity of constitutional form of great commercial intercourse of proximity in fact or of the construction or contemplated construction of line of transit for our trade and commerce between the atlantic and the pacific with several of they we have peculiar treaty relation the treaty of 1846 between the united states and new granada contain stipulation of guaranty for the neutrality of the part of the isthmus within the present territory of colombia and for the protection of the right of sovereignty and property therein belong to colombia similar stipulation appear in the treaty of 1867 with nicaragua and of july 1864 with honduras those treaty like the treaty of alliance make with france in 1778 by dr. franklin silas deane and arthur lee constitute pro tanto a true protective alliance between the united states and each of those republics provision of like effect appear in the treaty of april 19 1850 between great britain and the united states
 brazil with her imperial semblance and constitutional reality have always hold relation of amity with we which have be fortify by the opening of her great river to commerce it need only that in emulation of russia and the united states she should emancipate her slave to place she in more complete sympathy with the rest of america
 it will not be presumptuous after the foregoing sketch to say with entire consideration for the sovereignty and national pride of the spanish american republics that the united states by the priority of their independence by the stability of their institution by the regard of their people for the form of law by their resource as a government by their naval power by their commercial enterprise by the attraction which they offer to european immigration by the prodigious internal development of their resource and wealth and by the intellectual life of their population occupy of necessity a prominent position on this continent which they neither can nor should abdicate which entitle they to a lead voice and which impose upon they duty of right and of honor regard american question whether those question affect emancipate colony or colony still subject to european dominion
 the public question which exist as to all european colony prior to and during the revolution in the continental colony of spain and portugal still exist with reference to the european colony which remain and they now return upon we in full force as we watch event in cuba and porto rico
 whatever may be the result of the pende contest in cuba it appear to be the belief of some of the lead statesman of spain that the relation which now exist between the island and the mother country can not be long continue it be understand that the resource for carry on the struggle have be supply mainly from cuba by the aid of that portion of the population which do not desire to see its political destiny intrust to the person who direct the movement of the insurgent but it do not follow that its political relation with spain be to remain unchanged or that even the party which be now dominant in the island will wish to forever continue colonist
 these fact give reason to think that when the contest shall close cuba with her resource strain but unexhausted whatever may be her political relation will resume and continue her old commercial relation with the united states and it be not impossible that at some day not far distant when measure by the course of history she will be call upon to elect her position in the family of nation
 although the resolution of the senate do not in term apply to the island of the antilles it be impossible to answer it without speak of they they outlie the southern coast of the united states and guard the approach to the port of mexico venezuela and the isthmus by which we reach from the east the western coast of mexico and of the spanish states the people of the spanish island speak the language and share the tradition custom idea and religion of the spanish american states of the continent and will probably like they become at some time independent of the mother country it would therefore be unwise while shape a commercial policy for the continent to disregard the island which lie so much near to our seaport
 with the spanish island of cuba and porto rico we maintain in spite of their adverse legislation a large commerce by reason of our necessity and of their proximity in the year end june 30 1869 we import from they merchandise value at $ 65,609,274 during the same time we send they good to the value only of $ 15,313,919
 the prohibitory duty force upon they by the policy of spain shut out much that we might supply their tropical production for instance be too valuable to allow their land to be give up to the growth of breadstuff yet instead of take these article from the superabundant field of their near neighbor they be force to go to the distant plain of spain it will be for the interest of the united states to shape its general policy so that this relation of import and export shall be alter in cuba when peace be restore and its political condition be satisfactorily establish
 with none of the other spanish american states in north and south america be our commercial relation what they should be our total import in the year end june 30 1869 from these country be less than $ 25,000,000 or not one half the amount from cuba alone and our export for the same time to they be only $ 17,850,313 and yet these country have an aggregate population nearly or quite as great as that of the united states they have republican form of government and they profess to be and probably really be in political sympathy with we
 this department be not able to give with entire accuracy the import and export of great britain with the same country during the corresponding period it be believe however the follow figure will be find to be not far from correct import to great britain $ 42,820,942 export from great britain $ 40,682,102
 it thus appear that notwithstanding the great distance which the commerce have to travel in come to and from great britain notwithstanding the political sympathy which ought naturally to exist between republic notwithstanding the american idea which have be so prominently and so constantly put forward by the government of the united states notwithstanding the acknowledge skill of american manufacturer notwithstanding the ready market which the great city of the united states afford for the consumption of tropical production the inhabitant of the spanish american continent consume of the product of great britain more than twice the quantity they take of the product of the united states and that they sell to we only three fifth of the amount they sell to great britain
 the secretary of state append to this report the table on which these statement be rounded that their commerce with the united states be not large may be partially explain by the fact that these states have be subject to many successive revolution since the failure of the congress of panama these revolution not only exhaust their resource and burden they with debt but they check emigration prevent the flow of foreign capital into the country and stop the enterprise which need a stable government for its development
 these suggestion be however applicable to the british commerce as well as to our own and they do not explain why we with the natural advantage in our favor fall so far behind the isthmus of panama be the common point where the commerce of the western coast of mexico and south america meet when it arrive there why should it seek liverpool and london rather than new york
 the political cause which have operate to divert this commerce from we the secretary of state have endeavor to explain a favorable time have now come for remove they for lay the foundation of an american policy which shall bind in close union the american republics let they understand that the united states do not covet their territory that our only desire be to see they peaceful with free and stable government increase in wealth and population and develop in the line in which their own tradition custom habit law and mode of thought will naturally take they let they feel that as in 1826 so now this government be ready to aid they to the full extent of its constitutional power in any step which they may take for their well protection against anarchy let they be convince that the united states be prepare in good faith and without ulterior purpose to join they in the development of a peaceful american commercial policy that may in time include this continent and the west indian islands let this be comprehend and there will be no political reason why we may not secure to the united states that proportionate share of the trade of this continent to which their close relation of geographical contiguity and political friendship with all the states of america justly entitle they
 it may not be enough to remove the political obstacle only the financial policy which the war make necessary may have operate injuriously upon our commerce with these states the resolution of the senate call on these point for detailed information which be not within the control of the secretary of state and for recommendation for the future which he be not prepared to give without that information to fully answer the senate&#39;s call it would probably be necessary to employ some competent agent familiar with the spanish american states to collate and arrange the information ask for for this there be no appropriation by congress
 respectfully submit
 hamilton fish
