by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas a state of war unhappily exist between france on the one side and the north german confederation and its ally on the other side and
 whereas the united states be on term of friendship and amity with all the contend power and with the person inhabit their several dominion and
 whereas great number of the citizen of the united states reside within the territory or dominion of each of the say belligerent and carry on commerce trade or other business or pursuit therein protect by the faith of treaty and
 whereas great number of the subject or citizen of each of the say belligerent reside within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states and carry on commerce trade or other business or pursuit therein and
 whereas the law of the united states without interfere with the free expression of opinion and sympathy or with the open manufacture or sale of arm or munition of war nevertheless impose upon all person who may be within their territory and jurisdiction the duty of an impartial neutrality during the existence of the contest
 now therefore i ulysses s. grant president of the united states in order to preserve the neutrality of the united states and of their citizen and of person within their territory and jurisdiction and to enforce their law and in order that all person be warn of the general tenor of the law and treaty of the united states in this behalf and of the law of nation may thus be prevent from an unintentional violation of the same do hereby declare and proclaim that by the act pass on the 20th day of april a. d. 1818 commonly know as the neutrality law the follow act be forbid to be do under severe penalty within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states to wit
 1 accept and exercise a commission to serve either of the say belligerent by land or by sea against the other belligerent
 2 enlist or enter into the service of either of the say belligerent as a soldier or as a marine or seaman on board of any vessel of war letter of marque or privateer
 3 hire or retain another person to enlist or enter himself in the service of either of the say belligerent as a soldier or as a marine or seaman on board of any vessel of war letter of marque or privateer
 4 hire another person to go beyond the limit or jurisdiction of the united states with intent to be enlist as aforesaid
 5 hire another person to go beyond the limit of the united states with intent to be enter into service as aforesaid
 6 retain another person to go beyond the limit of the united states with intent to be enlist as aforesaid
 7 retain another person to go beyond the limit of the united states with intent to be enter into service as aforesaid but the say act be not to be construe to extend to a citizen or subject of either belligerent who be transiently within the united states shall on board of any vessel of war which at the time of its arrival within the united states be fit and equip as such vessel of war enlist or enter himself or hire or retain another subject or citizen of the same belligerent who be transiently within the united states to enlist or enter himself to serve such belligerent on board such vessel of war if the united states shall then be at peace with such belligerent
 8 fit out and arm or attempt to fit out and arm or procure to be fit out and arm or knowingly be concern in the furnish fit out or arming of any ship or vessel with intent that such ship or vessel shall be employ in the service of either of the say belligerent
 9 issue or deliver a commission within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states for any ship or vessel to the intent that she may be employ as aforesaid
 10 increase or augment or procure to be increase or augmented or knowingly be concern in increase or augment the force of any ship of war cruiser or other armed vessel which at the time of her arrival within the united states be a ship of war cruiser or armed vessel in the service of either of the say belligerent or belong to the subject or citizen of either by add to the number of gun of such vessel or by change those on board of she for gun of a large caliber or by the addition thereto of any equipment solely applicable to war
 11 begin or set on foot or provide or prepare the mean for any military expedition or enterprise to be carry on from the territory or jurisdiction of the united states against the territory or dominion of either of the say belligerent
 and i do far declare and proclaim that by the nineteenth article of the treaty of amity and commerce which be conclude between his majesty the king of prussia and the united states of america on the 11th day of july a. d. 1799 which article be revive by the treaty of may 1 a.d. 1828 between the same party and be still in force it be agree that the vessel of war public and private of both party shall carry freely wheresoever they please the vessel and effect take from their enemy without be oblige to pay any duty charge or fee to officer of admiralty of the custom or any other nor shall such prize be arrest search or put under legal process when they come to and enter the port of the other party but may freely be carry out again at any time by their captor to the place express in their commission which the command officer of such vessel shall be oblige to show
 and i do far declare and proclaim that it have be officially communicate to the government of the united states by the envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary of the north german confederation at washington that private property on the high sea will be exempt from seizure by the ship of his majesty the king of prussia without regard to reciprocity
 and i do far declare and proclaim that it have be officially communicate to the government of the united states by the envoy extraordinary and minister plenipotentiary of his majesty the emperor of the french at washington that order have be give that in the conduct of the war the commander of the french force on land and on the sea shall scrupulously observe toward neutral power the rule of international law and that they shall strictly adhere to the principle set forth in the declaration of the congress of paris of the 16th of april 1856 that be to say
 first that privateering be and remains abolish
 second that the neutral flag cover enemy&#39;s good with the exception of contraband of war
 third that neutral good with the exception of contraband of war be not liable to capture under the enemy&#39;s flag
 fourth that blockade in order to be bind must be effective that be to say maintain by a force sufficient really to prevent access to the coast of the enemy and that although the united states have not adhere to the declaration of 1856 the vessel of his majesty will not seize enemy&#39;s property find on board of a vessel of the united states provide that property be not contraband of war
 and i do far declare and proclaim that the statute of the united states and the law of nation alike require that no person within the territory and jurisdiction of the united states shall take part directly or indirectly in the said war but shall remain at peace with each of the say belligerent and shall maintain a strict and impartial neutrality and that whatever privilege shall be accord to one belligerent within the port of the united states shall be in like manner accord to the other
 and i do hereby enjoin all the good citizen of the united states and all person reside or be within the territory or jurisdiction of the united states to observe the law thereof and to commit no act contrary to the provision of the say statute or in violation of the law of nation in that behalf
 and i do hereby warn all citizen of the united states and all person reside or be within their territory or jurisdiction that while the free and full expression of sympathy in public and private be not restrict by the law of the united states military force in aid of either belligerent can not lawfully be originate or organize within their jurisdiction and that while all person may lawfully and without restriction by reason of the aforesaid state of war manufacture and sell within the united states arm and munition of war and other article ordinarily know as contraband of war yet they can not carry such article upon the high sea for the use or service of either belligerent nor can they transport soldier and officer of either or attempt to break any blockade which may be lawfully establish and maintain during the war without incur the risk of hostile capture and the penalty denounce by the law of nation in that behalf
 and i do hereby give notice that all citizen of the united states and other who may claim the protection of this government who may misconduct themselves in the premise will do so at their peril and that they can in no wise obtain any protection from the government of the united states against the consequence of their misconduct
 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 22d day of august a.d. 1870 and of the independence of the united states of america the ninety fifth
 u. s. grant
 by the president
 hamilton fish
 secretary of state

to the senate and house of representatives a year of peace and general prosperity to this nation have pass since the last assembling of congress we have through a kind providence be bless with abundant crop and have be spare from complication and war with foreign nation in our midst comparative harmony have be restore it be to be regret however that a free exercise of the elective franchise have by violence and intimidation be deny to citizen in exceptional case in several of the states lately in rebellion and the verdict of the people have thereby be reverse the states of virginia mississippi and texas have be restore to representation in our national council georgia the only state now without representation may confidently be expect to take her place there also at the beginning of the new year and then let we hope will be complete the work of reconstruction with an acquiescence on the part of the whole people in the national obligation to pay the public debt create as the price of our union the pension to our disabled soldier and sailor and their widow and orphan and in the change to the constitution which have be make necessary by a great rebellion there be no reason why we should not advance in material prosperity and happiness as no other nation ever do after so protracted and devastate a war soon after the exist war break out in europe the protection of the united states minister in paris be invoke in favor of north germans domicile in french territory instruction be issue to grant the protection this have be follow by an extension of american protection to citizen of saxony hesse and saxe coburg gotha colombia portugal uruguay the dominican republic ecuador chile paraguay and venezuela in paris the charge be an onerous one require constant and severe labor as well as the exercise of patience prudence and good judgment it have be perform to the entire satisfaction of this government and as i be officially inform equally so to the satisfaction of the government of north germany as soon as i learn that a republic have be proclaim at paris and that the people of france have acquiesce in the change the minister of the united states be direct by telegraph to recognize it and to tender my congratulation and those of the people of the united states the reestablishment in france of a system of government disconnect with the dynastic tradition of europe appear to be a proper subject for the felicitation of americans should the present struggle result in attach the heart of the french to our simple form of representative government it will be a subject of still further satisfaction to our people while we make no effort to impose our institution upon the inhabitant of other country and while we adhere to our traditional neutrality in civil contest elsewhere we can not be indifferent to the spread of american political idea in a great and highly civilized country like france we be ask by the new government to use our good office jointly with those of european power in the interest of peace answer be make that the establish policy and the true interest of the united states forbid they to interfere in european question jointly with european power i ascertain informally and unofficially that the government of north germany be not then disposed to listen to such representation from any power and though earnestly wish to see the blessing of peace restore to the belligerent with all of whom the united states be on term of friendship i decline on the part of this government to take a step which could only result in injury to our true interest without advance the object for which our intervention be invoke should the time come when the action of the united states can hasten the return of peace by a single hour that action will be heartily take i deem it prudent in view of the number of person of german and french birth live in the united states to issue soon after official notice of a state of war have be receive from both belligerent a proclamation define the duty of the united states as a neutral and the obligation of person reside within their territory to observe their law and the law of nation this proclamation be follow by other as circumstance seem to call for they the people thus acquaint in advance of their duty and obligation have assist in prevent violation of the neutrality of the united states it be not understand that the condition of the insurrection in cuba have materially change since the close of the last session of congress in an early stage of the contest the authority of spain inaugurate a system of arbitrary arrest of close confinement and of military trial and execution of person suspect of complicity with the insurgent and of summary embargo of their property and sequestration of their revenue by executive warrant such proceeding so far as they affect the person or property of citizen of the united states be in violation of the provision of the treaty of 1795 between the united states and spain representation of injury result to several person claim to be citizen of the united states by reason of such violation be make to the spanish government from april 1869 to june last the spanish minister at washington have be clothe with a limited power to aid in redress such wrong that power be find to be withdraw in view as it be say of the favorable situation in which the island of cuba then be which however do not lead to a revocation or suspension of the extraordinary and arbitrary function exercise by the executive power in cuba and we be oblige to make our complaint at madrid in the negotiation thus open and still pende there the united states only claim that for the future the right secure to their citizen by treaty should be respect in cuba and that as to the past a joint tribunal should be establish in the united states with full jurisdiction over all such claim before such an impartial tribunal each claimant would be require to prove his case on the other hand spain would be at liberty to traverse every material fact and thus complete equity would be do a case which at one time threaten seriously to affect the relation between the united states and spain have already be dispose of in this way the claim of the owner of the colonel lloyd aspinwall for the illegal seizure and detention of that vessel be refer to arbitration by mutual consent and have result in an award to the united states for the owner of the sum of $ 19,702.50 in gold another and long pende claim of like nature that of the whaleship canada have be dispose of by friendly arbitrament during the present year it be refer by the joint consent of brazil and the united states to the decision of sir edward thornton her britannic majesty 's minister at washington who kindly undertake the laborious task of examine the voluminous mass of correspondence and testimony submit by the two government and award to the united states the sum of $ 100,740.09 in gold which have since be pay by the imperial government these recent example show that the mode which the united states have propose to spain for adjust the pende claim be just and feasible and that it may be agree to by either nation without dishonor it be to be hope that this moderate demand may be accede to by spain without further delay should the pende negotiation unfortunately and unexpectedly be without result it will then become my duty to communicate that fact to congress and invite its action on the subject the long defer peace conference between spain and the ally south american republics have be inaugurate in washington under the auspex of the united states pursuant to the recommendation contain in the resolution of the house of representatives of the 17th of december 1866 the executive department of the government offer its friendly office for the promotion of peace and harmony between spain and the allied republics hesitation and obstacle occur to the acceptance of the offer ultimately however a conference be arrange and be open in this city on the 29th of october last at which i authorize the secretary of state to preside it be attend by the minister of spain peru chile and ecuador in consequence of the absence of a representative from bolivia the conference be adjourn until the attendance of a plenipotentiary from that republic could be secure or other measure could be adopt toward compass its object the allied and other republics of spanish origin on this continent may see in this fact a new proof of our sincere interest in their welfare of our desire to see they bless with good government capable of maintain order and of preserve their respective territorial integrity and of our sincere wish to extend our own commercial and social relation with they the time be not probably far distant when in the natural course of event the european political connection with this continent will cease our policy should be shape in view of this probability so as to ally the commercial interest of the spanish american states more closely to our own and thus give the united states all the preeminence and all the advantage which mr. monroe mr. adams and mr. clay contemplate when they propose to join in the congress of panama during the last session of congress a treaty for the annexation of the republic of san domingo to the united states fail to receive the requisite two third vote of the senate i be thoroughly convince then that the good interest of this country commercially and materially demand its ratification time have only confirm i in this view i now firmly believe that the moment it be know that the united states have entirely abandon the project of accept as a part of its territory the island of san domingo a free port will be negotiate for by european nation in the bay of samana a large commercial city will spring up to which we will be tributary without receive correspond benefit and then will be see the folly of our reject so great a prize the government of san domingo have voluntarily seek this annexation it be a weak power number probably less than 120,000 soul and yet possess one of the rich territory under the sun capable of support a population of 10,000,000 people in luxury the people of san domingo be not capable of maintain themselves in their present condition and must look for outside support they yearn for the protection of our free institution and law our progress and civilization shall we refuse them?the acquisition of san domingo be desirable because of its geographical position it command the entrance to the caribbean sea and the isthmus transit of commerce it possess the rich soil good and most capacious harbor most salubrious climate and the most valuable product of the forest mine and soil of any of the west india islands its possession by we will in a few year build up a coastwise commerce of immense magnitude which will go far toward restore to we our lose merchant marine it will give to we those article which we consume so largely and do not produce thus equalize our export and import in case of foreign war it will give we command of all the island refer to and thus prevent an enemy from ever again possess himself of rendezvous upon our very coast at present our coast trade between the states border on the atlantic and those border on the gulf of mexico be cut into by the bahamas and the antilies twice we must as it be pass through foreign country to get by sea from georgia to the west coast of florida san domingo with a stable government under which her immense resource can be develop will give remunerative wage to ten of thousand of laborer not now upon the island this labor will take advantage of every available mean of transportation to abandon the adjacent island and seek the blessing of freedom and its sequence each inhabitant receive the reward of his own labor porto rico and cuba will have to abolish slavery as a measure of self preservation to retain their laborer san domingo will become a large consumer of the product of northern farm and manufactory the cheap rate at which her citizen can be furnish with food tool and machinery will make it necessary that contiguous island should have the same advantage in order to compete in the production of sugar coffee tobacco tropical fruit etc this will open to we a still wide market for our product the production of our own supply of these article will cut off more than one hundred million of our annual import besides largely increase our export with such a picture it be easy to see how our large debt abroad be ultimately to be extinguish with a balance of trade against we include interest on bond hold by foreigner and money spend by our citizen travel in foreign land equal to the entire yield of the precious metal in this country it be not so easy to see how this result be to be otherwise accomplish the acquisition of san domingo be an adherence to the monroe doctrine it be a measure of national protection it be assert our just claim to a control influence over the great commercial traffic soon to flow from west to east by way of the isthmus of darien it be to build up our merchant marine it be to furnish new market for the product of our farm shop and manufactory it be to make slavery insupportable in cuba and porto rico at once and ultimately so in brazil it be to settle the unhappy condition of cuba and end an exterminate conflict it be to provide honest mean of pay our honest debt without overtax the people it be to furnish our citizen with the necessary of everyday life at cheap rate than ever before and it be in fine a rapid stride toward that greatness which the intelligence industry and enterprise of the citizen of the united states entitle this country to assume among nation in view of the importance of this question i earnestly urge upon congress early action expressive of its view as to the good mean of acquire san domingo my suggestion be that by joint resolution of the two houses of congress the executive be authorize to appoint a commission to negotiate a treaty with the authority of san domingo for the acquisition of that island and that an appropriation be make to defray the expense of such a commission the question may then be determine either by the action of the senate upon the treaty or the joint action of the two houses of congress upon a resolution of annexation as in the case of the acquisition of texas so convinced be i of the advantage to flow from the acquisition of san domingo and of the great disadvantage i might almost say calamity to flow from nonacquisition that i believe the subject have only to be investigate to be approve it be to be regret that our representation in regard to the injurious effect especially upon the revenue of the united states of the policy of the mexican government in exempt from impost duty a large tract of its territory on our border have not only be fruitless but that it be even propose in that country to extend the limit within which the privilege advert to have hitherto be enjoy the expediency of take into your serious consideration proper measure for countervail the policy refer to will it be presume engage your earnest attention it be the obvious interest especially of neighboring nation to provide against impunity to those who may have commit high crime within their border and who may have seek refuge abroad for this purpose extradition treaty have be conclude with several of the central american republics and other be in progress the sense of congress be desire as early as may be convenient upon the proceeding of the commission on claim against venezuela as communicate in my message of march 16 1869 march 1 1870 and march 31 1870 it have not be deem advisable to distribute any of the money which have be receive from that government until congress shall have act on the subject the massacre of french and russian resident at tien tsin under circumstance of great barbarity be suppose by some to have be premeditate and to indicate a purpose among the populace to exterminate foreigner in the chinese empire the evidence fail to establish such a supposition but show a complicity between the local authority and the mob the government at peking however seem to have be dispose to fulfill its treaty obligation so far as it be able to do so unfortunately the news of the war between the german states and france reach china soon after the massacre it would appear that the popular mind become possess with the idea that this contest extend to chinese water would neutralize the christian influence and power and that the time be come when the superstitious masse might expel all foreigner and restore mandarin influence anticipate trouble from this cause i invite france and north germany to make an authorized suspension of hostility in the east where they be temporarily suspend by act of the commander and to act together for the future protection in china of the life and property of americans and europeans since the adjournment of congress the ratification of the treaty with great britain for abolish the mixed court for the suppression of the slave trade have be exchange it be believe that the slave trade be now confine to the eastern coast of africa whence the slave be take to arabian market the ratification of the naturalization convention between great britain and the united states have also be exchange during the recess and thus a long stand dispute between the two government have be settle in accordance with the principle always contend for by the united states in april last while engage in locate a military reservation near pembina a corps of engineer discover that the commonly receive boundary line between the united states and the british possession at that place be about 4,700 foot south of the true position of the forty ninth parallel and that the line when run on what be now suppose to be the true position of that parallel would leave the fort of the hudsons bay company at pembina within the territory of the united states this information be communicate to the british government i be request to consent and do consent that the british occupation of the fort of the hudsons bay company should continue for the present i deem it important however that this part of the boundary line should be definitely fix by a joint commission of the two government and i submit herewith estimate of the expense of such a commission on the part of the united states and recommend that an appropriation be make for that purpose the land boundary have already be fix and mark from the summit of the rocky mountains to the georgian bay it should now be in like manner mark from the lake of the woods to the summit of the rocky mountains i regret to say that no conclusion have be reach for the adjustment of the claim against great britain grow out of the course adopt by that government during the rebellion the cabinet of london so far as its view have be express do not appear to be willing to concede that her majesty 's government be guilty of any negligence or do or permit any act during the war by which the united states have just cause of complaint our firm and unalterable conviction be directly the reverse i therefore recommend to congress to authorize the appointment of a commission to take proof of the amount and the ownership of these several claim on notice to the representative of her majesty at washington and that authority be give for the settlement of these claim by the united states so that the government shall have the ownership of the private claim as well as the responsible control of all the demand against great britain it can not be necessary to add that whenever her majesty 's government shall entertain a desire for a full and friendly adjustment of these claim the united states will enter upon their consideration with an earnest desire for a conclusion consistent with the honor and dignity of both nation the course pursue by the canadian authority toward the fisherman of the united states during the past season have not be mark by a friendly feeling by the first article of the convention of 1818 between great britain and the united states it be agree that the inhabitant of the united states should have forever in common with british subject the right of take fish in certain water therein define in the water not include in the limit name in the convention within 3 mile of part of the british coast it have be the custom for many year to give to intrude fisherman of the united states a reasonable warning of their violation of the technical right of great britain the imperial government be understand to have delegate the whole or a share of its jurisdiction or control of these inshore fishing ground to the colonial authority know as the dominion of canada and this semi independent but irresponsible agent have exercise its delegate power in an unfriendly way vessel have be seize without notice or warning in violation of the custom previously prevail and have be take into the colonial port their voyage break up and the vessel condemn there be reason to believe that this unfriendly and vexatious treatment be design to bear harshly upon the hardy fisherman of the united states with a view to political effect upon this government the statute of the dominion of canada assume a still broad and more untenable jurisdiction over the vessel of the united states they authorize officer or person to bring vessel hover within 3 marine mile of any of the coast bay creek or harbor of canada into port to search the cargo to examine the master on oath touch the cargo and voyage and to inflict upon he a heavy pecuniary penalty if true answer be not give and if such a vessel be find prepare to fish within 3 marine mile of any of such coast bay creek or harbor without a license or after the expiration of the period name in the last license grant to it they provide that the vessel with her tackle etc shall be forfeit it be not know that any condemnation have be make under this statute should the authority of canada attempt to enforce it it will become my duty to take such step as may be necessary to protect the right of the citizen of the united states it have be claim by her majesty 's officer that the fishing vessel of the united states have no right to enter the open port of the british possession in north america except for the purpose of shelter and repair damage of purchase wood and obtain water that they have no right to enter at the british custom house or to trade there except in the purchase of wood and water and that they must depart within twenty four hour after notice to leave it be not know that any seizure of a fishing vessel carry the flag of the united states have be make under this claim so far as the claim be found on an alleged construction of he convention of 1818 it can not be acquiesce in by the united states it be hope that it will not be insist on by her majesty 's government during the conference which precede the negotiation of the convention of 1818 the british commissioner propose to expressly exclude the fisherman of the united states from the privilege of carry on trade with any of his britannic majesty 's subject reside within the limit assign for their use and also that it should not be lawful for the vessel of the united states engage in say fishery to have on board any good ware or merchandise whatever except such as may be necessary for the prosecution of their voyage to and from the say fishing ground and any vessel of the united states which shall contravene this regulation may be seize condemn and confiscate with her cargo "this proposition which be identical with the construction now put upon the language of the convention be emphatically reject by the american commissioner and thereupon be abandon by the british plenipotentiary and article i as it stand in the convention be substitute if however it be say that this claim be found on provincial or colonial statute and not upon the convention this government can not but regard they as unfriendly and in contravention of the spirit if not of the letter of the treaty for the faithful execution of which the imperial government be alone responsible anticipate that an attempt may possibly be make by the canadian authority in the come season to repeat their unneighborly act toward our fisherman i recommend you to confer upon the executive the power to suspend by proclamation the operation of the law authorize the transit of good ware and merchandise in bond across the territory of the united states to canada and far should such an extreme measure become necessary to suspend the operation of any law whereby the vessel of the dominion of canada be permit to enter the water of the united states a like unfriendly disposition have be manifest on the part of canada in the maintenance of a claim of right to exclude the citizen of the united states from the navigation of the st. lawrence this river constitute a natural outlet to the ocean for eight states with an aggregate population of about 17,600,000 inhabitant and with an aggregate tonnage of 661,367 ton upon the water which discharge into it the foreign commerce of our port on these water be open to british competition and the major part of it be do in british bottom if the american seaman be exclude from this natural avenue to the ocean the monopoly of the direct commerce of the lake port with the atlantic would be in foreign hand their vessel on transatlantic voyage have an access to our lake port which would be deny to american vessel on similar voyage to state such a proposition be to refute its justice during the administration of mr. john quincy adams mr. clay unanswerably demonstrate the natural right of the citizen of the united states to the navigation of this river claim that the act of the congress of vienna in open the rhine and other river to all nation show the judgment of european jurist and statesman that the inhabitant of a country through which a navigable river pass have a natural right to enjoy the navigation of that river to and into the sea even though pass through the territory of another power this right do not exclude the coequal right of the sovereign possess the territory through which the river debouch into the sea to make such regulation relative to the police of the navigation as may be reasonably necessary but those regulation should be frame in a liberal spirit of comity and should not impose needless burden upon the commerce which have the right of transit it have be find in practice more advantageous to arrange these regulation by mutual agreement the united states be ready to make any reasonable arrangement as to the police of the st. lawrence which may be suggest by great britain if the claim make by mr. clay be just when the population of states border on the shore of the lakes be only 3,400,000 it now derive great force and equity from the increase population wealth production and tonnage of the states on the canadian frontier since mr. clay advance his argument in behalf of our right the principle for which he contend have be frequently and by various nation recognize by law or by treaty and have be extend to several other great river by the treaty conclude at mayence in 1831 the rhine be declare free from the point where it be first navigable into the sea by the convention between spain and portugal conclude in 1835 the navigation of the douro throughout its whole extent be make free for the subject of both crowns in 1853 the argentine confederation by treaty throw open the free navigation of the parana and the uruguay to the merchant vessel of all nation in 1856 the crimean war be close by a treaty which provide for the free navigation of the danube in 1858 bolivia by treaty declare that it regard the river amazon and la plata in accordance with fix principle of national law as highway or channel open by nature for the commerce of all nation in 1859 the paraguay be make free by treaty and in december 1866 the emperor of brazil by imperial decree declare the amazon to be open to the frontier of brazil to the merchant ship of all nation the great living british authority on this subject while assert the abstract right of the british claim say it seem difficult to deny that great britain may ground her refusal upon strict law but it be equally difficult to deny first that in so do she exercise harshly an extreme and hard law secondly that her conduct with respect to the navigation of the st. lawrence be in glare and discreditable inconsistency with her conduct with respect to the navigation of the mississippi on the ground that she possess a small domain in which the mississippi take its rise she insist on the right to navigate the entire volume of its water on the ground that she possess both bank of the st. lawrence where it disembogue itself into the sea she deny to the united states the right of navigation though about one half of the water of lakes ontario erie huron and superior and the whole of lake michigan through which the river flow be the property of the united states the whole nation be interested in secure cheap transportation from the agricultural states of the west to the atlantic seaboard to the citizen of those states it secure a great return for their labor to the inhabitant of the seaboard it afford cheap food to the nation an increase in the annual surplus of wealth it be hope that the government encouragement will be give as will secure american shipping on the high sea and american shipbuilding at home the condition of the archive at the department of state call for the early action of
