to the senate and house of representatives
 the union of the states of germany into a form of government similar in many respect to that of the american union be an event that can not fail to touch deeply the sympathy of the people of the united states
 this union have be bring about by the long continue persistent effort of the people with the deliberate approval of the government and people of twenty four of the german states through their regularly constitute representative
 in it the american people see an attempt to reproduce in europe some of the good feature of our own constitution with such modification as the history and condition of germany seem to require the local government of the several member of the union be preserve while the power confer upon the chief impart strength for the purpose of self defense without authority to enter upon war of conquest and ambition
 the cherished aspiration for national unity which for age have inspire the many million of people speak the same language inhabit a contiguous and compact territory but unnaturally separate and divide by dynastic jealousy and the ambition of short sighted ruler have be attain and germany now contain a population of about 34,000,000 united like our own under one government for its relation with other power but retain in its several member the right and power of control of their local interest habit and institution
 the bringing of great masse of thoughtful and free people under a single government must tend to make government what alone they should be the representative of the will and the organization of the power of the people
 the adoption in europe of the american system of union under the control and direction of a free people educate to self restraint can not fail to extend popular institution and to enlarge the peaceful influence of american idea
 the relation of the united states with germany be intimate and cordial the commercial intercourse between the two country be extensive and be increase from year to year and the large number of citizen and resident in the united states of german extraction and the continued flow of emigration thence to this country have produce an intimacy of personal and political intercourse approach if not equal to that with the country from which the founder of our government derive their origin
 the extent of these interest and the greatness of the german union seem to require that in the classification of the representative of this government to foreign power there should no long be an apparent undervaluation of the importance of the german mission such as be make in the difference between the compensation allow by law to the minister to germany and those to great britain and france there would seem to be a great propriety in place the representative of this government at berlin on the same footing with that of its representative at london and paris the union of the several states of germany under one government and the increase commercial and personal intercourse between the two country will also add to the labor and the responsibility of the legation
 i therefore recommend that the salary of the minister and of the secretary of legation at berlin be respectively increase to the same amount as be allow to those at london and paris

to the senate and house of representatives
 i have this day transmit to the senate the announcement that senate bill no 218 an act prescribe an oath of office to be take by person who participate in the late rebellion but who be not disqualify from hold office by the fourteenth amendment to the constitution of the united states have become a law in the manner prescribe by the constitution without the signature of the president
 if this be a bill for the repeal of the test oath require of person select or appoint to office of honor or trust it would meet my approval the effect of the law however be to relieve from take a prescribed oath all those person whom it be intend to exclude from such office and to require it from all other by this law the soldier who fight and bleed for his country be to swear to his loyalty before assume official function while the general who command host for the overthrow of his government be admit to place without it i can not affix my name to a law which discriminate against the upholder of his government
 i believe however that it be not wise policy to keep from office by an oath those who be not disqualify by the constitution and who be the choice of legal voter but while relieve they from an oath which they can not take i recommend the release also of those to whom the oath have no application

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 the act of congress entitle an act to enforce the provision of the fourteenth amendment to the constitution of the united states and for other purpose approve april 20 a. d. 1871 be a law of extraordinary public importance i consider it my duty to issue this my proclamation call the attention of the people of the united states thereto enjoin upon all good citizen and especially upon all public officer to be zealous in the enforcement thereof and warn all person to abstain from commit any of the act thereby prohibit
 this law of congress apply to all part of the united states and will be enforce everywhere to the extent of the power vest in the executive but inasmuch as the necessity therefor be well known to have be cause chiefly by persistent violation of the right of citizen of the united states by combination of lawless and disaffect person in certain locality lately the theater of insurrection and military conflict i do particularly exhort the people of those part of the country to suppress all such combination by their own voluntary effort through the agency of local law and to maintain the right of all citizen of the united states and to secure to all such citizen the equal protection of the law
 fully sensible of the responsibility impose upon the executive by the act of congress to which public attention be now call and reluctant to call into exercise any of the extraordinary power thereby confer upon i except in case of imperative necessity i do nevertheless deem it my duty to make known that i will not hesitate to exhaust the power thus vest in the executive whenever and wherever it shall become necessary to do so for the purpose of securing to all citizen of the united states the peaceful enjoyment of the right guarantee to they by the constitution and law
 it be my earnest wish that peace and cheerful obedience to law may prevail throughout the land and that all trace of our late unhappy civil strife may be speedily remove these end can be easily reach by acquiescence in the result of the conflict now write in our constitution and by the due and proper enforcement of equal just and impartial law in every part of our country
 the failure of local community to furnish such mean for the attainment of result so earnestly desire impose upon the national government the duty of put forth all its energy for the protection of its citizen of every race and color and for the restoration of peace and order throughout the entire country
 in testimony whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 3d day of may a. d. 1871 and of the independence of the united states the ninety fifth
 u. s. grant
 by the president
 hamilton fish secretary of state

by the president of the united states of america
 a proclamation
 whereas by an act of congress entitle an act to enforce the provision of the fourteenth amendment to the constitution of the united states and for other purpose approve the 20th day of april a. d. 1871 power be give to the president of the united states when in his judgment the public safety shall require it to suspend the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in any state or part of a state whenever combination and conspiracy exist in such state or part of a state for the purpose of deprive any portion or class of the people of such state of the right privilege immunity and protection name in the constitution of the united states and secure by the act of congress aforesaid and whenever such combination and conspiracy do so obstruct and hinder the execution of the law of any such state and of the united states as to deprive the people aforesaid of the right privilege immunity and protection aforesaid and do oppose and obstruct the law of the united states and their due execution and impede and obstruct the due course of justice under the same and whenever such combination shall be organize and arm and so numerous and powerful as to be able by violence either to overthrow or to set at defiance the constituted authority of say state and of the united states within such state and whenever by reason of say cause the conviction of such offender and the preservation of the public peace shall become in such state or part of a state impracticable and
 whereas such unlawful combination and conspiracy for the purpose aforesaid be declare by the act of congress aforesaid to be rebellion against the government of the united states and
 whereas by say act of congress it be provide that before the president shall suspend the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus he shall first have make proclamation command such insurgent to disperse and
 whereas on the 12th day of the present month of october the president of the united states do issue his proclamation recite therein among other thing that such combination and conspiracy do then exist in the county of spartanburg york marion chester laurens newberry fairfield lancaster and chesterfield in the state of south carolina and command thereby all person compose such unlawful combination and conspiracy to disperse and retire peaceably to their home within five day from the date thereof and to deliver either to the marshal of the united states for the district of south carolina or to any of his deputy or to any military officer of the united states within say county all arm ammunition uniform disguise and other mean and implement use kept possess or control by they for carry out the unlawful purpose for which the say combination and conspiracy be organize and
 whereas the insurgent engage in such unlawful combination and conspiracy within the county aforesaid have not disperse and retire peaceably to their respective home and have not deliver to the marshal of the united states or to any of his deputy or to any military officer of the united states within say county all arm ammunition uniform disguise and other mean and implement use kept possess or control by they for carry out the unlawful purpose for which the combination and conspiracy be organize as command by say proclamation but do still persist in the unlawful combination and conspiracy aforesaid
 now therefore i ulysses s. grant president of the united states of america by virtue of the authority vest in i by the constitution of the united states and the act of congress aforesaid do hereby declare that in my judgment the public safety especially require that the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus be suspend to the end that such rebellion may be overthrow and do hereby suspend the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus within the county of spartanburg york marion chester laurens newberry fairfield lancaster and chesterfield in say state of south carolina in respect to all person arrest by the marshal of the united states for the say district of south carolina or by any of his deputy or by any military officer of the united states or by any soldier or citizen act under the order of say marshal deputy or such military officer within any one of say county charge with any violation of the act of congress aforesaid during the continuance of such rebellion
 in witness whereof i have hereunto set my hand and cause the seal of the united states to be affix
 do at the city of washington this 17th day of october a.d. 1871 and of the independence of the united states of america the ninety sixth
 u. s. grant
 by the president
 j. c. bancroft davis
 acting secretary of state

in address my third annual message to the law make branch of the government it be gratify to be able to state that during the past year success have generally attend the effort to execute all law find upon the statute book the policy have be not to inquire into the wisdom of law already enact but to learn their spirit and intent and to enforce they accordingly

 the past year have under a wise providence be one of general prosperity to the nation it have however be attend with more than usual chastisement in the loss of life and property by storm and fire these disaster have serve to call forth the good element of human nature in our country and to develop a friendship for we on the part of foreign nation which go far toward alleviate the distress occasion by these calamity the benevolent who have so generously share their mean with the victim of these misfortune will reap their reward in the consciousness of having perform a noble act and in receive the grateful thank of man woman and child whose suffering they have relieve

 the relation of the united states with foreign power continue to be friendly the year have be an eventful one in witness two great nation speak one language and have one lineage settle by peaceful arbitration dispute of long standing and liable at any time to bring those nation into bloody and costly conflict an example have thus be set which if successful in its final issue may be follow by other civilized nation and finally be the mean of return to productive industry million of man now maintain to settle the dispute of nation by the bayonet and the broadside

 i transmit herewith a copy of the treaty allude to which have be conclude since the adjournment of congress with her britannic majesty and a copy of the protocol of the conference of the commissioner by whom it be negotiate this treaty provide method for adjust the question pende between the two nation

 various question be to be adjust by arbitration i recommend congress at an early day to make the necessary provision for the tribunal at geneva and for the several commissioner on the part of the united states call for by the treaty

 his majesty the king of italy the president of the swiss confederation and his majesty the emperor of brazil have each consent on the joint request of the two power to name an arbiter for the tribunal at geneva i have cause my thank to be suitably express for the readiness with which the joint request have be comply with by the appointment of gentleman of eminence and learn to these important position

 his majesty the emperor of germany have be pleased to comply with the joint request of the two government and have consent to act as the arbitrator of the dispute water boundary between the united states and great britain

 the contracting party in the treaty have undertake to regard as between themselves certain principle of public law for which the united states have contend from the commencement of their history they have also agree to bring those principle to the knowledge of the other maritime power and to invite they to accede to they negotiation be go on as to the form of the note by which the invitation be to be extend to the other power

 i recommend the legislation necessary on the part of the united states to bring into operation the article of the treaty relate to the fishery and to the other matter touch the relation of the united states toward the british north american possession to become operative so soon as the proper legislation shall be have on the part of great britain and its possession it be much to be desire that this legislation may become operative before the fisherman of the united states begin to make their arrangement for the come season

 i have address a communication of which a copy be transmit herewith to the governor of new york pennsylvania ohio indiana michigan illinois and wisconsin urge upon the government of those states respectively the necessary action on their part to carry into effect the object of the article of the treaty which contemplate the use of the canal on either side connect with the navigation of the lake and river form the boundary on term of equality by the inhabitant of both country it be hope that the importance of the object and the benefit to flow therefrom will secure the speedy approval and legislative sanction of the states concern

 i renew the recommendation for an appropriation for determine the true position of the forty ninth parallel of latitude where it form the boundary between the united states and the british north american possession between the lake of the woods and the summit of the rocky mountains the early action of congress on this recommendation would put it in the power of the war department to place a force in the field during the next summer

 the resumption of diplomatic relation between france and germany have enable i to give direction for the withdrawal of the protection extend to germans in france by the diplomatic and consular representative of the united states in that country it be just to add that the delicate duty of this protection have be perform by the minister and the consul general at paris and the various consul in france under the supervision of the latter with great kindness as well as with prudence and tact their course have receive the commendation of the german government and have wound no susceptibility of the french

 the government of the emperor of germany continue to manifest a friendly feeling toward the united states and a desire to harmonize with the moderate and just policy which this government maintain in its relation with asiatic power as well as with the south american republics i have give assurance that the friendly feeling of that government be fully share by the united states

 the ratification of the consular and naturalization convention with the austro hungarian empire have be exchange

 i have be officially inform of the annexation of the states of the church to the kingdom of italy and the removal of the capital of that kingdom to rome in conformity with the establish policy of the united states i have recognize this change the ratification of the new treaty of commerce between the united states and italy have be exchange the two power have agree in this treaty that private property at sea shall be exempt from capture in case of war between the two power the united states have spare no opportunity of incorporate this rule into the obligation of nation

 the forty first congress at its third session make an appropriation for the organization of a mixed commission for adjudicate upon the claim of citizen of the united states against spain grow out of the insurrection in cuba that commission have since be organize i transmit herewith the correspondence relate to its formation and its jurisdiction it be to be hope that this commission will afford the claimant a complete remedy for their injury

 it have be make the agreeable duty of the united states to preside over a conference at washington between the plenipotentiary of spain and the ally south american republics which have result in an armistice with the reasonable assurance of a permanent peace

 the intimate friendly relation which have so long exist between the united states and russia continue undisturbed the visit of the third son of the emperor be a proof that there be no desire on the part of his government to diminish the cordiality of those relation the hospitable reception which have be give to the grand duke be a proof that on our side we share the wish of that government the inexcusable course of the russian minister at washington render it necessary to ask his recall and to decline to long receive that functionary as a diplomatic representative it be impossible with self respect or with a just regard to the dignity of the country to permit mr. catacazy to continue to hold intercourse with this government after his personal abuse of government official and during his persistent interference through various mean with the relation between the united states and other power in accordance with my wish this government have be relieve of further intercourse with mr. catacazy and the management of the affair of the imperial legation have pass into the hand of a gentleman entirely unobjectionable

 with japan we continue to maintain intimate relation the cabinet of the mikado have since the close of the last session of congress select citizen of the united states to serve in office of importance in several department of government i have reason to think that this selection be due to an appreciation of the disinterestedness of the policy which the united states have pursue toward japan it be our desire to continue to maintain this disinterested and just policy with china as well as japan the correspondence transmit herewith show that there be no disposition on the part of this government to swerve from its establish course

 prompt by a desire to put an end to the barbarous treatment of our shipwreck sailor on the korean coast i instruct our minister at peking to endeavor to conclude a convention with korea for secure the safety and humane treatment of such mariner

 admiral rodgers be instruct to accompany he with a sufficient force to protect he in case of need

 a small survey party send out on reach the coast be treacherously attack at a disadvantage ample opportunity be give for explanation and apology for the insult neither come a force be then land after an arduous march over a rugged and difficult country the fort from which the outrage have be commit be reduce by a gallant assault and be destroy having thus punish the criminal and having vindicate the honor of the flag the expedition return find it impracticable under the circumstance to conclude the desire convention i respectfully refer to the correspondence relate thereto herewith submit and leave the subject for such action as congress may see fit to take

 the republic of mexico have not yet repeal the very objectionable law establish what be know as the free zone on the frontier of the united states it be hope that this may yet be do and also that more stringent measure may be take by that republic for restrain lawless person on its frontier i hope that mexico by its own action will soon relieve this government of the difficulty experience from these cause

 our relation with the various republics of central and south america continue with one exception to be cordial and friendly

 i recommend some action by congress regard the overdue installment under the award of the venezuelan claims commission of 1866 the internal dissension of this government present no justification for the absence of effort to meet their solemn treaty obligation

 the ratification of an extradition treaty with nicaragua have be exchange

 it be a subject for congratulation that the great empire of brazil have take the initiatory step toward the abolition of slavery our relation with that empire always cordial will naturally be make more so by this act it be not too much to hope that the government of brazil may hereafter find it for its interest as well as intrinsically right to advance toward entire emancipation more rapidly than the present act contemplate

 the true prosperity and greatness of a nation be to be find in the elevation and education of its laborer

 it be a subject for regret that the reform in this direction which be voluntarily promise by the statesman of spain have not be carry out in its west india colony the law and regulation for the apparent abolition of slavery in cuba and porto rico leave most of the laborer in bondage with no hope of release until their life become a burden to their employer

 i desire to direct your attention to the fact that citizen of the united states or person claim to be citizen of the united states be large holder in foreign land of this specie of property forbid by the fundamental law of their alleged country i recommend to congress to provide by stringent legislation a suitable remedy against the holding own or deal in slave or be interested in slave property in foreign land either as owner hirer or mortgagor by citizen of the united states

 it be to be regret that the disturbed condition of the island of cuba continue to be a source of annoyance and of anxiety the existence of a protract struggle in such close proximity to our own territory without apparent prospect of an early termination can not be other than an object of concern to a people who while abstain from interference in the affair of other power naturally desire to see every country in the undisturbed enjoyment of peace liberty and the blessing of free institution

 our naval commander in cuban water have be instruct in case it should become necessary to spare no effort to protect the life and property of bona fide american citizen and to maintain the dignity of the flag

 it be hope that all pende question with spain grow out of the affair in cuba may be adjust in the spirit of peace and conciliation which have hitherto guide the two power in their treatment of such question

 to give importance to and to add to the efficiency of our diplomatic relation with japan and china and to further aid in retain the good opinion of those people and to secure to the united states its share of the commerce destine to flow between those nation and the balance of the commercial world i earnestly recommend that an appropriation be make to support at least four american youth in each of those country to serve as a part of the official family of our minister there our representative would not even then be place upon an equality with the representative of great britain and of some other power as now situate our representative in japan and china have to depend for interpreter and translator upon native of those country who know our language imperfectly or procure for the occasion the service of employee in foreign business house or the interpreter to other foreign minister

 i would also recommend liberal measure for the purpose of support the american line of steamer now ply between san francisco and japan and china and the australian line&mdash;almost our only remain line of ocean steamers&mdash;and of increase their service

 the national debt have be reduce to the extent of $ 86,057,126.80 during the year and by the negotiation of national bond at a low rate of interest the interest on the public debt have be so far diminish that now the sum to be raise for the interest account be nearly $ 17,000,000 less than on the 1st of march 1869 it be highly desirable that this rapid diminution should take place both to strengthen the credit of the country and to convince its citizen of their entire ability to meet every dollar of liability without bankrupt they but in view of the accomplishment of these desirable end of the rapid development of the resource of the country its increase ability to meet large demand and the amount already pay it be not desirable that the present resource of the country should continue to be tax in order to continue this rapid payment i therefore recommend a modification of both the tariff and internal tax law i recommend that all taxis from internal source be abolish except those collect from spirituous vinous and malt liquor tobacco in its various form and from stamp

 in readjust the tariff i suggest that a careful estimate be make of the amount of surplus revenue collect under the present law after provide for the current expense of the government the interest count and a sink fund and that this surplus be reduce in such a manner as to afford the great relief to the great number there be many article not produce at home but which enter largely into general consumption through article which be manufacture at home such as medicine compound etc etc from which very little revenue be derive but which enter into general use all such article i recommend to be place on the free list should a further reduction prove advisable i would then recommend that it be make upon those article which can well bear it without disturb home production or reduce the wage of american labor

 i have not enter into figure because to do so would be to repeat what will be lay before you in the report of the secretary of the treasury the present law for collect revenue pay collector of custom small salary but provide for moiety share in all seizure which at principal port of entry particularly raise the compensation of those official to a large sum it have always seem to i as if this system must at time work perniciously it hold out an inducement to dishonest man should such get possession of those office to be lax in their scrutiny of good enter to enable they finally to make large seizure your attention be respectfully invite to this subject

 continue fluctuation in the value of gold as compare with the national currency have a most damaging effect upon the increase and development of the country in keep up price of all article necessary in everyday life it foster a spirit of gambling prejudicial alike to national moral and the national finance if the question can be meet as to how to get a fix value to our currency that value constantly and uniformly approach par with specie a very desirable object will be gain

 for the operation of the army in the past year the expense of maintain it the estimate for the ensue year and for continue seacoast and other improvement conduct under the supervision of the war department i refer you to the accompany report of the secretary of war

 i call your attention to the provision of the act of congress approve march 3 1869 which discontinue promotion in the staff corps of the army until provide for by law i recommend that the number of officer in each grade in the staff corp be fix and that whenever the number in any one grade fall below the number so fix that the vacancy may be fill by promotion from the grade below i also recommend that when the office of chief of a corps become vacant the place may be fill by selection from the corps in which the vacancy exist

 the report of the secretary of the navy show an improvement in the number and efficiency of the naval force without material increase in the expense of support it this be due to the policy which have be adopt and be be extend as fast as our material will admit of use small vessel as cruiser on the several station by this mean we have be enable to occupy at once a large extent of cruising ground to visit more frequently the port where the presence of our flag be desirable and generally to discharge more efficiently the appropriate duty of the navy in time of peace without exceed the number of man or the expenditure authorize by law

 during the past year the navy have in addition to its regular service supply the man and officer for the vessel of the coast survey and have complete the survey authorize by congress of the isthmus of darien and tehuantepec and under like authority have send out an expedition completely furnish and equip to explore the unknown ocean of the north

 the suggestion of the report as to the necessity for increase and improve the materiel of the navy and the plan recommend for reduce the personnel of the service to a peace standard by the gradual abolition of certain grade of officer the reduction of other and the employment of some in the service of the commercial marine be well consider and deserve the thoughtful attention of congress

 i also recommend that all promotion in the navy above the rank of captain be by selection instead of by seniority this course will secure in the high grade great efficiency and hold out an incentive to young officer to improve themselves in the knowledge of their profession

 the present cost of maintain the navy its cost compare with that of the precede year and the estimate for the ensue year be contain in the accompany report of the secretary of the navy

 the enlarged receipt of the post office department as show by the accompany report of the postmaster general exhibit a gratifying increase in that branch of the public service it be the index of the growth of education and of the prosperity of the people two element highly conducive to the vigor and stability of republic with a vast territory like ours much of it sparsely populate but all require the service of the mail it be not at present to be expect that this department can be make self sustaining but a gradual approach to this end from year to year be confidently rely on and the day be not far distant when the post office department of the government will prove a much great blessing to the whole people than it be now

 the suggestion of the postmaster general for improvement in the department preside over by he be earnestly recommend to you special attention especially do i recommend favorable consideration of the plan for unite the telegraphic system of the united states with the postal system it be believe that by such a course the cost of telegraphing could be much reduce and the service as well if not well render it would secure the further advantage of extend the telegraph through portion of the country where private enterprise will not construct it commerce trade and above all the effort to bring a people widely separate into a community of interest be always benefit by a rapid intercommunication education the groundwork of republican institution be encourage by increase the facility to gather speedy news from all part of the country the desire to reap the benefit of such improvement will stimulate education i refer you to the report of the postmaster general for full detail of the operation of last year and for comparative statement of result with former year

 there have be impose upon the executive branch of the government the execution of the act of congress approve april 20 1871 and commonly know as the kuklux law in a portion of the state of south carolina the necessity of the course pursue will be demonstrate by the report of the committee to investigate southern outrages under the provision of the above act i issue a proclamation call the attention of the people of the united states to the same and declare my reluctance to exercise any of the extraordinary power thereby confer upon i except in case of imperative necessity but make know my purpose to exercise such power whenever it should become necessary to do so for the purpose of securing to all citizen of the united states the peaceful enjoyment of the right guarantee to they by the constitution and the law

 after the passage of this law information be receive from time to time that combination of the character refer to in this law exist and be powerful in many part of the southern states particularly in certain county in the state of south carolina

 careful investigation be make and it be ascertain that in nine county of that state such combination be active and powerful embrace a sufficient portion of the citizen to control the local authority and have among other thing the object of deprive the emancipate class of the substantial benefit of freedom and of prevent the free political action of those citizen who do not sympathize with their own view among their operation be frequent scourging and occasional assassination generally perpetrate at night by disguised person the victim in almost all case be citizen of different political sentiment from their own or free person who have show a disposition to claim equal right with other citizen thousand of inoffensive and well disposed citizen be the sufferer by this lawless violence

 thereupon on the 12th of october 1871 a proclamation be issue in term of the law call upon the member of those combination to disperse within five day and to deliver to the marshal or military officer of the united states all arm ammunition uniform disguise and other mean and implement use by they for carry out their unlawful purpose

 this warning not having be heed on the 17th of october another proclamation be issue suspend the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in nine county in that state

 direction be give that within the county so designate person suppose upon creditable information to be member of such unlawful combination should be arrest by the military force of the united states and deliver to the marshal to be deal with accord to law in two of say county york and spartanburg many arrest have be make at the last account the number of person thus arrest be 168 several hundred whose criminality be ascertain to be of an inferior degree be release for the present these have generally make confession of their guilt

 great caution have be exercise in make these arrest and notwithstanding the large number it be believe that no innocent person be now in custody the prisoner will be hold for regular trial in the judicial tribunal of the united states

 as soon as it appear that the authority of the united states be about to take vigorous measure to enforce the law many person abscond and there be good ground for suppose that all of such person have violate the law a full report of what have be do under this law will be submit to congress by the attorney general

 in utah there still remain a remnant of barbarism repugnant to civilization to decency and to the law of the united states territorial officer however have be find who be willing to perform their duty in a spirit of equity and with a due sense of the necessity of sustain the majesty of the law neither polygamy nor any other violation of exist statute will be permit within the territory of the united states it be not with the religion of the self style saint that we be now deal but with their practice they will be protect in the worship of god accord to the dictate of their conscience but they will not be permit to violate the law under the cloak of religion

 it may be advisable for congress to consider what in the execution of the law against polygamy be to be the status of plural wife and their offspring the propriety of congress pass an enable act authorize the territorial legislature of utah to legitimize all child bear prior to a time fix in the act might be justify by its humanity to these innocent child this be a suggestion only and not a recommendation

 the policy pursue toward the indians have result favorably so far as can be judge from the limited time during which it have be in operation through the exertion of the various society of christians to whom have be intrust the execution of the policy and the board of commissioner authorize by the law of april 10 1869 many tribe of indians have be induce to settle upon reservation to cultivate the soil to perform productive labor of various kind and to partially accept civilization they be be care for in such a way it be hope as to induce those still pursue their old habit of life to embrace the only opportunity which be leave they to avoid extermination

 i recommend liberal appropriation to carry out the indian peace policy not only because it be humane christian like and economical but because it be right

 i recommend to your favorable consideration also the policy of grant a territorial government to the indians in the indian territory west of arkansas and missouri and south of kansas in do so every right guarantee to the indian by treaty should be secure such a course might in time be the mean of collect most of the indians now between the missouri and the pacific and south of the british possession into one territory or one state the secretary of the interior have treat upon this subject at length and i commend to you his suggestion

 i renew my recommendation that the public land be regard as a heritage to our child to be dispose of only as require for occupation and to actual settler those already grant have be in great part dispose of in such a way as to secure access to the balance by the hardy settler who may wish to avail himself of they but caution should be exercise even in attain so desirable an object

 educational interest may well be serve by the grant of the proceed of the sale of public land to settler i do not wish to be understand as recommend in the least degree a curtailment of what be be do by the general government for the encouragement of education

 the report of the secretary of the interior submit with this will give you all the information collect and prepare for publication in regard to the census take during the year 1870 the operation of the bureau of education for the year the patent office the pension office the land office and the indian bureau

 the report of the commissioner of agriculture give the operation of his department for the year as agriculture be the groundwork of our prosperity too much importance can not be attach to the labor of this department it be in the hand of an able head with able assistant all zealously devote to introduce into the agricultural production of the nation all useful product adapt to any of the various climate and soil of our vast territory and to give all useful information as to the method of cultivation the plant cereal and other product adapt to particular locality quietly but surely the agricultural bureau be work a great national good and if liberally support the more widely its influence will be extend and the less dependent we shall be upon the product of foreign country

 the subject of compensation to the head of bureaus and official hold position of responsibility and require ability and character to fill properly be one to which your attention be invite but few of the official receive a compensation equal to the respectable support of a family while their duty be such as to involve million of interest in private life service demand compensation equal to the service render a wise economy would dictate the same rule in the government service

 i have not give the estimate for the support of government for the ensue year nor the comparative statement between the expenditure for the year just pass and the one just precede because all these figure be contain in the accompany report or in those present directly to congress these estimate have my approval

 more than six year having elapse since the last hostile gun be fire between the army then array against each other&mdash;one for the perpetuation the other for the destruction of the union&mdash;it may well be consider whether it be not now time that the disability impose by the fourteenth amendment should be remove that amendment do not exclude the ballot but only impose the disability to hold office upon certain class when the purity of the ballot be secure majority be sure to elect officer reflect the view of the majority i do not see the advantage or propriety of exclude man from office merely because they be before the rebellion of standing and character sufficient to be elect to position require they to take oath to support the constitution and admit to eligibility those entertain precisely the same view but of less stand in their community it may be say that the former violate an oath while the latter do not the latter do not have it in their power to do so if they have take this oath it can not be doubt they would have break it as do the former class if there be any great criminal distinguish above all other for the part they take in opposition to the government they might in the judgment of congress be exclude from such an amnesty

 this subject be submit for your careful consideration the condition of the southern states be unhappily not such as all true patriotic citizen would like to see social ostracism for opinion&#39;s sake personal violence or threat toward person entertain political view oppose to those entertain by the majority of the old citizen prevent immigration and the flow of much need capital into the states lately in rebellion it will be a happy condition of the country when the old citizen of these states will take an interest in public affair promulgate idea honestly entertain vote for man represent their view and tolerate the same freedom of expression and ballot in those entertain different political conviction

 under the provision of the act of congress approve february 21 1871 a territorial government be organize in the district of columbia its result have thus far fully realize the expectation of its advocate under the direction of the territorial officer a system of improvement have be inaugurate by mean of which washington be rapidly become a city worthy of the nation&#39;s capital the citizen of the district having voluntarily tax themselves to a large amount for the purpose of contribute to the adornment of the seat of government i recommend liberal appropriation on the part of congress in order that the government may bear its just share of the expense of carry out a judicious system of improvement

 by the great fire in chicago the most important of the government building in that city be consume those burn have already become inadequate to the want of the government in that grow city and look to the near future be totally inadequate i recommend therefore that an appropriation be make immediately to purchase the remainder of the square on which the burn building stand provide it can be purchase at a fair valuation or provide that the legislature of illinois will pass a law authorize its condemnation for government purpose and also an appropriation of as much money as can properly be expend toward the erection of new building during this fiscal year

 the number of immigrant ignorant of our law habit etc come into our country annually have become so great and the imposition practice upon they so numerous and flagrant that i suggest congressional action for their protection it seem to i a fair subject of legislation by congress i can not now state as fully as i desire the nature of the complaint make by immigrant of the treatment they receive but will endeavor to do so during the session of congress particularly if the subject should receive your attention

 it have be the aim of the administration to enforce honesty and efficiency in all public office every public servant who have violate the trust place in he have be proceed against with all the rigor of the law if bad man have secure place it have be the fault of the system establish by law and custom for make appointment or the fault of those who recommend for government position person not sufficiently well know to they personally or who give letter indorse the character of office seeker without a proper sense of the grave responsibility which such a course devolve upon they a civil service reform which can correct this abuse be much desire in mercantile pursuit the business man who give a letter of recommendation to a friend to enable he to obtain credit from a stranger be regard as morally responsible for the integrity of his friend and his ability to meet his obligation a reformatory law which would enforce this principle against all indorser of person for public place would insure great caution in make recommendation a salutary lesson have be teach the careless and the dishonest public servant in the great number of prosecution and conviction of the last two year

 it be gratify to notice the favorable change which be take place throughout the country in bring to punishment those who have prove recreant to the trust confide to they and in elevate to public office none but those who possess the confidence of the honest and the virtuous who it will always be find comprise the majority of the community in which they live

 in my message to congress one year ago i urgently recommend a reform in the civil service of the country in conformity with that recommendation congress in the ninth section of an act make appropriation for sundry civil expense of the government and for other purpose approve march 3 1871 give the necessary authority to the executive to inaugurate a civil service reform and place upon he the responsibility of do so under the authority of say act i convene a board of gentleman eminently qualified for the work to devise rule and regulation to effect the need reform their labor be not yet complete but it be believe that they will succeed in devise a plan that can be adopt to the great relief of the executive the head of departments and member of congress and which will redound to the true interest of the public service at all event the experiment shall have a fair trial

 i have thus hastily sum up the operation of the government during the last year and make such suggestion as occur to i to be proper for your consideration i submit they with a confidence that your combined action will be wise statesmanlike and in the good interest of the whole country
to the senate and house of representatives
 in accordance with the act of congress approve march 3 1871 i convene a commission of eminent gentleman to devise rule and regulation for the purpose of reform the civil service their labor be now complete and i transmit herewith their report together with the rule which they recommend for my action these rule have be adopt and will go into effect on the 1st day of january 1872
 under the law refer to as i interpret it the authority be already invest in the executive to enforce these regulation with full power to abridge alter or amend they at his option when change may be deem advisable
 these view together with the report of the commissioner be submit for your careful consideration as to whether further legislation may be necessary in order to carry out an effective and beneficial civil service reform if leave to i without further congressional action the rule prescribe by the commission under the reservation already mention will be faithfully execute but they be not bind without further legislation upon my successor
 be desirous of bring this subject to the attention of congress before the approach recess i have not time to sufficiently examine the accompany report to enable i to suggest definite legislative action to insure the support which may be necessary in order to give a thorough trial to a policy long need
 i ask for all the strength which congress can give i to enable i to carry out the reform in the civil service recommend by the commission and adopt to take effect as before state on january 1 1872
 the law which provide for the convening of a commission to devise rule and regulation for reform the civil service authorize i think the permanent organization of a primary board under whose general direction all examination of applicant for public office shall be conduct there be no appropriation to continue such a board beyond the termination of its present labor i therefore recommend that a proper appropriation be make to continue the service of the present board for another year and in view of the fact that three member of the board hold position in the public service which preclude they from receive extra compensation under exist law that they be authorize to receive a fair compensation for extra service render by they in the performance of this duty
 u. s. grant
 rule for the civil service
 1 no person shall be admit to any position in the civil service within the appointment of the president or the head of departments who be not a citizen of the united states who shall not have furnish satisfactory evidence in regard to character health and age and who shall not have pass a satisfactory examination in speak reading and write the english language
 2 an advisory board of suitable person to be employ by the president under the ninth section of the act of march 3 1871 entitle an act make appropriation for sundry civil expense of the government for the fiscal year end june 30 1872 and for other purpose shall so far as practicable group the position in each branch of the civil service accord to the character of the duty to be perform and shall grade each group from low to high for the purpose of promotion within the group admission to the civil service shall always be to the low grade of any group and to such position as can not be group or grade admission shall be determine as provide for the low grade
 3 a vacancy occur in the low grade of any group of office shall be fill after due public notice from all applicant who shall present themselves and who shall have furnish the evidence and satisfy the preliminary examination already mention and who shall have pass a public competitive examination to test knowledge ability and special qualification for the performance of the duty of the office the board conduct such competitive examination shall prepare under the supervision of the advisory board a list of the name of the applicant in the order of their excellence as prove by such examination begin with the high and shall then certify to the nominating or appoint power as the case may be the name stand at the head of such list not exceed three and from the name thus certify the appointment shall be make
 4 a vacancy occur in any grade of a group of office above the low shall be fill by a competitive examination of applicant from the other grade of that group and the list of name from which the appointment be to be make shall be prepare and certify as provide in the precede rule but if no such applicant be find competent the appointment shall be make upon an examination of all applicant conduct in accordance with the provision for admission to the low grade
 5 applicant certify as otherwise qualified for appointment as cashier of collector of custom cashier of assistant treasurer cashier of postmaster superintendent of money order division in post office and such other custodian of large sum of money as may hereafter be designate by the advisory board and for whose pecuniary fidelity another officer be responsible shall nevertheless not be appoint except with the approval of such other officer
 6 postmaster whose annual salary be less than $ 200 may be appoint upon the write request of applicant with such evidence of character and fitness as shall be satisfactory to the head of the department
 7 the appointment of all person enter the civil service in accordance with these regulation except person appoint by the president by and with the advice and consent of the senate postmaster and person appoint to any position in a foreign country shall be make for a probationary term of six month during which the conduct and capacity of such person shall be test and if at the end of say probationary term satisfactory proof of their fitness shall have be furnish by the board of examiner to the head of the department in which they shall have be employ during say term they shall be reappointe
 8 the president will designate three person in each department of the public service to serve as a board of examiner which under the supervision of the advisory board and under regulation to be prescribe by it and at such time and place as it may determine shall conduct personally or by person approve by the advisory board all investigation and examination for admission into say departments or for promotion therein
 9 any person who after long and faithful service in a department shall be incapacitate by mental or bodily infirmity for the efficient discharge of the duty of his position may be appoint by the head of the department at his discretion to a position of less responsibility in the same department
 10 nothing in these rule shall prevent the appointment of alien to position in the consular service which by reason of small compensation or of other sufficient cause be in the judgment of the appoint power necessarily so fill nor the appointment of such person within the united states as be indispensable to a proper discharge of the duty of certain position but who may not be familiar with the english language or legally capable of naturalization
 11 no head of a department nor any subordinate officer of the government shall as such officer authorize or permit or assist in levy any assessment of money for political purpose under the form of voluntary contribution or otherwise upon any person employ under his control nor shall any such person pay any money so assessed
 12 the advisory board shall at any time recommend to the president such change in these rule as it may consider necessary to secure the great efficiency of the civil service
 13 from these rule be except the head of departments assistant secretaries of departments assistant attorneys general and first assistant postmaster general solicitor general solicitor of the treasury naval solicitor solicitor of internal revenue examiner of claim in the state department treasurer of the united states register of the treasury first and second comptrollers of the treasury judge of the united states court district attorney private secretary of the president ambassador and other public minister superintendent of the coast survey director of the mint governor of territories special commissioner special counsel visit and examine board person appoint to position without compensation for service dispatch agent and bearer of dispatch

to the senate and house of representatives in transmit to you this my fourth annual message it be with thankfulness to the giver of all good that as a nation we have be bless for the past year with peace at home peace abroad and a general prosperity vouchsafe to but few people with the exception of the recent devastating fire which sweep from the earth with a breath as it be million of accumulate wealth in the city of boston there have be no overshadow calamity within the year to record it be gratify to note how like their fellow citizen of the city of chicago under similar circumstance a year early the citizen of boston be rally under their misfortune and the prospect that their energy and perseverance will overcome all obstacle and show the same prosperity soon that they would have no disaster befall they otherwise we have be free from pestilence war and calamity which often overtake nation and as far as human judgment can penetrate the future no cause seem to exist to threaten our present peace when congress adjourn in june last a question have be raise by great britain and be then pende which for a time seriously imperil the settlement by friendly arbitration of the grave difference between this government and that of her britannic majesty which by the treaty of washington have be refer to the tribunal of arbitration which have meet at geneva in switzerland the arbitrator however dispose of the question which have jeoparde the whole of the treaty and threaten to involve the two nation in most unhappy relation toward each other in a manner entirely satisfactory to this government and in accordance with the view and the policy which it have maintain the tribunal which have convene at geneva in december conclude its laborious session on the 14th day of september last on which day having avail itself of the discretionary power give to it by the treaty to award a sum in gross it make its decision whereby it award the sum of $ 15,500,000 in gold as the indemnity to be pay by great britain to the united states for the satisfaction of all the claim refer to its consideration this decision happily dispose of a long stand difference between the two government and in connection with another award make by the german emperor under a reference to he by the same treaty leave these two government without a shadow upon the friendly relation which it be my sincere hope may forever remain equally unclouded the report of the agent of the united states appoint to attend the geneva tribunal accompany by the protocol of the proceeding of the arbitrator the argument of the counsel of both government the award of the tribunal and the opinion give by the several arbitrator be transmit herewith i have cause to be communicate to the head of the three friendly power who comply with the joint request make to they under the treaty the thank of this government for the appointment of arbitrator make by they respectively and also my thank to the eminent personage name by they and my appreciation of the dignity patience impartiality and great ability with which they discharge their arduous and high function her majesty 's government have communicate to i the appreciation by her majesty of the ability and indefatigable industry display by mr. adams the arbitrator name on the part of this government during the protract inquiry and discussion of the tribunal i cordially unite with her majesty in this appreciation it be due to the agent of the united states before the tribunal to record my high appreciation of the marked ability unwearied patience and the prudence and discretion with which he have conduct the very responsible and delicate duty commit to he as it be also due to the learn and eminent counsel who attend the tribunal on the part of this government to express my sense of the talent and wisdom which they bring to bear in the attainment of the result so happily reach it will be the province of congress to provide for the distribution among those who may be entitle to it of their respective share of the money to be pay although the sum award be not payable until a year from the date of the award it be deem advisable that no time be lose in make a proper examination of the several case in which indemnification may be due i consequently recommend the creation of a board of commissioner for the purpose by the thirty fourth article of the treaty of washington the respective claim of the united states and of great britain in their construction of the treaty of the 15th of june 1846 define the boundary line between their respective territory be submit to the arbitration and award of his majesty the emperor of germany to decide which of those claim be most in accordance with the true interpretation of the treaty of 1846.his majesty the emperor of germany having be pleased to undertake the arbitration have the earnest thank of this government and of the people of the united states for the labor pain and care which he have devote to the consideration of this long pende difference i have cause an expression of my thank to be communicate to his majesty mr. bancroft the representative of this government at berlin conduct the case and prepare the statement on the part of the united states with the ability that his past service justify the public in expect at his hand as a member of the cabinet at the date of the treaty which have give rise to the discussion between the two government as the minister to great britain when the construction now pronounce unfounded be first advanced and as the agent and representative of the government to present the case and to receive the award he have be associate with the question in all of its phase and in every stage have manifest a patriotic zeal and earnestness in maintenance of the claim of the united states he be entitle to much credit for the success which have attend the submission after a patient investigation of the case and of the statement of each party his majesty the emperor on the 21st day of october last sign his award in writing decree that the claim of the government of the united states that the boundary line between the territory of her britannic majesty and the united states should be draw through the haro channel be most in accordance with the true interpretation of the treaty conclude on the 15th of june 1846 between the government of her britannic majesty and of the united states copy of the case present on behalf of each government and of the statement in reply of each and a translation of the award be transmit herewith this award confirm the united states in their claim to the important archipelago of island lie between the continent and vancouvers island which for more than twenty six year ever since the ratification of the treaty great britain have contest and leave we for the first time in the history of the united states as a nation without a question of dispute boundary between our territory and the possession of great britain on this continent it be my grateful duty to acknowledge the prompt spontaneous action of her majesty 's government in give effect to the award in anticipation of any request from this government and before the reception in the united states of the award sign by the emperor her majesty have give instruction for the removal of her troop which have be station there and for the cessation of all exercise or claim of jurisdiction so as to leave the united states in the exclusive possession of the lately dispute territory i be gratified to be able to announce that the order for the removal of the troop have be execute and that the military joint occupation of san juan have cease the island be now in the exclusive possession of the united states it now become necessary to complete the survey and determination of that portion of the boundary line through the haro channel upon which the commission which determine the remain part of the line be unable to agree i recommend the appointment of a commission to act jointly with one which may be name by her majesty for that purpose experience of the difficulty attend the determination of our admit line of boundary after the occupation of the territory and its settlement by those owe allegiance to the respective government point to the importance of establish by natural object or other monument the actual line between the territory acquire by purchase from russia and the adjoining possession of her britannic majesty the region be now so sparsely occupy that no conflict interest of individual or of jurisdiction be likely to interfere to the delay or embarrassment of the actual location of the line if defer until population shall enter and occupy the territory some trivial contest of neighbor may again array the two government in antagonism i therefore recommend the appointment of a commission to act jointly with one that may be appoint on the part of great britain to determine the line between our territory of alaska and the conterminous possession of great britain in my last annual message i recommend the legislation necessary on the part of the united states to bring into operation the article of the treaty of washington of may 8 1871 relate to the fishery and to other matter touch the relation of the united states toward the british north american possession to become operative so soon as the proper legislation should be have on the part of great britain and its possession that legislation on the part of great britain and its possession have not then be have and during the session of congress a question be raise which for the time raise a doubt whether any action by congress in the direction indicate would become important this question have since be dispose of and i have receive notice that the imperial parliament and the legislature of the provincial government have pass law to carry the provision of the treaty on the matter refer to into operation i therefore recommend your early adoption of the legislation in the same direction necessary on the part of this government the joint commission for determine the boundary line between the united states and the british possession between the lake of the woods and the rocky mountains have organize and enter upon its work it be desirable that the force be increase in order that the completion of the survey and determination of the line may be the soon attain to this end i recommend that a sufficient appropriation be make with france our early ally russia the constant and steady friend of the united states germany with whose government and people we have so many cause of friendship and so many common sympathy and the other power of europe our relation be maintain on the most friendly term since my last annual message the exchange have be make of the ratification of a treaty with the austro hungarian empire relate to naturalization also of a treaty with the german empire respect consul and trade mark also of a treaty with sweden and norway relate to naturalization all of which treaty have be duly proclaim congress at its last session having make an appropriation to defray the expense of commissioner on the part of the united states to the international statistical congress at st. petersburg the person appoint in that character proceed to their destination and attend the session of the congress their report shall in due season be lay before you this congress meet at interval of about three year and have hold its session in several of the country of europe i submit to your consideration the propriety of extend an invitation to the congress to hold its next meeting in the united states the centennial celebration to be hold in 1876 would afford an appropriate occasion for such meeting preparation be make for the international exposition to be hold during the next year in vienna on a scale of very great magnitude the tendency of these exposition be in the direction of advanced civilization and of the elevation of industry and of labor and of the increase of human happiness as well as of great intercourse and good will between nation as this exposition be to be the first which will have be hold in eastern europe it be believe that american inventor and manufacturer will be ready to avail themselves of the opportunity for the presentation of their production if encourage by proper aid and protection at the last session of congress authority be give for the appointment of one or more agent to represent this government at the exposition the authority thus give have be exercise but in the absence of any appropriation there be danger that the important benefit which the occasion offer will in a large degree be lose to citizen of the united states i commend the subject strongly to your consideration and recommend that an adequate appropriation be make for the purpose to far aid american exhibitor at the vienna exposition i would recommend in addition to an appropriation of money that the secretary of the navy be authorize to fit up two naval vessel to transport between our atlantic city and trieste or the most convenient port to vienna and back their article for exhibition since your last session the president of the mexican republic distinguish by his high character and by his service to his country have die his temporary successor have now be elect with great unanimity by the people a proof of confidence on their part in his patriotism and wisdom which it be believe will be confirm by the result of his administration it be particularly desirable that nothing should be leave undo by the government of either republic to strengthen their relation as neighbor and friend it be much to be regret that many lawless act continue to disturb the quiet of the settlement on the border between our territory and that of mexico and that complaint of wrong to american citizen in various part of the country be make the revolutionary condition in which the neighboring republic have so long be involve have in some degree contribute to this disturbance it be to be hope that with a more settle rule of order through the republic which may be expect from the present government the act of which just complaint be make will cease the proceeding of the commission under the convention with mexico of the 4th of july 1868 on the subject of claim have unfortunately be check by an obstacle for the removal of which measure have be take by the two government which it be believe will prove successful the commissioner appoint pursuant to the joint resolution of congress of the 7th of may last to inquire into depredation on the texan frontier have diligently make investigation in that quarter their report upon the subject will be communicate to you their research be necessarily incomplete partly on account of the limited appropriation make by congress mexico on the part of that government have appoint a similar commission to investigate these outrage it be not announce officially but the press of that country state that the full investigation be desire and that the cooperation of all party concern be invite to secure that end i therefore recommend that a special appropriation be make at the early day practicable to enable the commissioner on the part of the united states to return to their labor without delay it be with regret that i have again to announce a continuance of the disturb condition of the island of cuba no advance toward the pacification of the discontent part of the population have be make while the insurrection have gain no advantage and exhibit no more of the element of power or of the prospect of ultimate success than be exhibit a year ago spain on the other hand have not succeed in its repression and the party stand apparently in the same relative attitude which they have occupy for a long time past this contest have last now for more than four year be its scene at a distance from our neighborhood we might be indifferent to its result although humanity could not be unmove by many of its incident wherever they might occur it be however at our door i can not doubt that the continue maintenance of slavery in cuba be among the strong inducement to the continuance of this strife a terrible wrong be the natural cause of a terrible evil the abolition of slavery and the introduction of other reform in the administration of government in cuba could not fail to advance the restoration of peace and order it be greatly to be hope that the present liberal government of spain will voluntarily adopt this view the law of emancipation which be pass more than two year since have remain unexecuted in the absence of regulation for its enforcement it be but a feeble step toward emancipation but it be the recognition of right and be hail as such and exhibit spain in harmony with sentiment of humanity and of justice and in sympathy with the other power of the christian and civilized world within the past few week the regulation for carry out the law of emancipation have be announce give evidence of the sincerity of intention of the present government to carry into effect the law of 1870 i have not fail to urge the consideration of the wisdom the policy and the justice of a more effective system for the abolition of the great evil which oppress a race and continue a bloody and destructive contest close to our border as well as the expediency and the justice of concede reform of which the propriety be not question deeply impressed with the conviction that the continuance of slavery be one of the most active cause of the continuance of the unhappy condition in cuba i regret to believe that citizen of the united states or those claim to be such be large holder in cuba of what be there claim as property but which be forbid and denounce by the law of the united states they be thus in defiance of the spirit of our own law contribute to the continuance of this distressing and sickening contest in my last annual message i refer to this subject and i again recommend such legislation as may be proper to denounce and if not prevent at least to discourage american citizen from hold or deal in slave it be gratify to announce that the ratification of the convention conclude under the auspex of this government between spain on the one part and the allied republics of the pacific on the other provide for an armistice have be exchange a copy of the instrument be herewith submit it be hope that this may be follow by a permanent peace between the same party the difference which at one time threaten the maintenance of peace between brazil and the argentine republic it be hope be in the way of satisfactory adjustment with these states as with the republics of central and of south america we continue to maintain the most friendly relation it be with regret however i announce that the government of venezuela have make no further payment on account of the award under the convention of the 25th of april 1866 that republic be understand to be now almost if not quite tranquilize it be hope therefore that it will lose no time in provide for the unpaid balance of its debt to the united states which having originate in injury to our citizen by venezuelan authority and having be acknowledge pursuant to a treaty in the most solemn form know among nation would seem to deserve a preference over debt of a different origin and contract in a different manner this subject be again recommend to the attention of congress for such action as may be deem proper our treaty relation with japan remain unchanged an impose embassy from that interesting and progressive nation visit this country during the year that be pass but be unprovide with power for the signing of a convention in this country no conclusion in that direction be reach it be hope however that the interchange of opinion which take place during their stay in this country have lead to a mutual appreciation of the interest which may be promote when the revision of the exist treaty shall be undertake in this connection i renew my recommendation of one year ago that to give importance to and to add to the efficiency of our diplomatic relation with japan and china and to further aid in retain the good opinion of those people and to secure to the united states its share of the commerce destine to flow between those nation and the balance of the commercial world an appropriation be make to support at least four american youth in each of those country to serve as a part of the official family of our minister there our representative would not even then be place upon an equality with the representative of great britain and of some other power as now situate our representative in japan and china have to depend for interpreter and translator upon native of those country who know our language imperfectly or procure for the occasion the service of employee in foreign business house or the interpreter to other foreign minister i renew the recommendation make on a previous occasion of the transfer to the department of the interior to which they seem more appropriately to belong of all the power and duty in relation to the territories with which the department of state be now charge by law or by custom congress from the beginning of the government have wisely make provision for the relief of distressed seaman in foreign country no similar provision however have hitherto be make for the relief of citizen in distress abroad other than seaman it be understand to be customary with other government to authorize consul to extend such relief to their citizen or subject in certain case a similar authority and an appropriation to carry it into effect be recommend in the case of citizen of the united states destitute or sick under such circumstance it be well know that such citizen resort to foreign country in great number though most of they be able to bear the expense incident to locomotion there be some who through accident or otherwise become penniless and have no friend at home able to succor they person in this situation must either perish cast themselves upon the charity of foreigner or be relieve at the private charge of our own officer who usually even with the most benevolent disposition have nothing to spare for such purpose should the authority and appropriation ask for be grant care will be take so to carry the beneficence of congress into effect that it shall not be unnecessarily or unworthily bestow treasury .the money receive and cover into the treasury during the fiscal year end june 30 1872 be from customs$216,370,286.77from sale
